PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Consideration resumed from 18 September.
Consideration of Senate's amendments.
Senate's amendments-
No. 1-Page 10, sub-clause 8 (3), line 9, leave out ``paragraphs 7 (1) (d) and (e)'', insert ``paragraph 7 (1) (d)''.
No. 2-Page 10, clause 8, at end of clause, add the following new sub-clause:

``(4) So far as the Barley Research Trust Fund or the Wheat Research Trust Fund is concerned, the amounts required to be paid into that Research Fund that are referred to in paragraph 7 (1) (e) shall be credited to the various separate accounts kept in accordance with sub-section (2) in the same proportions as funds have been contributed from those various separate accounts for the purposes of making the investments referred to in that paragraph.''.
No 3-Page 21, sub-clause 22 (1), line 34, after ``form,'', insert ``in accordance with a determination in force under sub-section (6),''.
No. 4-Page 22, sub-clause 22 (2), line 2, after ``form,'', insert ``in accordance with a determination in force under sub-section (6),''.
No. 5-Page 22, clause 22, at end of clause, add the following new sub-clauses:

``(6) The Minister shall determine, in writing, the form of, and, subject to the other requirements of this section, the matters to be dealt with by, each research and development plan that is required to be prepared in accordance with sub-section (1) or (2) and may, from time to time, vary any determination so made.
``(7) The Minister-

(a) shall not make a determination under sub-section (6) or vary any determination so made unless the Minister has consulted with the persons attending a co-ordination meeting convened under section 61 concerning the proposed determination or the proposed variation and has had regard to the views expressed at that meeting in relation to that determination or variation; and

(b) shall notify, in writing, any determination or variation so made to the Chairperson of each Research Council or State Research Committee as soon as practicable after that determination or variation is made.''.

No. 6-Page 38, sub-clause 44 (1), lines 25 to 27, leave out ``such number of further members, not being a number greater than 3, as the Minister determines, in writing, to be appropriate'', insert ``3 further members, or, if the organization, or each organization, that is a relevant industry organization in relation to goods of the kind or kinds in respect of which that Research Council is established requests that a lesser number of further members be appointed, such lesser number of further members as is requested by that organization or by all of those organizations.''.
No. 7-Page 38, sub-clause 44 (2), lines 28 to 34, leave out the sub-clause.
No. 8-Page 40, sub-clause 46 (2), lines 9 to 12, leave out the sub-clause, insert the following sub-clause:
``(2) For the purpose of enabling it to nominate a person or persons for appointment to a Research Council, the Selection Committee-
(a) shall invite the nomination of persons for consideration by the Selection Committee-
(i) by advertisements placed in a newspaper that circulates throughout Australia; and

(ii) by notice in writing given to the organization, or each organization, that is a relevant industry organization in relation to goods of the kind or kinds in respect of which that Research Council is established; and
(b) may invite the nomination of persons for consideration by the Selection Committee in any other manner it considers appropriate.''.
Motion (by Mr Kerin) proposed:
That the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the amendments. I must say that it is unfortunate that the legislation was introduced into the Parliament before there was adequate consultation with the various organisations. I know that I had quite a few of the various rural industry organisations hammering on my door to draw attention to the fact that there were problems with the initial Bill. The resubmission of this Bill to the Committee for consideration of these amendments would not have been necessary if the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) had openly consulted with all those industry bodies affected by the legislation. Unfortunately, he or his Department-I do not know which-appears to have avoided proper industry consultation in an effort to get this legislation through the Parliament before its ramifications became clear.

SPEECH.PARA: I am informed that the only communication to industry bodies reasonably in advance of the introduction of the Bill was a letter sent in December which indicated in a very preliminary fashion that some changes to rural research were being planned. The next advice to at least half a dozen of the affected industries was from my office in April indicating that the debate on the Bill was imminent. Not even the National Farmers Federation was given a chance to meet and formally discuss what are very significant changes before the Bill was debated in the House.

The amendments now under consideration have the support of honourable members on this side of the chamber. They were the result of some rushed eleventh hour negotiations between the National Farmers Federation and the Minister while the Bill was awaiting debate in the other place. The Minister for Primary Industry did not help his own cause with subsequent claims that the Opposition had blocked the legislation. That was quite untrue. That was reported in a number of newspaper cuttings that came to my office. We did not block the legislation. In fact, it was held up in the Senate because it was decided, I presume by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) or whoever is responsible for Government business, to drop this piece of legislation down the list of priority because of pressure of business upon the available time for debate. I want to make that very clear. We did not block this legislation in the Senate. It is unfortunate that some people made erroneous claims. Not only did the Minister report in this way but a number of Labor members made this false claim. Eventually, the Bill was ruled off the list by the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Regrettably, the Minister saw fit to ignore this and on 9 August issued a public statement, one of a flurry of attacks on the Opposition at about Budget time, in which he said our parties had opposed the Bill. That is utter nonsense. The Minister would do well to check his facts a little more carefully before trying to excuse his own failings in this matter. The failures were basically that he did not have adequate consultations with the various organisations that would be affected by the legislation.

On 7 May in this place I outlined in detail the response of the coalition parties to this Bill and sought on behalf of the Opposition a reasoned amendment drawing attention to the failure of the Government to consult adequately with a number of the affected industries. That criticism still stands. The National Farmers Federation considered the legislation in detail at a meeting on 14 May, one week after the Bill had passed its second reading stage in the House of Representatives. The amendments before the House resulted from that meeting and from subsequent discussions with the Minister for Primary Industry.

The changes are as follows: First, the amendment to clause 8 (3) will ensure that interest on the trust fund investments accrues directly to the relevant State account; secondly, there will be an amendment to clause 22 which will strengthen the role of the co-ordinating committee in establishing uniform development plans between the Rural Industries Research Fund bodies; thirdly, the various research councils will have fewer than three members only upon agreement between the industry and the Minister, through two amendments to clause 44-in its original form the Bill gave the Minister direct power to appoint fewer than three industry members to the council, a liberty which was neither warranted nor fair-and, fourthly, clause 46 is amended to stipulate that the vacancies to be filled by the selection committee must be publicly advertised in advance. Each of these amendments is commonsense. It is only a pity that the Minister was unable to liaise adequately with the National Farmers Federation prior to the introduction of the Bill. The Federation is now satisfied with assurances given by the Minister on a further four matters of concern. As I have stated, the Bill was subsequently left on the table for the winter recess after the Senate's deadline had expired to consider the Bill and return it in amended form to this House.

During the recess further concerns over the legislation have been raised with me. Clearly, there is wide scepticism over aspects of the legislation among many of the industry organisations. In fact, I believe that several industries would have withdrawn their acceptance of the Bill had it not been for the threat that the Federal component of their research funding could have ceased. Among those bodies to bring their concerns to my attention have been the tobacco, egg, chicken meat, cotton, dried fruits, pork and dairy producer organisations. I mention them all because they asked me to say so in this place. Their concerns range over most aspects of the legislation. A common reaction has been to ask why changes are necessary to existing research arrangements when in most cases the present system is proving completely adequate. A typical example of the response to this legislation is indicated by the final response to me of the Australian Cotton Growers Research Association. The Chairman, Mr Richard Williams, has advised:
Whilst we still feel that there is no need for the cotton industry to be included in this omnibus legislation, we see no point now in taking further action at this stage to delay the Bill.
The Australian Dried Fruits Association has advised:

Discussions with the Minister have resulted in satisfactory assurances in regard to the future conduct of dried fruits research. This security could not have been achieved without your assistance in the Parliament.
I quote Mr Rigoni, President of the Tobacco Growers Council of Australia:

The key to successful agricultural research reform will be the membership of the core committee. Those members will need to be of high quality and experience. If not, there is a real danger that the new bodies will be no more effectual than the ones they have replaced.

The National Farmers Federation has subsequently met several industry bodies to review this legislation. Although there is a general acceptance of the Bill, the Minister has been placed on notice that his new arrangements must prove at least equally beneficial and effective as the existing research organisations. I am pleased that the suggestion of the Australian Cotton Growers Research Association for all RIRF members to convene a joint meeting early next year has been accepted. This should be complemented by periodic meetings of the various RIRF chairmen, perhaps with a second or third representative from each body.

Communications will be vital in determining the success or failure of the new research guidelines. I hope that they work well because I am sure that the research program is a very important one for agriculture. I know the Minister has placed a high priority on research. I am sure that he has the full support of most members of this Parliament. Rural research has already yielded tremendous benefits to those industries concerned with the community as a whole and I am sure this will continue in the future. Therefore, the Opposition accepts the Bill in its amended form and will not in any way obstruct its passage through Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to re-invigorate the debate, I think enough has been said on this legislation. I am a little disappointed that the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) put a different complexion on it. We started the whole consulting process in about October 1983. I do not know whether he wants the details of the consultation in hours, days or weeks but there has been a heck of a lot of consultation. There was a problem with some of the smaller organisations and smaller industries. We tried to change the legislation for three reasons: Firstly, to try to get all the legislation tidied up into the omnibus Bills for the research funds; secondly, the Cabinet took a decision to open up the one for one research funding to any rural organisation or rural commodity group and, thirdly, we moved towards achieving 0.5 per cent of gross domestic product. In the last two Budgets we increased funding for research and these Bills give the opportunity for vastly increased research funding.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: RURAL INDUSTRIES RESEARCH (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985

DEBATE.TITLE: WHEAT TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1985[COGNATE BILLS:GRAIN LEGUMES LEVY BILL 1985GRAIN LEGUMES LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 August, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the House to debate the Wheat Tax Amendment Bill concurrently with the Grain Legumes Levy Bill and the Grain Legumes Levy Collection Bill? There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Wheat Tax Amendment Bill 1985, the Grain Legumes Levy Bill 1985 and the Grain Legumes Levy Collection Bill 1985. Under the Wheat Tax Amendment Bill, the rate of wheat tax, which is levied to fund industry research, will increase from the current operative and maximum rate of 30c per tonne to a new maximum-I stress the word `maximum'-of $1.10. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) did not state clearly in his second reading speech whether the operative rate will increase and, if so, to what level the industry, through the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation, has sought an initial rise from 30c to 35c. This would represent only 40 per cent of the Government's stated objective that research funding be set at around 0.5 per cent of the gross value of the industry's production.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst the Minister appears to support the proposed operative rate of 35c per tonne for the current season, it would be of assistance to wheat growers if he gave a firm commitment as soon as possible, thereby confirming the procedure that the operative rate is set by regulation on the recommendation of the Wheatgrowers Federation. An early confirmation of the new rate will also ensure that it is applied to most of the new season's wheat, deliveries of which are already underway, particularly in parts of Queensland. The new rate and the provisions of the complementary Rural Industries Research Fund Bill should begin to influence the Government contribution by 1986-87. In the meantime, a prompt increase in the grower tax will help to rebuild the Wheat Industry Research Council's reserves, which were severely depleted by the four-year drought. These reserve funds are needed to give adequate flexibility should research programs need to be altered at short notice.

Prior to the drought the Research Council held about $800,000 in reserve, but by 1982-83 this had been exhausted and a decision was taken that no new projects could be funded that year. Around the same time the Victorian committee was forced to borrow some $200,000 from the State Government, and today Victoria still has only minimal reserve funds. The Western Australian committee operates on a nil reserve policy. Although South Australia has struck an additional voluntary levy on growers which is contributing to some increase in reserves, New South Wales has no State levy and the 15c levy in Queensland is under review. In these circumstances, it is important that the Wheat Research Council develop an adequate reserve of perhaps $2m to $3m to ensure the $10m to $12m research effort is fully flexible.

The decision to set a maximum rate of $1.10 per tonne will not be achieved for some years, so the Bill provides adequate scope for increases by regulation from time to time. At present the 30c tax raises some $12m annually, and so at the top rate industry research will be running at more than $40m. It is proper that the view of Federal Parliament should once again be formally sought if the industry does attain this level of research.

The National and Liberal parties have consistently maintained that rural industry research warrants encouragement from the Federal Government. Indeed, it has been receiving it over the years. The Australian wheat research program has been enormously successful. I want to take the opportunity of paying tribute to all those people involved in wheat research in Australia, for instance, those in my electorate at Narribri. I have visited the University of Sydney research institute there on many occasions. I have a very high regard for the very valuable work being done there in new varieties and strains of wheat. Such work has played a very significant part in increasing our productivity and efficiency as a wheat producing nation.

Without research, Australia would have been a second rate wheat producing country. Full credit must be given to the researchers and full credit must be given to governments over the years and the departments that have been responsible. The Department of Primary Industry has worked very closely with them. The benefits that have accrued, not only to the industry and their regional committees, are multiplied through the economy to the benefit of all Australians. Wheat is a very appropriate example and a very important export industry. This year more than 90 per cent of the crop will be exported, drawing on Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimates about $2.8 billion of valuable overseas income. There are very few other industries that will produce that sort of export income.

I know that the Department of Trade is pursuing and embarking on a policy of trying to make sure that sufficient attention is given to developing our manufacturing sector, our new tech sunrise industries and so on. I think it is a good idea that the Department try, but it should not be at the expense of some of these very important agricultural industries which will for the foreseeable future be the main contributors to Australia's export income. As much as we would like to see the development of these other industries, we must at no time overlook the necessity for maintaining an efficient, competitive agricultural sector capable of not only maintaining existing markets but also increasing market opportunities as they become available overseas.

Unlike large manufacturing export industries which may have only a few multinational companies, wheat production is spread over 60 000 growers. The Industries Assistance Commission found in its wheat industry report of September 1983:

There would be under-investment in rural research without some form of Government intervention. The Commission has judged that rural producers are able to appropriate a substantial proportion of the benefit of research.

Growers benefit substantially from their research and this in turn flows through the economy many times over. It is significant that growers are willing to pay an increased research tax despite current pressures on their farm returns, and they deserve encouragement.

The sharp economic recovery of 1983-84 was due in part to a 78 per cent leap in the gross farm product. Wheat was among the industries leading that change. The 1982-83 production was more than doubled in 1983-84 to an all time record of $3.6 billion. With the seasonal recovery, Australia had a high efficiency and high quality industry able to make the most of its export opportunities. This was due in part to the on-going research program identifying and treating the problems of soil deficiency, disease, rodent or insect damage; breeding those new varieties I mentioned earlier; uncovering new plant breeding techniques and evaluating cultivation, storage and handling techniques.

On a relatively highly elastic world market, the benefits of this research have a marked impact. At the same time, there is no gain if other factors undermine this market competitiveness. I agree that part of the difficulty stems from price undercutting by the European Economic Community and Argentina. Even the tumble in the value of the Australian dollar has only partially offset the decline in world prices. At the same time, Australian growers are being handicapped on the intense export market by a range of input cost hikes. Prices received have risen by over 2 per cent in five years and prices paid are up by 17 per cent. This rapid deterioration in the grower's terms of trade has in no way been compensated by productivity increases of about 2.5 per cent.

Closer analysis shows that there are a range of measures open to the Government to assist the industry through its current difficulties. Not surprisingly, many of these actions would be simply undoing the damage of Labor governments at both State and Federal level. The Minister for Primary Industry often responds to questioning on specific policies with the stock answer that it is his aim to set the right macro economic conditions for primary industries. Of course, he is right. That is part of his Cabinet responsibility. What the farmers generally and the wheat growers in particular want to know is when his Government will adopt monetary and fiscal policies which will reduce record high interest rates.

Interest rates are now one of the biggest problems confronting the debt-ridden farmers of Australia. The overall debt of the farm sector in Australia has now reached about $6 billion. That in itself is a very serious level of indebtedness. Of course, the interest repayable on that debt is very high. The policies being pursued by the Government are helping to stabilise the Australian dollar, but at a high cost in interest rates and at a high cost to farmers producing for the export markets. There is not the slightest doubt that the policy that the Treasury and the Reserve Bank of Australia are following in order to stabilise the Australian dollar at 67c or 68c when compared with the United States dollar is forcing up and holding up interest rates at record highs. Many of the farmers in my area are paying between 18 1/2 per cent and 20 per cent on their borrowed capital.

What the industries want to know is why the Minister told this Parliament a fortnight ago that interest rates will soon come down-a statement followed closely by yet another prime lending rate increase. I hope that the Minister is correct but he does not seem to be supported in those forecasts by his ministerial colleagues. While he is on the job, the Minister might also explain how the wheat industry will benefit from the devalued dollar and record and high interest rates. There is little potential income benefit with advance payments to growers now being funded by borrowing in US dollars. The devaluation has increased the cost of imported machinery, fuel and chemicals. Further rises are no doubt likely to occur.

Wheat growers are paying a high price for the Budget deficits and monetary policies of the Hawke Labor Government. On the one hand, they are saddled with a crippling debt-to use another figure, an average of $148,000 along the wheat belt of Western Australia. I was there the other day. Farmers are in desperate straits in many parts of the Western Australian wheat belt and, as I said earlier, they are suffering the burden of record real interest rates. On the other hand, they face a very bleak cash flow outlook of static returns and accelerating costs. The cost pressure drove hundreds of growers in my electorate of Gwydir and other areas to call a series of protest meetings late last year. Sadly, their claim for fair treatment remains virtually unanswered.

Closure of the fuel excise rebate gap used on farms in this Budget was an essential move; nevertheless, this action has not compensated primary producers for the $55m cost they have borne since the rebate was frozen by the present Government. Abolition of the petroleum products freight subsidy indexation of fuel excise and fuel price increases when world petroleum prices are in reverse have combined to thrust up the price of fuel by more than 25 per cent under the Hawke Labor Government. The abolition of the petroleum products freight subsidy equalisation scheme has affected the whole of the wheat belt in New South Wales.

Removal of the 15 per cent tariff on imported headers was a welcome, if belated, move to correct an anomaly costing growers $14m a year. However, the devaluation will ensure that these headers will not be any cheaper. The bounty to replace this tariff should cost only a fraction of the $14m. It will correctly be paid by the wider Australian community, achieving the same degree of protection for about 260 people employed in farm machinery manufacturing near Melbourne. Regrettably, the announcement of the decision has been messy to say the least. Six days after the Budget, the Government announced that the date of 1 January was the target for the announcement of the conditions of the bounty, but that it would now apply retrospectively to 21 August. This action failed to overcome the basic problem that growers will naturally wait until pre-Budget stocks are exhausted before making their purchase. As a result, these stocks are likely to attract sluggish demand and the benefit of the new arrangements will be delayed even further. In the meantime, at least one major Australian manufacturer has announced the retrenchment of 53 casual employees, with the remaining 250 staff under threat of complete factory closure. The company, Horwood Bagshaw Ltd, has sought specific assurances over the level and conditions of the bounty.

There would be two clear benefits in applying the abolition of the tariff to all sales from the post-Budget day, 21 August. First, growers would have the benefit of the new arrangements early in this season-and I believe the Government intends to do that-and, secondly, the unexpected cost burden on importers who have paid the tariff on new stocks will be minimised. To prolong the existing unsatisfactory arrangements will only add to the severity of the market distortion. Although this tariff has finally been removed, there is of course no compensation for the loss of some $14m a year incurred by the growers since 1983.

Turning to the other cost slugs, the imposition of dumping duties on imported fertiliser in late July is adding an estimated $80 per tonne to the cost of DAP fertiliser. Early last year the price ex-works stood at around $180 a tonne. Beyond these specific cost burdens are a range of additional imposts from both State and Federal governments. The industry in my electorate of Gwydir has been racked by industrial problems within the New South Wales Grain Handling Authority and right along the transportation chain to the point where Japan has now demanded that its Australian standard wheat orders be shipped through Brisbane. This decision is a sad indictment of the union turmoil in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a disgrace.

—It is a total disgrace. It is a shameful disgrace in fact. I know that the New South Wales Government has initiated an inquiry into the activities of the Grain Handling Authority, but it ought to initiate an inquiry also into the behaviour of the unions on the waterfront and the unions on the railways which have been responsible for this shocking state of affairs. Let it be understood that most of the employees associated with the Grain Handling Authority are earning between $55,000 and $60,000 a year. I have no objection to their earning that as long as they are prepared to do their job and to do it efficiently and properly. There is no justification for these characters to be earning that sort of money while messing up shipments within Australia, damaging our reputation, holding up shipments and making Australia appear to be totally unreliable on world markets. I do not think any reasonable person, whether he voted for the Australian Labor Party, the National Party, the Liberal Party or the Australian Democrats, or whoever, would have sympathy with that sort of behaviour on the waterfront and at our grain handling terminals in New South Wales. It is about time these people pulled up their socks, got on with the job and justified earning such large salaries. Nobody should be allowed to behave in this way without challenge and without rebuke.
—I'll tell the waterside workers in your electorate not to vote for you.

—Heavens above! I have no port in my electorate! To its credit, the National Party Government in Queensland has had action under way for some time to meet increased demand for transport and handling facilities in that State. The Fisherman Islands terminal will have the capacity to handle shipments through northern New South Wales, and the Queensland Government is complementing its port facilities with upgrading works on the Goondiwindi- Warwick rail line to A grade classification. As Minister for Transport in the former Government I actively promoted the standardisation of rail links to all our major Australian ports.

SPEECH.PARA: Construction of a standard gauge line from Boggabilla to Brisbane now has greater justification than at any previous time. Based on pure cost benefit analyses, the construction of standard gauge links to all ports may not be easy to justify. But in the longer term interests of most industries, such a project would be welcome and could spark a long-awaited revival of rail transport in Australia. However, any such project would take many years to complete, and the need for improved access to Brisbane for the northern New South Wales wheat belt is urgent. This applies not only in respect of wheat but also in respect of cotton and coarse grains.

The whole of that northern and north-western part of New South Wales has undergone an enormous change. The diversification of production today is quite staggering. For instance, the Moree Plains shire area produces by far and away the greatest amount of revenue from agriculture of any shire district in Australia. I think the amount is in the order of $250m a year. Yet we still have the same road and rail systems. Governments have not kept up with the infrastructure that is necessary to cope with the ever-increasing production and diversification that have occurred as a result of water conservation measures such as the Copeton Dam, the Keepit Dam and some of the dams that have been built in that area in the last 30 years. I well remember that the Bureau of Agricultural Economics recommended against the construction of the Copeton Dam; it thought the dam would not be an economic proposition. How wrong it was; how wrong the economists were at that time. The Copeton Dam has proved undoubtedly to be one of best cost benefit projects ever undertaken in New South Wales. This is an enormously successful irrigation area and we need adequate transport facilities for the products that come out of it.

The New South Wales standard gauge line presently reaches to Boggabilla, just a few kilometres short of the Queensland terminus at Goondiwindi. Options for linking these rail systems have been analysed in detail by the excellent Bureau of Transport Economics in a study released last year. I believe Japan's firm request to Australian wheat suppliers has come as the catalyst for the New South Wales Government to enter into discussions with Queensland to assess the options for linking the New South Wales system into Goondiwindi. Options such as the construction of a third rail on the track from Goondiwindi to Moree, or alternatively modern transhipment facilities at either Boggabilla or Goondiwindi, may well prove to be cost effective. A linking of the two rail systems is a logical step and deserves thorough consideration, free of any State jealousies.

In approving this legislation the Parliament must be mindful of the severe cost-price squeeze which is draining the badly needed cash flow of the industry. To be fully effective the research effort must be complemented with a new effort to get government off the backs of the wheat growers. No industry can continue indefinitely on hard-fought markets if it is crippled by huge debts and record interest rates. The problems are only being aggravated by a wide range of government imposts, Federal and State. There will be no credit to this Government for helping to boost the industry's research effort if growers are being driven out of the industry by an adverse economic environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating the Wheat Tax Amendment Bill, the Grain Legumes Levy Bill and the Grain Legumes Levy Collection Bill cognately. I will confine most of my remarks to the Wheat Tax Amendment Bill. However, it is important for the House to understand that the Australian production of lupins, which is just one form of grain legumes, has increased from 379,000 tonnes in 1983-84 to an estimated 630,000 tonnes in 1984-85. If the full potential of grain legumes is realised as a rotational and alternative crop there needs to be an increased research effort into production, processing, storage, transport and marketing of these crops.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go too far, I would like to comment on some of the wide-ranging issues which were raised by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) in his speech on these Bills. It is always a great amusement to me to hear members of the National Party of Australia come in here and talk about the dreadful fuel prices and the terrible effects of devaluation. During their term as a partner in the previous coalition they introduced world parity pricing. Their previous leader, Doug Anthony, quite clearly still supports that policy. Also, they underestimate the effects of the devaluation, which has made the Australian wheat crop very competitive on world markets. Because of the devaluation and because contracts were written in United States dollars, the Australian wheat crop can remain competitive in a very much diminished market. I was also interested to note the comments that the honourable member made about the Queensland National Party State Government plans to bring the rail from Goondiwindi through Warwick to Brisbane ports. As the member who represents the Warwick district in this Federal Parliament, I would be very pleased to see that happen. It would be a great reversal of the Queensland Government's attitude to Warwick, bearing in mind that it closed the railway workshops in 1961 and has continually put that town on the back burner by transferring all government infrastructures to Toowoomba.

A tax on wheat, which has been part of the Australian rural industry research since 1967, has enabled wheat growers to contribute to research on wheat diseases and various varieties of wheat. The funds raised are held in trust for research projects and are matched dollar for dollar by the Commonwealth Government. I have remarked previously that the Government has announced $11m for rural research in 1985-86 of which $5,777m has been allocated to the wheat industry for 58 new research projects. Also, 113 continuing projects will be funded. Research in the wheat industry in on-farm production and off-farm handling and processing is very important. It results in increased efficiency and the international competitiveness of Australian agriculture.

It should not be forgotten that the rural industry as a whole provides Australia with self-sufficiency in food supply. It contributes greatly to the national income and accounts for about 40 per cent of the nation's export trade. Wheat, on its own, brings in 9 per cent of Australia's export income. The industry is facing a crisis over the medium term. Huge production harvests overseas are going to make life difficult for our wheat producers for the next two to three years. I do not think there is a member in this House who does not condemn the zealous protectionist policies of the European Economic Community which they have created market distortions which will impact severely on our local industries. Our only hope of withstanding this distortion is to keep our technology to the forefront. This can be achieved only by adhering to policies which will encourage research.

This legislation will establish a maximum rate of contribution to wheat industry research at about 0.6 per cent of the industry's gross value of production. The proposed operative tax rate for this measure will be 35c per tonne. The industry's contribution in 1985-86 is estimated to be $5.2m. The new tax rate would be applicable only to about 95 per cent of 1985-86 season's wheat crop because deliveries made from about mid-August until the new rate comes into effect are taxed at the current rate. The Commonwealth's matching commitment in respect of the increased tax will not arise until 1986-87 and later years.

I cannot help wondering what the new dry faction leading the Liberal Party thinks of the Commonwealth contributing money to the wheat industry. I deliberately mention the Liberal Party because it is abundantly clear that in a future coalition government the National Party would have very little influence. I wonder whether in its exuberance to privatise everything the coalition believes that rural research should be privatised. I want to state quite clearly that I fully support government involvement in rural research. On behalf of my constituents, I want to know what those opposite think of the Government providing funds for rural research. They need to state quite clearly their attitude in this area.

In spite of what the economic dries opposite may think, I believe there is a compelling case for government involvement in research for the rural sector. The structure of rural industry makes it unlikely that the industry could conduct its own research. The industry is characterised by a very large number of independent operators. In 1982, there were 176,000 commercial holdings with 80,000 sub-commercial or unproductive holdings. Not only do businesses lack the resources to conduct meaningful and effective research programs, but also agricultural research tends to be unattractive to the corporate private sector because it is high risk activity. Even when such research is successful, it is unlikely to yield any worthwhile return to the investor. Private firms and individuals are expected in the first instance to bear the cost of research and then to share the benefits of their efforts with other groups in the community. Consequently, there is a compelling reason for the Federal Government to provide higher levels of research expenditure to make up for deficiencies in private expenditure. In my electorate I have recently visited members of the local graingrowers' association, looking at the ways in which they are using initiative in undertaking research into various crop planting techniques to stop erosion in the Warwick district. The rural community needs to continue research in such areas to make itself efficient and productive so that it can compete on an increasingly competitive world market.

This Government has shown a willingness to invest in research and to ensure that the rural sector benefits from it. Earlier this year the rural Industries Research Bill was introduced. The Senate amendments to the Bill have been considered by the Committee of the Whole. This legislation was the first major revision of rural research in 30 years. This upgrading was arrived at after several public reports and discussions on the direction and organisation of rural research. The wheat industry, too has benefitted from the recent Budget. The rural industry research fund finances research into the wheat industry from funds collected by way of industry levy and a matching Commonwealth contribution. In the Budget this year there was an 18.5 per cent increase in this program.

This Bill and the measures taken in the Budget demonstrate again the commitment of the Hawke Government to the rural sector. Continued growth in rural research is assured by these measures. As I have stated previously, it is very important that the Australian agricultural industry conducts research into making itself efficient and productive, because in the coming years Australian agriculture will truly face its greatest test. If Australia is to continue to be an exporter of agricultural products, every government in this country-both State and Commonwealth-should be keen to encourage agricultural research. As a nation we have an excellent record for providing efficient and cost-productive agricultural endeavours that are the envy of many countries. Perhaps if the industry in other countries of the world was as cost-efficient and productive as ours, there would not be the need for of the highly protective policies of such bodies as the European Economic Community, which is trying to distort the world markets.

I certainly support the Bills that are before the House. I think they indicate to us the commitment of the Government to the rural sector. This sort of legislation, rather than trying continually to divide rural communities from urban communities, will bring to the minds of the urban dweller the importance of rural industries. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Since we are having a cognate debate on three pieces of legislation, which include, of course, the Grain Legumes Levy Bill 1985 and the Grain Legumes Levy Collection Bill 1985, I would like to make it clear that the Opposition supports the Grain Legumes Levy Bill and also the Grain Legumes Levy Collection Bill. These pieces of legislation are very important to a small but rapidly growing agricultural industry. The purpose of the Bills is to impose a research levy on grain legume production. At present there is no national research levy on grain legume production. There is, however, a State statutory levy in Western Australia at present for funding of lupin research in that State.

SPEECH.PARA: The new arrangements under these Bills will take over from the Western Australian levy. Field pea production is concentrated in South Australia. Growers of field peas in South Australia pay a voluntary research levy to support the development of this industry. The levy to be established under these Bills will apply initially only to lupins and field peas. There is provision for other grain legume crops to be brought into the scheme by the Minister for Primary Industry by regulation at a later date.

The levy will apply at the initial rate of 75c a tonne of grain legumes processed or delivered. Further increases in the levy can be made by regulation by the Minister up to $2.60 per tonne. This gives the capacity for the industry to increase its own contribution to research funding. The actual amount of the levy will be determined by the Research Council which will be established under the Rural Industries Research Bill 1985. The Opposition supports those two pieces of legislation and wishes them a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the comments that have already been made by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt). I think he has summed up many of the important points, but I would like to add just a few more. Firstly, I want to remind the House of the importance of the wheat industry. It is, in fact, Australia's largest primary production export earner. The value of the wheat industry last year was a record $3.6 billion. But as the honourable member for Gwydir has already pointed out, some significant problems face the industry. In particular, the prices received by the industry have risen by only 2 per cent over the last five years; yet the prices paid-that is, the costs-by farmers in the wheat industry have risen by over 17 per cent. Over that period the increases in productivity of the wheat industry have been only about 2.5 per cent. Anyone doing some simple calculations can work out very quickly that the industry is in fact going backwards financially.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course we welcome the Government's moves to increase research in the wheat industry. But I hasten to point out that research is only one aspect of the industry. The Government should have a co-ordinated approach to dealing with the problems of the industry. Improving research really will not make up for some of the other problems that are facing the wheat industry in particular at the moment. The most important problem is that much greater efforts must be made to increase our international competitiveness. At the moment all export industries are facing serious problems. This is due by and large to the problems being faced in our international competitiveness.

Obviously, the increase in research funds cannot offset these problems. It cannot offset the massive increases in fuel costs which have had to be faced and which, of course, are one of the biggest inputs of a wheat farmer. As the Deputy Leader of the National Party has already mentioned, since this Government came into power fuel prices have increased by over 25 per cent. That is a massive increase. Although we welcome the extension of the rebate for off-road users of diesel fuel, I hasten to add that that does not make up for the fact that the Government has already collected an additional $55m by not fully indexing this rebate over the last two years. It is interesting to look at what the level of assistance to the wheat industry really is. I want to quote very briefly from the Bureau of Agricultural Economics publication `Quarterly Review of the Rural Economy' of February last year. It talked about the level of assistance to the wheat industry and stated:

According to the Industry Assistance Commission's annual report for 1980-81, the wheat industry has had low or negative effective rates of assistance since 1972-73. Furthermore, it has been estimated that assistance provided to the manufacturing industry cost the average wheat grower $134.62 a week. . .

I repeat that $134.62 a week has been the cost of the level of assistance to the manufacturing industry borne by every wheat grower in Australia. That was during 1981-82, so it is probably greater now. The BAE journal went on to state:

That is, Australia's wheat industry has been growing and performing well internationally without significant assistance and, indeed, against a significant penalty. For these reasons, it can be argued that there is no economic case for reducing the current level of assistance.

Obviously, in this case there is a small but welcome increase of significance because of the Government's commitment on the dollar for dollar matching of the funds for research. Over the years several papers have been produced which show quite clearly that there is an economic justification for the Government to support research in the wheat industry. One to which I can refer is the October 1982 report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources which said quite a lot about the economic justification for government involvement in agricultural research and, obviously, particularly in the wheat industry. Furthermore, the Industries Assistance Commission report of 1976 entitled `Financing Rural Research' states:
Economic analyses in a number of countries point to agricultural research being highly profitable and having a significant effect on the rate of productivity increase.
On this point I want to quote very briefly from the report of the working group on agricultural policy which, under Sir James Balderstone, produced its report in September 1982. The report states:

Overall, the Group believes that agricultural research funding should be increased and that increased expenditure should be concentrated on applied research. The benefits producers derive from research justify an increase in their proportionate contribution to research funding. The Commonwealth should also significantly increase its overall funding of agricultural research. The Group considers that research is an appropriate area for providing assistance to raise farmer incomes on the grounds discussed in Chapter 4.
I think there is no doubt that government involvement in rural research is very much justified and, in particular, in the wheat industry.

Obviously, as I have mentioned already, the industry is facing a lot of problems. Naturally enough, we welcome the Government's decision to remove the tariff on headers and replace it with a bounty. But let us face it, this will save the industry only some $14m. It will not be the great panacea.

As the Deputy Leader of the National Party has already stated, the industry is facing some massive problems. I think the one to which he alluded should be highlighted again and again, and that is the massive problem faced by growers in trying to export their wheat. In particular, we can look at New South Wales and some of the headlines appearing in the newspapers over the last few months which highlight this very clearly. One article appearing in the Australian this year was headed: `Strikes cost $270m in wheat exports'. Honourable members should note the amount of $270m when we are looking at some of the assistance the Government has given the wheat industry. If we look at this matter a bit further we find in the Sydney Morning Herald of August this year a quick analysis about the problems of the Grain Handling Authority in New South Wales and about the massive costs it is bringing on to the wheat industry in particular but, more importantly, Australia. Bearing in mind the problems we have with our balance of payments at the moment, anything that is inhibiting exports should be very quickly stopped. I think the Government should make a far greater effort in tackling this problem.

If we look at some of the main points about this dispute which has been going on in the New South Wales Grain Handling Authority we find that there was nearly a loss of a market worth $160m in the wheat trade to Japan. I understand that Japan is now saying that it will not take wheat exported from the Grain Handling Authority in New South Wales. Let us look at the record of the Grain Handling Authority. It has, in fact, the worst industrial record of any authority in Australia. New South Wales has the greatest number of shipping days lost of any State in Australia. Last year there was a carry over of four million tonnes. When one thinks about it, four million tonnes out of a total crop of some 19 million is a fairly significant amount. It has been estimated that the cost of that carry over will penalise growers $60m in interest payments alone. Because shippers cannot get their grain out of New South Wales in time, it is putting additional pressures on other States-in particular, Queensland and Victoria. So serious is the problem that the Premier of New South Wales has even gone on the record describing the behaviour of the Grain Handling Authority workers as a disgrace to the union movement. He has even threatened to dismantle the whole organisation.

It is interesting to mention some of the salaries these people are getting. Standard conditions for workers include a 32 1/2-hour week, although effective working hours are just over 25 hours a week. The workers receive 30 days paid sick leave, double time for all overtime, a 50 per cent penalty loading on afternoon shift and 100 per cent loading on night shift. By utilising the `system' most workers can earn double their base salary. In fact, the highest wage last year in the Grain Handling Authority was $70,000 to a Sydney foreman whose base wage was $23,000. Other stupid things go on. For example, Grain Handling Authority employees, who work in air-conditioned offices, demand a wheat dust allowance. It is a massive problem, indeed one of the major problems facing the wheat industry right now, and the Government cannot turn a blind eye. It should be prepared to intervene and support the views of the Premier of New South Wales. It is coming at a time when the industry and Australia can ill afford it.

New South Wales is not on its own with some of the problems of grain handling. In Victoria the State Government has decided that the Victorian Grain Elevators Board is a great way of milking the system. In fact, it has now imposed a dividend tax-I am not sure how one works out why it is a dividend-of something like $6m a year. This tax has been placed on the Victorian Grain Handling Authority despite the fact that most of its capital has been supplied by the grain growers over the years, not by the Government. The Government may have guaranteed the loans, but it has all been paid for by the wheat growers in dues for the use of the Victorian Grain Hand- ling Authority.

On the subject of wheat research, I think it is time the Minister for Primary Industry also looked at a matter that very much involves wheat, and I refer to plant variety rights. The Minister indicated prior to the 1983 election that he supported plant variety rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —He supports everything in the bush but never delivers.
—That is probably true. He did support such rights but since becoming Minister we have seen nothing and there is no excuse for this lack of action.
—It is the left wing that doesn't want it.

—The Left should be told to keep out of it. We have seen no action. The Minister is probably well aware that the wheat industry may be a little hesitant about the introduction of plant variety rights, but he has had the matter put to him on a number of occasions. Indeed, in another place one of our senators has introduced a private member's Bill to try to get plant variety rights for the horticultural industry; yet apparently the Government will not even face up to this one. I hope the Minister will take this opportunity to respond and explain when the Government plans to take the first step in introducing plant variety rights in Australia. There is overwhelming evidence, and the Minister knows it, to support plant variety rights at least in one section of the agricultural industry to help Australia become more competitive on world markets.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like briefly to touch on the grain legume industry, in particular peas and lupins. The value of the grain legume industry nowadays is over $100m. In particular with lupins we have seen an increase in production of over 65 per cent in the past year. As the Minister will know, the importance of the grain legume industry is becoming increasingly recognised as part of the rotational cycle of farming. Legumes have the added value of putting back into the soil between 40 and 100 kilograms of nitrogen per hectare, an essential element in growing all crops and all grasses. The other value of the grain legumes in the rotation is that it gives the farmer the chance to break the disease cycle; it also has the added value that grain legumes are very high in protein and have good value as stock feed. In fact, lupins are 23 per cent higher in protein than wheat. The other aspect about grain legumes is that there is considerable potential for export, particularly to Asia, especially Japan and Taiwan. If these industries can benefit through research, no doubt there is considerable scope for increasing production and productivity.

I have touched on some of the problems facing the wheat industry. I suggest to all honourable members that these problems are most serious. I give one small example. Recently I was talking to a bank manager in my electorate and, although he was not prepared to divulge too much information, he mentioned that unless the crop is very good this year in his area and the price is fairly good, it is likely he will have to approach 17 of his clients and suggest that the time has come to move off. That is a serious matter, and I am talking of one of the premier wheat growing areas of Australia. It is a serious situation when just one bank manager in a small town may have to go to 17 of his clients and say: `Your overdraft has got too high, and we might have to suggest that you sell up'. In Victoria we have been more fortunate than others. If somebody from Western Australia were to outline the facts, I am sure that honourable members would find them even more frightening. I understand that the level of debt on wheat farms in Western Australia these days is horrendous and the interest payments, which this Government knows or should know only too well, are going up and up every day. This is causing great hardship to some of these people who have been working extremely hard to try to make their wheat crop bigger, but the harder they work it seems the faster they are going down.

I have also mentioned the problem of industrial disputes. It is ludicrous for this country to put up with selfish unionists moving in for their own selfish ends and crippling an industry. The whole nation will suffer because as our exports suffer, so are we seeing the reflection in the value of the Australian dollar. The cost-price squeeze is continuing to hurt and, although this legislation may in the long run help in some way to increase productivity in the wheat industry and also in the grain legume industry, there is little doubt that the benefits will be more than outweighed by some of the problems I have already touched upon.

In conclusion, the Opposition supports these three Bills, but we would put the Minister on notice that, while we support his efforts in this area, we believe massive problems face rural Australia right now. We have told the Minister time and time again of these problems, and if he wishes to prove that the Government is serious about trying to help agriculture, he should be addressing those problems-in particular high costs and industrial disputes. If he is serious about his job, I hope that he will look closely at these matters and show that the Government is fair dinkum when it says that it is interested in the problems facing rural Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the Wheat Tax Amendment Bill, the Grain Legumes Levy Bill and the Grain Legumes Levy Collection Bill, I would observe that most of the nitty-gritty of this legislation has been spelt out by previous speakers, particularly in a very good exposition by the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall). I wish to address a few opening remarks on the Wheat Tax Amendment Bill and to say that I am continually appalled in this House at the Opposition's attitude. Opposition speakers today have done nothing but regurgitate the effects in the industry without looking at the causes. In fact, many confuse effects with causes. They lament the problems but do not look for solutions. It is depressing to see the Opposition carrying on in this way because it is certainly not in the interests of the rural community.

SPEECH.PARA: Western Australia is the premier lupin producing State, and there is no doubt there will be an increase in lupin production. It is a valuable asset to the mixed farming regime. It will help to break dependence on one crop which has developed in some areas. It is of course also a fertiliser supplement, a point that is often overlooked as it feeds valuable nitrogen back into the soil. With the advent of lupins for human consumption, we shall see some more stability in that industry.

One crop that obviously has a great future in the eyes of the Opposition is mushrooms. It was depressing to hear the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), treating farmers as mushrooms. In this place he lamented the high cost of money and interest rates. This came from a member of the Opposition which today purports to be a free market party. He lamented the high cost of interest rates, he supported devaluation and he opposed devaluation; he was all over the place. Delivered in measured and quiet tones he may think that he can get away with it but I can assure him that farmers know the realities of the situation. They know that they must have stable, good, macro economic conditions in order to survive.

Interest rates are high; there is no doubt about that. However, the solution put forward by the Deputy Leader of the National Party really stretched the credibility of just about anyone who listened to him. He wants to reduce the value of the dollar still further. This would have enormous inflationary and cost repercussions for farmers. There was no consistency at all in what he had to say.

In attacking this problem this Government has done what the Opposition never had the nerve to do; that is, we legislated to allow foreign banks into this country. I am sure that when those foreign banks become established we will see a downward pressure on interest rates brought about by the competitive mechanism. There is no doubt that the commercial banks of this country have a very bad record in this regard. I include, of course, the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. An enormous amount of bad advice has been given to farmers. Many farmers in my electorate, and in Western Australia generally, have a very high level of farm debt and they are in that situation because of the bad economic advice which were given. Some of the people who gave that advice have now walked away from it and are giving contrary advice, still garbed as experts. One thing this Government has done is legislate for the entry of foreign banks and I am sure this will result in more expertise in this area and a downward pressure on interest rates.

The devaluation which this Government brought about by floating the dollar was also an initiative about which the Opposition talked but something which never had the nerve to do. It has been enormously beneficial in terms of prices but it has been somewhat undermined by the Common Market. This has been mentioned but people tend to forget the United States action in this regard. The United States offered 20 per cent free wheat for every 100,000 tonnes sold. This really amounted to a 20 per cent cut in price. The people who are supposed to be masters of the free enterprise system thought that they would increase their sales. What happened, of course-anyone could have predicted it- was that buyers simply went out on the market and said: `This is now the bottom line price'. This has had a tendency to drive down prices everywhere so we have to contend with not only the actions of the Common Market but also the stupidity, and perhaps cupidity, of the United States.

The honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) mentioned the old hoary fuel price issue. The fact is that the most significant price rises occurred under a Liberal-National Government. We opposed the world parity pricing system when it was brought in. It was sold to the public of Australia-no doubt the Press helped to sell it to the public of Australia-as a fuel conserving measure. It never was. At that time we correctly identified it as a revenue raising measure. But the problem was-

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you done about it? You are a hypocrite.

—I will tell the honourable member what I have done about it. I may be a lot of things but I do not think hypocrite is one of them. If he would just listen he might learn. When we came to power, although we recognised what world parity pricing was and clearly identified it, we were locked into the revenue. The previous Government had spent the revenue which it had gained. One simply cannot write off $4 billion which has been spent. If honourable members opposite had ever had any experience in business, instead of being silver spoon fed sons of lucky parents, they would know a little about business and would realise that fact. We were locked into parity pricing but we said that we would index the price so that it would never rise by more than the increase in the consumer price index or the increase in the price for Saudi light crude, whichever was the lesser. That measure was applauded by the farming community, the business community and the Press in this country. At the time honourable members opposite also agreed with it. Unfortunately, events overtook us and with the rapid drop in the value of the Australian dollar the price rose because it was written in Australian dollars. But it must be remembered that the price-
—It was American dollars.

—The prices of oil contracts are written in American dollars. Proportionally the price of wheat rose far more than the price of fuel. That fact must be remembered. Therefore, obviously farmers were the net gainers.
—It is only seasonally a net gain.

—Overall there was of enormous benefit to farmers and that fact cannot be argued. Let us look at protection. Protection was built up by honourable members opposite. They were the architects of the protection in this country. Black Jack McEwen was the man who brought it in and it is now a fact of life in the Australian community. I want to point this out to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the abolition of the duty on headers. I certainly support that; we should never have had that duty. I remember a while ago this was the crisis. The Opposition was trumpeting it as one of the great imposts on farmers. Now it is saying: `It is only $14m; it is really not all that significant'. The truth is that the duty should never have been imposed but in the overall context it was never all that significant to farmers. This shows the Opposition's inability to see the real issues.

The Opposition talks about abolishing this dreadful protection. It bandies around figures, most of which cannot be sustained, but it overlooks one simple fact. Honourable members should remember that there was a government which legislated for a 25 per cent across-the-board tariff reduction and that was a Labor Government. With a few honourable exceptions that Government was hounded and abused by the Liberal and National parties. Honourable members opposite were the people who abused the Labor Government. The effect that reduction had was to impact 50,000 on the unemployment figure. I accept that in the long term protection or free trade is fairly neutral in terms of employment but in the short term there is no doubt that free trade would impact on unemployment. Those who were earning money would save by not paying protection but they would pay out more for the additional social security payments required to fund the people out of jobs. What has to be done in this country, and what farmers must realise has to be done, is to ensure a viable manufacturing industry based on manufacturing products that we can export. We have the ability to do that. I think research is the key to new industries which will make this country viable. It is also the key to viability in the farming sector.

The honourable member for Gwydir praised the level of research in the Australian wheat industry. If the honourable member for Gwydir and honourable members opposite are satisfied with the level of research in the wheat industry, they are very badly mistaken. The record, certainly in the last decade or two, has been fairly appalling. We have not seen the increases in productivity through research into wheat that have been experienced in other countries, notably the United Kingdom. It is interesting to note that the first 10 tonne per hectare crop, which we grew in Tasmania, was grown entirely with British technology. No Australian technology at all was used.

If we are to have research it must be nationally based to get over the propensity we, as a country, have had to keep reinventing the wheel. This has been brought about by State rivalries and parochial attitudes generally. There must be a measure of government involvement in research because its benefits do not all flow directly to farmers; they flow to the entire community. It is only fair that the general community should make a contribution to the cost of research because obviously everyone benefits. I am a very strong supporter of government involvement in research in this area.

The answer is in high technology, which is not just about silicon chips, arsenide and those sorts of things; it is about high technology in plant breeding research. Perhaps one day we will see the ultimate genetic engineering breakthrough when we can marry the properties of legumes with the grasses to get the benefit of the symbiotic relationship with the rhizobia that live in the root systems of all legumes and which extract free nitrogen from the atmosphere and fix it in a usable form. If they could be grafted onto grasses, which are great users of nitrogen, there would be an exponential increase in production.

Australia has been quite advanced in high technology areas. Some time ago I noticed with regret that a soya bean developed in Australia has gone to the United States. It has the ability to fix atmospheric nitrogen at a far higher rate than do soya beans generally. It is not often known that, although soya beans are a legume, they are not good fixers of nitrogen and generally the rhizobia tend not to work until the level of nitrogen in the soil has been depleted. So soya beans are net users of nitrogen in most cases. But a strain was developed which had a much higher nitrogen fixing ability-an enormous breakthrough, funded at a relatively modest cost of just a few million dollars. That research went to the United States holus-bolus. It was lost to Australia. However, I think that through the efforts of the Parry Corporation Ltd in Western Australia this may be redeemed in some measure. But it has happened so often before that Australia has done the basic research and failed to capitalise on it.

Another thing we must do is incorporate overseas experience. It would be very foolhardy for Australia to invest research funds in information that is readily available from overseas. We have to overcome the level of parochialism that has often kept us from that. In this regard, we must look at plant variety rights. There is no doubt that my Party will have to reassess its position.

TALK.START.PARA: —When?
—It will happen in the fullness of time.
—You have been in government for 2 1/2 years.
—I point out to the honourable member who interjected that his party had the government bench in this House for many years. It did nothing.
—We did not have the report until late 1982.

—Those opposite had every opportunity to introduce plant variety rights and put the legislation into effect. They did nothing. So the honourable member should not sit in opposition with his holier than thou attitudes because they will not fool anyone. There is no doubt that plant variety rights will have to be looked at. The Australian Labor Party will have to reassess its position. Plant variety rights have a potential to increase productivity. Without them, we will lock ourselves out of a lot of that very valuable overseas research. We have neither the time nor the economic resources in Australia to undertake that research.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also research in other areas. I digress to deal with some other plants. My electorate has a weed, calotropis. It grows with reckless abandon. It is quite a problem. In the wet season it grows as much as two feet in a month. This plant is interesting because it has the ability to synthesise directly to a hydrocarbon. The sap from it, as with that from a rubber tree, can be readily cracked by the same sort of process that we use now for crude oil. We have identified these plants in the wild as having between 3 and 12 per cent oil content. This genetic pool could be used to obtain a very rapid expansion of that amount. With very limited research we could probably get the oil level up to 15 to 20 per cent. But even at that rate of 12 per cent we are looking at 20 to 30 barrels of oil per hectare, or 2.5 to 4 tonnes of oil per hectare. At that rate, 8 million hectares of country which is presently unused could supply our entire fuel needs.

I am not suggesting that we go that way because at this time I do not think that it would be economic. But we should continue research in this area and feed some into our present supply because we ought to have an economic assessment of it. It may well be that we can afford to abolish government taxes on oil produced in this manner and gain by pay as you earn taxation levied on those who would work in the industry. I do not have the facilities or the ability to work that out, but some of our agricultural economists should look very closely at it. Eight million hectares is not a lot of land considering that about 12 million hectares is used for wheat production. Perhaps calotropis as a fuel supplement could be economically used to replace some of the sugar which is so inefficiently grown in Queensland. It might be cheaper to look at doing this and phasing down some of the production in Queensland. We could move it to the Ord River where the sugar would grow much better, with greater productivity and more cheaply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) in a debate. I say that in no way cynically but with a measure of genuine commendation because snippets of what the honourable member has had to say are endorsed by members on this side of the House.
—But not by his own party.

—As the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) interjected, it is fair to observe that there is a shade of schizophrenia about the honourable member for Kalgoorlie in that his entrepreneurial skills, individuality, flair and colour clearly tempt him from time to time to join us, but he is caught by ingrained prejudices and finds himself still sitting on the other side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: While the honourable member for Kalgoorlie has ranged wider than the Wheat Tax Amendment Bill and cognate Bills would allow, I endorse his earlier remarks in that much of what needs to be said about wheat research has been said by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) and the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker)-and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie. All the orders of the day that have been dealt with by the House this morning have focused on rural research, particularly as it applies to grain crops and the expanding grain legume industry. The Bills before the House allow a maximum rate of $1.10 per tonne to be set for rural research. They have the support of the industry and, as the honourable member for Gwydir said, they have the support of the Opposition.

It is valid for the House to bear in mind, particularly this week with the Budget debate having been rather cruelly curtailed before some honourable members had an opportunity to speak, that all that has been said in the Budget debate about economic recovery-all the plaudits with which the Government has showered on itself about the economic recovery-have failed totally to recognise that much of the economic recovery came from the grain industry. In fact, it was the 78 per cent increase in gross farm product in 1983-84 that did more to fuel economic recovery than did any other single occurrence.

The Government cannot run around this nation claiming to have engineered an economic recovery that has largely resulted from a benevolent mother nature. Much of that economic recovery, I am proud to say, came out of the electorate of Wakefield and, I am prepared to concede, the electorate of Gippsland. There can be no denying, when we look at the Bills before the House, that the same drought that depleted the Australian economy also depleted the research reserves of the grain industry. This legislation is about building those reserves once again. This legislation focuses, as has the debate this morning, on the importance of research in agriculture. It is appropriate, as the member for Wakefield, that I acknowledge much of what happens in my electorate to facilitate agricultural research. For example, my electorate has the premium agricultural college in Australia-Roseworthy Agricultural College.

Much of the best work that has been done on varietal research in wheat has been done at Roseworthy College and on farms in South Australia. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie and the honourable member for Wannon have already alluded to the importance of plant varietal rights and its implications for plant breeding. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie has been very anxious to sidestep the question of why it has taken so long for this Government to take some action on plant varietal rights. He conveniently used the political excuse: What did the Opposition do for seven years? As the honourable member for Gippsland pointed out, the report was not available to the former Government until 1982. We have been from 1982 to almost the end of 1985 with no action at all. It is in this area that a great deal could be done to assist not only the wheat industry but also the workers in wheat research at Roseworthy College and on other farms across Australia.

It is only through rural research, and the development of new grains that are fungus-disease resistant and even more nematode resistant than those that are already available, that there is the opportunity for farmers to increase their production. The delay in plant varietal rights cannot be separated from this legislation and cannot be excused in the light of the inaction by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill from South Australia has a great Bill.

—As the honourable member for Gippsland has pointed out, Senator Hill from South Australia has a private member's Bill that deserves the support of members of both Houses of Parliament. Historically, the grain industry in Australia has always started off on a high. Prior to the nitrogen being leached from virgin soils, grain production is always good. However, as history has taught us, continuing to farm without being aware of what we are doing to the soil structure breeds disaster. So it is that the farmers of Australia have been prepared to fund research to enable them not only to build but also to continue to increase their wheat production. Movements into areas such as minimum tillage and modern chemical farming techniques have enabled farming production to be further increased.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the attention of the House to page 53 of the Australian Wheat Board report where it is indicated that in my own State of South Australia from the year 1974-75 to 1983-84-in that ten season period-the area sown to wheat in South Australia went from 1,220,000 hectares to 1,527,000 hectares, an increase of 26 per cent. In the same ten season period the quantity of wheat grown in my State went from 1,486,000 tonnes to 2,839,000 tonnes, an increase of almost 100 per cent on a land increase of 26 per cent. That is a classic illustration of what farmers are prepared to do in order to increase their productivity and obviously the wealth of the nation. This productivity increase, the funding of which this legislation is all about, has been achieved by innovative farmers. It has been achieved in research institutions such as Roseworthy College and even more significantly it has been achieved by farmers on their farms.
