As the honourable members for Wannon and Gippsland know, because they join me, on farm field days farmers see what other farmers are doing to increase their production. It is this willingness of farmers in the rural industry to share production increasing techniques that is so significant and characteristic of the rural industry. Farmers making their own advances in farm research and in grain growing techniques make them available to fellow farmers.

The Bills before the House bring into rural research a new measure of predictability because as a result of these Bills it will be easier for research organisations to predict the level of funds available to them. It will be easier for them to lay down research projects that will be ongoing and which will cover a number of seasons, so important in rural research as researchers are enabled to take the crop of one season and evaluate it against the crop of another and minimise the seasonal variations that may otherwise occur in short term evaluation. This legislation is all about predictability for research funds, but it is also about predictability for the funds that farmers will be required to make available for research. The maximum sum has been set in the Bills so that it will not be necessary for research organisations to come back to the House frequently seeking further amendments in order to raise the sum.

What farmers ask of the Minister and of the Government but have not received as yet is some indication of what the requirement for research will be this year. Farmers have already indicated, in spite of rising farm costs, a willingness to take it from 30c to 35c, but there is no indication from the Minister of precisely what will be expected of them. The legislation before the House represents a plea for self-sufficiency. The honourable member for Wannon has already indicated that while there has been some criticism of these Bills by the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), in fact, as Senate committees indicate, rural research is an investment by the nation in ongoing rural productivity. The industry has already contributed $5.2m to research and these Bills encourage growers to continue to be self-sufficient.

The honourable member for Rankin used this debate to make some cheap political propaganda out of these Bills, and that was quite inappropriate. The honourable member for Rankin chose to say that the Opposition is floating the concept of privatisation. He asked what that has to do with rural research and where the Opposition stood on the question of government funding. I could think of a few actions lower than that when in fact privatisation has nothing to do with the Bills before the House. The Opposition has no problem in encouraging the Government to match on a dollar for dollar term the concept of rural research because, as the honourable member for Wannon has said and as the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources has already indicated, what is spent on rural research is nothing more than an investment by Australians in the future productivity of Australia. The honourable member for Rankin, if he has a skerrick of honesty in his bones, must concede that point and that the remainder of his debate was nothing more than cheap political point scoring on what is in fact important legislation for Australia's rural industry.

The significant thing is that these Bills allow farmers to continue to contribute to rural research in the face of falling farm incomes. No one has denied that farm incomes have fallen. Farmers across Australia have been marching because they have had to face cruelly rising farm costs. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie has quite wrongly accused the Opposition of making political capital out of allegations that the Government created farm poverty. The Government has never been accused of that by anyone on this side of the House. It is rather more accused of exacerbating the problem that farmers face instead of taking some action to solve them. Those problems are focused in the area of interest rates, rising farm costs because of rising wages and salaries, problems in the fuel area, which we debated this morning, problems in the area of rising fertiliser costs and problems in the area of tariffs on grain headers. All of these rising costs are faced by farmers and in spite of those rising costs and in spite of the consequent fall in farm profits, farmers have indicated a willingness to continue to fund rural research.

The Bills before the House indicate the willingness of Australia's farmers to continue to become more productive in order to survive. They have been accused, in fact, of being productive simply to be profitable. The truth is that unless they increase their production they cannot survive. It must be sobering for many honour- able members on the other side of the House who would have productivity claims used to justify wage increases, to consider now the uncomfortable truth that farmers have productivity simply to enable them to survive at a very low standard of living. It is in the interests of farm survival that these Bills come before the House and it is in the interests of farm survival that the Opposition supports them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Grain, wool and meat together have determined the overall success of Australia's rural industries and our primary industries, occupying nearly half our exports, largely determine the overall success of our economy. I recall being told by a businessman some 35 years ago that our dependence on rural industries would be next to nothing before long. He predicted that manufacturing exports would take their place. That has not happened. Fortunately, a succession of Australian Governments during and following World War II have-without a lot of mollycoddling-made sure that primary industries are not leaned on simply because of the large capital investments involved. Heavy taxing of farmers in Argentina certainly inhibited primary production there. We did not make the same mistake in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Of the successful trio-wool, meat and wheat-wheat showed its economic significance in the June quarter of 1985 when the forecast real net value of rural production fell by 22 per cent, largely because there was a drop in the value of the wheat crop. There is a downward trend in wheat prices. High world production-probably four million tonnes higher than in 1984, which was itself a record-puts a restraint on prices. In Australia there will be a carryover in wheat stocks of over five million tonnes. In the United States of America the Commodity Credit Corporation may have 18 million tonnes in stock in 1985-86. One Kansas farmer said: `I don't know how many bags we have, but we stacked all we could outside and then stored the rest of the crop in the barn'.

Even the most cursory examination of rural history in Australia will show the fallacy of accepting things as they are. We are proven as a primary product supplier to the world and there can be no doubt that our efficiency and capacity will again return a dividend in higher sales. To that end we must develop our marketing and we must research. The wheat tax dealt with in the Wheat Tax Amendment Bill 1985 is used to finance research in the wheat industry. The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) have already discussed wheat research. The amounts collected as tax for wheat research are spent in the State of collection on projects approved by a State wheat research committee and the Commonwealth matching contribution is used to fund research projects approved by the Wheat Industry Research Council. These projects must have a national rather than a local significance. Recognising the need to improve research, the Australian Wheat Growers Federation has requested an increase in the operative rate of tax from 30c a tonne to 35c a tonne. To do that it is necessary to amend the ceiling rate set in the Wheat Tax Act.

I ought not finish without pointing out that there is some optimism in the industry. Reporting to the National Agricultural Conference in Canberra in January-February of this year, the Australian Wheat Board Chairman, Sir Leslie Price, told the conference that despite problems faced by wheat exporters the Australian Wheat Board was confident that it would be able to sell the current crop without resorting to extraordinary measures such as those currently being used by Argentina, where wheat has been offered at fire sale prices and where in some cases wheat prices have been lower than corn prices in order to clear the handling system prior to the coarse grain harvest. In talking about future marketing prospects, Sir Leslie said that world exportable supplies were outstripping growth in demand, that there was no indication of an end to this trend in the near future and that increasing competition and downward pressure on prices were likely to be the rule for some years. He said:

Fundamental changes to this situation seem unlikely to come from the demand side in the next few years. There has been a major shift in importing patterns in recent years, with India and China moving towards self sufficiency in grains. Growth in import demand had occurred in the Middle East and the USSR. However, major new markets seem unlekely to emerge in the current world economic environment.

On the supply side, the future is much more difficult to predict as it will be determined largely by political developments in the US and EEC. There are signs that the cost of supporting agriculture is becoming unacceptable in both countries.The new US Farm Bill currently under consideration represents a fundamental change in US agricultural policy and one that will have a major impact on the world wheat marketing environment in the next decade.

Proposals include the elimination of current measures which hold grain off the market to support prices and a significant reduction in support levels. If implemented, these proposals can be expected to have a major impact on world prices and some observers are already predicting prices will fall by up to 25 per cent by 1986.

The historic national partnership between the Federal Government and the wheat industry is well and truly continuing. The full rebate of the diesel fuel excise for fuel use in primary production will substantially help the industry, as will the replacement of tariffs on imported harvesters with a bounty.

Work by the Government and proposals announced in the recent mini-budget and the Budget include national soil conservation, rural research, the appointment of an agricultural attache to Tokyo, agricultural health and quarantine measures, special adjustment assistance measures and marketing and promotion activities, which have all been welcomed by farmers, including wheat farmers. Far less costly but of enduring importance will be the Government financing of a major report on agriculure to the year 2000. The Wheat Growers Federation and the National Farmers Federation are to be congratulated on their responsible attitudes to marketing and research. The Wheat Growers Federation is to be congratulated particularly on its request for the action that has been taken in this House today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure on behalf of the constituents of Maranoa who are involved in the grain industry to support the Wheat Tax Amendment Bill, the Grain Legume Levy Bill and the Grain Legume Levy Collection Bill. We all know how important it is to continue our research into all facets of endeavour in Australia if we are to remain competitive on world markets. We consume only about 20 per cent of our wheat production and we export about 80 per cent. The importance of the wheat industry and the grain legumes industry throughout Australia has been mentioned in the speeches made here today. The wheat industry is very much the bigger export earner, and we have heard quite a deal on the problems that it is facing today.

SPEECH.PARA: Thank goodness, at long last people are starting to tell not just Federal Governments but State and local governments in Australia about the precarious financial position we are in. It is only industries such as the grain industry that will get us out of the rut that we seem to have fallen into, if we are not going to go totally bankrupt. Unfortunately, farmers throughout the world have mechanised since the last war in particular, and we are facing enormous production although in many parts of the world, as highlighted by the concert held for Ethiopia, a great number of people are still starving.

In my electorate of Maranoa we see many stockpiles of wheat stored under the cover of huge plastic tarpaulins, waiting to be shipped-that is, when the unions allow the ships to move. Of course, I have previously highlighted in the House the problem that the Japanese will not take any grain from New South Wales, a Labor State, but are prepared to take grain from Queensland ports. The shadow Minister mentioned that the Queensland State Wheat Board is taking a lot of New South Wales grain through the rail head at Boggabilla. Of course, there is no rail connection between Boggabilla and Goondiwindi. One of the quirks of our early colonial days was that someone somewhere decided that most States would have separate rail gauges. Because of the parochialism of States, many railways head towards State borders and then stop. In the case of Boggabilla, it stops within 10 miles of Goondiwindi and, therefore, all the grain from northern New South Wales has to go towards Newcastle or Sydney. But of course the wharfies there, who live in the lap of luxury these days, have decided not to ship grain and the railways are having go slow strikes, et cetera. So, a lot of northern New South Wales grain is being shipped through Boggabilla.

The honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) mentioned that he felt that the price of wheat had risen. I inform the House that, unfortunately for people who grow wheat, the real price of grain is far from good. In fact, the real price of grain is probably as low as it has ever been. The highest real price for grain we ever had was in 1972 and it has never been as high since. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has announced an increase in the guaranteed minimum price-GMP-of $130, which is better than a decrease in that amount, but it certainly will not make up for the ever-increasing fuel costs, government charges, capital gains taxes and every other damn sort of tax you like to mention which is going to be brought down in this House this afternoon. But we battle on.

Although the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) says that he is the friend of the farmers, there was not a farmer in the 50,000 outside this place who believed him. But he seems to think he still is their friend. I would like to assure him that he is not. The farming community is now united behind the National Farmers Federation. We had members of the NFF here yesterday briefing Opposition rural committee members.

TALK.START.PARA: —Telling you what to do.

—No, briefing us on the good work that they have been doing in getting people back to work and getting some exports under way from Mudginberri and places like that. It is high time they did so. Fortunately for us, Joh Bjelke-Petersen, that great Premier of Queensland, has led the fight in this direction and continues to do so. It is important, of course, that research be carried out, because the price for prime hard wheat is roughly $150 a tonne gross. Of course, the net payment to farmers is nothing near that; it is roughly $100. Then all ploughing costs, fuel costs and everything else has to come out of that and one is lucky today, after paying 20 per cent interest rates, to be netting anything out of producing wheat. The difference in price between feed wheat and prime hard wheat on today's market is roughly $60 a tonne. I think this really highlights the fact that we need to produce quality wheat, and of course the research undertaken by the industry helps us to do this.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage I would like to congratulate Clinton Condon, a grower from just outside Dalby in the electorate of Maranoa, who has been nominated by the Minister for Primary Industry to serve as the new Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board. We of the Dalby district feel very proud of the fact that Clinton has been nominated. Of course, Sir Leslie Price is retiring. He is an ex-Dalby grain grower also out of that great electorate of Maranoa. I would like to take this opportunity of thanking Sir Leslie and his good wife. Because it is a full time job these people unfortunately have to move to Melbourne to live, and in that sense it is a little like being in Parliament. Clinton and his wife, Lorraine, still have a young family. I have talked to him since his appointment. I was fortunate to spend quite a long time with him as a youth and I more or less grew up with him in one sense. I can assure the Minister that he has made a very wise selection and that he will not be disappointed in Clinton as Chairman of the new Wheat Board.

Rod McLeud farms wheat only about 30 miles from my property in the Goondiwindi-Tara-The Gums area. He is now the Chairman of the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation. My brother, Brian Cameron, who farms next door to me at The Gums, is a member of the Queensland State Wheat Board. I have been farming for 20 years and presently have a reasonable wheat crop growing. So in one sense I like to think that, as member for the area of Maranoa, which grows approximately 80 per cent of the wheat grown in Queensland, I have a pretty close association with the industry. I spend a lot of time on tractors and running trucks and working my guts out sometimes to earn a bob, apart from being in this place. I must say that I enjoy the work; it is good fun. I am very privileged to own a farm. I really enjoy getting back out of this place and going home to do some physical work. It does me the world of good.

The assistance we are debating is the only government assistance given to the grain industry. I tell those in the industry that I can never understand why they want to be as much in the clutches of government as we are. It is incredible that it took nine months of fighting and disagreement for the Minister at long last to bring in a Bill to keep control of the industry in the growers' hands. Previously he was not going to let them have that. I would say that the GMP of the grain industry in Australia is about 20 per cent to 25 per cent of total production in Australia, yet the Government gives it very little and wants total control of it-wants to socialise it. I am pleased that the Bill is to go through the House and that the growers have had a win. Queensland being a semi-tropical environment, the research carried out there is somewhat different from that carried out in Western Australia, South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria. In Queensland the Wheat Institute is headed by Dr Allan Clarke. Paul Brennan is the plant breeder. Rowan Dahl concentrates on soil fertility, Bob Rees on disease and Bob Henry on quality evaluatiion and weathering. Of course, weathering is a very important facet of wheat growing in Queensland because usually, just as we are about to harvest the crop, we get downpours of rain. The Industry Committee appointed by the growers consists of John Bell from Jandowae, the Chairman; John Obst, the Secretary; Ian McCrow from Moura, and Noel Nelson from Drillham. They are small townships in the electorate of Maranoa. Maranoa runs from Goondiwindi in the south to and beyond Emerald in the north.

The Emerald-central Queensland area has enormous potential for farming and is where the bulk of the increase in farm development in Australia today is taking place. It covers more than half the potential farm area in Australia, which is quite incredible when one thinks about it. Last year about $250,000 was spent in Queensland on research into grain, et cetera. It looked at things like zinc defficiency, fallow practices, soil management, evaporation, nitrogen fixing with chick peas, publishing books on weeds, communicating with growers and weathering resistance. Researchers also work with the University of Queensland in looking at the degradation of soil structure under continuous cropping conditions. There is a research property at a small place called Wellcamp just outside Toowoomba.

The biggest problem with this year's crop-and we are looking at an 18 million or 19 million bushel crop following pretty good rains throughout Australia-is that it is not going to be easy to sell. There is always some disease in crops, but this year we have yellow spot due to the build-up of stubble. Minimum tillage and stubble retention have been the swing on grain growing farms in the last few years to try to conserve our soils. With the build-up of stubble, fungi and such things are carried over from one year to the next. The stubble sits on top of the ground to try to stop the water run off and yellow spot has developed. This is a fungus disease which attacks the crops in its very early stages and rapidly reduces the yield.

Driving around the grain growing areas in my electorate of Maranoa, one sees many crops suffering from this disease. No doubt in the next few years researchers will spend a lot of time looking at yellow spot. The only way to get rid of yellow spot is to burn stubble, so people will see an awful lot of black smoke throughout Australia after Christmas, which is a great pity. I see that the Minister for science (Mr Barry Jones) has entered the chamber. I know that he is very interested in these matters. I think that he does an excellent job in his portfolio promoting research and development in Australia. He will be disappointed to know that the only way to get rid of yellow spot is to burn stubble and to burn the host, so to speak. That is very sad for the soil conservationists. We will have to come up with something a little better in that area.

The tariff which was applied on headers has been removed, but it is incredible how the Government has replaced that tariff with a subsidy to which we, as taxpayers, contribute. I do not know that we have gone any further down the line on this problem. Industry is still over protected in many respects. When the report of the Industries Assistance Commission on chemicals comes down, as I mentioned, we will be looking at the question of minimal tillage. That is one of the areas in which we used to try to save and conserve our costs in farming. I hope that when the report comes down common sense will prevail and the tariffs and costs imposed by government will be reduced or taken away so that the price of chemicals will be reduced.

The honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) referred to the reduction in fuel excise. The Labor Government, of course, runs pretty strong on this. It was the farmers' right to receive a fuel rebate and it should never have been taken away from them. The Hawke Government gave it back to them in the last Budget. However, farmers are still worse off than they were last year. In terms of the fuel tax alone they are $60 billion worse off now than they were at the same time last year, a few weeks after last year's Budget. This hoop-la publicity is a nonsense. The gurus of the Press claim that the farmers are being spoon fed by the Hawke Labor Government by way of the Minister's supposed great package. If one does a bit of figuring one finds that the farm sector in Australia is paying $60 billion more by way of fuel tax than it did last year. There are 170,000 farm households in Australia which are paying $3,500 each in tax. Those people are three times worse off than the average taxpayer. I think it is important for people such as the Minister to remember that when Ministers are caucusing around this place every second hour of the day on their tax packages. I invite them to consider the fact that the farming community is very much disadvantaged in this area.

This year farmers are paying $600m in fuel tax as against $539m last year. Although the rebate for diesel fuel was taken off, because the excise on petrol and other fuels and oils, et cetera, is indexed and the price continues to rise because of inflation-it is going up rapidly-and because we estimate that the farm sector has about a 10 per cent share of the sale of those products, the farmers continue to pay a higher proportion of tax in that area. As the amount applicable under the fuel freight subsidy scheme has been increased to 5.2c, any person taking part in that scheme does not receive a fuel freight subsidy at all. This year, that will cost the farmer $20m. When one adds up all these things one finds that proportionately farmers continue to pay much higher taxes than any other taxpayer. They continue to be disadvantaged by our fuel price arrangements.

In the last few days I have seen articles in the Press about Saudi Arabia reducing the price of oil. Hopefully, it will start to undercut the price of oil. It looks as though the Organisation for Petroleum Exporting Countries might be about to collapse. I hope it does. Considering the way the share market is running at the moment in expectation of the wonderful tax package which we will receive this afternoon and the fact that the value of the dollar will drop out of sight, one wonders whether there will be any gain at all for farmers regarding the price of fuel, even though the Arabian price might come down by $3 or $4 a barrel. A sales tax has been imposed on greases and oils. That represents another impost on the farming community since the Labor Government came to office.

I mentioned the capital gains tax. Such a tax will have a very depressing effect on farm land prices. The introduction of this tax occurs right at the time when the Government is running interest rates of 18 to 20 per cent and when farmers need some equity and value in their land more than ever. We see these characters on the Labor side of politics bringing in a brand new lot of taxation measures. Who needs taxes? We need them like a hole in the head. Nobody wants a new tax. Farming small buisiness cannot continue under this regime of new taxes such as capital gains tax. We understand that the family home will be exempt from a capital gains tax. Straightaway there is a gross distortion in the system by the Prime Minister. What will be the value of his home in the middle of Melbourne as against the value of my home out on a farm? Straightaway there is a discrimination by the Prime Minister. Firstly, he exempts the family home and, secondly, becuase the value of the farm home cannot be anywhere near the value of a home in the middle of Melbourne, such as the Prime Minister's, there is a discrimination. The National Party of Australia is totally opposed to a capital gains tax of any description. Such a tax can do nothing but depress the economy right at the stage when it is the last thing we need. One has only to look at this morning's newspaper reports of the share market. They should give members of Cabinet some idea of what the people of Australia think of the moves the Government intends to announce this afternoon.

I turn to soil and water conservation. The Minister for Science encourages people to take part in these programs; yet his colleagues drop the tax incentive whereby in the year that the money was expended there was a 100 per cent write-off. That has now been cut back to a 20 per cent write-off over five years. That must be another disincentive to people who want to help in conserving our soil and water. The Labor Government is spending nothing on water conservation. A measley amount of $30m or $40m is being provided, some of which is being spent in town. Nowhere near enough is being spent.

I direct the Minister's attention to the fact that we cannot earn money off-farm now. I highlight the fact that during the depression of the beef industry the grain growers-now it is the sugar growers-were able to go out to work and earn some other income. They ought to be allowed to do that and write it off against their farm income. Only six months ago this Government introduced legislation to allow Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd to do exactly that-to write off some of its earnings from its oil producing area into its other areas and to move its income. Yet this Government does not allow the farming industry to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourble member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank most of the honourable members who have contributed to this debate. I will comment on some of the wild charges made by the Opposition, particularly those by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), in a moment. The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), in putting the Opposition's view on the Wheat Tax Amendment Bill, the Grain Legumes Levy Bill and the Grain Legumes Levy Collection Bill, of course, agreed to them-they are simply, non-contentious Bills-and I thank him for his comments. He asked a few questions. He stated that it was not clear whether the operative rate would be increased as requested by the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation. The simple answer to that is that the process of amending regulations on passage of the Wheat Tax Amendment Bill is under way and this will increase the operative rate from 30c to 35c, as requested by the Wheatgrowers Federation. This will be effective, possibly, from 1 November-if the legislation is not held up in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Gywdir also queried the benefit to the wheat industry and the grain growing industry of devaluation. We only ever work with estimates, not on the basis of knowledge, but at one point in time the value of the devaluation to the wheat industry was estimated at $260m for this year. Later on an estimate came out from the Bureau of Agricultural Economics that the value was about $500m. Against that, one has to take into account the fact that the Australian Wheat Board is involved in currency hedging and that the wheat pools pay out over quite a considerable time. So even if those figures are correct the full benefit will not come through straight away. It is an easy jibe to make but the basic economics are sound if the exchange rate goes down, particularly against the United States dollar-and wheat sales are made in United States dollars. Of course, we have gained very substantially with respect to our export industries from the devaluation of the Australian dollar. I say it is a very easy point to make because on the one hand the farmer only sees the Bills and on the other hand when he gets the cheque for his sales he does not know to what extent devaluation has helped in terms of the gross sum that he receives. So, I guess the Opposition will continue to make these points. However, I must simply reiterate that the fundamental economics are that, given the relative exchange rates between Australia and particularly the United States of America, we have a very distinct advantage.

The honourable member for Gwydir also mentioned the fact that now tariffs have been pulled off headers and we have moved to subsidies, some 250 people have been put off by Horwood Bagshaw Ltd. I am not sure whether he was bleating about that or not because in the next breath he said how bad it was that the anti-dumping action had been taken and that that was going to put up the price of DAP fertilisers. I think he understands that that decision by the Customs Service is not yet final, that the findings are only preliminary. The honourable member has to realise, of course, that one cannot have it both ways. One of the big problems is that generally the farm sector argues for free trade when it suits it to do so. It is very logical, consistent and sensible for our broadly based grazing and crop industries to advocate a free trade approach and I can understand fully the reasons why they do so. However, on the other hand they cannot say that if one kilogram of lamb crosses the Tasman or if some additional cheese comes in there should be an instant cut-off. One cannot run both arguments at once.

Similarly, one cannot run both arguments with respect to dumping and the whole question of tariffs. Only economists believe that there are not any short term effects if protection and industry assistance arrangements are changed. Many people have been dismissed in the fertiliser industry as a result of the fact that subsidies are now paid on imports. Announcements have already been made in respect of Christmas Island. We are in a far different situation now with the whole question of fertilisers. Perhaps the farm sector would like to put itself in the hands of overseas exporters and see us importing forever. However, I point out that it is not certain that we will forever and a day get cheap fertilisers from Florida. We might be prepared to pay subsidies on imports, and wipe out Christmas Island and our other usual sources of supply and put ourselves in the hands of countries like Morocco, Algeria and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. However, we will do so at our cost because we cannot predict what is going to happen in those countries.

I think, and I hope that the Opposition will endorse this view, we should now be concentrating on the future of Australian fertiliser supplies. If there is to be more investment in Australian phosphate deposits, if there is to be the massive investment that will be needed in respect of nitrogenous fertilisers, possibly using North West Shelf gas as the feedstock, we need to devise policies that take into account very loing term investment decisions. If we are going to encourage those investment decisions in this country we cannot at the same time also encourage imports. The Government is addressing these important questions.

Members of the Opposition made quite a bit of play about the pretty dreadful industrial situation with respect to the New South Wales grain handling system. Again, one cannot have it both ways by accusing people of being socialists and centralists and propping up States rights. The rail gauge situation is a classic example of States rights gone mad. This week's Bulletin contains an article which lists the worst mistakes that have ever been made in Australia. Quite apart from the siting of Canberra and what we have done to our soils, the whole rail gauge system certainly came up for comment by very wise people in our community.

The situation in New South Wales is not new. I am rather amazed that nothing has come out of all the work that has gone on over the years. However, there was a dreadful situation in respect of the farmer dominated grain elevators boards. The structure of the New South Wales grain handling is still basically flawed because of the parish pump approach that the old Grain Elevators Board took many years ago. The New South Wales Government acted. It had to fight the farm organisations which did not want change. However, we got a better grain handling authority. The farmers have now been mounting enormous pressure. Mr Dobbin has gone as head of the New South Wales Grain Handling Authority. Again, the New South Wales Government is trying to get a better situation there. I think we are all dismayed that the industrial relations set-up does not seem to get any better. This is to be deplored.

Fuel prices came in for quite a bit of comment. I simply point out that index of fuel prices paid rose this year by about 8 per cent. There was a counterbalance due to the exchange rate variation. The wheat and grains industry is certainly more than well compensated by the exchange rate movement-fuel vis-a-vis price received. Of course, under the previous Government fuel prices actually went up by about 40 per cent in about 1979-80 and 1980-81. This was the time of the so-called second oil shock. The import parity pricing policy has not caused this problem this year so much as has devaluation. In the long haul the thing that really counts for our competitive industries is that very word `competitiveness'. While ever we are paying about the same or less for our fuel, by and large in the long haul we remain competitive.

Comment was made on the subject of plant variety rights. It was alleged that I had done nothing. The Australian Labor Party passed a motion at its last conference that we should have an inquiry into Australia's plant breeding needs and alternatives to PVR. This whole question was broadened out into a sensible approach to our plant breeding needs. Quite frankly, because of the size of the local market, we will never be able to get into the breeding of some plant species which are planted and used by farmers. Of course, we have a very big plant breeding effort at present with the broader crop species. I have appointed Professor Alex Lazenby to report to the Government on Australia's plant breeding needs and alternatives to PVR. However, I point out to honourable members opposite that the previous Minister for Primary Industry could not get agreement with the States. This is on the public record; it can be found in the minutes and the reports of Australian Agricultural Council meetings. However, we are making some progress.

As far as the Bills before the Parliament are concerned, our plant breeding effort in respect of cereals is one of my real concerns in terms of plant variety rights. I would not like to see ideologues of the character of the Premier of Queensland come along with the theory that just because plant breeding can be private it is therefore better for it to be private. I think it is terribly important to realise with respect to cereals that we have to take into account environmental conditions and differences in conditions in the various States and the fact that a lot of the research that is going on in relation to plant breeding at present, particularly for cereals and the broadacre crops, is concentrating on matters other than productive species. Work is being done on cloning, hail shattering, frost resistance and salt resistance. All of these sorts of things may not necessarily be carried out by private plant breeders. They try to sell a product quickly, possibly without all the research back-up and the large public investment that is going on at present. In other words, I do not think that criticism about lack of plant variety rights really applies on cereals. I have been at pains to make the distinction between plant breeding and plant buying. As I said earlier, we will never get into the business of plant breeding in respect of some species. I can see no reason why Australia's farmers should be denied access to those species. This matter particularly falls into the area of horticulture.

I would like to make some final comments on what the honourable member for Maranoa had to say. I certainly endorse his comments about the coming retirement of Sir Leslie Price. He will choose the time to go but he has been reappointed. So that there would be no confusion, I thought it very important that I announce his successor. In keeping with my view of trying to get a corporate board on the various statutory marketing authorities and trying to get the best people possible, after a lot of thought and consideration I felt that Mr Clinton Condon best met those criteria. So another man from Queensland has been appointed. I did not appoint him because he came from Queensland; quite frankly, I appointed him because I thought he was the person who was best fitted to carry out that job.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a good point.
—I say to the honourable member for Franklin that if there had been a good Tasmanian I would have grabbed him, too.
—There are some good Tasmanians.

—They do not grow much wheat in Tasmania; that is the problem. With respect to some of the other erratic comments by the honourable member about my wanting to socialise the wheat industry and about the Government doing nothing for the wheat industry-he asked why it should be involved-I simply point out that the public backs this industry with respect to a 95 per cent net underwriting. If there is a collapse in the wheat market the public faces very large bills. At one stage since I have been Minister, if the market had not turned, the Government faced a payout of about $190m. We also provide enormous national interest cover with respect to credit markets. We have also given the Australian Wheat Board the power to involve itself in transactions on overseas money markets with respect to forward cover and interest. This has saved the industry tens, if not hundreds, of millions of dollars.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the arguments that I have had with the industry about the composition of the people on the Board, I have always been inclined, and I have always been at pains to point out, that I was quite happy that it have a grower majority, given the history of this Board, the history of the industry and the fact that the growers own the wheat. In other words, it is different from other statutory authorities. I have never had any problems about there being a grower majority. But I do want to have on that Board the most competent, efficient and capable people, and a Board which is able to act corporately. There should be a balance in terms of the professional staff and a balance in terms of giving a broad perspective to the very big testing problems that the Wheat Board has before it.

The final point I mention is the whole question of taxes. I am sure that other words will be spoken about the question of taxes today and in the next day or two. I think farmers should also be aware that they should concentrate not only on whether they may or may not be required to pay additional taxes but also on the fact that if the 60 per cent tax scale is reduced to 49 per cent they will benefit. Farmers will benefit if the measures being implemented by the Government give it a lot more revenue, so that we do not continue to allow people to avoid and evade the payment of tax forever and a day. It appears that tax paying is becoming optional in this country. We must realise that more and more people are accumulating wealth and economic power in this country, while the ordinary farmers and the ordinary wage blokes pay more and more tax. The White Paper and some of the option A proposals disclose information about people avoiding the payment of tax. Farmers are not fools. They, too, are opposed to the enormous tax evasion and avoidance that is going on in this country. They, too, know that they stand to benefit if we have a taxation system that is a lot fairer and a lot more equitable for all Australians. There should not be double standards which protect those who can so arrange their affairs that the payment of tax becomes optional. I commend the Bills to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Kerin) read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw to the attention of the House to the presence in the gallery of a distinguished former member of this place, the Hon. W. C. Wentworth.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 August, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Kerin) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 22 August, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Kerin) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SNOWY MOUNTAINS ENGINEERING CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 18 September.
Consideration of Senate's amendment.
Senate's amendment-
Page 13, clause 8, after proposed new paragraph 52 (b), insert the following new paragraph:
``(c) a report on the operations of any partnership or company in the formation of which the Corporation has joined,''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate's amendment be agreed to.

The amendment agreed to by the Senate relates to paragraph 52 of that part of the Bill entitled `Part VII-Miscellaneous'. Paragraph 52 deals with the necessity for the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation to produce an annual report and to include various matters. The Senate in its wisdom has suggested that after paragraph 52 (b) we add the following new sub-paragraph:
(c) a report on the operations of any partnership or company in the formation of which the Corporation has joined.

We accept that amendment. The reference to companies and partnerships and, by implication, joint ventures, relates to clauses 6 and 7 of the Bill, which set out the functions and powers of the Corporation. Clause 7 repeals section 18 of the principal Act and allows the Corporation to enter into partnerships, companies, joint ventures and so on, in the pursuit of its functions, which are to investigate, advise on, design, supervise and construct engineering works in Australia and overseas.

As I said, the Government will accept that amendment. The legislation assists the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation in its envisaged operations as a flag carrier in representing Australia overseas and in assisting the Australian engineering design industry in the private sector. It imposes obligations on it to enter into this sort of activity and to assist as many Australian companies as possible in the pursuit of work overseas. Obviously, given that explanation, the Government would have absolutely no objection to reports upon the companies, joint ventures and partnerships that the Corporation enters into being included in its annual report. It should be as open and frank as possible with the Parliament and the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition also supports the amendment. We believe that the amendment is necessary because the Opposition remains very concerned about the operations of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. Although the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation Amendment Bill was well debated both here and in the Senate, I will reiterate some points. The Corporation has had losses in its last two years of operation of about $10m. Its superannuation liabilities of the order of perhaps a further $10m still have not been brought to account in the Corporation's accounts. The accounts of the Corporation have been qualified for the last three years. That simply would not be tolerated in the private sector. We remain concerned about its current profitability. The Corporation's 1983-84 report stated that the Corporation would be operating on a profitable basis in 1985-86. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) in his second reading speech said that he accepted that in that year the Corporation would break even. Perhaps at an appropriate time we should invite the Minister to say whether he still believes that his projections for the breaking even of the operations of the Corporation in 1985-86 are accurate because when the Corporation loses money it loses the taxpayers' money.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 18 of the Bill gives the Corporation the power, amongst other things, to join in the formation of partnerships and companies. The Minister's second reading speech made it clear that the relevant amendments involved included the overseas operations of the company. I draw the attention of the House to the report from the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations which, in turn, drew the attention of the Parliament to the fact that the Australian Dairy Corporation had created an off-shore subsidiary which had functions wider than those of the parent authority. Accordingly, it was somewhat disappointing that the Senate chose to reject three other amendments to Clause 7 in relation to proposed new section 18, which were:
(3) The Corporation shall not join in the formation of a partnership of a company unless the Minister has approved in writing of the participation of the Corporation in that partnership or company.

(4) An approval given under sub-section (3), together with a statement of particulars of the partnership or company to which the approval relates, shall be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the giving of that approval.
(5) The Corporation shall not join in the formation of a partnership or a company which has any function or power which is not a function or a power of the Corporation.'.

This amendment seeks to address that deficiency in the amendment Bill to some extent. The Opposition's policy is that when in government we will transfer the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation from the control and influence of political forces and bureaucratic domination to the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a disgrace.
—If the honourable member thinks that losing the taxpayers' money in the way the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation has lost money is not a disgrace, I do not know what is.
—It is an excellent engineering organisation and you are just going to hand it over to one of your friends.
—Order! The honourable member for Dunkley will be quiet.
—I do not mind him saying that he thinks that losing the taxpayers' money is a good idea.
—Order! The Chair minds.

—It is our proposal to develop a detailed plan on how transfer to the private sector can take place and to put this plan to the Australian people as part of our general privatisation plans and revised policy on the Department of Housing and Construction. In the meantime it seems appropriate to assure the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation that it has nothing to fear from a coalition government. On the contrary, we would want it, firstly, to be free from the claws of Canberra; secondly, to take its place in the more invigorating private sector; and, finally, to make certain that management and employees are given appropriate incentives to make the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation profitable again and to maintain and improve its undoubted engineering reputation. The Opposition supports the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 September, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In debating the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Amendment Bill, I say that the Opposition does not oppose the Bill because it is part of proposals that members of the Opposition put to the Parliament in connection with declarations made last year about making the implementation of the Bill more effective. This legislation follows the May expenditure statement when the Government decided to increase the limit on the fuel subsidy levy from 1.2c to 5.2c, whereby it created an additional revenue saving of some $116m. Whilst the Opposition did not oppose that measure by amendment or otherwise because of the nature of the expenditure, that has had a dramatic effect on industries across Australia. Unfortunately, many of those industries add to the real wealth of Australia-those that are exporting and those in the rural and primary industry area which feeds the rest of Australia. That was a tremendous cost and a blow to them at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is to give more effective administration to the implementation of the Bill. For instance, it was found-I understand from the reports that have been given that this is quite accurate-that false claims were being made about the subsidy. I realise that the lifting of the limit from one amount to the other and the rate of subsidy overcame some of these problems because the points of delivery have been reduced from 3,900 outlets to 1,650 outlets. That applied also in connection with the nomination of a distribution point. But I think the big problem was and may still be the effect of jobbers in the market. People in a service station which was free from any other restraints of trade were able, at times, to buy their fuel and retail it at a lower price than that at which the legitimate retailer was able to buy fuel from the same station. That was reflected quite dramatically at points in Queensland. I understand that that is still the case. In spite of the fact that the subsidy rate exemption has risen from 1.2c to 5.2c these jobbers can still have available to them fuel which they can use to undersell the legitimate retailer in the market.

There is also the aspect, which does concern Australians, about the ability of some refining companies to enter into price wars and to discount substantially the price in particularly big areas where there is a mass of custom. This is done at the expense of those people in country areas where there is no such competition and the price of fuel automatically rises to the highest level which the retailers and the oil companies feel they can get from those people. I do not believe that the legislation will effect changes in those respects, but they are problems that should be addressed.

Clause 3 (1) introduces registration conditions which will further restrict the scope of the scheme. The Bill will also require a statutory declaration to inhibit false claims. In the financial impact statement there is no indication of any cost or gain to revenue. I think the Government should have identified for the Parliament places where there will be expenditure savings.

One might say that the oil industry of Australia greases and powers the economy of Australia, particularly with the present reliance on self-production. It is important that such an industry not in its own way reflect losses to the economy. This has been the situation in the last 12 to 18 months, with the devaluation of the dollar and the fact that we have been linked to the Saudi Arabian price. It has put up the price of fuel in the community by substantial amounts. Some people estimate an increase of up to 12c a litre. Increased fuel prices will have an effect particularly in the area in which I am particularly interested-trade. This factor is built into the whole production costs of export industries and is making them less competitive on the open market. The Opposition would free up this market as far as possible so that we were not bound by some of the stringent conditions that are presently in the import parity pricing arrangements. We want that to be understood. In saying that, there is no guarantee that the prices themselves would fall at the bowser, but it would free up the companies and refineries of Australia as to how they might participate in bringing fuel on to the market at the cheapest price. The situation of discounting and jobbing is not making any easier the life of those marketeers, the people who are producing Australia's exports.

The fuel industry is important to Australia, particularly in terms of our self-sufficiency. This Bill basically deals with distribution rather than with refining, which will come into an argument later today. This scheme was shown to have led to abuse, particularly with northern prawners. I understand that the complexity and difficulties of the scheme led to spot checks on payments instead of full verification of claims. Some artificial schemes were designed to attract subsidy, some distributors maintained substandard accounts and the records caused difficulty in verification. If this Bill is to improve that situation, there must be some cost effectiveness for government. However, it has not been possible to show the impact of the financial implications, and this perhaps indicates the shambles in which the Government has got itself in this respect.

The Bill also validates certain practices for mini-refineries, particularly the one at Roma. All that we say in connection with this matter is that there will be no further subsidies under current legislation. The subsidies will be passed back to consumers. The Opposition is concerned-and we shall be moving an amendment on this matter in Committee-that the conditions laid down for the recognition of a mini-refinery preclude consideration of another mini-refinery anywhere else in Australia which might be set up as a small oil flow-and it might be to the best advantage to treat it in that way because of the limitation on litreage. We intend to move an amendment on that aspect because it is important to give the most encouragement to people in the industry to develop, produce and refine if that is possible. If a limit is imposed, those people will not be encouraged, because those undertaking this task will look at it from the point of view of what subsidy is available in order to determine their viability. We shall be dealing with that matter in Committee. The Opposition does not oppose this Bill. All we are saying is that we will free up the market in respect of oil.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 106A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member for Dawson will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Citizenship Ceremonies-Australian Press Council-Death of Mr Neil Davis-Privatisation-Australian Sugar Industry-Unsolicited Telephone Selling-High Rise Buildings-Australian Attitudes-Youth Unemployment

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been brought to my attention that consideration is being given, and docments are being prepared, by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to changing the traditional arrangements whereby citizenship ceremonies are carried out by local government authorities on behalf of the Federal Government. If this comes to pass I believe it will be a totally retrograde step. I rise then, Mr Deputy Speaker, to lodge my protest and objection to any such move away from a very fine tradition acceptable to all Australians and trust that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) will reject any such recommendation from his Department.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the great strengths of the present arrangements is the significance that is given to the public act of taking out Australian citizenship by renouncing a former citizenship; an act that has great emotional involvement for most people taking part in the ceremonies. Since first being elected to this Parliament in 1966 I have attended over 100 citizenship ceremonies-or, as they were formerly known, naturalisation ceremonies-conducted on behalf of the Federal government of the day by the Sutherland Shire Council. Irrespective of who has occupied the important role of President of that shire-whether it was Arthur Gietzelt, presently a Minister in the Hawke Government; the Liberal President, Councillor Michael Tynan; the Independent President, Jean Manuel; or the current President, Councillor Skinner-the ceremony has been carried out with the dignity appropriate to the importance of the occasion. The regular attendance of large numbers of families and friends of those receiving their citizenship ceremonies is testimony to the high regard that people throughout the community put into the public declaration of taking out the prized possession of Australian citizenship.

There is no reason, then, why we should move away from this established format which has developed traditions which indicate to the community at large that the taking out of citizenship papers is not just an administrative act like applying for a pension. It is an important event for the community to be made aware of the decision by so many residents born overseas to taking out Australian citizenship. The public declaration is a fitting format and I believe it must be maintained. The use of local government as the intermediary in these ceremonies is particularly appropriate. It is that form of government closest to the day to day lives of the average Australian which personalises the event. By using local government facilities we show what can be achieved through the co-operation of all levels of government. It personalises the ceremony of citizenship. It stops the act of citizenship becoming institutionalised into a statistical figure.

Citizenship must not ever be regarded as a mere statistic. The act of taking out citizenship is very individual and very personal. To discourage the format of public declaration at a centrally located place, such as the local shire hall, is wrong and totally contrary to the spirit and mood of taking out citizenship. Of course, there are instances of people whose shyness and language disabilities can, and do, cause them embarrassment. For these folk there is already a way by which private ceremonies can be performed, and over the last 19 years I have been privileged to attend a couple of these and I note that they were carried out with great dignity by officers of the Department

Were this proposal something that stood isolated perhaps it may not have needed to be publicised and it could have been regarded as merely the effort of an over-zealous departmental officer keen to make his mark, keen to impress his Minister. However, I believe that this should be seen against the background of other moves that have been made since this present Hawke Government took office. We have seen a series of moves which could have downgraded the significance of citizenship ceremonies. There has been an attempt to change surreptitiously the need for those taking out new citizenship to declare allegiance to the Queen of Australia. There was also the attempt to remove the choice of taking the oath or making an affirmation. Fortunately both of these attempts were futile in view of strong protests from members of the Opposition parties and the resultant general public outcry. There has been the fact that the paper upon which the certificate is printed is now of a much poorer quality. I would acknowledge at this stage the vocal protests made by a good friend Alderman George Moore, Mayor of Kogarah, in Sydney, on this subject.

Now we have the strong likelihood that encouragement is to be given to all applicants for Australian citizenship to have their certificates presented to them at private ceremonies in the departmental office without any public statement or acknowledgement of this major event in the lives of each person who has made the decision to join us all as Australian citizens. The Minister must deny any such move or departmental recommendation and see that local governments throughout Australia are not only maintained as the intermediary to conduct these ceremonies but stoutly encouraged to improve continually the dignity and solemnity of such occasions.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I am aware there is an embarrassment and uncertainty among many permanent residents of Australia when it comes to following through the formalities which lead up to the taking out of Australian citizenship. Ethnic traditions can cause emotional and social barriers for many, particularly for many women who are the victims of broken marriages. I know from talking with social workers in this field that the public ceremony of granting citizenship is an horrific prospect and is the main reason why so many of these disadvantaged persons in our community will not take the necessary steps, with the resultant disadvantages which accrue to them and more particularly to their children if they do not hold Australian citizenship. For example, I know members and you particularly, Mr Deputy Speaker, will appreciate that employment in the Commonwealth Public Service is now not open to non-citizens. So any barriers which can be removed should be removed for these people. That is to say, private ceremonies should continue to be made available to them. there is a good argument, which I support, for facilitating the process of having a private ceremony.

What concerns me today is the move within the Department-I know not whether it has the Minister's nod of approval or not-to do away with the ceremony performed by our local governments. A lot has been said about privatisation of certain government instrumentalities and institutions. What is very important to me is the need to personalise government in all its activities and to this end any shift away from the use of local government must be seen as a further move to depersonalise a very emotional decision in a growingly computerised society.

I believe that the Minister is a compassionate man. I have had evidence of this in regard to some of the cases from my electorate which I have put to him. So I appeal to him on two points today. On the one hand, I believe he should be facilitating the ease with which certain categories of applicants should be allowed to have private ceremonies when making their statement of allegiance to our Queen of Australia. Unfortunately time does not allow me to properly develop this theme today. Secondly-and I believe there is a sense of urgency in this grievance today-I appeal to the Minister in the strongest terms to ignore any departmental pressure to have public ceremonies conducted by local governments throughout Australia, stopped. As I have already mentioned it would be depersonalising for all involved, and this proposal should be rejected by the Minister when or if it now finds its way to him. I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, my grievance today is about the Australian Press Council and, indeed, the bias of much of the country Press in Australia. The Press Council is on of those self-regulating bodies that tends to pat itself on the back for a job well done. I firmly believe, from personal experience, that this Council is a sham, its function is to protect the Press from criticism.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us examine the statement of principles put out by the Australian Press Council. It claims that it will treat the public interest as its first and dominant consideration, and that readers of a newspaper are entitled to have both news and comment presented to them with complete good faith and, therefore, with scrupulous honesty and fairness in both statement and omission to ensure the truth and exactness of articles. The statement of principles goes on to say:

A newspaper is justified in advocating its own views on controversial topics providing in doing so it treats its readers fairly by not mis-stating or suppressing facts which are relevant to conclusion which it encourages readers to accept--
I have no disagreement with that statement--
and not distorting or unfairly colouring news, either in the text or in headlines.

Can we in all honesty say that many newspapers in Australia achieve this? This extract from the statement of principles is very important, as I will show later on in this speech. Just after I was selected as the Australian Labor Party candidate for the seat of Macarthur, the seat I held before the last election, the then Mayor of Nowra-at the instigation of the local Press, I might add-burnt an Aboriginal flag. This got a lot of publicity throughout Australia. At a fund-raising function for me a couple of people took up a collection to place an advertisement in another paper apologising to the local Aboriginal people for this great insult to them. A reporter from the Shoalhaven and Nowra News approached me and told me I had to use my influence to stop the advertisement appearing. I said that I could not do that, and even if I could I would not. The reporter then told me in front of many witnesses that the paper would work against me in the election campaign.
Three days later the editor's secretary telephoned me and said that the editor had said that I did not exist. If I did not exist, how could they be ringing me up to tell me that I did not exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —They didn't even report me when I went there.

—The newspaper did not even report the Minister for Science when he came to my electorate then to campaign for me. It ignored him, as it ignored the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and many other Ministers who came, because it claimed I did not exist. It said that it would accept no copy from me, which it did not, and throughout the campaign this paper refused to publish my name or make any mention of me at all, except during the week before the election when it published a front page story hinting that I was living in an illegal dwelling-which I was not. Then, on the day of the election-it is usually published on a Wednesday-it published a 12-page edition which came out against me and praised my opponent. In fact, when we organised a few letters to the editor of the papers, having made sure that my name was included in those letters, the paper printed the letters but it took my name out each time.

SPEECH.PARA: The town of Nowra has two papers and when I was not advertising enough in the other paper one day it removed all my Press releases and replaced them with those of my opponents. It informed me that, unless I took out full-page ads, it would publish nothing from me. In fact, Mr Deputy Speaker, that paper blackmailed me into spending over $4,000 in advertising. On the eve of the election it was going to publish a totally false and misleading story. I found out about this and eventually, on the day before the election, had to obtain a Supreme Court injunction against it. Despite my frequent challenges since the election to publish the story now, it has refused. My argument is that if it was important enough to appear the day before the election, when we had an electronic blackout and I could not answer it, why not publish it after the election?

I could speak for hours about my treatment by these newspapers-the phone calls in the middle of the night, the invasion of my privacy and the many other problems that I have had with the media of Nowra. But I turn to another paper in my former electorate, the Camden Crier. For many years the transportation of coal in the Illawarra has been one of the most emotive and sensitive political issues. There have been endless discussions about rail verus road transport. The people of Camden had been convinced, wrongly, that unless the coal was transported by road the mines in the Burragorang Valley would close. Mr Deputy Speaker, I am of necessity condensing and simplifying a somewhat complicated issue. In November 1982 the New South Wales State Government relaxed the limit on coal transportation. I was contacted by the Camden Crier and asked for my views. The point here is that I was contacted by the newspaper; I did not contact it. What I said over the phone was that, although disappointed that the road limit had to be lifted, given the economic climate it was a realistic decision and it would save the mining jobs in the Burragorang Valley. When the article appeared on 10 November it quoted many people welcoming the decision, including the then sitting member, and went on to say that not everyone welcomed the decision:
The endorsed Labor candidate, Colin Hollis, said he was disappointed that the limit had been lifted.

My political opponent seized on this statement and used it in his campaign against me. Indeed, the article was reproduced and circulated throughout the electorate to show that I was anti-mining. The statement damaged me significantly in the election but, thank goodness, not enough to prevent me from being elected.

When I was aware that I had been misquoted and that it was being used politically against me, I telephoned the editor, Barbara Turner, and, as she was out, I explained to a reporter the nature of my complaint and asked that the editor return my call. This she did not do despite me making several telephone calls. I reported the matter to the Press Council on 2 December. The Executive Secretary telephoned me and his whole attitude was to try to get me to drop the matter. In one telephone call he said that if I cared to send a letter to the editor he would see that it was published. I said that that was not good enough, that I wanted the same treatment that the original story had received and wanted my complaint to proceed. Despite the Press Council asking the Camden Crier for its version of events the Crier refused to co-operate. Finally Mrs Turner wrote on 24 June, saying:

Mr Hollis was at no time misquoted but he was not fully quoted. Mr Hollis has been treated no differently than any other politician. Press releases sent by Mr Hollis have always been placed in the Camden Crier.

How does this fit in with the stated objectives of the Press Council of not mis-stating or suppressing facts and not distorting or unfairly colouring news. The case was adjudicated on 28 July. The Press Council accepted what the editor of the Camden Crier said, including the lies in her letter, and dismissed my case. Even the report the Press Council issued was full of inaccuracies. It said:
He had issued a Press release welcoming the State Government's decision to begin work on economic planning of the Maldon--
which the Council could not even spell-
Dombartan--
which it also misspelt-
rail link and stage two of the Port Kembla coal loader.

It went on to refer to what was said in the Press release, but that was a lie because I never issued a Press release. I was responding by telephone to questions from the Camden Crier. By not fully quoting me, especially on such a sensitive, political issue, I have no doubt the Camden Crier and its editor were deliberately attempting to damage me politically. The Council said in its report:
The Press Council believes the matter could have been resolved if Mr Hollis had taken advantage of the 7 December offer.

That is rubbish. If the Press Council feels a letter placed in any position in a newpaper one month after such a damaging report is any compensation, it is naive. I do not argue that papers cannot decide whether or not to use a Press release, but when they seek views and one gives them, and those views are deliberately misquoted, I believe that the Press Council should act. Because of my lack of faith in the Press Council I would not bother putting any other case to it. I accept that there is always an uneasy relationship between politicians and newspapers, and politicians have no right to expect their utterances to be reported. But when a newspaper asks for our views and when presenting those views distort them, I do not consider that to be acting in a responsible manner. The newspapers talk a lot about freedom of the Press and we all agree with that. As politicians we know that we are going to be criticised and often taken to task, but how responsible are many of the country newspapers that exercise this freedom?

I believe that the present Press Council, which is a sham, should be abolished. It serves no real purpose except to confirm the high opinion newspapers have of themselves. As I said, it should be abolished. But we do need a body with a watching brief on the media, especially the print media, as there are regulations on the electronic media and I personally have always found them to be less biased than the print media. They are more likely to give balanced reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I follow a very serious grievance. I have shared a place on a committee with the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) and I have always found him to be a most honourable person. I am sorry that he has been placed in such a dilemma. Today all the world is searching for the truth; all the world is looking to journalists and cameramen to provide the truth, to make absolutely certain that the things that we read about and see on television are the truth. We want to see not just one side of the argument but both sides and we want to be able to determine what is right and what is wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an old saying in Tasmania that once a Tasmanian, always a Tasmanian. If one was born in Tasmania, has lived there, there is always a very close kinship, a relationship that is inexplicable. Most people in Tasmania were saddened by the passing of Neil Davis and I would like to read what Bruce MacDonnell, his former colleague and boss, if I may put it that way, said about the late Neil Davis, as faithfully reported in an article in the Hobart Mercury of 16 September 1985, headed `No tears are left for a frontline legend.
Neil Davis died filming a military coup that would have not made news it did but for his death.

It is a bitter irony and one which Davis's former boss feels only too well. Mr MacDonell is the General Manager of the American television network, NBC, in Asia and the Pacific and was a friend of Davis. They had worked on the front line together for years. Mr MacDonell flew into Hobart at the weekend to return Davis's ashes to his brother at Mornington. The article stated:

It was a drained and grieving Mr MacDonell who spoke at the weekend about his dead friend. `There are very few tears left. Neil was a legend and, it is sad that in his own country you don't seem to realise what a legend he was', Mr MacDonell said.
`He was probably the greatest war correspondent ever produced. People in my country are saying he was the Ernie Pyle of television.'
Mr MacDonell worked closely with Davis in Kampuchea in 1978 and was in daily contact with him until his death.
`He was a cool guy, and one you always wanted to work with', Mr MacDonell said.
Mr MacDonell said that Davis knew the fine line between danger and death, and time again had warned colleagues of impending danger.
Last Monday, that line blurred-and Neil Davis died.
Mr MacDonell said the coup that caused his death was foolish and petty. One happened every two or three years in Thailand, and they were often resolved without a shot being fired.
This time, Mr MacDonell said, someone in one of the rebel tanks wanted to show some strength by shooting at something, and the unarmed camera crew were the closest targets at the time.
`It was an act of murder', he said.

`He died instantaneously. Just before he died he said to his soundman `get down Bill'. He was worried about his soundman to the end. If anyone said Neil would have wanted to go this way, I would punch them in the mouth. He wasn't a hero, he was out there to stay alive.
Mr MacDonell said NBC would offer a yearly television scholarship at the University of Michigan, in honour of Davis.

The late Neil Davis, affectionately known as Tiny Davis, was born in Tasmania on 14 February 1934, son of the late Mr Geoffrey Davis, who was tragically killed in the horrific bushfires of 1967, and the late Marjorie Davis who unfortunately passed away when Neil was only 10 years of age. He attended the famous old Hobart High School, and many of his former colleagues living outside Tasmania would remember him most affectionately. He has one sister, Barbara, living in Hobart and a brother, Darryl. I extend to them I am sure on behalf of everybody in this Parliament our sincere condolences, and remind them that people outside Australia are now saying that he was a legend; he was the greatest.

The honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), a former Minister for Foreign Affairs, said to me just before I decided to pay this tribute to the late Neil Davis that he was a very fine Australian and a very fine professional journalist and cameraman.
