Most people would not realise that the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock)-and let us remember that Neil Davis was apolitical-was a close personal friend of Neil Davis. They wrote to each other and, of course, we all remember the great contribution that the honourable member for Kooyong made for Australia in the area of foreign affairs. They wrote and they talked about the problems in Vietnam and Kampuchea, and of course Neil Davis faithfully photographed and reported some of those horrific scenes, including the fall of the Presidential Palace in Saigon, over 10 years ago. If one has not been in those areas and does not know what they were really like it is hard to understand the anguish and the problems that were associated with those poor countries.

Neil flirted with death. He did a brave job, he knew what he was doing, but he did his job with a responsibility that could only be indicated by his bravery in reporting faithfully the problems in those countries. I am sure that, as the years go by, his work will be even more recognised than it is today. There was an editorial in the New York Times; there have been thousands and thousands of tributes. Apparently the funeral in Saigon was a massive one and it indicated just what the people of Saigon thought about this great man. To his family, rest assured that he will be remembered, and rest assured, Tasmania, that you have another great son. I am sure that as the years go by more recognition will be given to Neil Davis, cameraman and journalist extraordinaire.

The honourable member for Kooyong said to me that he was going to have a talk to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) about the possibility of awarding yearly some scholarship to an outstanding war correspondent to commemorate this great man. Members of the Parliament, I am sure, join with me, and I again remind his family that they are linked with greatness. I am sure that the ceremony on 27 September 1985 at 3 p.m. in the large St David's Cathedral in Hobart will be overflowing. The tributes have come from several sources, and I should remind people that they too are Tasmanians. Tim Bowden from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, who was going to write a book, is a Tasmanian and Phillip Koch, who attended the same school and is now Manager of the ABC here in Canberra, is also a Tasmanian who finished his education at the old Hobart High School. The boys and girls who attended the old Hobart High School will always remember with fondness that nice, young, tall blond boy by the name of Neil Davis who was always friendly, who was always decent and reliable. Incidentally, he was a very good Australian Rules footballer. He represented Tasmania in one of the early carnivals and played senior football for the Clarence club but because of his pursuit of finding out what was going on on the other side of the world of course he was lost to that sport. I have completed not really a grievance, though we do grieve that this good man was killed so tragically.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I speak today about my growing concern at the emergence of a new and dangerous force in Australian politics. Proponents of the new movement, whether they be called the dries, the radical right or neo-conservatives, are revolutionary in intent and arrogant in their beliefs. For the past few years we have seen the unfolding of a move by a small extreme group of radicals to take control and change direction of the Liberal Party of Australia. A few years earlier we saw the abortive attempt by the so-called uglies to do a similar thing in the Liberal Party with their own unique brand of emotive and irrational extremism. Of course the uglies failed in their ultimate objective. They softened up the Liberals for the so-called neo-conservatives. I say so-called because the use of the term neo-conservative is just one of the many deceptions they indulge in. They can claim to have classic values, but the classic period these values come from tends to predate democracy. In fact, I would suggest that neo-feudalists is a more appropriate term.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at a few of their articles of faith: Firstly, dispense with public ownership of the great public enterprises and instrumentalities of Australia, including Trans Australia Airlines, Telecom Australia, the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, The Australian National Line, Qantas Airways Ltd and so on; secondly, reverse the industrial relations framework in Australia to a frenzied free-for-all; thirdly, re-establish the financial exploitation of our young by the removal of minimum wages; and fourthly, participate fully in the Reagan star wars experiments. These four are just examples of their articles of faith; there are many more. The rhetoric behind these proposals would have us believe that there is evidence to prove that these actions would result in an improvement in the conditions and living standards of all Australians. But when the rhetoric is stripped away the sole basis for their claims is a flimsy ideology which is not only unproven but untried.

The Australian Constitution is a fragile and imperfect instrument, aimed at forming a single unified country out of six competing States. Our early parliamentarians, including the conservatives, understood and responded to that. Over time they established a network of national instrumentalities that spanned our continent, bringing not only a sense of equality for all Australians but also, perhaps more importantly, a sense of pride in being Australian. An Australian, whether he or she lives in Port Hedland, Perth, Alice Springs or Artarmon, pays the same price to post a letter to anywhere else in the country. They pay the same price for a local telephone call and the Commonwealth Bank offers the same services, often through the local post office.

All Australians are aware that they own Qantas, and they do so with a sense of pride. They are aware that all of our great instrumentalities are owned by them and are there to serve them. Convert those instrumentalities to private ownership and Australia will begin to fragment on vertical lines, with each community dependent upon the profitability of each service. Of course one must accept that each and every enterprise, whether public or private, will vary in its performance and efficiency from time to time. The mere ownership of an organisation does nothing, in itself, to ensure efficiency. Clearly an organisation can only be efficient and effective if its owners are committed to it, if its management is competent and if the members of its work force have a sense of pride in their organisation.

The Opposition constantly refers to the sale of British Telecom as justifying the sale of Australian Telecom. I make it abundantly clear that the two organisations are very different and cannot be compared in terms of population distribution, services, demands, et cetera. However, having said that, let us consider some of the implications of the famous British Telecom sale. British Telecom's value has increased by some 150 per cent since it was sold and its shareholding has dropped from 1.7 million shareholders to one million. In other words three-quarters of a million shareholders have cashed in their shares in British Telecom, more than doubling their money. The cost of selling British Telecom was in the order of #300m. That went to the stockbrokers, underwriters et cetera, so they also made a very healthy profit. Since the sale the cost to domestic subscribers has increased whilst the cost to business subscribers has reduced.

So who are the winners and losers? The winners include the stockbrokers, the advertising industry and all those who were involved in handling the sale. They included also those who were able to get in early at the subscription level and then cash in their shareholding not long afterwards, and of course the business community were winners as a result of reduced charges. The losers, of course, is the domestic subscribers, the normal English telephone user who is now paying a higher price for his domestic calls. Let us not try to pretend that it can be any different in Australia, because the shares will be sold only if they offer guaranteed profits for the purchaser, if they are a good investment. There will have to be a commission of some kind or other to the stockbrokers involved and the eventual large corporate multinational ownership will move the balance in relation to charges et cetera towards business subscribers.

Another question that the Australian public should think about is who will be advising the Government on the value of these public enterprises. Can they be sure that it will not be a group that includes the right wing trio of Morgan, Elliott and Valder, and would that trio have first go at the purchase? Which stockbroker would handle the Commission for the sales, and can we be sure that those same stockbrokers will not be members of the Liberal Party. Down the trail one can see these major enterprises, of which Australians were so proud, eventually being controlled by overseas owners. Qantas could become Saudi-Australian Airlines, TAA would make a natural Austro-Asian Airways, the Commonwealth Bank would have to become the Westcom Bank and its Chairman would have to be Mr Bob White.

Madam Deputy Speaker, the ideas the neo-feudalists present in industrial relations hark very much to their feudalistic basis. The voluntary agreements for employers and employees to go outside the industrial relations system is an open-ended invitation to mass exploitation. If employees of small organisations wish voluntarily to assist their employer there is no reason why they cannot do so now by contributing part of their income to purchasing shares in the company or extending loans to the employer. They can donate back part of their salary if that is what they want to do. There is no prohibition on that happening and we do not need a new industrial relations system for it to come about.

What the Leader of the Opposition and honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) is proposing is something quite different. His proposal consists of the employer suggesting that unless the employee takes a cut in wages he will either sack him or close the business down. Hence these forms of voluntary agreements will be achieved at the point of a gun. The only logical result of this system will be a reduction in wages for tens of thousands of Australians who will be given the choice of a lower wage or the dole. On the other hand, the stronger strategic unions will have no such difficulties. This kind of industrial relations philosophy will ensure the establishment of new records of industrial disputes and erratic production.

It is reasonable to ask how come this trend has developed in Australian politics. To explain it in depth would take more time than I have but one must look closely at the role of Mr Hugh Morgan, Mr John Elliott, Mr John Valder and others all of whom have one thing in common-an incredible faith in their own beliefs and an equal arrogance in their attitudes towards other Australians. The Liberal Party was weak and ineffectual following years of decay in the two main States and was ripe for a takeover, and that is what occurred. The takeover experts moved in. They, together with Bob White-who incidentally gave the famous instruction to dump the previous Leader of the Opposition-have staged a coup of monumental proportions. Not only have they obtained control of the Party machine thus allowing them to threaten pre-selections, but also they have been able to dictate the membership and policies of the shadow Ministry.

Australian politics has a new radical force whose objectives are to dismantle many of the organisations and instrumentalities that we have long cherished and appreciated and to eventually dismantle our whole industrial relations system. At the end of all this they suggest that somehow the majority of Australians will end up being better off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I wish to address a major grievance of the sugar industry concerning the attitude of the Hawke Labor Government. There has been a 100-day committee of inquiry into the sugar industry and its recommendations have been made. I think most honourable members of this House are aware of the major crisis that the industry currently faces. There are two major problems and two alternatives. The first and major problem concerns the means by which European Economic Community countries and some other countries, but basically the EEC, have produced a major sugar surplus. That has led to a depressed world price for sugar, perhaps the lowest world price in real terms since the end of the second world war. Recently I read in a magazine, the Economist of 10 August, an article entitled `Enslaved by subsidies'. One part of that article, which has the sub-heading `Taxing the rich to ruin the poor, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The European common market pays its farmers 20 cents-ie more than five times the current world market price to grow each lb of sugar. With such rewards, European farmers have increased annual production from 10.8m to 13.3m tonnes since 1977, when the EEC began to export more sugar than it imported. To avoid adding a sugar lump to its beef, butter and grain mountains, the EEC has `sold' 38m tonnes of sugar in the past eight years. The difference between the 20 cents a lb are paid for it and the 4 cents or so it fetches on the market is paid for by European taxpayers, who at present lose about $350 on each tonne unfortunately sold.

In the United States, sugar farmers are getting about 17 3/4 cents a lb, or about four-and-a-half times the world price, with similar results. American sugar imports have fallen from 6m tonnes a year a decade ago to less than 3m tonnes now. Though America is at least not dumping sugar on the world market, it foolishly keeps domestic prices very high. This has made every kind of alternative to sugar artificially competitive. In consequence, a sugar substitute made out of maize, and called high fructose corn syrup, has captured about half the import market. With ludicrous logic, this has now set grain growers from the cornbelt to lobbying alongside plantation owners from the deep south for continued high rigged prices for sugar.

All of this is an absolute disaster for Australia. We trade about 80 per cent or 2.5 million tonnes of our raw sugar on the world market. Subsequently we are at the mercy of the trade policies of Europe and the domestic pricing policies of the United States of America.

The second major problem facing the Australian producing industry is one of domestic costs. While one cannot be categorical about the efficiency of all producers and all millers, they all suffer from the consequences of the rising costs of fuel-particularly those producers who have large acreages and perhaps something less than the latest technology in farm equipment; and they all are affected by the high real interest rates that this Government's economic policies have created for Australia. These interest rates, which range from about 19.5 per cent and higher, are considerably higher than those payable by overseas producers. We also have a great difficulty arising from our inflation rate. The projected inflation rate for Australia is some 6 or 8 per cent; the inflation rate for the EEC is 5.8 and United States rates are also considerably lower.

Given that this is a deliberate policy of this Government to shore up our flagging dollar and given the low rate of interest of our competitors, the Federal Government has a real responsibility to help redress this particular position. Because it prevents individual producers faced with high interest rates benefiting from the collective advantages given by the devaluation these borrowers of funds at high interest rates are the real losers in the ailing sugar industry at present. The Savage Committee recommendations suggest as sistance through a price support scheme with a trigger point too low to assist either growers or millers and an interest rate scheme which is designed to assist in relation to only about $118 million of the some $300m of borrowings currently estimated to be outstanding in the sugar industry.

Within the recommendations was a crop of deregulation procedures. These were forced on the Committee by the Government which, I feel, is seeking to implement Bureau of Agricultural Economics recommendations through the Industries Assistance Commission report on the industry. The alternative is to leave the industry to its own devices without price assistance to offset the corrupt practices of the EEC. If this is the option adopted by this Government the industry is damned to bankruptcy. Without adequate price assistance and being forced to deregulate, the industry will be damned to an almost similar fate. It is a matter of being damned if left to itself or being damned if locked into the recommendations of this Government's committee of inquiry.

The answer is for the Commonwealth Government to provide adequate price support immediately, and to provide funds under the rural adjustment scheme for adjustment. In 1966-67 the Commonwealth provided loans for price support while the States financed the co-operative millers. The circumstances that exist in the sugar industry today are very similar to those that existed at that time and there is justification for a similar policy approach. Governments should join together in providing funds for the adjustment scheme, which is vital to the survival of the industry, and just as vital is the implementation of a price support scheme. This assistance must be made immediately available and the question of deregulating the sugar industry should be addressed by the industry itself.

I believe that the responsible voices of the sugar industry recognise that there is a need for them to implement a program of structural change which will allow them to be competitive in world market circumstances which seem unlikely to change in the immediate future. It is to be hoped that if Federal Cabinet is to consider the sugar industry at its meeting on Monday in Townsville it will recognise the realities, recognise that it is dealing with people, that there is a future for the sugar industry in Australia-albeit on a changed structural basis-and that there is an absolute necessity for the Government to take more seriously its obligations to advance the case of the sugar industry both in the EEC and also with the United States Government insofar as its domestic pricing policy for sugar is having an impact on the world consumption of sugar by distorting the market for sweeteners towards the consumption of artificial sweeteners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, may I take this opportunity, on behalf of the Government, to mark the passing of Neil Davis who died during the abortive coup in Bangkok. I would like to support what the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) said about Mr Davis. Neil Davis, as indicated by the honourable for Franklin a native of Hobart, will be remembered as one of the greatest war reporters of our time. His work covered almost without break the unhappy history of conflict in Indo-China from the early 1960s. There seems almost no time over the last 20 years that his name has not been in the forefront of those journalists living and working close to the scene. Neil Davis worked first and foremost as a cameraman. In that sense, his work is especially associated with recent developments in war reporting which, without supplanting traditional print journalist reports, have added critical dimensions of impact, insight and immediacy.

SPEECH.PARA: As many have noted, the Vietnam war was the first war fought on the screens of television. That aspect permitted many people to see, first hand, as it were, the agony and cruelty of the conflict. There is little doubt that television coverage was especially important in the development of critical attitudes to Western development in the war. However, as valuable as that work is, few people probably understand the special dangers of the camera crews whose work obliges them to expose themselves at moments of maximum danger. These crews, linked together by sound cables and stumbling under the weight of their equipment across the battlefield, were and are amongst the bravest of war reporters and, of them all, the bravery of Neil Davis was legendary.

There was another side to him which I think was magnificently portrayed in the 1979 Australian Film Commission documentary, Frontline, which brought his work to a wider audience. I feel that some Western journalists whose work takes them into the war zones develop a degree of insensitivity to unfamiliar Third World cultures. I suppose, in a way, this is an occupational hazard of sorts but Neil Davis, throughout his career, retained a remarkably humane outlook to life and a profound affection for the peoples amongst whom he lived and worked. His film footage is an irreplaceable part of the recent history of Indo-China. His career will be a continuing inspiration and example to all those journalists who follow him. The circumstances of his tragic death are, in microcosm, eloquent enough testimony to the value democratic people everywhere place in the work of the free Press.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I am happy to have given some of my time to the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) to pay tribute to Neil Davis and to also support the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) in his tribute. I commend both of them and I am sure that they have the support of members of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise today a couple of matters. One that I think is of concern to a lot of people in the Australian community concerns unsolicited telephone selling. In the last week constituents of mine in the electorate of Stirling, Mr and Mrs Gifford of 29 Payne Court in Karrinyup, who own a small plumbing business, were telephoned by a company called Australian Wide Review and asked if they would like to take up some space in a purported journal called the Australian Engineering Review. The Giffords cannot recall agreeing under any circumstance to place that advertising space. However, in subsequent days they received a letter confirming that they had placed the advertising space and invoicing them for $195. Being people who, like many small business people, are very busy-they are hard at work trying to earn a living-they were a bit alarmed at this, particularly at a bill of $195. Fortunately they contacted my office, and I pay tribute to my staff who picked it up very quickly and drew it to my attention. We have been able to rectify the situation. Australian Wide Review now says that the contract has been cancelled.

The important point is that this was a try-on involving a couple of innocent people who were trying to conduct a business properly and who received a letter alleging that they now owe a company money. I would like to draw to the attention of people listening and members of the House that this sort of activity is very wide spread. I am sure many people have received telephone calls soliciting business, and I would like to express the following thoughts: I draw the attention of the general community to the fact that people engaged in these schemes are engaged in nothing other than fraudulent and illegal behaviour because they are issuing invoices against goods or services that have never been provided. Business people should be very much aware that that can happen. I hope that the 400-odd members of the Osmond Park-Balcatta Business Association in my electorate are all aware that they can be prey to such practices.

The problem when a business does not have an authorised advertising agency is that there is a tendency for it to not always be aware of what advertising expenditure it is undertaking, whereas if it is being funnelled through an agency there is an extra guarantee. That is an important issue that we ought to be addressing.

A couple of things arise from that. I would be keen to see the Trade Practices Act when it is brought forward in a revised form increase penalties and toughen up these kinds of breaches because they are, literally, rip-offs. There is no doubt about it and I am sure members of this House have heard of them occurring in their own electorates. These schemes are ripping off people in the Australian community who quite innocently are being caught by these purported journals. Interestingly, when we checked with the circulation of Australian Engineering Review we found that it circulates to about 35 people. All they do is sent it to advertising agencies. It is not a journal-unlike the Bulletin, or whatever-that circulates widely through the community. It is just a rip-off.

The other point I would like to make too, Mr Deputy Speaker, is that I believe that we, as a community, must now start to look seriously at prohibiting telephone selling. It would be impossible to stop people picking up telephones and seeking to sell things but I believe it would be quite possible, within the context of the Companies Act in particular and the Trade Practices Act as well, to suggest that any purported contract entered into in such a way would in fact be null and void; that if a contract is not entered into in the presence of the parties to that contract, that contract would have no validity.

That is the sort of situation we are going to have to face because clearly an increasing number of these crooks are seeking to take advantage of good people who are going about their normal business. In this case we have got the clear evidence and in this case fortunately Mr Gifford and Mrs Gifford have no particular debt. But I can imagine many people who perhaps might be less aware, who are very busy and who might just get caught out. It is a matter that we are going to have to take up; it is a serious matter and I would hope that we, as a community, can begin to address it urgently.

The second matter that concerns me is the issue that has developed in the suburb of Scarborough in my electorate. In the last few days the former head of the Metropolitan Region Planning Authority, Mr Wilkins, has basically said that he is in favour of high rise buildings in Scarborough and, in fact, he favours more high rise buildings in Scarborough. He points out that people in Scarborough are getting a better result with the high rise construction of the Bond Corporation. He also adds that neither the Government nor the Stirling City Council should kow-tow to suburban terrorism. I resent strongly Mr Wilkins implying that people in Scarborough are guilty of suburban terrorism. These are ordinary people in Scarborough who were very annoyed that Mr Wilkins, when he was Chairman of the MRPA, approved a building which has turned out to be both an eyesore and a public nuisance.

The public nuisance aspect is quite significant. Mr Wilkins has decried allegations that television reception was being interfered with. I would ask Mr Wilkins to come to my office in Karrinyup and I will show him the letters of some 200 people who have written to me complaining about television interference in their own house. In many cases these people are elderly or invalids and watching television is one of their major forms of recreation. Their television has been completely disrupted by what, in my view, was a negligent decision by the MRPA. I say negligent because it was clearly known that such buildings cause television interference. It was clearly recognised in relation to the proximity of the Merlin Hotel project to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation station on Riverside Drive in Perth, yet the MRPA went ahead and approved the building. So they and the city of Stirling, in my view, have engaged in planning which is negligent to say the least.

I might also add that we are having very good co-operation from officials of the Bond corporation including Bruce Buckley, who is in charge of the area. We are not having any obstruction at all from them; the obstruction has come from the city of Stirling and the former chairman of the MRPA. It is up to the new Chairman of the MRPA, Mr Bill McKenzie, who is doing an excellent job, to try to restore public faith and acceptance in the MRPA because it was seen as nothing but a rubber stamp for developers.

I conclude by saying that these comments of Mr Wilkins only further shore up the belief that in fact his only interests are those of the developers. They are certainly not of the people of Scarborough. If he comes into Scarborough and talks with some of the ordinary people there he would recognise that the Authority's decision was gross, it was wrong and it was negligent. I believe that members of the public in Scarborough are paying the price for what was really a very bad decision.

I make one other point relating to the MRPA. There is a proposal to extend Marmion Avenue into Scarborough; in other words to increase substantially the traffic volume in Scarborough. There has been a great deal of debate about it and it is still a matter that is up for decision by the State Government but there has also been a great deal of personal attack. It is interesting that the proponents of the road extension have chosen to attack the Scarborough Ratepayers Association and myself on the grounds that we have a vested interest. We have no vested interests; what we do have is an interest in preserving Scarborough and preserving its integrity as a suburb. I also have to point out that many people who are proponents of the road in fact live in the area of the West Coast Highway and their circumstances would be advantaged by such extension.

My own position would be advantaged if the road were built, so one has to ask why would I oppose it. The grounds are clear-they are economic grounds, environmental grounds and the grounds of having concern for the suburb of Scarborough. With both high rise buildings and this proposal to extend Marmion Avenue the problems we face is that no one has had a good look at what is best for Scarborough. It is time that we did. It is an important area. Millions of people will be coming to Western Australia and many thousands to Scarborough as a result of tourism developments over the next couple of years. Very clearly it is time that we asked what is in the best interests of the people of Scarborough; how can we ensure that for a change their interests are protected. Their interests will be protected not by willy-nilly putting up high rise buildings on the beach, not by willy-nilly putting in roads which would dump more traffic into their suburbs, but by having a comprehensive plan to look at their interests for a change.

Mr Deputy Speaker, these are two issues which I believe are of great concern to constituents of mine. The first concerns unsolicited telephone selling-it is wrong and should be prohibited by the operation of the Companies Act and the Trade Practices Act-and the second concerns recent comment in relation to planning in Scarborough which, in my view, leaves the people in Scarborough quite disadvantaged. It is important that some of us stand up for Scarborough. I believe that we can do a lot to preserve their interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, there is a certain justification for adopting a policy of looking forwards rather than backwards. Those who constantly refer to the good old days leave themselves open to legitimate challenge on the basis that we are inclined to remember the best and forget the worst when recalling past experiences. However, it is valid to use history as a guide and teacher, to learn from previous success. The present generation does not have a monopoly on all the good ideas and they are not less prone to errors in judgment than their predecessors. To introduce and implement innovative and positive reforms of benefit to society generally is one thing, but to initiate change for the sake of change is quite a different kettle of fish. We are witnessing changes within this country and our community which are indefensible in terms of what is fair and best for Australia and Australians now and in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Not so long ago, certainly within the recall of most members of this Parliament, this country enjoyed a spirit of patriotism, adventure and advancement which was developed and maintained by an unashamed sense of loyalty and duty to and love of country, and a common bond which united Australians in the desire to be of service to their nation and each other. We were committed to establishing and maintaining an Australian democracy with just, reasonable and responsible laws-freedom of speech, religion and association and the freedom of opportunity for citizens to choose their own way of living and life subject to the rights of others. We accepted the responsibility and necessity of protecting people against exploitation, of caring for those who could not, for whatever reason, care adequately for themselves. We encouraged individual initiative and enterprise as the means by which to achieve real progress and stability. We were dedicated to ensuring at all costs the security of our country and the traditions and values which are the cornerstone of a decent and moral society.

We were truly a lucky country. We knew it and we believed it. We enjoyed the benefits of our faith in ourselves and Australia and our confidence in our abilities to overcome any difficulty or challenge. Perhaps we became overconfident and too complacent. For some reason, perhaps because we had not been required for some years to put our beliefs, courage and determination to the test, perhaps because we simply became too involved with our own personal needs and advancement to bother about what was happening around us-the famous `I'm all right Jack' syndrome-as a nation and as a community we started to lose our way. The situation deteriorated so rapidly that eventually when someone told us that in fact we were an unlucky country some, unfortunately, started to believe it and react accordingly.

There developed within our society a new breed of Australians who preferred to criticise and condemn rather than to praise and encourage, who sought out and publicised the negatives while ignoring the positives, who endeavoured to impose the will of a disgruntled and disillusioned few without regard for the rights of the vast majority of decent law abiding citizens. Increasingly sectional interests and vocal minorities were allowed to become too influential and powerful. They pursued their objectives with irrational, ill-founded arguments and misguided zeal-even, at times, with violence.

The politics of envy replaced the politics of reasoned responsibility. The traditional standards and institutions which had served this country so well for so long were sacrificed on the altar of so-called social progress and justices. Governments kowtowed to the pressures exerted by these new order zealots and reacted by endeavouring to shut them up by paying them off with millions of dollars of taxpayers' money collected in spiralling amounts from those who were often quite wrongly classified as the haves and distributed it to those who were often quite wrongly regarded as the have nots. The cry `All aboard the Government gravy train' was heard so often that it became boring. Unfortunately, it was seldom ignored by the powers that be.

Over the past three years the cry has become louder and even more frequent and the Government has become more unjustifiably generous in its response. Too much is being given away too easily. The long-suffering taxpayer is being asked to fund grandiose schemes and projects of little relevance or consequence for the welfare and well-being of the vast majority of Australians. These government initiated and/or approved and/or tolerated spending sprees are indicative of a disturbing trend towards government acceptance if not government advocacy of the concept of the public funding known as the Columbus doctrine. When Columbus set out he did not know where he was going, when he got there he did not know where he was and when he returned he did not know where he had been-but it really did not matter because he did it all on government money.

The obvious flaw in this doctrine is that there is no such thing as government money per se. Government money is money provided by others for governments to use. Governments are not productive; they are spenders rather than earners. Their income is derived in a somewhat parasitic manner by compulsorily acquiring a portion-often an unjustifiably large portion-of the hard-earned income of the productive sector of the economy. The community has every right to expect the Government to administer these funds in a responsible and efficient manner so that unnecessary duplication within the various levels of government will be avoided, expenditure will be confined to areas that are appropriately and rightfully government responsibilities, benefits will be directed to people who are really in need, and grants and other forms of government aid and assistance will be allocated in a fair, equitable, practical and beneficial manner.

But this is not the case. Consider the current trend to replace voluntary aid groups and organisations and the dedicated and competent volunteers, who provide a wide range of welfare and support services, with government funded agencies and highly paid administrators who, in some instances, provide greatly decreased assistance at greatly increased cost. Volunteers are becoming a disillusioned and dying race for want of adequate government encouragement and support yet they have always provided, and against enormous odds are endeavouring to continue to provide, a maximum contribution to the well-being of our community at a minimum cost to the public purse.

There is something very wrong when voluntary aid agencies are being forced to close their doors for want of a few dollars-some small and reasonable financial gesture from the Government to indicate that their efforts are needed and appreciated-while at the same time one man is presented with half a million dollars of taxpayer's money as he deserts the sinking ship known as the Australian Bicentennial Authority. I do not believe that the majority of Australians want to see our heritage and our traditional standards swept away in a backwash of misguided so-called social reform. We must be vigilant to protect what must be preserved while at the same time recognising those things which should be changed.

But this latter category does not include those ideals and institutions which are currently gravely threatened with replacement by less worthy substitutes-our flag, our constitutional monarchy, the role and relevance of our traditional family unit which must remain if we are to maintain a secure and stable society, and even our faith in and fear of God. All these things are being wrongly called into question and are endangered by those who seek to impose socialist concepts and policies in place of the hard won and irreplaceable freedoms, liberties and opportunities which are the basis of democracy. For the good of Australia we must now be prepared to say enough. As those who are entrusted with the enormous responsibility of safeguarding and guiding this nation through the uncertainties of the remainder of this century and into the challenges of the next, we must put aside any petty or preconceived jealousies, prejudices, bias or bitterness, forget favours owed or promised and get on with the enormous and exciting task which confronts us with tolerance, honesty and goodwill. The progress and prosperity of Australia and her citizens must be our first and only consideration.

As James Truman Clarke once observed, a politician thinks of the next election; a statesman of the next generation. Unfortunately for Australia and Australians, particularly young Australians, there are far too many politicians and far too few statesmen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I want to continue the theme of the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) and discuss youth. I wish to raise the matter of youth wages and their relationship to the levels of youth unemployment. Statements by Opposition members clearly indicate that as part of their policy of deregulation of the labour market the first victims of their drive to cut wages are to be Australia's youth. Both the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) are on record as saying that youth wages must be reduced before there can be any increase in youth employment. The Leader of the Opposition recently told the Victorian Young Liberal Movement that this policy of slashing youth wages was the only way to go and that this `may be heresy, it may be sound; it may sound troglodytan and we will be accused of returning to the sweatshops of the industrial revolution'.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate gives me the opportunity to test whether the Leader of the Opposition and his mimic, the honourable member for Tangney, are guilty of the charges they suggest will be raised against them.

Under this Government there has been a gradual fall in the level of teenage unemployment since it peaked, under Liberal Party policies, at over 28 per cent. In 2 1/2 years junior employment has risen by over 6.5 percentage points, representing a major reversal of the long term decline in junior employment that has persisted for nearly 20 years. Why was it that under the present Opposition Australia's youth were the greatest losers in our growing level of unemployment while they have been the major winners under this Government's policies? An examination of youth unemployment over the last 20 years provides the clue. We can see that there is a reasonably constant ratio between the rate of youth unemployment and the rate of unemployment generally for the entire work force. Between the 20 years 1966 to 1985 that ratio stood around 2.3 to 3; so there was a 2 per cent increase in general unemployment, youth unemployment rose 4.6 to 6 per cent and the reverse occurred when unemployment dropped.

This constant ratio shows that the most promising solution to the problem of youth unemployment lies in the area of macro-economic policy and demand management rather than any changes in wage relativities. Broadly speaking, a fall in the overall level of unemployment because of successful expansionary government economic policies will produce the equivalent of between a 2.3 and threefold effect on the rate of youth unemployment. The figures I gave earlier for the last 2 1/2 years confirms that conclusion.

Let me return to the Opposition's claim that the big rise in youth unemployment is due to junior wages being too high. To quote the honourable member for Tangney again, he said in the Canberra Times of 18 March this year:

If you look over the last decade you will see that as wage relativities between young people and adults in the work force have been compressed so almost hand in hand have we seen a rise in youth unemployment.

In the Opposition's mad rush to prove the basis of its dry labour market economics it has deliberately tried to mislead the public as to the reason for the changes in the levels of youth unemployment. The Opposition hoped that the community would actually believe that wage rates were the sole cause of unemployment and not its disastrous economic policies, which saw double digit unemployment and double digit inflation occur simultaneously-the only time in Australia's history.

Evidence to the contrary cited by the bureau of Labour Market Research suggests that while there was some compression of youth-adult relativities between 1972 and 1974, that compression was not spectacular, nor was it fully sustained, and no similar compression occurred between 1981 and 1983 when the rate of youth unemployment rose by 64 per cent under Fraser-Howard policies. Obviously the question of youth relativities is of peripheral importance.

Honourable members will be aware of a recent State award in Western Australia providing for lower youth wages through agreement provided extra jobs are created. The Chairman of McDonalds Family Restaurants, Mr Peter Ritchie, claimed that another 20 young people would be hired in western Australia under the State Industrial Commission's new ruling and a further 1,000 young people nationally if wages were more flexible. It is well known by teenagers that a job at McDonalds only lasts until they turn 18, then they are put off. It should be no surprise to honourable members to learn that 85 per cent of McDonald's 12,000 staff are under 18. If lower wages were introduced and a few jobs created by deregulation the way would be open to replace departing staff with new staff at the lower wages. This would be sheer exploitation and the charge of returning to the sweatshop, put forward by the leader of the Opposition, would surely stick. I ask the youth of Australia and this Parliament to compare the economics of this baccalaureate of hamburgology with the conclusions drawn by the reputable Bureau of Labour Market Research.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with Standing Order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to raise a matter of parliamentary privilege. You will recall earlier this week having canvassed the failure of the delivery of Hansard because of difficulties in the Government Printing Office. I understand the reason for the delay today is that the Government has instructed the Government Printer to give priority to the printing of tax documents rather than to Hansard. In my view the availability of Hansard is an absolute prerequisite for the proper functioning of this place. I do not believe that the Parliament should be required to accept a delay in the availability of that document for the sake of the Government's trying to get together whatever tax package it will finally present to us. While I understand that the nature of this matter of parliamentary privilege is unusual, I see it as absolutely essential that Hansard be printed. I see no basis on which this Government can have its requirements for the publication of a tax statement and associated documents take precedence over the printing of Hansard.

—I remind the right honourable member that a breach of privilege involves a breach of one of the particular and special rights or immunities enjoyed by the House, its committees or its members. A contempt may be defined as an act or omission which obstructs or impedes either House, its committees members or officers in the discharge of their duties or which has a tendency to do so. As I understand the comments of the right honourable member, they do not contain grounds on which I could consider, for the purposes of standing order 96, that a prima facie case has been made out. The right honourable member has not presented any evidence of attempts to influence or obstruct any honourable member in the course of his duties as a member.
—The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) is in Melbourne today. In his absence he will be very capably deputised for by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy).

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN COUNCIL OF TRADE UNIONS: PROPOSED INDUSTRIAL CAMPAIGN

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to his statement yesterday, which I commend, concerning the decision of the Australian Council of Trade Unions to mount an industrial campaign in retaliation for the fines imposed on the Australian Meat Industry Employees Union. The Minister will recall that he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: I shall certainly be talking to the ACTU about it and seeking to persuade the ACTU and the unions that might be involved in any such campaign not to take part in such a course.

Because it would be counter-productive. Has the Minister had discussions or any contact on this matter with the ACTU and with what result? If not, in view of the importance of the matter, will he tell us when he proposes to see, or talk to, the ACTU?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will attempt to arrange those discussions as soon as possible. It has not been practicable to do that since I made the statement yesterday.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BICENTENNIAL AUTHORITY: DR D. P. ARMSTRONG

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Prime Minister advise the House of the full circumstances of the payment to Dr Armstrong which the Opposition has sought to exploit in an attempt to destroy the bipartisanship which should exist on the question of the 1988 bicentennial celebrations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter of importance; I hope that my answer can be heard in silence. When this Government came to office it inherited the legislative structure of the Australian Bicentennial Authority from the previous Government. It was staffed by people in whose appointment it had no input. One of the very first decisions I made as Prime Minister was that while I had grave reservations about the structure of the ABA and its lack of accountability to both the Government and the Parliament, we as a government would do nothing to put at risk celebrations in 1988 or the long preparation for them. I decided that attempts to change the Authority risked creating a political battlefield around a body that ought to be exempt from the normal partisan struggles that would certainly have flowed from such structural changes. Consequently, no changes were made. Most of the personnel of the ABA who are so actively the centre of both headlines and discussions in this place today were there when we came to government.

ANSWER.PARA: In recent times the very harmony and unity that we sought to preserve around the Bicentennial Authority is being threatened by a growing storm of criticism and unease. In that context, I had several discussions with the Chairman of the Authority, Mr Reid, and on two occasions I had discussions with his officers as well. I asked Mr Reid to see me on 15 August in an attempt to find some solutions to the problems that were starting to beset the ABA. Among the matters I raised at that meeting, I told him that I had received a number of expressions of concern regarding the performance of the Chief Executive of the ABA and that there had been a unanimity of view regarding his inadequacy in that position-as it had been put to me. I told Mr Reid that I was concerned that the prospects for success of the bicentennial celebrations were likely to be substantially compromised if Dr Armstrong remained as Chief Executive. Mr Reid said that he would take on board my concerns and come back to me.

On 19 August, after writing to me on the subject, Mr Reid phoned and said that he had given a lot of thought to my concerns, that he had spoken with Dr Armstrong and that as a result it had been decided that the ABA would be best served if Dr Armstrong were to end his service in it. Mr Reid told me that Dr Armstrong still had six years of his contract to run and that a very substantial settlement would have to be negotiated.

I took the view that the highest priority had to be given to the protection of the ABA, to the morale of the people who would be continuing to plan for 1988, to the continuing unity and purpose towards the celebrations and to ensuring that whatever changes were necessary to better equip the ABA to fulfil its functions were carried out with the least possible disruption and acrimony.

I told Mr Reid that the Government had no desire to be harsh or punitive towards Dr Armstrong and that if it were necessary for him to err on the side of generosity in the course of negotiating a harmonious and non-disruptive settlement, I thought that appropriate. Mr Reid told me that in view of Dr Armstrong's salary, long service leave, superannuation and other entitlements, the settlement figure would total more than $400,000. He was also adamant that he and he alone has the right and the obligation to negotiate the settlement with Dr Armstrong and I left the matter with him on that basis. Mr Reid further told me that discussions would take place between Dr Armstrong's solicitors and the Authority's solicitors. That was, of course, consistent with article 41 of the Articles and memorandum of association.

On 28 August Mr Reid wrote to me and sought from me approval for the payment to Dr Armstrong in terms of the settlement he had negotiated with him. I shall seek leave to table that letter at the end of my answer. While the total amount contained in it is consistent with the amount Mr Reid had first mentioned to me, the method of arriving at it was vastly different from the formula, based primarily on six years of salary, that had first been outlined to me by Mr Reid. A large part of the settlement figure was made up of an item of $240,000:

To refrain from becoming involved with the promotion and celebration associated with the Bicentenary in 1988 including acting as a consultant or discussing confidential matters relating to his employment with the authority.

On 30 August, after having received from my Department advice on the legal position with regard to the authorisation of the settlement, I wrote to Mr Reid and told him that authority to settle any such payment was vested to himself as Chairman of the trustees, provided such payment was made within the general financial allowances for the Authority as agreed to by the Minister. He had this authority under sections 11 and 12 of the Australian Bicentennial Authority Act and article 41, to which I have referred. I shall seek leave to table that letter at the end of this answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister does not need leave to do so.

—I was somewhat surprised by the change in the composition of the total amount. I took no action about it at that stage. I readily concede to the House today that perhaps I would have been wiser if, whether or not I had authority, I had questioned Mr Reid about it at that point. However, on 10 September I spoke again to Mr Reid. I raised with him my puzzlement at why the basis for the settlement had been altered. Mr Reid told me that the total figure was exactly that which would have been arrived at by the method that he had originally discussed with me.
—That was 10 September?

—Yes. However, the composition had been arrived at after negotiations between the Authority's solicitors and Dr Armstrong's solicitors to provide him with the best tax arrangements. He said that the Authority's solicitors had stated that the agreement reached was within normal commercial practice. I told Mr Reid that I would be most concerned if a settlement had been negotiated in such a way as to provide a contrived scheme to minimise Dr Armstrong's tax. Mr Reid told me that no discussion had taken place with him to that effect. I asked him to find out whether any such discussions had taken place with any other person and to come back to me with such information. That he undertook to do. When he had not provided me with that information by the time I returned from my short visit to Papua New Guinea on 17 September, I wrote to Mr Reid seeking from him an assurance that Dr Armstrong's settlement was not a device to minimise his tax. At this point I still have not received a reply from Mr Reid who is overseas, but I have been informed that he will reply early next week. Again I will seek leave to table a copy of my letter to Mr Reid at the end of this answer.

ANSWER.PARA: These are the facts; the details of precisely what has happened as far as the Government is concerned with the departure of Dr Armstrong and the settlement that was paid to him by the ABA. Further, I add that on 10 September I asked Mr Reid whether he would be prepared to have a discussion with the Leader of the Opposition to acquaint him with all the facts of the matter. Mr Reid said that he would be happy to do so. I spoke to the Leader of the Opposition who also said he would wish such a discussion to take place. I asked Mr Reid to facilitate such a discussion and told him that I would want it on the basis that nothing was to be held back and that the Leader of the Opposition should be made privy to all the facts. I did that because I believed that it was vitally important that the ABA not become a political football and that for once in our lives we as a nation might be able to do something without the bickering and squabbling that so often seems to disrupt our economic and social life.

I had hoped to have been able to take the steps to make the Bicentennial Authority a stronger and more vibrant body better able to carry out the tasks that all Australians expect of it with vigor, enthusiasm and efficiency. It has become clear in past days that such achievement is not possible, that the Opposition is determined to snipe away at the Government with no care for the damage that it may now have caused to the Authority or the celebrations. Having put the whole story on the table I put to the Opposition that the Authority was its creation while in government. The Chairman is its appointee and Dr Armstrong was appointed under its auspices. Now is the time for the Opposition to say whether it has lost confidence in Mr Reid.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister can just table the letters. There is no need for leave.

—I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. I draw your attention to the fact that the answer to that question took almost 15 minutes. You would be aware of precedent in this place. I ask that the Prime Minister be prepared, therefore, to extend Question Time while he is trying to get a bipartisan situation.
—Order! The honourable member's point of order does not come as a point of order; It comes as a request.

—Having just heard the Prime Minister condemn himself from his own mouth, I ask him two very simple questions. On the basis of the statement he has just made and on the answers he gave in the last two days, will he explain to the House how he reconciles the information that he has now given us with his Press release of 11 September 1985 when he said that the terms of settlement-I quote the words for the benefit of the House yet again-were `entirely a matter between the Chairman and Dr Armstrong'? Secondly, can he add some light to the question of why his first meeting with Mr Reid on this subject-the future of Dr Armstrong-was held at his request on 15 August, yet he wrote to Mr Reid on only 17 September?

—In the very complete answer that I have given, I covered all the facts relevant to this issue. It should be apparent to the Opposition that the Press statement to which I have referred is a totally accurate statement of the position. The negotiations were, properly at the insistence of Mr Reid, a matter between Mr Reid and Dr Armstrong. Of course, it is true, as I made clear, that I had discussed this matter with Mr Reid beforehand. This is quite clear and apparent, but the actual negotiations were a matter between Mr Reid and Dr Armstrong. Indeed, in the sequence of events after I had spoken to Mr Reid on the date to which I have alluded, Mr Reid indicated that he would go away and think about what I had put to him. He thought about my view of the need for the termination of the services of Dr Armstrong. He then said that he had come to that view and insisted-as he properly had the right to insist under the law-that negotiation of the matter should be between Dr Armstrong and him. That was his proper insistence, proper in the sense that under the law passed by the previous Government that was as it had to be. So the statement that I made that the negotiations were between Mr Reid and Dr Armstrong was not only the fact, but the fact that it had to be under the legislation.

—Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of concerns in Tasmania about Japanese sensitivities concerning the time being taken to decide on export licences for wood chips from Tasmania? When will the Government make a decision? Will that timing cause problems for the licences? What criteria will be used in reaching a decision on the conditions to apply to such licences?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the concerns being expressed about wood chipping. There has been a very vigorous write-in campaign, putting forward both sides of the argument, to my colleague, the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, and me. Of course, wood chipping is a very complex and important matter.

ANSWER.PARA: I have had various discussions in Canberra and I have visited Tasmania three times. I had discussions with Japanese importers in Tokyo in June this year and also in April 1984. I have listened to the views of environmentalists, wood chip employers, wood chip employees and Japanese importers. In all instances I have explained to these groups the processes involved in arriving at a final decision.

The major input into the decision-making process is an extensive environmental impact statement which has now been something like two years in preparation. It is a very extensive statement. It is really an environmental impact statement for a whole State. The final EIS should be handed to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment soon and he will then consider it and advise me accordingly.

It is the proponents who at this stage are delaying presentation of the EIS to the Government, but they have had to take on board something like 450 submissions during the public comment stage since the draft EIS was available. The Government, in coming to its decision, must take into account three other major issues-the economic impact, the impact on the country's national estate and the social impact, especially on employment.

In a recent letter to the honourable member for Lyons, the Prime Minister indicated that in taking into account these processes, the Government would be likely to reach a decision on the licences before the end of this year. When that information was provided to the honourable member it was thought, of course, that the Government was going to receive the EIS quite a bit sooner.

Our customers have informed me that they are very much aware of our procedures, including the way in which environmental legislation is applied to wood chips, and that they have to deal with the same issues themselves in Japan. They have not indicated concern about the timing of the decision and it must be remembered that the licences are not due for renewal until 1988. A decision by the end of this year will give adequate lead time.

I have previously stated my view that there should be a continuation of wood chip licences beyond 1988. This is not to prejudge any conditions that may be attached to the licences, nor to suggest that the wood chip industry will have carte blanche to move into environmentally sensitive areas or areas of particular importance to the national estate.

Wood chipping is an important issue. The Government will make a decision after and only after all considerations have been taken into account. The honourable member for Bendigo, who takes a close interest in these matters, can rest assured that in issuing the licences that he has referred to and, indeed, in the case of other licences in the future, these important matters and the full processes will be given proper consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Prime Minister. In view of the lengthy answer that the Prime Minister gave about the Australian Bicentennial Authority, which disclosed quite clearly that Dr Armstrong's position was central to the concern he discussed with Mr Reid about the ABA, why did the honourable gentleman omit any reference to Dr Armstrong in the explanatory statement he gave on 11 September regarding that discussion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I go to the point that I made at the outset of the answer I gave at the beginning of today's Question Time. From the time we came to government, we have been concerned to try to conduct our relations with the ABA in a way which would ensure the least amount of disputation and the greatest degree of harmony. I saw no purpose in trying to have in the public arena difficulties in regard to Dr Armstrong.

ANSWER.PARA: It was properly said by the Chairman of the Authority in the discussions that I had with him that this was a matter he wanted to handle in a way in which he believed, if handled properly by him, as was required by law, would achieve an outcome in which there would be no repercussions as far as Dr Armstrong was concerned. That seemed to me to be an eminently proper and desirable course of action.

I have conducted myself in relation to this matter in a way that is consistent with that very proper expression of view by the Chairman of the Authority. On behalf of the Government, at this stage I have conducted our response to these matters in a way which I hope will still mean that that view, which was expressed and which was common to Mr Reid and me as to the desirability of maintaining an exposure of the problems in regard to Dr Armstrong will be maintained, to the most limited extent.

I add to that what I have said in my first answer. Once, on a concentration on this matter, it became apparent to me that there were questions that needed to be asked about the composition of the payment, then of course it has not been possible to adhere to that desire to keep the question of Dr Armstrong's termination at a minimal level of publicity, something which was obviously regarded as desirable in everyone's interest. We were not going to allow that proper concern to stand in the way of a proper question that needed to be put when the composition of the payment became apparent.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. What is the Government's immigration policy response to the worsening situation in South Africa with the increasing unrest and government repression affecting all sections of the South African community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of background to this matter, 1,700 people-white, black and coloured-arrived as immigrants from South Africa in 1984-85. Whether more people will arrive this year depends on who qualifies under our global non-discriminatory rules. It is now too early to tell, but the House may be interested to know that inquiries in our offices in Pretoria and Cape Town have doubled in the first half of 1985 compared with the first half of 1984. Indeed, there was a big increase in July 1985, when eight times the number of people were in touch with our office compared with July 1984.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, inquiries do not necessarily mean that those inquiring will come under our global rules and qualify to come to this country. Frankly, I do not expect any dramatic increase. If I can remind the House of those global rules, they are based on family reunions, on our skilled labour requirements and on business migration. When it comes to refugees and the special humantarian program, only nine people came here from South Africa in 1984-85 as refugees.
The only exceptions to our global rules are New Zealand, where we have a common labour market, and also the Lebanon, where temporarily we are discriminating in its favour because of its troubles.

The Government has no plans to make any exception for South Africa. Any such move would also apply to Sri Lanka or any other sadly disrupted place. Re-settlement in Australia is not a solution to all of the trouble spots of this world, whether it be Sri Lanka, South Africa or anywhere else.

I wish to say a little more about those global rules as they apply to South Africa because although a number of members in this House at the moment are interested in other things, a lot of people in Australia are interested in the future of settlement from South Africa. The global rules are such that no account is taken of a person's race, colour or ethnic origin. The predominant number of those applying in Pretoria are white, but 70 per cent of those applying in Cape Town, for instance, are non-whites, mainly coloured people. Another point is that anecdotal evidence shows us that those coming here are predominantly opponents of apartheid.

Lastly, I would like to say that although an immigrant's politics is not known, there are selections where we take note of whom we are bringing here and our selection processes bar anybody with a terrorist background and also people who are known racists and who would consequently not settle well in this multiracial, multicultural society of ours.

This Government's objective in relation to South Africa remains peaceful change. We have sought to play our part to change the hearts and minds of South Africans to bring about peaceful change through our sports contact policy and through our sanctions. Just as we would not be allowing racists here under our settlement policies, at the same time we hope we will not attract too many sensible South Africans who have a capacity to lead South Africa to that peaceful change.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask-
—Can we hear about-
—Order! One of the Leader of the Opposition's colleagues is interrupting him.
—I am used to that Mr Speaker; we are old friends.
—I have noted.

—I ask the Prime Minister a question. Will the honourable gentleman tell the House whether he had in his mind concern about the composition of the sum to be paid to Dr Armstrong when he first spoke to me about this matter?

—Yes indeed; when I spoke to the Leader of the Opposition in my office, I certainly had a question about the composition of the sum and it was a matter that was discussed with the Leader of the Opposition.

—I ask the Minister for Aviation whether his attention has been drawn to an article in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald which suggests that the Department of Aviation has now completed its inquiries into allegations that the Premier of Queensland and his chief pilot, Ms Beryl Young, breached air safety regulations and claims that key witnesses to the investigation have been intimidated by the Premier. I ask whether the Minister has the results of the Department's inquiries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. There has been a number of Press reports which allege that the Queensland Premier had flown the Queensland Government's Super King aircraft at various times during 1983 and 1984 although his pilot's licence was not endorsed for that aircraft. It was alleged also that Ms Young, as pilot and commander of the aircraft, had permitted Sir Joh to fly the aircraft even though his licence was not appropriately endorsed. As a result of this media interest-

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. As I understand it, this matter is presently before the Federal Court of Australia. It is up for litigation. It is something that should not be discussed in this Parliament.
—Is it a matter that is before the court?
—No.
—Order! It is not possible for the Chair to be conscious of the process of legal cases. The Minister assures me that it is not before the court and I have to accept his assurance.

—As a result of this media interest, six journalists were interviewed but, unfortunately, only one formal statement was obtained. Two journalists preferred not to make statements while three journalists had not seen the Premier at the controls of the aircraft. The Australian Federation of Air Pilots claimed that a former pilot with the Queensland Government air wing had conclusive evidence in this matter, but he declined to provide information, apparently fearing retaliatory legal action by the Premier. All the evidence gathered was passed to the Australian Government Solicitor and the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions in Brisbane for assessment.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government Solicitor has formally advised the Regional Director of my Department in Queensland that there is insufficient evidence to support licence suspension or cancellation action under the Air Navigation Regulations. The Director of Public Prosecutions has formally advised that there is no case against the Premier, as each of the alleged breaches being more than 12 months old, is statute barred. Therefore, on the advice of the Australian Government Solicitor, no action has been taken under the Air Navigation Regulations regarding the licence of either the Premier or Beryl Young. Beryl Young has stated categorically that at all times she was in control of the aircraft and that the Premier occupies the co-pilot's seat but for public relations reasons appears to be in control. That is a bit like the current situation in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bit like the Government up there.

—It is a bit like the Government up there. The Premier of Queensland has clearly used the media to convey the impression that he is an intrepid pilot who flies the Queensland Government's Super King aircraft, an aircraft which he is not qualified to fly. The Premier in the past has been most voluble about his flying prowess, but now he is notably mute. The question remains: Has the Premier been engaging in an elaborate hoax to inflate his own ego and to dupe the people of Queensland and the media, or has he been breaching the Australian's Air Navigation Regulations? Whatever the answer, this unnecessary situation brings no credit to the office of the Premier of Queensland or to Sir Johannes's self-proclaimed reputation as a responsible pilot. All I can say is that this maverick and irresponsible kind of attitude can only harm the advancement of aviation safety in this country.

—I ask the Prime Minister a question. He will recall advising the House a few moments ago that in the course of his discussions with Mr John Reid a sum of $400,000 was mentioned as the possible quantum of the settlement with Dr Armstrong. At the time of those discussions, was reference made to the legal entitlement of four months notice for Dr Armstrong? If so, was there any suggestion that the terms of settlement would be a matter between only the solicitors for the Australian bicentennial Authority and Dr Armstrong? Did the Prime Minister take separate legal advice? If so, when? At what stage did he decide that the amount of $400,000 was beyond that which might reasonably be paid in the circumstances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the discussion I had with Mr Reid the point was made that the settlement to buy out the contract would be substantial because the contract had about six years to go. The salary was $60,000 to $70,000 and applying to that the relevant long service leave and annual leave provisions gave us the sort of figure that was being talked about. That was the extent of the conversation which set the order of the figure that could be involved.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the second part of the question by the Leader of the National Party, my concern about the amount went predominantly, as honourable members can see, to its composition. It was in regard to the composition that I had the telephone conversation with Mr Reid-on 10 September, as I recall it-and in respect of which the letter was subsequently written. I am not sure whether I am correct in saying that the conversation was on 10 September, but it was on the Thursday before I returned from Papua New Guinea that I wrote to Mr Reid confirming the conversation I had had with him at the end of the previous week. My concern, as I have made clear, was about the composition because my original understanding was that we would get to that order of figure by multiplying Dr Armstrong's salary by six. I referred in my answer to the first question on this matter today to the concern about that composition and the fact that it differed from that which was originally indicated.

It was for that reason that I wrote to the Chairman of the Authority. As I have said, I expect to get an answer from him early next week as he is overseas now. The appropriate time to get advice as to the composition or the appropriateness of that amount in terms of its composition will be after I get that reply from Mr Reid, and not before.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation been drawn to the unscrupulous advertising campaign launched by Air New Zealand? Will he urge Qantas Airways Ltd not to use the fringe benefits, if any, provided by its stewards and stewardesses to compete with Air New Zealand?

—I do not thank the honourable member for the question. My attention has not been drawn to the advertising campaign by Air New Zealand, but the honourable member has drawn my attention to a report in this morning's Melbourne Sun entitled `Passenger tells of sex in Jumbo'. It is under the by-line of one Bruce Morris, who I have to say is unknown to me.
—And, more importantly, unrelated.

—And unrelated, as the Prime Minister reminds me. I can only leave it to the gallery and to honourable members to interpret for themselves what the honourable member is referring to when the article refers to `sex in jumbo'. There are a number of interpretations one can place on that. I do not know what the case is about compensation. All I can say in respect of the issue is that it may be an occupational hazard for those employed in the industry. On the other hand, for the passengers it may be a hazard of long distance travel.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to paragraph 2 of the letter of 19 August 1985 to the Prime Minister from Mr Reid, the Chairman of the Australian Bicentennial Authority. That second paragraph reads as follows:

QUESTION.PARA: I have already taken first steps to achieve the objective you wished.
Does that mean that the objective wished by the Prime Minister on Mr Reid was in fact the resignation of Dr Armstrong?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already made it clear in my answer today that, amongst the matters I discussed with Mr Reid, was precisely that matter.
—So, you agree?
—I said; I say again in case-
—It is relevant to your credit.

—I have made it clear in the first answer I gave today that I had conveyed to Mr Reid the view that, in terms of all the advice I had, the best future interest of the Authority would be served by the resignation of the current Chief Executive and that that is what should occur. As I have already said in answer to a previous question, Mr Reid said that he would consider that. He went away and considered it and contacted me and he said that he had come to the position that that should be done. It was in that context of him having come to that position in light of the view I had put to him-
—But you have been claiming that you had no authority-

—Let me deal with the inane interjection of the honourable member for Bradfield saying that I claimed that I had no authority. This is the very point. I had no authority. I did not create the legislation. The people opposite created it. If they had created legislation whereby the Government had authority I would not need to have had the discussion with Mr Reid, with the Chairman of the Authority.
