The fact is that the only way in which that objective could be achieved is if the Chairman of the Authority came to the decision that that in all the circumstances was the appropriate thing to do; and he conveyed back to me that that is what he would do. The fact of authority existed because of the legislation that those opposite passed. I conveyed a view to the Chairman of the Authority. He considered it and then conveyed to me that then he would take the steps as only he, under the legislation of those opposite, could do.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Aviation to an application by East-West Airlines Ltd to relocate its Victorian based operations from Melbourne Airport at Tullarmarine to Essendon Airport and to the many expressions of concern by local communites to such a proposed move. Can the Minister advise the House of the current status of this application?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I am aware of the very keen interest that he has taken in this matter on behalf of his constituents. I had the opportunity of discussing East-West's proposals to transfer its operation from Tullarmarine to Essendon Airport with the honourable member, as I have indicated, and with representatives of local communities. There has been considerable adverse community reaction to the proposal and I understand that the cities of Essendon and Keilor have stated that they wish East-West to remain at Tullamarine. I have to say that a review of the role of Essendon Airport is nearing completion and the House of Represenatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation is conducting its own aircraft noise inquiry, including an examination of operations at Essendon. I expect that both of those reports will be available later in the year. In these circumstances I have advised East-West Airlines this morning that I consider that it would not be appropriate to agree to its proposal at this stage for a transfer to Essendon. In coming to this view, I have also taken into account the fact that there are facilities available for regular public transport services at Tullarmarine and I have directed my Department to ensure that East-West Airlines is accomodated at that airport.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Aviation, also concerns East-West Airlines Ltd. I was beginning to despair whether he would ever get a serious question on the subject. On what basis does the Minister justify the inordinate delay in the processing of East-West's application to import F28 and Boeing 737 aircraft? Why is the application not processed on the same basis as those from Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans Australia Airlines, when one remembers that it made that application in March-April?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is very simple. In respect of the Boeing 737-200 application, the airline itself some time ago asked that further consideration of that matter be deferred. In compliance with its request, I have deferred consideration of it. That was its request. I do not know what misinformation the honourable member for Murray has been receiving, but that happens to be the fact. If he asks silly questions he will get the answers he deserves.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the application to import the F28, on 26 July I discussed that matter with the Managing Director of East-West Airlines. In the matter of that discussion I drew to his attention and that of his colleague present that, in differing items of correspondence provided to me by the airline, it had provided conflicting claims. On the one hand, it said that it had excess capacity. On the other hand, it sought additional capacity. Obviously both versions could not be correct. On that date I asked the airline to clarify the situation. As of this time, this afternoon, I have not received a response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Primary Industry to the continuing attempts by the Bjelke-Petersen National Party State Government to politicise the crisis in the sugar industry. Is it correct that it has been the Queensland Government that has been procrastinating and delaying the finalising of a support package? Will the Minister outline the steps that he, as Federal Minister, has been taking to try to have the State Government meet to resolve this issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could just go briefly into some background, the industry of course has very difficult internal politics. The situation between the millers and the growers is well known, as is the difference between regions; and the fact that this industry is also bound up very tightly with Queensland law makes change in an industry that is clearly under stress-and that is understood by all members of this House-very difficult to achieve. What has been achieved is this: At the end of last year when the Prime Minister met a delegation from the Queensland Cane Growers Council agreement was reached to set up a committee between the Commonwealth and State Government and the industry to try to look at the industry within 100 days because the Commonwealth and, we thought then, the Queensland Government accepted the urgency of trying to reach a decision on this industry and on which was the best way to go. What we have before us now is a report by that committee, the 100-day committee, under Mr Russell Savage, which put a view agreed to by the Commonwealth Government, the State Government and the industry members of that committee. Of course, that committee came up with a package that had been agreed to in varying degrees by various people in the industry. That report was to be presented to both governments.

ANSWER.PARA: When I went to Queensland on the day that the report was to be presented to Mr Turner, the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries, and me, I arrived to find that any negotiating position that Mr Turner had had been withdrawn by the Queensland Premier; that is, we were not to talk about the report. The report had already been given out to the Press with an accompanying statement. I swallowed my pride at that, but I simply say that the report was to be given to both governments and it reflected an enormous discourteousness to the Prime Minister of Australia that that should take place. The report is now widely released and people are taking all sorts of decisions on it. State National Party members are taking rather extreme positions, amounting to saying that there is no need to involve the Commonwealth at all. That is absolute nonsense. I am happy to report that Mr Turner is prepared to talk with me on this matter next Wednesday. The Commonwealth will be having a Cabinet meeting in Townsville on Monday and will discuss the whole question of the sugar industry once again.

All that has happened since the report was delivered in terms of contact between the Queensland Government and the Commonwealth Government is that the Queensland Premier, in his Budget, came forward with $10m for a rural adjustment part B-that is, the part of the rural adjustment that requires additional money from the Commonwealth, or matching money-but there is no discussion about that. Therefore, he is now running around claiming $20m assistance to the sugar industry when in reality there is no capacity in that industry to pay off carry-on finance. I think that basically the whole proposal smacks of a little bit of opportunism.

I do not want to make a lot of politics about this industry. It is a very complex issue and we need to talk about it. I make the point that it is absolutely essential for the two governments and the industry to work together. In terms of looking at other industries which are in trouble, whether the car industry or the steel industry, we have put together packages involving the principal parties. If anyone does not think that the Queensland Government is involved as a principal party in the sugar industry he ought to look again. The Queensland Government set up all the legislation. Ninety-four per cent of Australia's sugar is grown in Queensland. It is Queensland's second biggest rural industry and Queensland well knows it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is rubbish. It is an export industry and you know it. There is no sense in talking about income support, which was one of the recommendations of the Queensland Government.
—I did not hear the right honourable gentleman's interjection.
—Order! I suggest that the Minister ignore the interjections and keep on with the answer.
—I am talking about the legislation, Mr Speaker.
—Perhaps he should go to Tasmania.
—You ought to read the Hansard too, dumbo.
—Order! I invite the Minister to ignore interjections.

—There were three or four major recommendations of the Savage committee. One was about various measures with respect to restructuring which will require the Commonwealth Government and the Queensland Government to talk. The second concerned income support which, again, will require the Queensland Government and the Commonwealth Government to confer. The third measure was about a rural adjustment package which, in dealing with other States-as I am doing with Victoria regarding dairying and dried vine fruits-it is essential and sensible for the two governments to confer. The fourth matter was whether, with respect to research, the Commonwealth can deal directly with the industry.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as income support is concerned, it is not just a question of snapping a figure out of the air. If one looks at the Savage recommendations one takes into account the fact that the sugar price is pooled through a year and that we have a floating exchange rate. It is very important that we agree not only to the level of funds to be supplied by both governments but also on the method of supplying such moneys. I have said that the Queensland Government ought to be involved financially with respect to this industry. The Queensland Government has indicated that, as far as rural adjustment is concerned, it is prepared to be involved. I welcome that. However, I do reject some of the claims by the Queensland Premier that Queensland has no capacity to contribute to this industry. We have a fair idea of how much capacity the Queensland Government has through information available publicly through the Commonwealth Grants Commission, the Loan Council and the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

For example, in 1984-85 Queensland had a cash surplus of something like $100m which has gone into off-Budget accounts. From ABS figures we know that in 1982-83, it had at least $284m in terms of cash holdings; in terms of borrowing surpluses, in 1983-84 it had $634m, in 1984-85 it had a $121m borrowing surplus, and we know that it had $39m up the Rural Reconstruction Board hollow log. So it is nonsense for the Queensland Government to say that it has no capacity to contribute to this industry. What the Queensland Government lacks is a willingness to contribute and a willingness to talk and discuss this vitally important Queensland industry.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Clerk-I have received from the Leader of the Opposition notice of his intention at the next sitting to move:
That this House censures the Prime Minister for his misleading statements and inadequate handling of matters related to the resignation of Dr Armstrong from the Australian Bicentennial Authority.
Motion (by Mr Young) agreed to:

That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith the motion of censure of the Prime Minister of which he has given notice for the next sitting.
Motion of Censure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Prime Minister for his misleading statements and inadequate handling of matters related to the resignation of Dr Armstrong from the Australian Bicentennial Authority.

The Opposition moved censure of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the matter of Dr Armstrong's resignation from the Australian Bicentennial Authority because we believe that on two accounts the Prime Minister is guilty of misleading the Australian public and, more specifically, of misleading the Australian Parliament. The matter does not relate, as those in the Government would allege, to whether or not Dr Armstrong should have continued as Chief Executive of the Bicentennial Authority; nor indeed does it relate to the continuing fitness or otherwise of other senior office bearers of the Bicentennial Authority. It is not Dr Armstrong or Mr Reid who is in the dock today; it is the Prime Minister who is in the dock today, because it is the Prime Minister who has misled this Parliament. We have just had the Prime Minister, characteristically and predictably, on a day that a taxation package-which will swamp the news media tonight and tomorrow-is about to be brought down, come into this Parliament and get up in the most abject circumstances to say that he misled the Parliament and the people in the previous statements that he made. Mr Speaker, I take you back to the statement made by the Prime Minister on 11 September. That followed the stories circulating about the payout of a large sum of money to Dr Armstrong in consideration of his retirement as Chief Executive of the Bicentennial Authority. I ask honourable members to listen very carefully to what the Prime Minister said and to assess for themselves whether the charge of misleading the Parliament and the people is a fair one. The Prime Minister said:
I have been asked about reports of the settlement of the terms of the contract of the former General Manager of the Australian Bicentennial Authority, Dr David Armstrong.
Critically, in the second paragraph, he said:
In recent weeks I have had several discussions with the Chairman of the ABA, Mr John Reid, about both specific criticism of the ABA and the plans that were being made for the 1988 celebrations.
He went on to say:

After those discussions took place, Mr Reid and Dr Armstrong concluded that the interests of the ABA would be best served if Dr Armstrong were to leave its service. The negotiation of the terms of settlement of that departure was-as it had to be under the terms of the legislation establishing the ABA-entirely a matter between the Chairman and Dr Armstrong.
I have no comment to add about those terms.

That was the text of the Prime Minister's statement. That is what he said about his discussions. At that time, no doubt the Prime Minister and his advisers believed that this was a matter that somehow or other would go away-that there would be other things that would occupy the minds of the public. But it has now transpired-not the least on the Prime Minister's own admission-that the truth of the matter is that he told Mr Reid that he thought David Armstrong ought to go. I am not going to contest with the Prime Minister whether or not that was a valid judgment reached by him as the Minister responsible.

I want to make clear on behalf of the Opposition that we are not disputing the right of the Prime Minister, as the Minister responsible for the Authority, to express the strongest possible view to the Chairman of the Authority that something ought to be done about the administration of the Authority. We are not saying that. I have to say on behalf of the Opposition that now that the matter has been raised that there are aspects about the direction of the Australian Bicentennial Authority and some of the approaches being taken that do cause us some concern. It is not my argument with the Prime Minister that he exercised his authority to talk to Mr Reid about it. I have no quarrel with that. But what I quarrel with and what we censure the Prime Minister about is that he did not come clean in his statement of 11 September because that statement of 11 September, against the admission he has now made, at least by omission was patently misleading. It now transpires, according to the Prime Minister's own admission, that what really happened was that they had a discussion and the Prime Minister told Mr Reid that in his view Dr Armstrong ought to go.
The letter from Mr Reid to the Prime Minister dated 19 August 1985 reads as follows:
1. I refer to the matter we discussed on Thursday last, 16th August, item one of our meeting.

Not just one of a number of matters, as the Prime Minister would have us imagine, but item 1. It could concern only one subject, and that presumably was the position of Dr Armstrong. Mr Reid then goes on to say:
2. I have already taken first steps to achieve the objective you wish.

I repeat: `First steps to achieve the objective you wish'. Yet, the Prime Minister would have us believe on 11 September that they discussed criticisms of the ABA and concern about the 1988 bicentennial; but then, dismissively, all of the negotiations are a matter between Dr Armstrong and Mr Reid. The Prime Minister cannot run the argument that by covering this up he was trying to avoid criticism of the Authority because the explanation he gave was that they had canvassed criticism of the Authority. So he cannot run that as a satisfactory argument. Mr Reid then went on to say:
3. As agreed between us, he and I discussed the subject which was item one of your and my conversation at our meeting.

Once again this item 1 comes back. It is item 1 on the agenda for their discussion but it does not rate a mention in the public Press statement of the Prime Minister. Yet, he will tell the Parliament that he has come completely clean and that he has been totally candid. Mr Reid then goes on to say:
4. All being well, I hope to have the matter settled this week or early next week. However, see below.
He then went on to say:
5. I am anxious to achieve a civilised and especially a non-public statement. This will require care and skill to accomplish.
He then makes certain other requests which, for the moment, I will omit. Perhaps prophetically, in the penultimate paragraph of his letter to the Prime Minister, he went on to say:
It is vital that no mistakes are made on this matter.

Of course, that is one expectation expressed by Mr Reid that has not been realised. So, criticism and complaint number one against the Prime Minister is that at least by omission he blatantly misled the public in his Press statement of 11 September. All of the material that he has tabled in the Parliament today and all of the admissions that he made conclusively demonstrate that he has misled the Australian public.

But, of course, that has not been the end of the matter. Under questioning in this Parliament and under the pressure of mounting public concern, the Prime Minister over the last couple of days has engaged in a quite extraordinary performance in this Parliament, first trying to brush it all off and trying to say: `You are a grubby bunch for even raising it'. That basically is what the Prime Minister said. Bipartisanship is great when one is in trouble but when one is not in trouble one does not even get a mention. I believe that basically that is the philosophy that has been tried to be applied in this matter. I want to say to the Prime Minister that I do not accept for a moment the proposition that a bipartisan approach by this side of the House to the bicentennial or, indeed, any other matter for a moment precludes the legitimate right of an opposition to ask straight probing questions about the conduct of a government. The idea that bipartisanship should muzzle an opposition into asking questions is an absolute nonsense. It is certainly not something that we are going to allow.

You will remember, Mr Speaker, that yesterday at the end of Question Time I asked the Prime Minister two questions. First of all I asked him whether he would table all of the relevant documents. The second question I asked him was whether, in the name of achieving a bipartisan resolution of this matter, he would agree to the appointment of an independent arbitrator acceptable to him and acceptable to me who would advise whether in all of the circumstances the amount paid to Dr Armstrong was fair and appropriate. He did not answer that second question. He ducked away from it which, of course, has to raise certain queries about his bona fides on bipartisanship on this issue. But very importantly, in answer to my first question, he made an extraordinary comment, extraordinary in the light of the admissions that he has made today. He said:
I appreciate the question that has been put by the Leader of the Opposition and I respond in these terms.
Listen to this-
In regard to the relevant documents, I am prepared to do what I have already done; that is, to show the Leader of the Opposition the relevant documents.

This is what he said yesterday. He told this Parliament that he had shown me all of the relevant documents. Yet I get in front of me today a pile of documents, only one of which I have seen before, and that is the memorandum of legal advice from Allen, Allen and Hemsley to Mr Reid as Chairman of the Bicentennial Authority. None of the other documents has been shown to me. They are clearly relevant. Probably the most relevant of all is the letter from Mr Reid to the Prime Minister from which I have just extensively quoted and which demonstrates that what really happened in this matter was that the Prime Minister heavied Mr Reid into getting rid of Dr Armstrong. That is what really happened. Yet, the Prime Minister would have us believe that that is not a relevant document. The only reason that he has finally had to come clean about this matter is that he has been flushed out. The pressure of media comment and Opposition pressure has meant that the Prime Minister has had to come clean and has had to admit that the role that he, by omission in his Press statement, wanted us to believe that he did not have in this matter, he did in fact have.

I go back to that Press statement because that was the beginning of the Prime Minister's deceit on this matter. He sought in that Press statement at the very least to imply that he had not discussed Dr Armstrong's position and that he had absolutely nothing to do with the removal of Dr Armstrong as the Chief Executive of the Bicentennial Authority. Yet, it now transpires from the documents that have been tabled in the Parliament today that in fact the Prime Minister heavied the Chairman of the Bicentennial Authority into achieving and bringing about the resignation of Dr Armstrong. So the first and most serious charge that we make against the Prime Minister is that he misled the public in his Press statement of 11 September and that he misled the Parliament in his answer yesterday to me. That has been conclusively demonstrated not just by argument and questioning from the Opposition but by the material that he, the Prime Minister, tabled in the Parliament today.

The other matter that causes us at least areas of grave concern and is the basis of further questioning by the Opposition and by the public is the simple fact that the Prime Minister has suddenly discovered a concern about the size of this amount. He did not have a concern about the amount when he made the statement on 11 September, although he now says that he formed that concern on 10 September. If he was concerned about the amount, why did he disclaim any responsibility for it? Perhaps it was because he was concerned about it that he suddenly decided that he ought to display a bit of responsibility. We all are entitled to have the impression that the Prime Minister's concern about the level of the amount became a reality when he perceived public disquiet about the level of the amount. In fact, he started off by saying that he wanted the matter dealt with leniently and generously. Yet, further down the track he discovedred that, because of public probing and because of public questioning, in fact he ought to evince some kind of public concern.

It is not good enough for the Prime Minister to say, as he has constantly said throughout this matter, that it is all a question of the responsibility of the Bicentennial Authority, because he knows that section 11 of the Australian Bicentennial Authority Act states that the money expended by the Authority are those approved by the relevant Minister. Who is the relevant Minister? The Prime Minister is the relevant Minister in this matter. No other person is the relevant Minister. No doctrine of ministerial responsibility, however contorted or however misrepresented, can absolve the Prime Minister from ultimate financial responsibility, as the responsibile Minister, for the expenditure of funds.

He knows as well that ultimately, no matter what kind of corporate structure one has, no matter what kind of interventions of an administrative kind one has, in our system of government the buck stops when one signs the cheque. That is what it all boils down to. Any kind of proposition or doctrine that suggests that the Prime Minister was a mere cipher in this matter, that at the end of the day he had no alternative but to sign the cheque that was put in front of him, that he had no alternative but to rubber stamp the deal which Mr Reid had negotiated with Dr Armstrong, is absolute nonsense. He was aware from the very beginning that a fairly generous settlement would be required because of the nature of the discussion which he had with Mr Reid and which has now been disclosed in the documents that have been tabled. He knew that. Any proposition that the Prime Minister had reason only over the last few days to be concerned about the level of this amount will be demonstrated to be patently false and patently inadequate by any fair examination of the documents.

Our charge against the Prime Minister is not that he concerned himself about the Bicentennial Authority; not that he formed a view that maybe it was a good idea that Dr Armstrong should go; not that he will in the future concern himself more about the Bicentennial Authority; not that he does not have a right to talk to Mr Reid, and talk to him ad nauseam if he wishes to do so, as the responsible Minister for the operation of the Bicentennial Authority-that is not our complaint. Let us hear nothing from the Prime Minister about the long term future of the Authority. That is not the issue. The issue is the long term future of the Prime Minister. It is not the long term future of the Bicentennial Authority. On this occasion the Prime Minister has been guilty of misleading the Parliament. He has been guilty of misleading the Australian public. He has been guilty, at the very least, of sloppy and inadequate administration and discharge of his ministerial responsibility. On all of those counts he is deserving of the censure of this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—The motion is seconded and I reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make it clear that, of course, I repudiate completely the observations-I do not put them any higher than that-made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), because no one sitting in this House would have regarded his speech as a very convincing attack. Of course, I completely repudiate the observations of the Leader of the Opposition, and I will proceed to deal with them. But before I do so, may I say that it must strike not only people in this House but in this country as passing strange that the man who deliberately perpetrated the greatest fraud on the people of this country, who, not in regard to a matter of half a million dollars, but in the matter of $9 billion, deliberately-

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition was heard in relative silence. I would ask honourable members to reflect on the fact that those who desire freedom of speech should also allow others freedom of speech and not behave in this organised way.
—That does not give him a licence to-

—Order! The honourable member for Tangney sits on my left. I have heard him using language which is offensive in Parliament on any terms. I do not pull him up because I do not want it recorded in Hansard. I suggest he show some respect for himself and the House.

—I will come to the issues in a moment. But I think it is appropriate that, if we are to listen to this Leader of the Opposition making accusations about other people misleading the Parliament and the people, let us at the outset place on the record the magnitude-the bizarre magnitude-of this man's record on deliberately misleading the people of Australia, not in regard to half a million dollars but in regard to a sum of $9 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the observations of the Leader of the Opposition. He admitted on 8 March 1983 that the deficit figure used during the election campaign was not based on Treasury figures, but was made up by him. In talking to the Prime Minister, he said: `I just gave a broad idea that the situation looked as though it was worse than we had really imagined'. By way of preface to the response that I will make to the Leader of the Opposition I say this: Let the people of Australia remember, when they listen to this man attempting to censure a Prime Minister, that this is the man who deliberately lied to the Australian people-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the Prime Minister to withdraw.
—He deliberately put a false position to the people of Australia.
—Has the Prime Minister withdrawn?

—Yes, I have withdrawn that. He deliberately put a false position to the people of Australia. He said that he knew what the real position was; he had been told by Treasury; he knew the figure was worse than had been stated, but that was not going to worry him; he was deliberately going to mislead to the tune of $3 billion. That is the man who has the hide in this House to misrepresent what has happened in this case and say that it involved misrepresentation. If it were misrepresentation, I would not be in the same league. He is a $10 billion misrepresenter. He has the hide to talk in here about misrepresentation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get to the facts. After listening to this hypocrite talk, we find that what he had to say was that the question of the adequacy of Dr Armstrong to continue in his position as Chief Executive was the No. 1 item on the agenda for the meeting with Mr Reid, but that it was not No. 1 on the Press statement which I released on 11 September. That is absolutely right. There is a reason why it is No. 1 on the agenda in talking with Mr Reid and not No. 1 on the Press statement. It was not involved with any attempt to hide or delude; it was concerned with the very real and proper objective which I had and which I shared with the person appointed by the Government-that is, Mr Reid-that what ought to be done in this matter was to try to handle it in a way which would be not only in the best interests of the Australian Bicentennial Authority but of the people of Australia. That was a shared position that was reflected in the letter by Mr Reid to which the Leader of the Opposition has referred.

So it should not be a matter of surprise when he says in here: `Look, there is a difference between the agenda discussion by Mr Reid and the Prime Minister and what is contained in the Press statement'. There was a reason for it-a reason that has been made clear.

I have not at any point attempted to deny this either in my public statements or in my conversation with the Leader of the Opposition. The Leader of the Opposition has the most convenient memory I have ever come across. He asked whether I went to a certain matter. He knows that I went to these matters in the conversation with him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not according to my record.

—Of course, the Leader of the Opposition's notes that he goes away and writes afterwards-very convenient notes. If he would mislead the Australian people to the tune of $3 billion or $4 billion, what sort of concern would he have about subsequently trying to misrepresent events for his own perceived advantage?

SPEECH.PARA: The reason that I spoke with the Chairman of the Authority on the day in question was that there had been a range of representations-not only the most publicised one from Mr Ranald Macdonald-made to me in regard to the welfare of the Bicentennial Authority, which has the responsibility for preparing this country for its celebrations in 1988. Unfortunately, there was this common thread in them which went to the question of the adequacy or otherwise of the Chief Executive. It was my responsibility in those circumstances to take that issue up with the Chairman of the Authority. It would have been irresponsible if, those matters having been brought to my attention, being the Minister responsible, I had not, as the first item on the agenda with him, discussed those matters with him. That is precisely what I did.

The response of the Chairman was to listen intently to what I had to say. Then he said: `Well, I will go away and consider it'. He went away and considered it-and he went away and considered it in the knowledge that he was acting in the context of the legislation passed by those opposite, legislation which I say is very strange legislation. Is it not remarkable that they could have a government responsible for putting out hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money, but what was the deal that they came to? What was the organisation? No opportunity of any governmental or parliamentary involvement, direction and responsibility for the expenditure of the taxpayers' money. Those opposite have the hide to get up here and say: `Oh, look, there is a half a million dollars of taxpayers' money involved in this. Did you behave aptly and properly in the expenditure of half a million dollars of taxpayers' money?'

The very reason why we have got this problem is that the people opposite deliberately set up legislation which took away from government, which took away from parliament, the opportunity of supervising, controlling and regulating not half a million dollars, but hundreds of millions of dollars. Does not the bizarre hypocrisy of this become so evident? Honourable members opposite get up here and talk about whether there might have been possible mishandling-bad decision-about half a million dollars, deliberately having created the legislative position where this Parliament and this Government have not got the authority or the power to look over hundreds of millions of dollars.

As I have said, it would have been appropriate for this Government when we assumed office to say: `That is a gross dereliction of responsibility on the part of our predecessors' and move then to undo the ABA, to get rid of the appointments the former Government had made. But with a great sense of responsibility we said: `No. The greater interests of this country demand that we seek out views about that issue, accept what the former Government foisted upon us and within that framework try to deal with the problems that emerge'. That is, with a sense of responsibility, precisely what I have tried to do since we came into government generally.

As problems started to emerge under the structure which the former Government created and in the terms of the appointments of the people it put in place, what did I do? I immediately said: `Well, we have got to examine those widespread criticisms and see what it is that we can do to handle those within the legislative framework that you foisted upon us'. So I listened to, I studied and I asked for advice on those criticisms that had been made. Having done that, I called in the Chairman of the Authority. Of course, with a sense of responsibility, the first item on the agenda was the common thread of the criticisms that had been put to me. I said to him: `Well, there it is'. He made it clear that he listened intently. He made it clear that he had to study the criticisms, the points I had made to him. He said that he would go away and do it. When he contacted me back what did he say? He said: `I make it clear that it is for me to negotiate this issue. I have the responsibility under the legislation. Leave it with me'. If honourable members want to know whether he asked for authority, he had it in the Act. I made it clear that in conducting those negotiations with the Chief Executive he was doing it properly, following the discussions that I had had with him and the limited amount of discussions in terms of legislative opportunity or responsibility that I was able to have. It was appropriate that Mr Reid should so conduct those discussions.

I make it clear that the original intimation to me was that, in terms of the amount, the size that would emerge related to the fact that in buying out the contract one had about six years of that contract to go and when one took six years of the contracted salary into account and related the long service leave and annual leave provisions, one was talking about something over $400,000.

The Chairman of the Authority went away and conducted the negotiations in those terms. When I came to consider this matter, after he had written back to me and said `these are the areas of components', it was quite clear, as one addressed one's mind to it, that there was a distinct difference in terms of the composition of the amount. It was distinctly different from the basis which had been put. I therefore raised in that telephone conversation on 10 September this question and said: `It is the case, is it not, that this composition is different from that which you intimated to me'? The Chairman of the Authority said quite unequivocally: `Yes, it is different'. I said: `Well, look, I am concerned about this and I want you to assure me that what has been done is not something which is inappropriate'. In those circumstances he sent me the letter from Allen, Allen and Hemsley, which indicated, as the Bicentennial Authority's solicitors, that there was nothing inappropriate, that it was in accordance with appropriate practice. I still said to him: `Well, look, I want to be assured on this matter'. I did not have the right under the Act as it was to do anything about it because the legislation which the former Government passed had taken that authority away from the Government, had taken that authority away from the Parliament. But I still was not going to allow something improper to occur. So I said: `I want it in writing and I am awaiting that in writing'.

When we get that in writing from the Chairman of the Authority we will examine it. If, in fact, there is something improper, then we will have to do something about it. I hope that if that arises-if it arises-we will not have a continuation of the hypocrisy from those on the other side of the House; that they will agree with us that something will have to be done about the legislation so that the people of Australia are protected, as they were not by the legislative action of those opposite; that the people of Australia will have their interests protected in such a way that control can be exercised by the Government and the Parliament of this country if something improper in fact turns out to have occurred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am entering this debate as the shadow Minister responsible for the affairs of the bicentennial. I commence by making the point that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has declared that, in fact, he misled this House and that he has conducted himself in a manner which is totally inconsistent with the fundamental responsibilities applicable to any Minister of this Parliament. These responsibilities were accepted by the Prime Minister after the last election when he changed his administrative orders and took the responsibility for the Australian Bicentennial Authority from the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen), who I have not the slightest doubt could have done a better job, as events have turned out. He changed the situation and took responsibility for the Authority. In the last 10 months we have seen case after case of catastrophe and climactic situations which have resulted today in the Opposition moving a motion of censure against the Prime Minister of Australia. I say to my colleagues and to honourable members opposite that this Parliament can debate no more important motion than a motion of censure against the Prime Minister. It is an absolute disgrace that what we have gone through this week in this Parliament is a farrago of lies, deceptions and misrepresentations of the fact. Yet today we are seeing a Prime Minister who has accepted the fact that he has been wrong for so long.

SPEECH.PARA: Two months ago-in July-a senior member of the Board of the Authority resigned. Mr Ranald Macdonald, the Victorian representative, a friend of the Victorian Premier and known as a friend of the Prime Minister, resigned saying that the state of affairs in the Australian Bicentennial Authority was nothing less than a shambles. What did we hear from this Government and, more importantly, what did we hear from the Prime Minister? Total silence. We have been told today that he wanted to be bipartisan about this whole affair. I remind him that on 12 July this year, following the resignation of Mr Macdonald, on behalf of the Opposition I wrote him a letter in which I said:
I am writing to advise you of the community's growing concern--
because clearly he had not noted it--

at continuing allegations relating to the manner in which the Bicentennial Authority is controlling the expenditure of $166m at July 1982 prices provided by the Commonwealth for the funding of the Bicentenary 1988.
In my concluding paragraph to that letter, I said:

I wish to reiterate that the Opposition believes the Bicentennial celebrations should not be subject to political disagreement. Nevertheless, it is clearly your duty as the responsible Minister to ensure that the community's interests are fully safeguarded. It is the intention of the Opposition to see that this is done.

I did not know when I wrote those words that two months later we would be debating this motion of censure against the Prime Minister. But the important thing is that the letter was written-and I say this to Labor members because they might be used to this sort of inactivity-and I still await a response. This is an example of the fact that this Prime Minister for the last 10 months, when he has been responsible for the Authority, has totally refused at any time to take a serious interest in its affairs Is it any wonder that one can say of the quality of his administration only that it is inept, incompetent-and now we add to that, deceitful? The people of Australia will make the judgment. There is not an editorial in any major newspaper in recent days which has not criticised this Government and in particular this Prime Minister for the manner in which he has conducted himself in this affair.

Let us go back to where it all started, the infamous Press release of 11 September 1985. As my colleague the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) pointed out, it was a statement better known for what it did not say than for what it did say. The simple fact is that Mr Reid, the Chairman of the Authority, was summoned to Canberra to see the Prime Minister on 15 August, when there were some three hours of discussion on the affairs of the Authority. Yet when this matter was released by Laurie Oakes in the media, when he stated that a settlement of some $500,000 had been achieved, what did we hear from the Prime Minister? Again, as with my experience at the time of the Macdonald resignation, total silence. But we are assured that of course the Prime Minister is responsible and is interested in the affairs of his portfolio.

Nevertheless, the days have passed; questions have been asked for three days in this House. We saw yesterday the refusal of the Prime Minister to table documents. We saw his rather sleazy attempt to try to embarrass and implicate the Leader of the Opposition by calling him behind the table, by inviting him to his room, at which time he showed him one letter. That was the legal opinion from Allen, Allen and Hemsley. On two occasions we asked the Prime Minister what additional legal opinion he had sought to ensure that all legal implications of the decisions had been covered. This was obviously his duty as the Minister responsible under the Australian Bicentennial Authority Act. It is significant that whenever that question has been asked, he has failed to answer it. The reason he has failed is quite obvious. There is no other opinion. He did not seek the opinion of the Crown legal officers. He did not seek the opinions of independent lawyers. He accepted at face value one document from Allen, Allen and Hemsley-the lawyers of the Authority. He can do that if he wishes, but if he had demonstrated any real concern to ensure that the national interest and Australian taxpayers' money were being protected, clearly he should have ensured, and it was his responsibility to ensure, that he checked the opinion against the views of the Crown law officers.

The Prime Minister's `charity'-I used the word because it is the word he used to describe the outcome of his negotiations with Mr Reid in terms of what he thought ought to be the settlement on Dr Armstrong-is simply `charity' with other people's money. It is `charity' with the money of the taxpayers of Australia. Let us look at the matter in more detail. The document tabled by Mr Reid last Friday in the SenateEstimates Committee falls into two important categories. First, we are told there are what are called legal entitlements. They include superannuation payments of $73,709; long service, recreation leave, $24,020; and minimum notice under the terms of the appointment, $24,844. In other words, the legal entitlement for this man was $122,573. I emphasise that at no stage during the questioning did the Leader of the Opposition, or any other members on this side of the House, question the legal entitlement. We accept that because it was covered by the contractual agreement between Dr Armstrong and the Authority as we understand it. What we have questioned continually has been the settlement term payments, the additional payments valued at a further 366,193 of taxpayers' dollars.

What does that consist of? Eight additional months notice with added superannuation and compensation for restraints and releases! Time after time we have asked the Prime Minister to go into details of what this means. He started off in his Press release by denying that he knew anything about it. Somehow he had a three-hour discussion with Mr Reid on 15 August, during which time, we were led to believe, the affairs of Dr Armstrong and his future were not considered. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment knows as much about this as I now know about it, and he is equally aware, as I am that we were not given the reality of the situation. Yet the Prime Minister, during inquiries about his Press statement, continued to tell this Parliament, for a number of days, a fabrication of reality. Now he finds himself having to defend a position which is simply indefensible. As I said in my first question here today, he has condemned himself from his own mouth. He has done enormous damage to his Party, he has done enormous damage to the role and function of Prime Minister, and he has brought discredit to this Parliament.

One of the principles on which parliamentary democracy stands is that in this House one tells the truth. If one is caught out, as the Prime Minister was, one clears one's name at the first opportunity, not after three days of continued questioning. That is the record and standard that the Labor Party has brought into this Chamber. They are the standards that the parties in opposition repudiate.

Let us look at the legal situation which the Prime Minister has been trying to confuse in this question. He claimed that he had no power. He claimed that it was all our fault. What he has not told the Australian people, what he has not told this Parliament, is that the signatories to the articles of association included not only Malcolm Fraser and the Deputy Leader of the Government at that stage, but also Mr Hayden, who was then the Leader of the Opposition, and his Deputy. If ever there was a serious attempt to make a bipartisan arrangement, it was initiated by the Fraser Government on terms and conditions accepted by the honourable member opposite, now the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). Yet the attempt has been made to say it is all our fault. How ridiculous can that be. Let us take the matter a step further. We have been told now for three days: `I didn't know the gun was loaded. I did not have the power. It is all the Opposition's fault'. Let us look at the situation. In the Australian Bicentennial Authority Act, which is related to the very basis of the Commonwealth, is power which everybody knows has to subsume anything which may be contained in a mere memorandum and articles of association-section 41 is continually mentioned by the Prime Minister. We are told section 6 of the Act gives the Minister the power to direct the Authority on matters of policy. He has told us that he had nothing to do with it. Page 2 of the document which was tabled last Friday by the Authority's Chairman at the Senate Estimates Committee hearing stated:
The Commonwealth Government has accepted the program after minor amendment to take account of its own priorities.

For Heaven's sake, on matters of policy the Commonwealth is obviously premier in such matters. The Prime Minister said to the Australian Bicentennial Authority: `We want to review your programs. We want to put money into all sorts of minority interest groups. We are not interested in the mainstream of Australian thought, and because we have the power under section 6 of the appropriate legislation you will do what you are told'. Of course, that does not seem to happen where taxpayers' money is concerned. In sections 11 and 12 of the Act we are told about estimates of expenditure. The document stated:
Moneys of the Authority shall not be expended by the Authority otherwise than in accordance with estimates of expenditure approved by the Minister.

Can anything be more clear than that? Estimates of expenditure must be approved by the Minister. But what have we had-only a farrago of lies! Last Wednesday the Prime Minister said to the Leader of the Opposition: `I want to show you a letter'. Dated 30 August, it said to Mr Reid: `If you have a financial problem go and talk about it to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment'. At no stage did the Prime Minister ever suggest, publicly or apparently privately, that he was in any way concerned that funds would be made available. As he said: `I want to be `charitable' with this settlement'. I hope the Australian people will be charitable with this Prime Minister and his rag-tag bobtailed Government because after what is imposed upon the Australian people tonight and after what they have had to go through over the last three days with this farrago of lies, they will see the Government for what it is and they will cast it adrift with its bags and baggage.

The fact of the matter is that we have reached a situation today where the Prime Minister has been caught out. It has been demonstrated that he has carried out his responsibilities with ineptitude and incompetence. He has failed to face realities. As the Minister responsible for the Bicentennial Authority it is to his failed judgment alone that the Australian people must look. This Parliament expects sensible, truthful answers to questions which are of major concern to the Australian people. It is a matter of the greatest concern that this has not taken place. The Prime Minister has suggested that generosity shown is to be the criterion of policies. I would have thought that the criteria for the policies of any government, even the Hawke Government, must always be the absolute interests of the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing is more disturbing than to see a graduate from a private school of the North Shore getting angry in the Parliament. When the old smile cunningly the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) really gets angry. It upsets the Parliament. It must be a matter of great moment for the Parliament to stop and listen to what the Opposition has brought forward today. It is a censure motion on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The new Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) could not wait to use the Standing Orders to have his first go at censuring the Prime Minister. What reason does the new Leader of the Opposition put forward for censuring the Prime Minister? It is a motion that has been moved perhaps once or twice a parliament on a Prime Minister since Federation. As the honourable member for Bradfield said, it is one of the most important motions that can be used in Parliament on serious matters. Do honourable members know what he wants to find the Prime Minister guilty of? It is not that he put out a Press statement on 10 or 11, or whatever day of September it was. It was rather that a paragraph was missing. It is not as though anything was wrong in what he put out; but it did not go far enough for the Leader of the Opposition. It is like telling Tolstoy: `We like 30 chapters of War and Peace but it would be much better if you had written 31'. That is the ridiculous level to which the Leader of the Opposition now drags this Parliament. He wants to discuss a censure motion on the Prime Minister about the Australian Bicentennial Authority and what has occurred.

SPEECH.PARA: Whenever the Leader of the Opposition hears the name Big Mal it makes him blink. People keep talking about the Leader of the Opposition and all the great policy ideas he had from 1975 to 1983, but whenever he took them to Big Mal he started to shudder because Mal used to put them through the shredder. There is now talk of Big Mal coming back. The Leader of the Opposition is trying to get all of his policies in place before Mal-the dreaded squire from Nareen-returns.

Who appointed John Reid to the position of Chairman of the Australian Bicentennial Authority? It was Big Mal. Of course the Leader of the Opposition, who was a great antagonist of Big Mal in the Cabinet as it then was, strongly argued against him. He said: `No, you cannot have John Reid. He won't run it efficiently'. He acted on this question as he did on thousands of questions that were raised in Cabinet between 11 November 1975 and 3 March 1983. Whenever Mal said something had to be done the Leader of the Opposition agreed with him. He put out his big, brown tongue as far as he could and said: `Mal, I'm with you 125 per cent' and he is still playing that role. The Leader of the Opposition wants to use the Parliament to grow 6 inches under the auspices of a censure motion on the Prime Minister so that everybody in Australia will take a little more notice of him. What a ridiculous move! One would have thought, with a couple of years to go to the next election, that he would be a little more patient with the use of the parliamentary theatre and the Standing Orders to make his presence felt. I am sure that a bit of bad tactical advice has been given to both past and present Leaders of the Opposition in the last couple of weeks. I think the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) would admit that. Surely we will read in his memoirs that he took some bad advice a couple of weeks ago. I suggest to the honourable member for Bennelong that he took some bad advice in moving this censure motion today. There has been no substance to the allegation about the Prime Minister misleading or telling lies. What the Leader of the Opposition is really saying is that the Prime Minister did not tell us everything that he possibly knew about the matter.

Let us look at the Australian Bicentennial Authority. Firstly, the Opposition set it up a few years ago. It has a budget-supposedly it is an amount of money that will be spent from the time of its inception, when it was set up by the Fraser Government, until it carries out its program in 1988-of $200m. It is not likely to be an authority that will escape any sort of surveillance by people outside. In recent weeks and months there has been a lot of publicity about the conduct of the Australian Bicentennial Authority and its administration. I will tell honourable members what the Prime Minister is guilty of, if he is guilty of anything. He is guilty of acting like a Prime Minister in saying to the Chairman: `Come and see me. There is a lot of public concern about what is going on. I want you to answer some of the questions. We have had the resignation of a very well known Australian from the Board. He has made a lot of allegations about the misuse of money. The organisation has already spent something like $47m. I want some answers about where we are going'. The Bicentennial Authority, with its $200m, is supposed to plan a celebration in 1988 for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you come clean last July?

—The honourable member for Bradfield says: `Come clean'. Honourable members opposite have referred to some of the things that have occurred. Mr Reid had a meeting with the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister has repeatedly told the Parliament that he expressed his concern about the administration of the Australian Bicentennial Authority. The Leader of the Opposition made great play about one sentence in a letter dated 19 August sent by Mr Reid following his meeting with the Prime Minister. The Leader of the Opposition, in his usual debating capacity, picked out the line that suited him best. The letter stated:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. I have already taken first steps to achieve the objective you wish.

`Ah', the Leader of the Opposition said, `there it is. That one line. Why didn't John Ried just sign the letter after that?' He did not. What the Leader of the Opposition did not tell the Parliament was what else was in the letter. Let us take it a bit further. The letter continued:
3. As agreed between us, he and I discussed the subject which was item one of your and my conversation at our meeting.
4. All being well I hope to have the matter settled this week or early next week. However see below.
5. I am anxious to achieve a civilised and especially a non-public settlement. This will require care and skill to accomplish.
6. To assist me in this task I should appreciate receiving from you specific assurances as follows:-

That no comment inside or outside the Parliament will be made by anyone in senior political office until I have advised you of the proposed timing of a proposed Press Release by me whenever that might occur.
I would hope that no other comment would be forthcoming thereafter either, except in terms of the agreed Press Release.

B. That I have your authority to negotiate a financial settlement to the contract of employment, details of which would be certified by professional advisers to me in the first instance and then to you as being reasonable and appropriate under the circumstances.
7. In this context you should know that still to be negotiated are, inter alia:
Mutual releases from future action on past and future obligations.
Restraints on speaking to the media.
Restraints on entering into competitive employment.
Restraints on disruptive contacts with staff of the organisation.
Obligations to provide me with information and background knowledge over the next 12 months.
Restraints from possible litigation for wrongful dismissal.
Restraints against involvement in political dialogue which could destabilise the work of the organisation.

Who laid down the conditions? John Reid, the person appointed by the Fraser Government, was laying in place the way in which he felt it was best to come out of the dialogue with the Prime Minister in terms of putting the Bicentennial Authority back on an even footing, so that it could get on with its work for the celebrations in 1988.

One thing is disturbing to perhaps all of us. This includes the Sydney Morning Herald. We will now see in its editorial what will develop, with the Sydney clique taking over the Liberal Party again. In the days of little Billy McMahon, the Sydney Morning Herald would publish an editorial and Billy would come into the Parliament and carry it out. Now we will have the same thing. So when we read an editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald which says what the Opposition ought to do while we are in government, the little member for Bennelong will come in and do that. The leader writers on the fourteenth floor at Broadway, New South Wales, will dictate the policies and actions of the Liberal Party.

What happened today? As we were eating our cornflakes and reading the editorial this morning of only about 50 of us in Australia read it-we could see that the editorial was telling the Liberal Party what to do in parliament today. Honourable members should look at it. It may interest honourable members to know, when we are talking about the half million dollars about which many people have raised questions-they have certainly done so in my electorate-that I was informed by my colleague the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) that only this week the Principal of the Chisholm Institute of Technology was paid $300,000 after three years service for the termination of his employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a disgrace.

—The honourable member may say that these payments are disgraceful and that they should not be made, but no honourable members opposite said that this money should not be spent when Mal was in parliament. Do honourable members remember the amount of money he spent before the 1983 election, holding all those businessmen's lunches during the election campaign? Tens of thousands of dollars were spent by the Liberal Government, trying to persuade the business people of this country to put all their donations into the Liberal Party to make sure that we did not win the election. Which honourable members on the other side of the House said: `That is government money; we cannot do that'? Who said: `We should not be allowed to spend that sort of money'? No one in the Liberal Party said that.

SPEECH.PARA: It is wrong to use the Parliament to say that the Prime Minister perhaps should have said after his discussion with John Reid `I want to come in here and make a statement. I want to tell you what all the problems are. I will tell you where all the money is. Let us put it all out in public so that that is all in the headlines'-so the whole thing becomes disruptive and the Bicentennial Authority disintegrates. Is that what those opposite want? That is what they are doing in the Parliament today. They are condemning the Australian Bicentennial Authority to disintegration. Not one word would in any way imply that the Prime Minister has misled this Parliament in statements that have been made and given to the Leader of the Opposition or in statements or answers to questions given in the Parliament. As I said, some very serious questions were raised about the Bicentennial Authority by the member of the Board, Ranald Macdonald. That is quite legitimate. He served on the Board. He was extremely concerned about the direction that the Bicentennial Authority was taking.

Obviously, the Prime Minister, as the Minister responsible for the Authority, had a responsibility to be concerned. It was legitimate. It was his responsibility to call in Mr Reid and ask what was going on. If the ultimate action of that discussion led to the resignation of Dr Armstrong, that is one thing. If Mr Reid then made a settlement with Dr Armstrong-an amount of money which some of us do not like-that is between Mr Reid and Dr Armstrong. It comes out of the appropriations given to Mr Reid last June under authority of the Australian Bicentennial Authority Act. It is as simple as that. If those opposite want to chop out these sorts of payments, they should chop them out right across the board. They should not select Dr Armstrong or the Bicentennial Authority and think that they will gain a political plus from this. It is absolutely ludicrous to try to use the Parliament to censure the Prime Minister in this way because, as I said, there is not one element of truth in the charges that those opposite bring-that he misled the Parliament.

If we devalue censure motions to the level to which those opposite have dragged them down today, we will have censure motions on the hour. In fact, when the Fraser Government was in office, if we had moved censure motions every time big Mal-and his then Treasurer-told us an untruth or mislead the Australian public we would have done nothing else in the Parliament but have censure motions, because they never stopped telling untruths. There were some whoppers. Do honourable members remember when the State Premiers met here? The Government had a celebration. It kept $70m that it was supposed to give to the State Premiers. Former Government members boasted, skited and celebrated the fact that they were able to keep $70m that was pinpointed to go to the States.

What those opposite have done today is absolutely ridiculous. This matter would not have been worth more than a Press release. If the Leader of the Opposition does not have enough staff with the ability to put out a two-paragraphs Press release, would he please see me. I would be very sympathetic to those sorts of pleas from the Opposition if they need more staff. I believe in the Westminster system-that there will be a better Opposition if its members have talented staff. The unfortunate feature of giving them extra staff is that they are employing dummies. They do not know how to use the Parliament, they do not know what to put in their speeches and how to use the forms of Australian politics. This has got them in a mess. At the end of a fortnight all one can say is that they find themselves in a position in which they did not want to be. The bloke outside is the bloke that those opposite still want to be the Leader of the Opposition. Nothing has changed. The Opposition has eight eight people on the back benches that it wanted on the front, and eight people on the front bench that it wanted on the back. We have not yet met some of the fellows on the front bench of the Opposition. They will make some outstanding contributions. My shadow Minister came to meet me. I said: `I am very pleased to meet you. You get your pension after you have been here for three terms'. He said: `I have been here for four now'. I said: `Well, where have you been?'. He said: `I am a Tasmanian'. I said: `You are supposed to come up here to the Parliament when you are elected'.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the question be now put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question put:
That the motion (Mr Howard's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF THE PARLIAMENTARY REPORTING STAFF

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the annual report of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff for the year 1984-85.

—Pursuant to Standing Order 18, I lay on the table my warrant nominating the honourable member for Dundas to act as Deputy Chairman of Committees when requested so to do by the Chairman of Committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to sections 6 and 7 of the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973, I present the Remuneration Tribunal 1985 Review.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Kerin) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.
Debate (on motion by Mr N. A. Brown) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMITTEE OF REVIEW INTO ABORIGINAL EMPLOYMENT AND TRAINING PROGRAMS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members I present the report of the Committee of Review into Aboriginal Employment and Training Programs.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.
Debate (on motion by Mr N. A. Brown) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members I present the resolutions of the 122nd meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council, held in Darwin on 21 July 1985.
—For the information of honourable members I present the resolutions of the 15th meeting of the Australian Fisheries Council, held in Darwin on 21 July 1985.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members I present an information paper on the outlook for the aviation industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.
Debate (on motion by Mr N. A. Brown) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Lalor-Minister for Science)-For the information of honourable members I present the National Research Fellowships Advisory Committee report on fellowships awarded for 1984 and 1985.
—Mr Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—I think the honourable member seeks to make a personal explanation on the ground that he has been misrepresented. I allow him indulgence to continue.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. In an article on the front page of yesterday's Sun-News Pictorial headed `Tax rift: PM calls in chiefs', by Niki Savva-unfortunately not referring to me as one of the chiefs-there is reference to comments that I allegedly made in the Caucus meeting the previous day. Having regard to the age of the people in the gallery, I shall not record the alleged remarks in accurate detail. Suffice to say that the swear words attributed to me were not used by me either in the Caucus meeting or in any other meeting.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Small Businesses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth.
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not ``windfall gains'' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell their business to sustain them in retirement;

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Fife,Mr McArthur and Mr Miles.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established which will work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all, fulfilling employment, a sustainable society conserving natural resources and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Create an Australian Ministry for Peace specifically devoted to peace-building and the non-violent resolution of conflict;
2. Convene a national Summit for Survival to discuss the issues of world disarmament, security and national and internatioal co-operation;
3. Fully support the United Nations World Disarmament Campaign by allocating the equivalent of at least 10% of the defence budget to fund peace activities;
4. Actively assist the International Year of Peace in 1986 by initiating programs for peace education, self help development and environmental repair;
5. Develop National Employment Programs to give priority to the planting and growing of forests, food-producing trees and other crops;

6. Implement National Recycling Programs to reuse water and to compost all presently wasted sewage-sludge and organic garbage into hygienic humus, a natural fertiliser, for use in rehabilitating impoverished soils;
7. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dobie,Mr Sinclair and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established which will work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
2. Implement Action Programs leading up to 1989 which will include:
(a) Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.

(b) Implementing National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost into hygienic humus all presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground powder from mineral rich and rocks, to use as a natural fertiliser in revitalising impoverished soils;

(c) Developing National Employment Programs to give priority to irrigation systems and the planting and growing of healthy forests, food producing trees and other crops and vegetation to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr John Brown,Mr Carlton,Ms Fatin,Mr Hollis and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Child Care Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, the Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the recent cuts announced in the Mini-Budget to Preschools and Day Care Services are a reversal of A.L.P. policy to make child care services available to all at an affordable cost. Further, that the fee rises arising from the cuts will cause great hardship to the majority of families using these services.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House fully restores all Federal funding to children's service in Australia, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Carlton,Mr Simmons and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Private Health Insurance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth:
That we the undersigned are totally opposed to any taxation change which involves a tax on Health Fund contributions, health charges or benefits;

That we are already required to pay a 1 per cent levy to partly finance the Medicare scheme and that we would regard any futher taxation of our health insurance arrangements as unfair and unreasonable;
That therefore we urge the Government to ensure that there is no taxation on illness and no special taxation on those who seek to insure themselves against the cost of private health care.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dobie,Mr Fife and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The proposed service tax on all accommodation provided by hotels and the proposals to disallow legitimate entertainment expenses as a deduction for taxation purposes will lead to a dramatic fall-off in tourism, business travel and will have a deleterious effect on restaurant patronage. This will threaten present employment and extensively curtail job opportunities in the Industry.
Measures as proposed will seriously jeopardise the livelihood of Australians engaged in the Accommodation and Hospitality Industry.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that a service tax not be imposed on short-stay accommodation and that a deduction for tax purposes for legitimate entertainment expenses remain. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew and Mr Hodges.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Price
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble Petition of the South Australian Country Women's Association Incorporated and the undersigned shall showeth:
The necessity to restore the concessional price of fuel in rural areas-without which there will be increased freight and production costs.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will restore concessional price of fuel in rural areas for the benefit of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew and Mr Porter.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
