Let me go through some of the details of the package that has been announced by the Treasurer. Naturally, in the time available it is not possible to make a comprehensive response to all of them. We welcome the reductions in marginal rates of tax and also the steps towards relieving the double taxation of dividends. Let me remind the Treasurer--

TALK.START.PARA: —How would you pay for them?
—I say to the honourable member for Maribyrnong: Hang on; do not get too excited; all in good time.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Treasurer that a start towards relieving the double taxation of dividends was made in 1982. One of the first acts of the Hawke Government when it got into power was to put that proposal on the back burner. The Government now thinks it is a terrific idea and it is parading itself as being the friend of small business for doing it. It is a bit like its opposition to the special deduction for self-employed superannuation. That was said in 1980 to be a bankrolling of our financial supporters. The Government in the last Budget increased that deduction from $1,200 to $1,500-another initiative that it has introduced!

Let me make it perfectly clear that we welcome those steps. We would have financed those changes in a different manner. I go back to what was said in our taxation policy statement before the last election. We have said all along that the Governmnent has paid insufficient regard to expenditure restraint and expenditure reduction in this whole taxation reform exercise. I also repeat the commitment which is contained in that taxation policy towards a greater dependence on indirect taxation and a lessening of our excessive reliance on direct personal taxation as a source of revenue. Honourable members opposite may ask me what alternative approach we would take to funding those measures. It is based upon our well-known approach in those areas.

I have indicated to the House the attitude of the Opposition towards the introduction of a capital gains tax and our commitments on that-made recently and foreshadowed during the election campaign-are reaffirmed today. The Treasurer would have us believe, and we were led to believe before the tax package was announced, that the rationalisation of the wholesale taxation system would be revenue neutral. I simply remind the House that the rationalisation of the wholesale tax system will increase indirect tax revenue by about $125m. That ought to be kept in mind by those who simply see it as being a rationalisation of the wholesale taxation system.

By far one of the most controversial aspects of the taxation package announced by the Treasurer is the proposals that he has introduced in the fringe benefit area. Let me say on behalf of the Opposition that, when these proposals were first mooted in the White Paper, we described them as a discriminatory jackbooted approach to the problem of fringe benefits, and the form in which they have emerged today does not require us to alter that description one iota. They represent in the eyes of many a de facto tax on employment and a de facto payroll tax. They will have an anti-employment effect and a particularly severe effect on the operations of many small businesses throughout Australia. It is simply a cop-out to the trade union movement for the Government to impose this tax on so many private sector employers around Australia. It will not have much success in explaining to the general public that it will be able to treat people in public sector employment in precisely the same way as it treats people in private sector employment. The Government will hear over the weeks and months ahead a great deal more about this fringe benefits proposal. It is going to understand that its proposals for changes in that area will reach far beyond the areas of the Australian economy and the Australian society than it ever imagined.

One could be forgiven for being a trifle cynical when one turns to the paragraph dealing with the gold tax. We are going to have an inquiry into the gold tax, and it is going to report in six months time. I wonder what will have happened between now and the end of the `six months time'. Honourable members opposite are laughing in their embarrassment. We might almost call it the Western Australian election paragraph. I say to the voters of Western Australia right here and now that that is the most cynical element of the taxation White Paper. Every voter in Western Australia ought to be on notice now that Burke and Hawke got together. Brian said to Bob: `Can you put it off until after the election?' Bob said: `When is the election going to be?' Brian said: `It is going to be on such and such a date.' Bob said: `Oh, I know. We will have an inquiry. We will do something original. We will have an inquiry and we will put off the tax until after the election has been held'. Either the Labor Party is in favour of the tax or against it. Without question, that is the most cynical exercise that I have ever seen it engaged in.

As we move on, and once again applying the test of consistency, looking back at what the Government and the Opposition have said in the past, I note that there is a total absence from this statement by the Treasurer of any reference to the impact of these taxation changes on Australian families. Where is the reference to the need to improve the lot of the single income family with young children? There is no such reference at all in this statement. It is supposed to be the most comprehensive taxation reform package that we have seen since Federation, but the single income family with young children, or, for that matter, the double income family with young children, does not rate a word. Not a word is contained in the statement about the impact of these taxation changes on Australian families. Is there any reference to the need for income splitting? Is there any reference to the provision of tax deductibility for child care expenses in recognition that now almost 50 per cent of married women in Australia with dependent children are part of the work force? Is there any reference in the Treasurer's speech to the need to facilitate a choice amongst middle and lower income Australian families with young children as to whether they will be single or double income families? Of course there is not. There are plenty of references to tax avoidance and tax evasion but there is no reference at all to the need to provide a more sympathetic taxation system as far as Australian families are concerned.

But it is not only Australian families who, I think, will feel neglected by many elements of the Treasurer's speech. I also believe that the combined effect of the proposals contained in the speech, despite the attempts by the Treasurer to soften the blow in a number of areas, will be greeted with a great deal of trepidation and gloom within the length and breadth of rural Australia. The effect of these proposals, particularly the imposition of a capital gains tax, will be felt. It is all very well for the Treasurer to say that it will yield only $25m after five years. One may well ask: If it going to yield only $25m after five years, why on earth go to the trouble of imposing it? It is just some kind of blind ideological hang-up that the Government has about the introduction of a capital gains tax. It is not only the revenue yield from a capital gains tax that is important; it is also the depressing effect that it will have on investment expectations and on small business and farmers throughout Australia. That effect will be felt, and it will be resented throughout the rural community.

It is no good talking about how the Government has taken out all the nasty parts. Take the example of group of people who are getting a return of about 2 or 3 per cent of their investment. They are seeing their markets around the world disappearing in front of their eyes. They are facing the greatest cost burdens that the farmers of Australia have faced since Federation. The Government says to them: `You ought to be happy and you ought to break out into applause because it is not quite as bad as you thought it was going to be'. If honourable members opposite think that it will satisfy the farmers and the rural community in Australia, I think they have another think coming. The rural community in Australia is a wake up to the sort of con trick that is represented by that, just as it has been a wake up to the costs that are imposed on it by the Government's rotten centralised wage fixation system which takes absolutely no account of the difficulties of different industries throughout Australia; and just as they are a wake up to the way in which the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions have got together over the Mudginberri dispute and are denying individual Australians the right to make a decision that benefits their own destiny.

An area of the Government's announcement that will also be approached with a great deal of trepidation throughout the rural community is of course its attack which parades under that great catchcry of getting rid of the Pitt Street farmers, or should I say the Pitt Street-Collins Street farmers. The Government would have us believe that every person in Australia who sets off losses on farm income against income in another area is a Pitt Street farmer. The reality is that there are tens of thousands of farmers in Australia who have to get non-farm income to survive, and that is the reason why there has been such an extensive resort to this offsetting of income. True it is that the quarantining measures are not quite as severe as was canvassed in the White Paper, but the reality is that these proposals will have an effect on many bona fide farmers who have had to get off their farms merely to get income from other sources simply to survive and keep their families going. Anybody who understands the plight of rural Australia at present will know that everything I have said on that subject is absolutely correct.

Let me also say this of Pitt Street farmers and of the ideological descriptions that are used in relation to people who invest in rural Australia. Undoubtedly there are tax advantages in it. I know that and everybody in the Parliament knows that. But what we have to do is net out the costs and losses in things like this, and we have to ask ourselves whether Australia would have been a better place had we not had the huge investment in rural Australia by many of these people over the last 10 or 20 years. There are many people, not just those interested in preserving these benefits, who believe that implementation of the proposals advanced by the Government will have a devastating effect on land values throughout rural Australia. It will be on the head of this Government and this Treasurer that, on top of the misery of disappearing markets only two years out of the worst drought we have had since Federation and all the other costs problems that those in rural Australia have to suffer at present, the Hawke-Keating Government has visited on them a measure which will have a devastating effect on their land values. If the Government wants to live with that and if its Ministers want to go round the farms and country areas of Australia and argue their case, they are welcome. I can promise on behalf of the coalition that there will be speaker after speaker to match them on every platform throughout rural Australia, because they do no understand, they have never understood, the farmers and primary producers of Australia, and by this speech today they demonstrate that they never will.

The cynicism and the contradictions of the Government do not end there. We have the proposition that negative gearing is wrong and that more than a limited amount of non-farm income cannot be set off against farm income, yet in another part of the statement the Government is facilitating the exact opposite. It is going to make it easier-and I do not object to this-for petroleum and mining companies to merge their losses and their profits from different sources of endeavour. In other words, it is going to facilitate group taxation in that area, yet in relation to farmers and those who invest in property through negative gearing it is going to do the exact opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do they hate the farmers?

—That represents a valid question. Why are those opposite so insensitive towards Australian farmers? The contradictions, the cynicism and the blind subservience to ideology simply do not end there. As one goes through the statement made by the Treasurer one finds that there is not a commitment to the fundamental reform of the Australian taxation system, that is, to reduce our excessive reliance on direct personal taxation. The Treasurer, by his statements at the Tax Summit and in his speeches in the lead-up to the Tax Summit, has demonstrated that he knows that is the great and fundamental reform of the taxation system that needs to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: Another area where I think the Treasurer has demonstrated that he simply does not understand is the proposal to introduce a foreign tax credits system. When I was Treasurer in 1978 I proposed, on advice I then received, the introduction of that system, and I put it out for public discussion. I had a large number of representations. I cannot recall when, in the time I was Treasurer, I had a greater volume of representations from the total cross-section of the Australian business community than I had on that particular issue. The uniform plea that I had from Australian business on that issue was that if I introduced a foreign tax credit system I would hamper economic investment and expansion of Australian enterprise in the area of the Association of South East Asian Nations and in South East Asia.

With great respect to the Treasurer-and I do not say this with any sense of rhetoric-comparisons with the United Kingdom and the United States on this issue simply are not relevant. It is of enormous long term importance to Australia strategically, economically and politically that we multiply our links with the South East Asian area. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), to his great credit, has spent a lot of time extolling the virtues of a new vision, of a new relationship between Australia and China. I say to the Prime Minister: `If you introduce a foreign tax credit system you will do more to damage the potential economic relationship between Australia and China and you will do more to damage investment by Australian companies in countries like Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia'.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you are wrong.

—Frankly those countries are more important to our foreign policy than many of the countries with which the Foreign Minister (Mr Hayden) is currently pre-occupied. I genuinely ask the Treasurer to reconsider that particular proposal. It seems clever. It seems smart. It seems the right thing to do. It is all done in the name of anti-avoidance. But what it will do is deny the availability of many of the tax breaks and tax incentives in these developing countries to people who are prepared to invest their dollars. I should feel comfortable that I am totally wrong. I am assured by the former South Australian Attorney-General, the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan), who really is a whiz when it comes to these sorts of investment decisions, that everything is absolutely right and I need not have any worries. I have to say to the honourable member that I, many on this side of the House, the Australian business community and people on the ground in these countries are very worried about a proposal that has the potential to deny to them the tax incentives and inducements available in these countries to encourage overseas investment. I think it will be a great shame if Australia falls behind in that and does not take every advantage to diversify and multiply her economic as well as her political links with those countries.

SPEECH.PARA: As I indicated at the outset of this statement, given all the detail and the enormous number of subjects that have been canvassed in the Treasurer's statement, it is not possible in the short time I have had it to give a comprehensive reply to each and every detail, but of course we are going to have plenty of opportunity over the weeks ahead. We are scuttling and running tonight. The Parliament is not sitting tomorrow. We are not sitting next week. Well may those opposite scuttle and run tonight after the pathetic performance of their Prime Minister at Question Time. But we will be coming back and those opposite will be hearing a great deal more from us about this taxation package.

I simply conclude on the point on which I commenced: This statement may contain the largest number of announcements and the largest number of changes to the Australian taxation system that a Treasurer has announced for many years, but according to not only our criteria but also his own criteria this is not a comprehensive reform of the Australian taxation system. In our view, if fully implemented, it will do lasting damage to many sections of rural Australia and to many sections of the small business community. Most damming of all, the taxation package that the Treasurer has just announced not only fails the criteria laid down by the Opposition and by other people in the community it also fails the criteria that he himself laid down with such bold language only a few months ago. According to his own test, which is the most important test of all, the Treasurer has failed to deliver fundamental reform of the Australian taxation system.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Dr Blewett, for Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Earlier today the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced a number of significant initiatives, as part of the Government's tax reform package, that will rationalise the structure and broaden the scope of the present wholesale sales tax system. This is the main Bill in a series of 11 Bills that will amend the sales tax law to give effect to those rationalisation and base broadening measures.

At this stage it would perhaps be useful to honourable members if I were to outline briefly the changes to be made by these Bills. First, the wholesale sales tax base is to be broadened, principally with the intention of reducing anomalies by subjecting to tax certain goods that are presently exempt. Secondly, the rate of sales tax payable on records and sound and video tapes, a number of household and personal care items and certain other goods is to be substantially reduced. Finally, several classification anomalies and inconsistencies that presently exist in the sales tax law are to be rectified.

The Bills will also effect some rationalisation in the present multiple rate structure of the wholesale sales tax by reducing from four to three the number of rates that apply to various goods. The Bills will also give effect to the Government's decision, announced in the 1985-86 Budget Speech, to provide an exemption from sales tax for horses imported into Australia after 20 August 1985. The opportunity is also being taken to make several technical changes and to correct certain drafting errors associated with amendments of the sales tax law enacted earlier this year. Taken together, these measures are estimated to produce a net revenue gain in 1985-86 of $75m and $110m in a full year.
I turn now to discuss in detail the changes to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act proposed by this Bill.
BASE BROADENING MEASURES

The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act is a key element in the legislative structure of the wholesale sales tax. Its first Schedule describes all classes of goods that are exempt from the tax. It also contains five further schedules that specify goods or classes of goods that are taxable at the rates specified in the sales tax Acts. Goods that are not described in any of those six schedules are taxable at the general rate of tax. That rate is presently 20 per cent.

Confectionery is presently taxable at the 20 per cent general rate. This Bill will specifically include confectionery in the third Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. The effect of this, together with certain changes to the rates Acts that I propose to introduce shortly, will be to reduce the rate of tax payable on confectionery items from 20 per cent to 10 per cent.

There is, however, a wide range of goods that are non-staple food items and close substitutes for taxable confectionery that is presently exempt from sales tax. These goods, that might generically be described as snack foods, include potato crisps, nuts, ice creams, flavoured ice blocks and most biscuits. These goods are often used in substitution for confectionery and compete for sales in the market place with it. In order to remove inequities in taxation treatment between confectionery and snack foods, the Government has decided to bring snack foods within the sales tax base. These goods will be taxed at the same rate-that is, 10 per cent-that will after today apply to confectionery.

I turn now to the other base broadening measures in this Bill. Goods that are ordinarily used for household purposes are presently subject to tax at the rate of 7.5 per cent. Examples of these goods, that are included in the third Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act, are refrigerators, washing machines and portable cooking appliances. There are, however, a number of other similar goods such as domestic stoves and ranges and water heating and storage equipment that are specifically exempt from sales tax by reason of their inclusion in the first Schedule to that Act. This Bill will bring the sales tax treatment of all these household goods into line by incorporating them in the existing third Schedule. I will shortly introduce further Bills to set the rate of tax for goods in this Schedule at 10 per cent.

Various goods presently exempt from sales tax will, by virtue of the changes proposed in this Bill, also become taxable at the proposed rate of 10 per cent by reason of their inclusion in the third Schedule. These include wrapping materials, bags and fastening materials for domestic or household use, water filtering and sterilising equipment and books of maps.
HIGH RATE GOODS

The second Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act specifies goods that are presently taxable at the highest rate of 32.5 per cent. Many of the goods covered by the second Schedule are everyday household or personal care items. Other goods in that Schedule, such as totalisators, are more akin to computers that are taxable at the lower 20 per cent rate.

Consistent with the Government's broad objective of rationalising the wholesale sales tax system, this Bill will remove a range of these goods from the second Schedule. As the goods to be omitted will no longer be specified in any schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act they will generally fall to be taxed at the lower rate of 20 per cent. Some goods will, however, remain in the second Schedule and fall to be taxed at the rate of 30 per cent-a reduction of 2.5 percentage points. Among the goods that will in future be taxed at the 30 per cent rate are jewellery, furs and fur garments, cosmetics, television and radio receivers, video recorders, photographic equipment, watches, clocks and gambling and amusement machines.
ANOMALIES AND INCONSISTENCIES

The need to specify in the law and in some detail the various goods and classes of goods that are subject to sales tax at differing rates has led to anomalies arising from time to time as new and changed products come onto the market. Unless corrected, the existence of such anomalies involves particular goods, et cetera, being taxed at higher rates than broadly comparable products or close substitutes. For example, while tea as ordinarily understood is exempt from sales tax, herbal teas are taxable. Anomalies of this kind have, by governments past and present, regularly been addressed by amending legislation.

In yet other cases, goods which ought in logic to be taxable are exempt, often because of drafting defects or oversights in specifying the category of goods to be exempt or taxable. For example, ships and vessels designed for use for private purposes such as pleasure or recreation are generally taxable. If however, a ship or vessel is purchased to be used for private transport or accommodation, it is exempt from tax. The Bill will correct these and a number of other anomalies, details of which are contained in the explanatory memorandum.
IMPORTED HORSES

As part of the Government's 1985-86 Budget, the Treasurer announced several measures to assist the Australian horse racing industry. This Bill will give effect to the decision to exempt from sales tax horses imported into Australia after 20 August 1985.

Finally, I take this opportunity to announce the Government's decision to exempt from sales tax earth stations, designed to receive the household and community broadcasting satellite services, that are purchased after today for domestic use to receive that service. This proposal is not contained in this Bill. However, the Government proposes to move an amendment during the Committee stage of debate on the Bill to give effect to its decision.
ANTI-AVOIDANCE PROVISIONS

The amendments of the sales tax law that I have just outlined for honourable members will come into effect from midnight tonight. Sadly, there are still those in the community who may, between the time when these measures were announced by the Treasurer and midnight tonight, enter into transactions in order to avoid sales tax liabilities resulting from classification and rate changes which would clearly arise after midnight. Against that possibility, I mention that anit-avoidance provisions designed to protect the revenue from such last minute transactions are included in the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985 which I will introduce shortly.

An explanatory memorandum containing detailed explanations of technical aspects of the Bill is being circulated to honourable members, I do not, therefore, propose to further address the matters covered by this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (Nos 1-4 and 6-9) AMENDMENT BILLS 1985SALES TAX (No. 5) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills presented by Dr Blewett, for Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.

Under the present structure of the sales tax legislation, each of the Sales Tax Assessment Acts (Nos 1-9) has a complementary taxing Act. These taxing Acts impose the sales tax and prescribe the rates of tax payable in respect of goods. The rate depends on the particular Schedule, if any, of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act, that the goods may be listed in.

These nine Bills will amend the sales tax Acts to rationalise the wholesale sales tax rate structure by reducing the number of rate categories from four to three. The specific changes are as follows. Goods that continue to be covered by the Second Schedule of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act will, under these Bills, be subject to tax at the new rate of 30 per cent. As I mentioned in my second reading speech on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill goods including jewellery, furs, cosmetics and certain electronic equipment will be in this category. At the same time, the Bills will increase the rate of tax payable on goods covered by the third Schedule to that Act from 7.5 per cent to 10 per cent.

Finally, the Bills will reimpose tax at the existing rates on goods covered by the Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Schedules to that Act, as well as goods that are subject to tax at the general rate. Details of these Bills are also set out in the explanatory memorandum that is being circulated to honourable members. I commend the Bills to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Dr Blewett, for Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This is the last Bill in this series of 11 Bills. This Bill will amend several sales tax statutes to make a number of technical changes and correct certain drafting errors that have been identified in connection with anti-avoidance amendments of the sales tax law enacted earlier this year. In this area, the amendments proposed by this Bill are, without exception, not substantive in nature.

The Bill will also make consequential changes to the sales tax regulations to `mirror' changes, associated with the imposition of tax at the 10 per cent rate on biscuits and ice cream products, that are to be made by the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1985.

As I mentioned earlier, when introducing the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1985, this Bill contains an anti-avoidance provision that will strike down last minute transactions carried out by persons in an attempt to avoid a liability for sales tax that would arise out of the amendments of the sales tax law being made by these Bills. The explanatory memorandum being circulated to honourable members also contains detailed explanations of the technical aspects of this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill is the first in a package of four Bills. It will amend the various taxation laws in several respects. The Bill proposes amendments of the income tax law to give effect to the Government's decisions to counter the use of non-leveraged finance leases and similar arrangements to achieve tax benefits. It will introduce statutory loan back rules that employer sponsored superannuation funds will be required to follow to secure relevant tax concessions.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill will also give effect to a number of the Government's 1985-86 Budget proposals. Among these is the increase in two superannuation related monetary limits that apply for income tax purposes. Further, it will authorise income tax deductions for gifts made to the Australian Academy of the Humanities and to the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists.

The Bill will amend the income tax law to allow a deduction of up to $1,000 per election for expenses incurred by candidates contesting elections to local government or to the Australian Captial Territory House of Assembly. One of the three measures this Government has announced to assist the horse racing industry-the exemption from income tax of the income of animal racing clubs-will be given effect by this Bill. For persons wholly or mainly dependent on social security, unemployment sickness or special benefits, the Bill will increase the income threshold below which they will not be required to pay tax.

As is customary at Budget time, this Bill will also provide the basis for calculation of provisional tax for the 1985-86 year of income. Also included in the Bill are the amendments to give effect to the measure announced on 17 July 1985 to replace the existing concessional expenditure rebate for eligible expenditure exceeding $2,000 with a rebate for net medical expenses exceeding $1,000. The Bill will also amend the Taxation Administration Act to provide for co-operation with the States and the Territories in the administration of their revenue laws.

The secrecy provisions of various taxation laws administered by the Commission of Taxation are to be amended to cover persons such as those from country performing duties while on attachment to the Australian Taxation Office. Finally, the Bill will make a number or minor technical amendments of the taxation laws.
I now turn to outline in more detail the more significant measures contained in the Bill.
Non-leveraged Finance Leasing and Similar Arrangements

Measures announced on 15 May and 16 December 1984 to treat, for income tax purposes, certain non-leveraged finance leases and similar arrangements as though they were loans by the lessor to enable the lessee or user to acquire the leased property are to be implemented by this Bill. Under the arrangements in question, the lessor passes on to a lessee such as a tax exempt body, in the form or lower lease rentals, some of the tax benefits that would be available to the body if it owned the property and were subject to tax. At the same time, the tax exempt body assumes most of the risks and benefits associated with ownership of the leased property.

By amendments proposed in the Bill, the lessor will be denied income tax deduction in respect of capital expenditure on property that is the subject of such an arrangement. Instead, the lease payment made to the lessor will be treated as consisting of non-taxable repayments of principal and taxable repayments of principal and taxable payments of interest. Deductions for interest on moneys borrowed to fund the captial expenditure will not be affected.

These measures will mean that the tax advantages, and therefore substantial revenue losses, associated with the use of these arrangements will be removed. In more detail, the measures are to apply where plant, equipment or other property is leased under a finance lease either to a government or tax exempt government authority or to a person who uses the property outside Australia to produce income that is not subject to Australian income tax. They will also apply where such property, although not leased is the subject of an arragement having the hallmarks of a finance lease.

The amending legislation contains tests as to whether an arrangement is a finance lease or similar arrangement. These tests are based on those developed for accounting and commercial purposes and are aimed at determining whether all, or substantially all, of the risks and benefits associated with ownership of the subject property are transferred from the lessor to the lessee. It is estimated that the measures will result in a tax saving in excess of $100m in 1985-86 and even larger amounts in subsequent years.
Statutory Loan-back Rules

This Bill will give effect to the Government's decision, announced on 11 March 1985, to introduce statutory rules to apply to certain investments by employer sponsored superannuation funds. That decision reflects the Government's concern that excessive investment by a superannuation fund in the sponsoring employer's business may mean in the event of the failure of that business, that employees lose not only their jobs but also their superannuation entitlements. This concern was shared by the Commonwealth Task Force on Occupational Superannuation, the Asprey Taxation Review Committee, the Hancock National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry and the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System.

The basic rule contained in the Bill adopts the recommendation of the Commonwealth Task Force. This is that not more than 10 per cent of the assets, measured at cost, of an employer sponsored superannuation fund should consist of equities in, or loans to, the employer or associated persons or entities. For funds established after 11 March 1985, that basic rule is first to apply for the 1985-86 year of income.

For funds in existence at 11 March 1985, a special transitional rule will apply over the 10-year period ending with the 1994-95 year of income. The special transitional rule will limit employer investment by such a fund to the greater of 10 per cent of the fund's assets or the level of investment as at 11 March 1985. That rule will allow those funds in existence at 11 March 1985, that would otherwise breach the 10 per cent investment restriction, to comply with the basic rule by way of natural growth, so avoiding significant refinancing problems for some businesses.

In announcing the Government's decision to introduce statutory loan-back rules for employer sponsored superannuation funds, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) stated that the consequences of non-compliance would be that the investment income of the fund would be taxed at the rate of 60 per cent, that employer contributions would not be deductible and that member contributions would be neither deductible nor rebatable. The no rebate consequence for member contributions is no longer relevant following the Government's decision to abolish the concessional expenditure rebate. The no deduction consequence for both employer and member contributions will, however, remain.

On further consideration the Government has decided that the announced penalty tax rate of 60 per cent on the investment income of non-complying funds is inappropriate. Having regard to the non-deductibility of contributions and to the fact that payments to members-either in the form of pensions or lump sum termination payments-will be subject to tax, it has been decided that a more appropriate rate of tax is 30 per cent. That rate is being imposed by another Bill that I will introduce shortly. The new rules are not there for revenue raising purposes but are designed to protect members' benefits by encouraging superannuation funds to restrict the level of their investments in sponsoring employers.The amendments should therefore have little effect on the revenue.
Superannuation Contributions

The Bill will give effect to a 1985-86 Budget proposal to increase from $1,200 to $1,500 the maximum annual income tax deduction allowable for contributions to approved superannuation funds by self-employed persons or employees not covered by employer-funded schemes. The increase is to apply for the 1985-86 and subsequent income years. The estimated revenue cost of this measure is nil in 1985-86, $14m in 1986-87 and $10m in 1987-88.
Lump Sum Termination Payments

The Bill will also increase the amount of lump sum superannuation and kindred payments relating to the period after 30 June 1983 that is taxed at the concessional rate of not more than 15 per cent. Under the existing law, the first $50,000 of such payments made to a person aged 55 or more qualifies for the 15 per cent rate of tax.

As announced in the 1985-86 Budget, that limit is being increased to $55,000 for the 1985-86 and subsequent income years. This particular measure will cost an estimated $500,000 in 1985-86, increasing to $8m per annum in future years when relevant payments are wholly attributable to the period after 30 June 1983.
Concessional Expenditure Rebate and Medical Expenses Rebate

The draft White Paper on tax reform canvassed the abolition of the concessional expenditure rebate and its replacement with a rebate for medical expenses. On 17 July 1985 the Treasurer announced that the Government had decided to proceed with this proposal in relation to the 1985-86 and subsequent income years. This Bill will give effect to that decision.

As indicated at that time, only about 6 per cent of taxpayers incur sufficient expenses to benefit from the concessional expenditure rebate. It was also noted that most of the items under the rebate already receive substantial government assistance in other ways and that it was therefore inappropriate to provide assistance to a small section of the community by way of a tax rebate.

However, the Government also recognised a continuing need for some assistance to those incurring high unreimbursed medical expenses and has therefore decided to introduce a new medical expense rebate for net outgoings exceeding $1,000. This rebate will apply to the existing range of medical expenses which form part of the concessional expenditure rebate, including payments to medical practitioners, nurses, hospitals and chemists in respect of an illness or operation and payments for dental and optical treatment. The decision to abolish the concessional rebate requires some consequential amendments, one of which I particularly draw to the attention of honourable members.

Under existing arrangements the first $250 of the net amount of self-education expenses necessarily incurred in connection with a prescribed course of education is absorbed by the concessional expenditure rebate provisions, leaving the general deduction provision of the income tax law, where it has application, to allow a deduction only for the balance of such expenditure. Provisions in this Bill will ensure that, with the abolition of the concessional expenditure rebate, a taxpayer's entitlement to a deduction for relevant self-education expenses will continue to fall for consideration under the general deduction provision of the income tax law only to the extent that such expenses exceed $250. The net gain to revenue from these measures is estimated at $15m for 1985-86 and $60m in 1986-87 and subsequent years.
Animal Racing Clubs

The Treasurer in his Budget Speech foreshadowed three measures designed to assist the horse racing industry. This Bill will give effect to one of those measures by amending the income tax law to exempt from income tax the income derived by animal racing clubs. The exemption will apply primarily to horse and greyhound racing clubs. Consistent with the exemption currently applying to clubs conducting athletic sports, it will not apply to clubs the activities of which are predominantly social in nature or are carried on for the purposes of profit or gain to individual members. The exemption is to apply for the 1985-86 and subsequent years of income. The estimated revenue cost of this measure is nil in 1985-86 and $1m for a full year.
Local Government Election Expenses

This Bill will implement the Budget proposal to allow, in 1985-86 and subsequent income years, a deduction of up to $1,000 for expenditure incurred in contesting local government elections. The deduction will also be available to candidates for the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly.

The present income tax law includes in assessable income the amount of any election expenditure that has been allowed as a deduction to a candidate for this Parliament or a State parliament and which is reimbursed or paid on the candidate's behalf. Similar provisions are included in this Bill in relation to candidates for local government elections.

However, because of the $1,000 ceiling proposed, the provisions in this Bill will effectively ensure that relevant payments will be included in a candidate's assessable income only to the extent that they exceed the amount of total expenditure incurred in relation to a particular election which has not been allowed as a deduction. The Budget announcement on this matter indicated that the allowance of a deduction for election expenses would be subject to verification of the expenditure.

Provisions to this effect are not contained in this Bill but will be taken up in the context of the substantiation rules the Treasurer announced in his statement on tax reform. It is estimated that the cost of this measure will be nil in 1985-86 and $2m in a full year.
Social Security Beneficiary Rebates

As announced in the Budget Speech, the maximum rebates of tax and the taxable income levels at which the rebates begin to shade-out for taxpayers in receipt of social security unemployment, sickness or special benefits, are to be increased with effect from 1 July 1985. The rebates will continue to ensure that persons wholly or mainly dependent on social security benefits do not have to pay tax.

For married beneficiaries the maximum rebate will be increased from $75 to $220 and no tax will be payable in 1985-86 on taxable incomes up to $8,795. For other beneficiaries the maximum rebate will increase from $50 to $170 and no tax will be payable on taxable incomes up to $5,275.

The rebates will shade out above those income levels, resulting in some rebate being available until the 1985-86 taxable income exceeds $10,555 for married beneficiaries and $6,635 for other beneficiaries. The cost to revenue of this measure is estimated as nil for 1985-86 and $9m for a full year.
Gifts

The Bill will amend the gift provisions of the income tax law to give effect to the decision announced in the 1985-86 Budget to allow deductions for gifts made after 20 August 1985 to the Australian Academy of the Humanities and to the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists. The cost to revenue of this measure is estimated at nil for 1985-86 and less than $200,000 in a full year.
Sitting suspended from 6.29 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I turn to provisional tax for 1985-86. As provisional tax is part of the pay as you earn system and is designed to collect tax on income other than salary and wage income within the year in which the income is derived, it is generally accepted that the amount of provisional tax charged should approximate as closely as practicable the amount of tax actually imposed for the year. Incomes for 1985-86 are expected to be higher than for 1984-85 and, due to the changes to the personal income tax rate scale that applied from 1 November 1984, effective rates of tax for 1985-86 will be lower than for last year. Accordingly, as in past years, it is proposed to vary the basis of calculating provisional tax for 1985-86 to be notified in assessment notices to issue this year.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill provides for 1985-86 provisional tax to be calculated on the basis of 1984-85 taxable income increased by 11 per cent and applying the lower rates of tax for 1985-86. Also reflected in the provisional tax calculation will be the Medicare levy of one per cent. The removal of the ceiling on the maximum amount of levy payable by a taxpayer or by a married couple and the increased low income thresholds to apply for levy purposes in 1985-86 will be taken into account. Generally rebates and credits will be allowed in the provisional tax calculation at the levels allowed in 1984-85 assessments.

However, the concessional expenditure rebate allowed to a taxpayer in 1984-85 will not be allowed in the provisional tax calculation. This rebate is to be removed effective for 1985-86 and subsequent years. Taxpayers will continue to have the right to `self-assess' and have the provisional tax for 1985-86 recalculated on the basis of their own estimates in appropriate circumstances.
Co-operation between Commonwealth, State and Territory Revenue Authorities

Measures announced on 20 December 1983 to assist the States and the Northern Territory to counter avoidance and evasion of State and Territory taxes are contained in the Bill. The Commissioner of Taxation is to be empowered, on request by a State or the Northern Territory revenue authority, to authorise a Commonwealth, State or Northern Territory taxation officer to conduct in the Australian Capital Territory an investigation for the purposes of a State or Northern Territory taxation law. For that purpose, the authorised officer will have investigation powers similar to those a Commonwealth taxation officer has for Commonwealth purposes. The Commissioner will also be able to require persons to furnish information or produce documents that are relevant to such an investigation. State and Northern Territory taxation officers will be under the obligation to maintain secrecy in relation to information obtained while undertaking investigations in the Australian Capital Territory. The Commissioner will further be authorised to provide Commonwealth taxation information to State and Territory taxation officers to enable them to administer their laws, if those laws provide reciprocal rights for the Commissioner. For the purposes of these co-operative measures, the Bill provides that, in proceedings relating to Federal taxation laws, an appropriately certified true copy of, or extract from, an original document that is obtained under a State, Territory or Commonwealth taxation law will generally be admissible as evidence as if it were the original document. To ensure that these measures are fully effective, it will be necessary for the States and the Northern Territory to introduce complementary legislation. The practical application of co-operation will require some Australian Taxation Office resources, but the additional administrative costs should be offset by the revenue yield from reciprocal State and Territory co-operation.
Secrecy Provisions

Under the taxation secrecy provisions taxation officers are, except in carrying out their duties or in other specified circumstances, prohibited from disclosing confidential taxation information. That prohibition extends to all other persons appointed or employed by the Commonwealth. The income tax secrecy provisions were amended last year to ensure their application to persons such as those from overseas countries working in the Taxation Office under exchange arrangements. These persons are neither appointed nor employed by the Commonwealth.

The secrecy provisions of the various other laws administered by the Commissioner of Taxation are, by this Bill, to be amended in a similar fashion. The amendments will have no effect on the revenue. Broad explanations designed to give a guide to the provisions of the Bill are contained in part A of an explanatory memorandum being circulated to honourable members. A clause-by-clause explanation of each provision of the Bill contained in part B of the explanatory memorandum will be made available to honourable members in the next few days. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Dr Blewett, for Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This is an annual measure which formally imposes personal income tax rates for the current financial year. The rates imposed by this Bill are those declared for the 1985-86 financial year in the Income Tax (Rates) Act 1982. The rates for 1985-86 reflect, for the full year, the significant cuts in personal income tax which were announced in the 1984-85 Budget and have applied since 1 November 1984. The full year effect of those tax cuts will result in a reduction in tax payable, on equivalent taxable incomes, in 1985-86 assessments as compared with 1984-85 assessments.

A five-step tax scale applies. At the lower end of the scale for resident taxpayers, no tax is payable on taxable incomes up to $4,595. On taxable incomes in the range of $4,596 to $12,500 the rate is 25 per cent. In the range $12,501 to $19,500 the rate is 30 per cent and increases to 46 per cent in the range $19,501 to $28,000, to 48 per cent in the range $28,001 to $35,000 and to 60 per cent on income in excess of $35,000. These general rates also apply to non-residents who receive Australian social security and repatriation pensions that are taxable in Australia, or who were residents at any time during the income year. For all other non-resident taxpayers, the standard rate of 30 per cent applies to incomes up to $19,500 and the general rates apply to income above that level.

The rate of 46 per cent or higher continues to apply to certain types of income derived by some unmarried minors. Similarly, the $417 income threshold at which tax is payable by resident minors on that income and the associated shading-in arrangements remain unchanged. The full year effect of the tax scale will be reflected in provisional tax payable for 1985-86, which is also formally imposed by this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX (COMPANIES, CORPORATE UNIT TRUSTS AND SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Dr Blewett, for Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will formally impose income tax for 1985-86 on the 1984-85 taxable income of companies, registered organisations and unit trusts treated as companies for tax purposes. It also imposes tax on the current year taxable income of superannuation funds, ineligible approved deposit funds and trust income of non-resident company beneficiaries.

The rates of tax are also declared by the Bill. Except for the imposition of income tax at the rate of 30 per cent on the investment income or employer-sponsored superannuation funds that fail to meet the loan-back rules, the rates are the same as for 1984-85. The provisions of the Bill follow the format of other years and details of the various rates are set out in the explanatory memorandum that is being made available to honourable members. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Dr Blewett, for Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Medicare Levy Bill 1985 will declare the basic rate of Medicare levy for 1985-86 and, until the Parliament otherwise provides, for 1986-87. The basic rate will be one per cent of taxable income. The Bill reflects the removal of the ceiling on the amount of levy payable, and contains the income threshold levels below which people with low incomes will not be called on to pay any levy. In addition, it contains rules for reducing the levy otherwise payable by veterans, war widows, Defence Force personnel and certain other prescribed persons who are exempt from the levy for part of a year, or who are required to pay levy because they have dependants eligible for Medicare benefits.

From 1 July 1985, there will be no ceiling on the amount of levy payable by an individual or a married couple. In order to continue to shelter low income earners from the levy, the income thresholds at which levy becomes payable are to be increased from 1 July 1985. For 1985-86, individuals with taxable incomes of $7,526 or less, and married couples or sole parents with family incomes of $12,504 or less, will be exempt from the Medicare levy. The income threshold for married couples and sole parents will increase by a further $1,530 for each dependent child or student. For example, a married couple with two dependent children will pay no levy until their combined taxable incomes exceed $15,564. The estimated cost of the increased low income thresholds is $10m in 1985-86 and $15m in a full year. The gain to revenue from the removal of the ceiling is $7m in 1985-86 and $12m in a full year.

New tax instalment schedules to reflect the changes to the Medicare levy arrangements are being prepared and will be released as soon as possible to enable employers to incorporate the changes in their payroll procedures before 1 November. These new schedules will also reflect the change in the scale of deductions to be made from second job income of more than $7,000-$134 per week-details of which were contained in Statement No. 4 to the Budget Papers.
Explanations of the Bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum which is being made available to honourable members. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 237th report of the Committee, relating to the Finance minute on the Committee's 225th report which was entitled `Stratplan-Department of Social Security ADP re-equipment program-First report.' I seek leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report which I am presenting today contains the Government's response, in the form of the Department of Finance minute, to the Committee's first report on Stratplan, report 225. It reports considerable progress by the Department of Social Security on the installation of computer equipment and on the provision of initial services to departmental staff through this computer network. However, several matters have been dealt with in the Committee's first report to which satisfactory responses have not been provided in the Department of Finance minute. Since it is almost 12 months since the Committee last reported to Parliament on Stratplan's progress, the Committee is not proposing to defer tabling of the Finance minute pending further and more satisfactory advice from the responsible departments and agencies. Instead, the Committee has decided to proceed with tabling the Department of Finance minute while noting these unsatisfactory responses and indicating the action the Committee is taking on them.

SPEECH.PARA: There are principal matters which remain of concern to the Committee. The first is project costs and benefits. During the first phase of its inquiry the Committee was unable to obtain clear and confident information about Stratplan's current projected total cost, including all attributable staff costs. The latter would appear to be a substantial component of total project costs and one area where unanticipated system development and support needs have resulted in considerable cost escalation. The Committee recommended in its report that a review of total project costs be undertaken and requested a submission on this matter as soon as the review was completed. It is still awaiting that submission.

The Committee was also presented with mutable information about the benefits asserted to result from Stratplan and, in particular, the cost savings resulting from staff savings. The Committee does not refute that considerable benefits should flow from Stratplan in the form of improved client service, greater system reliability, and more rapid implementation of government initiatives. However, the Committee was concerned that the cost effectiveness of Stratplan should be comprehensively reviewed so that cost savings in the form of staff savings, reductions in overpayments, and any other asserted efficiency improvements are fully characterised and quantified. The Committee is still awaiting advice on the results of the review of the project's cost effectiveness which it requested in its report.

The second principal matter of concern is that of project financial management. The Committee was informed, during its public hearings, that an on-line computer-based financial management system for Stratplan was under development. It considered that the completion of this system was vital to satisfactory budgetary control and the cost effective implementation of Stratplan. The response from the Department of Social Security does not state that the financial management system has been completed. In addition, the Department has indicated considerable difficulties in providing the Committee with current information on the precise costs incurred to date for Stratplan. The Committee is seeking prompt advice from the Department as to why the system has not been completed and when it will be.

The third matter is that of implementation strategy and contingency planning. In this regard the Committee made several recommendations in the 225th report which presumed a phased introduction of Stratplan products whereby they would be tested and proven in New South Wales before being introduced elsewhere on a State by State basis. The response from the Department of Social Security indicated that this original implementation strategy has been changed and that Stratplan products will now be implemented concurrently in New South Wales, Queensland and Tasmania. No reasons have as yet been given for this change. The Committee is seeking advice on the reasons for this alteration. It is also requesting further advice from the Department of Social Security on the progress of the contingency plans currently being developed by the Department but which the Committee recommended be completed before implementation proceeded beyond New South Wales.

The fourth matter of concern is the use of contract analysts and programmers. The Department of Social Security has made extensive use of contract staff in the development and implementation of Stratplan systems. This has been justified in terms of providing access to specialised expertise not otherwise available, greater project management flexibility and a reduction in development times. However, the use of contract staff has involved a considerable labour cost premium and may unduly compromise the development of the internal expertise necessary to support the long term maintenance of Stratplan systems. The Committee will be reviewing the overall cost effectiveness of employing contract analysts and programmers in Stratplan's continued implementation. It will be pursuing these and other outstanding matters through further submissions and hearings during the next phase of its monitoring and report on Stratplan.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Holding, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is necessary to rectify a discrepancy in the boundaries of an area of Aboriginal land described in Schedule 1 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act as `Petermann'. The discrepancy, which was only recently drawn to this Government's attention, concerns a small area of land on the eastern boundary of the Petermann land. The area involved is a narrow strip of land about nine kilometres long by some 220 metres wide with a total area of about two square kilometres.

In summary, the problem arose in this way: The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 included in Schedule 1 description of the Petermann Aboriginal Reserve. In accordance with that Act, title to the land was granted to the Petermann Aboriginal Land Trust in 1978. The deed of grant described the land by reference to a compiled plan prepared on the basis of the description in Schedule 1 to the Act. A later deed of grant to that land, containing the same description, was registered by the Registrar-General of the Northern Territory and was deemed to have taken effect from September 1978. Land adjoining and to the east of the Petermann land was vested in the Director of National Parks and Wildlife in 1977.

The Proclamation of the Uluru (Ayers Rock-Mount Olga) National Park contained a description of the boundaries of the land in the park. The recent amendment to the Aboriginal Land Rights Act, which added a description of Uluru to Schedule 1 of the Act, followed the 1977 proclamation description. That proclamation encroached upon the Petermann land as described in Schedule 1 of the Act and the deeds of grant. The misdescription can be traced back to 1958 when land which became the national park was excised from the Petermann Aboriginal Reserve, and the revised reserve boundaries were separately described. As I have indicated, parts of the common boundaries were inconsistently described.

This Bill will rectify the discrepancy and remove any possible confusion in respect of the description of the Petermann land. The Bill will effect the change in two ways. First, it will make a minor variation to the description of the boundaries of land granted to the Petermann Aboriginal Land Trust, ensuring that the description of the land does not overlap with any part of the Uluru land. Second, it will confirm the validity of the 1977 proclamation of the Uluru (Ayers Rock-Mount Olga) National Park, notwithstanding that the proclamation included a description of land which included a small area of land described in the deed of grant to the Petermann Aboriginal Land Trust.

There is Aboriginal support for this action. I understand that on 17 September this year the Director of Legal Services with the Central Land Council met with the relevant Aboriginals in Central Australia. Those people agreed to the action being taken in respect of the Petermann land. The net result of this legislation will not be to deprive Aboriginals of land. This Bill will merely ensure that the common boundaries of two adjacent blocks of Aboriginal land are correctly described and it is clear from what I have said that this is no more than a means of rectifying a minor technical irregularity in the description of the area of the Petermann Aboriginal Land Trust. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fourth report from the Publications Committee sitting in conference with the Publications Committee of the Senate. Copies of the report have been circulated to honourable members in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not take up much further time; I just failed to conclude my remarks by the time the House moved into grievance matters. I just want to address myself to the amendments that we shall move in Committee. They refer to mini-refineries. At present, the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Act provides as a condition for the establishment of a mini-refinery in the future a certain litreage per day, which is associated entirely with the production at Dalby. We feel that if we are to encourage exploration and the development of oil fields in the future, we should recognise, firstly, that they are likely to be small and, secondly, the condition upon their development could well be the effect of a subsidy that might be available under this scheme towards the pricing of the product out of the refinery.

SPEECH.PARA: If a refinery did not fit into the conditions of the Bill and it produced under the flow of Roma, that would mean, as far as I can see, that it would be denied any assistance under the scheme. Therefore, in the amendment, we are suggesting that we do not concern ourselves with the actual production associated with Roma, but that we leave the sum to be fixed by regulation. As I say, we believe that it is very important that we do this so that we give some impetus and encouragement to the development of the oil industry in Australia. As mentioned earlier, Australia is about 70 per cent self-sufficient, or a little better, but that is likely to decrease in view of our finite reserves. We must encourage at all stages what must be small developments. So I just flag the fact that those amendments to clause 3 will be moved in Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I rise to speak to the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Amendment Bill 1985. The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the Government's decision to amend the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme that was announced by the Government on 7 September and 26 October 1984. The petroleum products freight subsidy scheme basically provides for the payment of a subsidy on the cost of transporting certain petroleum products from coastal refineries to consumers in country areas and to fishing vessels which are fuelled at sea. This is extremely important for the fisherman in the Northern Territory, in the Gulf of Carpentaria and that area.

SPEECH.PARA: Two major areas that this Bill addresses for amendment are: The introduction of administrative reforms to control the potential for abuse by claimants of the subsidy by enabling the scheme formulated under the Act to contain provisions designed to ensure that the petroleum products for which the subsidy has been claimed have actually been delivered, and that the persons claiming the subsidy are, indeed, bona fide claimants. There have been some stories about petrol and goods being delivered to some people who are not really eligible for them. It also includes the extension of the subsidy scheme to petroleum products coming from inland mini-refineries. I believe that these mini-refineries may be something which will develop in Australian oilfields which have yet to be discovered. I believe that there is a lot of oil in Australia just waiting there, and I am quite certain that these mini-refineries will be built very close to these particular oilfields.

The administrative reforms are to implement changes resulting from the Government's review of administrative arrrangements for controlling potential abuse of the scheme with regard to the petroleum products at safe anchorage locations for the fishing industry. Some of the conditions which distributors will be asked to comply with to ensure safe anchorage when delivering petroleum products are as follows: The distributor's vessel must be capable of transporting a minimum quantity of fuel; the vessel's carrying tanks must have the facility to enable the measurement of fuels by means of a dip so that the quantities can be checked; the vessels must have metering devices capable of accurately measuring the quantity of product which will be discharged; and the registered distributor must keep and retain records for two years and furnish details of each voyage with his claim for a subsidy.

The Bill also provides for the payment of subsidy on the sale of petroleum products produced at these inland mini-refineries and sold at the location of the refineries. Some of the points to be included are as follows: Subsidy will be paid only to those mini-refineries which have a refining capacity of a maximum of 238,500 litres, or about 1,500 barrels, per day. The rate of subsidy paid on the product produced at mini-refineries will be the same as that payable if those products were transported from coastal refineries.

While we are talking about coastal refineries I must mention the British Petroleum Co. of Australia Ltd refinery at Hastings, which has been closed down because of the cartel to which BP belongs and the rationalisation which it is implementing within the petrol retailing and wholesaling business. BP has gone into an arrangement with the other oil companies. I think at this very moment it is exchanging with Mobil Oil Australia Ltd sites within Victoria for the exclusive franchise of its products in Western Australia. Mobil is actually offering its lessees a contract, if one can call it that, with the following conditions: If the present lessee of the service station wants to stay on at his service station he has two options. Either he must sign with Mobil for nine years or he may purchase the site. Mobil has said that he may purchase the site but it will not tell him for how much it will sell it to him. If he says that he will purchase the site and accepts the price, he cannot later during the process of finalising the contract change his mind and say that he will lease his site from Mobil. If Mobil tells him that the site is worth $500,000, which he may not be able to afford, he does not know this until he has agreed not to take a nine-year lease with Mobil. If he then decides to take up a lease for nine years, he has to pay Mobil the goodwill which it estimates for his business. Mobil is actually forcing small business people out of their livelihoods.

The big multinational companies are forcing these people out of the industry. They are taking over the industry. They are opening up petrol stations which have, as an adjunct to their petrol sales, milk bar facilities and the one stop shop that such companies are moving into. It is putting out of business many small business people in the milk bar or corner shop industry. It is a disgrace that these big multinational companies, can, through their monopoly position, take over businesses and ruin the livelihoods of many people within Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you please table evidence-figures-statistics?

—It is amazing that when members of the Australian Labor Party support small business some members of the Opposition-not all of them-stick up for huge multinational companies such as the Shell Co. of Australia Ltd, Mobil and BP. One cannot name an Australian company among them. We used to have Ampol Petroleum Ltd and we used to have the Commonwealth Oil Refineries which was taken over by BP many years ago. It was an Australian refinery and has been taken over and lost somewhere within this huge conglomerate. All of these things are affecting small business people within our community. We are trying to look after the jobs that they provide. Years ago a person could go to a service station and there would be a mechanic, someone pulling petrol and someone behind the counter in the shop. What do we find now? A person has to front up to some stainless steel concrete mess and fill up his own car. He then goes into the shop and pays his money to a person behind the counter. All this has been brought about by multinational greed on a huge scale.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill also provides for another subsidy that will be paid retrospectively to the commencement of production in the mini-refinery. There is one existing mini-refinery at Roma. The commencement date is effectively 1 January 1984. Prior to that date legal opinion from the Office of Parliamentary Counsel suggested that the Act did not preclude subsidy from being paid on the sale of eligible petroleum products produced at that refinery. The amendments incorporate proposals contained in a submission made to the review by the Northern Australian fishing industry task force in March 1984. The amendments are aimed at guaranteeing that petroleum products, for which the subsidy is claimed, have actually been delivered and also that the person or persons claiming the subsidy are actually legitimate claimants.

Honourable members should note that the measures contained in this Bill have no real direct financial implications. The provisions relating to the extension of the subsidy to the products from inland mini-refineries have the effect of validating subsidy payments already made. The Opposition will move two amendments to the Bill. We will not oppose those amendments. This is something that will assist people in remote areas. It is something that is looking to the future, something that our Opposition colleagues never did. I commend this Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Amendment Bill 1985 which proposes to amend the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Act 1965 to implement the legislative changes to the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme announced by the Government on 7 September and 26 October 1984. We can all recall when the freight subsidy scheme was introduced. I think at the time I voted by myself. I will digress for just a moment. I said: `How can we introduce a freight subsidy scheme?' Of course I wanted to help the farmers and to help the people out in the rural and remote areas.
—And Tasmania.

—And Tasmania too, but I found to my dismay that there was always a relevant city price. The word `relevant' is interesting. It means the price at that particular time. I said: `Fine, if it is going to be 1c a litre above the relevant city price that will be good for the farmers and it will be good for the people in the remote areas'. But unfortunately the relevant city price has been destroyed. That is the reason why there is so much discontent in Australia with the ordinary people who can read and who can travel around and see a bowser. They are not stupid like the manager of Ampol Petroleum Ltd who had the audacity to say on AM one morning: `Half of Sydney is paying 44c a litre, the other half of Sydney is paying 55c a litre.' The people were asking why. Of course they would. I am trying to work out the difference in the cost per gallon. If the price were calculated in cents per gallon, they would absolutely die at the difference. He said: `Because certain people in one part of Sydney are getting a special price, that is good. That is what they call competition'. But the unfortunate thing is that the Prices Surveillance Authority set a maximum wholesale price in every capital city. One of my friends, a very diligent friend incidentally, travelled all over Australia. I said to him: `For a bit of fun tell me the price of petrol at every pump at every place you pull up for petrol'. Not one price was the same. Of course they should not be; we do not want collusion and under the trade practices legislation anybody can charge what he likes. But unfortunately the difference on some occasions was absolutely beyond comprehension. I am not going to run down oil companies and refineries and say-
—Please, please!
—No, I am not going to, because they employ a lot of people in Australia. They provide jobs and finance. That helps the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —My friends opposite may be concerned about prices and about small businessmen, but what we have to realise is that the oil industry is ever changing; it changes from day to day. The oil companies are very expert at running their markets, in moving from left to right, up the straight, or however we like to term it. Therefore, we have to realise that they have a job to do and they need support. When the Fraser Government introduced import parity pricing--
—Shameful day.

—No, I will just explain something to the honourable member. A lot of people do not realise this. Import parity pricing was introduced at a time of world shortage when we needed more exploration and more alternatives. We do not want to be dependent on the Arabs or other countries. If we can do it in Australia, we need to do it. We need to be self-sufficient. So, begrudgingly I went along with it because, if it is done on a fair basis for everybody in Australia, it is good. But the oil companies have a wonderful ability to drop the price when they feel like it, and when people in Tasmania see that the price is 14c a litre cheaper in Sydney they ask why-and rightly so. When we introduced import parity pricing we hoped that we would get to self-sufficiency. We are about 70 per cent self-sufficient now and we need to be up another 30 per cent. Therefore, we need to support the explorers and the oil companies, but they have to realise that we are not all fools. If they are going to drop prices in certain parts of Australia to the disadvantage of others, the consumers will not go along with it. That is one of the reasons why the farmers are so uptight. They see a petrol price war in Sydney. They see that the price is 14c a litre cheaper than they are buying it to put into their cars and tractors and they get upset. I do not believe everything I read, of course, but the Australian Financial Review said today that the farmers are in a terrible plight. I hope that they are not.
—They are.
—My friend says that they are and I believe him.
—And they are being destroyed by the Labor Government.
—The Labor Government made a very bad mistake. Paul Keating stood up at that table over there-
—Order!

—I beg your pardon, Mr Deputy Speaker; the Treasurer of this country stood up and he said that there was taxation by stealth at the petrol pump. He was alleging that the Fraser Government took taxes from the people by stealth. He said during that election campaign that he would reduce the price of petrol by 1.6c a litre when he got into government. But he did not do it. I know that the dollar created a problem. When oil is imported and the dollar is not of the same value as it was previously, we have to pay more for it.
