I understand that, but what about the consumers-the farmers and the ordinary people out there? The third biggest investment that a person makes in his lifetime, after his wife and house, is his motor car. Most people love their motor cars. Some have two, some have three. We all know that having a motor car is a very costly affair.
—Children or motor cars, Bruce?
—Everything is expensive, but I mean cars.
—What model do you drive?
—I change my model like I change my suit.
—But not your wife?

—No, not my wife. Cars are a very important ingredient in the economy of the family. They are very expensive. When the price of fuel goes up it has an adverse effect on the family economy. When it goes up by nearly $5 a week-that is what it is at the moment; it is up by $5 a week from what it was two years ago-it has an adverse effect on the economy. If the young people up in the gallery go to buy a motor car they know that its initial cost will be quite high; they will need to have repairs done on it; they will need to pay registration. Some of them will then find it very difficult to use the motor car because fuel is so expensive. Fuel is an important ingredient in the economy of Australia. When people read that its price varies so much from pump to pump they get a bit disillusioned. It is useless oil companies and the Australian Institute of Petroleum writing to me and telling me about the market. I know all about the market. I know that it has to be competitive. I know that it has to make a profit. I know that it may have an excess in one area and that it has a big market.

SPEECH.PARA: The people of Australia are travelling now. They do not understand-the farmers do not understand-when there is a 15c price difference in fuel in certain areas. It is useless the oil companies saying to me that one can buy liquefied pertroleum gas, for example, in Victoria for 23c a litre when in Tasmania it is 36c a litre. That was one of the reasons we went to import parity pricing. We had to tell the people of Australia that they have to change, that they have to look for alternatives such as LPG on which motor cars will drive economically and efficiently. LPG is used in nearly every motor car in South Korea. All the taxis in Japan use LPG. Where does it come from? It comes from Australia. We need to do something about it. We need to tell people: `You can have an alternative. Look for alternatives'. Motor vehicle manufacturers need to leave options open. They have diffs, gear boxes, upholstery and everything else, but they do not have LPG. The Datsun company brought out a car. But as it was driven specifically on LPG people shied away from it. We need to talk about the dual system. As I have said on many occasions, the oil industry needs looking at in a sensible way for the sake of everybody within it.

As for the poor fellows in their service stations who were mentioned previously, I agree and I disagree. We are all subject to change. The world will not stop still for the small bloke in the service station. We have three different types who sell us petrol today. We have the little bloke who owns his own site and who is dependent on a few repairs and a bit of petrol. He can put the price up and down. We have the lessee type and we have the franchise type, or whatever one terms it, who is owned by the oil company. Of course, the oil companies own most of the lessee and franchise types. The lessee gets a percentage of the price of the petrol that goes through the pumps. They are ever-changing. They are looking for better profits. I agree that the individuals have to be thought about a little. It is useless talking about key money now. After the leases run out some of these people have to pay X amount of dollars to maintain their businesses. They have to be considered in a sensible way.

Regrettably, the oil companies made the rules earlier. They went from solo marketing to every street corner. They were the ones who spent their money on building service stations everywhere. But the individuals who go into those businesses mortgage their homes. They have families. They work hard to make a decent, respectable living and they have to be given a fair go. There are many things I would like to say about the oil industry but I think I have said enough tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep going. Tell us about Tasmania.

—We in Tasmania get penalised. The argument is freight. It is just not true. They say it is because Tasmania is a small market. They say it is the roster system. What a lot of rot for every service station to stay open in Tasmania on a cold winter's night for the benefit of a few silly travellers! It would be great for the travellers, would it not? But it would not be great for the people in those small businesses. There has to be a bit of common sense in this industry. The oil companies have to realise that we are all not damned fools. The explorers have to get on with the job. We want to support them and make certain that the oil industry is going to be good for everybody in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I would like to thank my colleagues, who at the last moment have given me the opportunity to say a few words on this very important piece of legislation. A large number of members on this side of the house wish to participate in this debate. Many of them have given way to allow me to say a few words. Without wanting to incur the wrath of my parliamentary colleagues on this side of the chamber, I pay tribute to the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), who has just concluded his speech. The honourable member is extremely genuine about this matter. He has a very good record of putting the case for small business and for people in the remote parts of Australia. I must concur with many of the sentiments he put about the price differential between metropolitan and country areas. I thank him for his participation in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) has adequately covered the provisions of the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Amendment Bill. I just point out that the decision in this year's Budget to rebate fully from 1 November 1985 the diesel fuel excise for farming, fishing and forestry users who are presently eligible for partial rebate was a positive move. The cost to revenue of this decision will be $24m in 1985-86 and $35m in a full year. Fuel is a major cost for primary producers, and action on this question was a major issue at the farm cost meeting between the Government and the National Farmers Federation earlier this year. At the moment these users get a rebate of 7.619c per litre for diesel fuel but are required to pay excise of 2.4c per litre. The full rebate of diesel excise will contribute to improving the competitiveness of farmers and fishermen who presently face a depressed outlook for any commodity. The costs of these producers have risen faster than prices received, particularly in the late 1970s and the early 1980s. As a representative of a rural area, I certainly hope to get costs down even further. I hope that the taxation package introduced this afternoon by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will go some way to alleviating the costs and assisting the man on the land.

Probably the leading tuna and prawn industries in Australia are located in my electorate at Port Lincoln. I think it is very important to point out that the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme provides for the payment of a subsidy on the cost of transporting certain petroleum products from coastal refineries to consumers in country areas and to fishing vessels which are fuelled at sea. At present the scheme provides that country consumers and fishing vessel operators should pay no more than 5.2c per litre of the cost of transporting eligible petroleum products to their country location or ship refuelling zone.

This Bill proposes to strengthen the administration of the freight subsidy scheme, especially in its application to claimants for subsidy at safe anchorage locations, and to provide for payment of the freight subsidy on petroleum products produced at inland mini-refineries. The administrative reforms to the scheme are the result of a review of administration of the scheme at safe anchorage locations for the fishing industry which was initiated by the Government in November 1983. On 7 September 1984 the Government announced the introduction of a number of changes resulting from that review designed to strengthen the administration of the scheme as it applies to the fishing industry and to control the potential for abuse by claimants under the scheme. I think this extremely constructive scheme will assist in the safe refuelling at sea of prawn and tuna vessels, which do so much not only for the economy of South Australia but for Australia in general. I certainly hope that the hard-working tuna and prawn fishermen of Port Lincoln are well aware of this measure.

There are present many obviously genuine representatives from the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party of Australia who really have a bipartisan approach to this matter. I am sure that they are appalled by the high cost of fuel in country areas. I mention to the House, particularly for the benefit of those honourable members who come from metropolitan areas, that country residents have to endure high additional freight costs because of higher fuel prices. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has released figures on the variations in the prices of food in my electorate of Grey. In some towns in my electorate, for example, Ceduna, food can cost up to 10 per cent more than it costs in Adelaide. People living in Leigh Creek pay 15 per cent more for food than people in Adelaide, people in Port Lincoln pay 11 per cent more and people in the iron triangle-Whyalla, Port Augusta and Port Pirie-pay up to 8 per cent more. This is the obvious result of freight costs. Of course, in some South Australian areas the price of fuel can be 15c a litre more than in the metropolitan area. As the honourable member for Franklin quite correctly pointed out, people in remote areas may get the same salaries as those in metropolitan areas but are certainly at a big disadvantage because they virtually have to subsidise those people who live in the cities, who have all the trappings of modern day life. People in the country areas have to go without some of the things that people in the metropolitan areas take for granted.

What can the Federal Government do about this? Why is there such a variation in petrol prices, in particular between city and country areas? Why does the Government not do something about this? That is not a bad question. The Commonwealth Government's legislative authority to control retail prices, including petrol prices, is very limited. The constitutional authority to control retail petroleum product prices lies primarily with the States. However, the Government has created the Prices Surveillance Authority to ensure that the wholesale price of a range of important commodities, including wholesale petroleum product prices, are fair and reasonable. The Authority sets maximum wholesale prices for petroleum products for each capital city in Australia. Retail prices of petrol are generally determined by the refining companies, distributors and agents. Differences between metropolitan and country prices occur because of two main factors. It costs more to supply consumers in remote areas-for example, freight costs are higher-and wholesaling and retailing costs are also higher in areas with smaller sales volumes. However, the basic differences are compounded by the existence of discounting. Nowhere is this more explicit than in Adelaide, where at times petrol prices can be as low as 45c or 46c a litre, whereas in my city, the beautiful city of Whyalla, the lowest it can be is 59.8c a litre.

Discounting in metropolitan retail outlets does take place. Discounting of petrol prices at both the retail and wholesale levels typically occurs in high volume outlets in areas of high competition, especially near sources of bulk supply such as refineries and particularly in periods of excess supply or refinery underutilisation. Discounting does not usually occur in the more remote areas. For instance, in Coober Pedy, which is something like 200 kilometres north of Whyalla, petrol is cheaper than in the industrial areas of Port Pirie, Whyalla, and Port Augusta. So it is not surprising that large differences occur in petrol prices between city and country areas from time to time. The Government operates the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme, which subsidises costs in excess of 5.2c per litre for transporting petroleum products to country areas. The answer would be for the Federal Government to take over the control of prices from the States. In other words, if the States were prepared to give the Federal Government control over pricing, we could certainly lower the price of petrol. This is something that I have advocated. I have taken up this point with the Federal Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans). He supports the scheme. Unfortunately, the problem lies in getting Queensland and some of the more conservative States to hand over their rights to the Federal Government.

I think it is important, particularly in this debate, to talk about the price of fuel. This does not help people in country areas, but many people believe that we pay extremely high prices for petrol. I point out that in comparison with other countries, including those which are members of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, petrol rates per litre in Australia are very low. I will cite some figures in relation to the price of a litre of petrol in other countries. In Austria, the figure is 88c a litre; Canada, 58c; the Federal Republic of Germany, 78c; France, 96c; Greece, 61c; and in Italy it is 100c a litre. In Japan it costs 87c a litre; the Netherlands, 89c; New Zealand, 71c a litre; Norway, 85c; Spain, 80c; Sweden, 82c; Turkey, 66c; Great Britain, 90c; Argentina, 67; India, 83c; Malaysia, 65c; Malta, 80c; the Philippines, 66c; Singapore, 97c; South Africa, 57c; and in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics the price is 69c a litre. Honourable members will note that Australia, with its average price of 56c a litre throughout the country has fairly low prices in comparison with the OECD and other countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —In April we had the cheapest petrol in the world.
—As my good friend and colleague the Minister for Science points out, in April we had the cheapest petrol in the world.
—That is all very well for metropolitan users.

—That is all very well, as my colleague the honourable member for Eden-Monaro points out, for metropolitan users. However, for country users it is still extraordinarily high. I would like to see a positive contribution in this debate. If honourable members opposite-I refer to members such as the honourable member for Franklin, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) and, of course, the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar)-joined with us in taking a bipartisan approach to getting some of the conservative States to hand over price control to the Federal Government, we could certainly have price control throughout this country. The price of fuel could then be lowered in those areas where it was nesessary and imperative.

SPEECH.PARA: I plead with honourable members opposite to support honourable members on this side of the House in trying to get the States to hand over the control of prices to the Federal Government so that the price of fuel can be controlled in this country. Therefore, country people who are extremely disadvantaged will not have to carry the burden as they do at present. I will leave it on the basis that honourable members opposite, particularly those who represent country electorates, will support me in calling for price control to be handled specifically and only by the Federal Government, so that we can bring down the price of fuel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In following the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil), I feel obliged at once, firstly, to lay to rest the greatest furphy which the Government is guilty of promoting and, secondly, to pick up the challenge that he has thrown at the feet of the Opposition. I am able to do both simultaneously. The greatest furphy propagated by the honourable member for Grey and his colleagues is that prices and price surveillance are the root problems in regard to high fuel costs in Australia today. The real problem, and it is an inescapable problem which no member of the Government will address, is the level of taxation by both State and Federal governments. Up to 70 per cent of the price-
—I take a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. I just point out that the honourable member for Franklin was honest-
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Price is not so much the problem as the level of taxation. Up to 70 per cent of the price consumers pay for each litre of fuel goes to either the State or Federal governments. We all know that there are problems in pricing and retailing. The answer to that is simply deregulation of the fuel industry. No government can hide behind the skirts of pricing. Unless this Government is prepared to reduce the level and burden of Federal taxation, we are delving into the realms of the ridiculous if we believe we can reduce the burden on consumers, particularly primary producers who have a very high reliance on fuel in the production of their income.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Grey and his colleagues come into this House and talk about the multinational companies and offences under the Trade Practices Act which see the setting of a common price for people in one area. All of us understand that there are errors or mistakes or licences taken by either retailers or producers. None of us runs away from that. Deregulation is the best method of tackling those problems. But I have yet to hear one member of the Government put forward to this House one way of reducing significantly the cost of fuel. It is simply a question of taxation.

Therefore, I pick up the challenge put forward by the honourable member for Grey when he asked this chamber: What can we do about the price of fuel? Firstly, we need to deregulate the petroleum industry. Secondly, we must abandon fuel parity pricing. Thirdly, we must reduce the level of taxation on fuel by way of that automatic six-monthly excise that this Government introduced in its 1983 Budget.

The purpose of the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Amendment Bill before the Parliament this evening is twofold. Firstly, it introduces administrative reforms to control potential abuse of the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme and, secondly, it extends the scheme to sales of product from inland mini-refineries. It seems to me that this evening's debate is almost totally an exercise in futility given that in the May mini-Budget of this year the Government completely and utterly gutted the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme. It was made almost completely inoperable.

There is something of an element of Alice in Wonderland about the debate tonight. We are discussing reforms to the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme when it hardly exists any longer. The responsibility for that lies with the Government which in the May mini-Budget of this year so cut back its operation as to make it almost useless to consumers in country areas. It may well be that the scheme operates to some extent at least for people in areas such as Port Lincoln, within the electorate of the honourable member for Grey. But for most country people, particularly in the eastern States, the scheme has meant an increase in fuel costs of 4c a litre. Would the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) or any country members of the Government here this evening deny that that scheme has been rendered inoperative and that the cost of fuel since May has increased some 4c?

Let us look now at world parity pricing. When it was introduced in the mid to late 1970s its purpose was clearly set out and I believe had been largely successful. Its aim was twofold: Firstly, it was to ensure a proper return to explorers on their high investment. Without a guaranteed return the explorers would simply have taken their bat and ball and gone to the Gulf of Mexico. Let nobody deny that the Government at the time had no choice but to ensure that the producers could obtain the same return for investment in Bass Strait, the North West Shelf and inland oil exploration as they would have for investment in other parts of the world. Secondly, we had to encourage a sense of conservation. The realisation that fuel was almost as cheap as water had passed.

On both those objectives we have been remarkably successful, but that was nearly a decade ago. I do not believe that world parity pricing serves the best interests of this country and, by extension, its people, its primary producers, any longer. I therefore believe that we must abandon fuel parity pricing, but it is difficult to imagine this Government undertaking that major decision. It is quite prepared to come into this chamber as late as today and introduce a whole range of taxation measures dealing with capital gains taxes, fringe benefits and associated measures, all of which will disadvantage those in the private sector. Those measures will hit at initiative, risk taking and entrepreneurs. When it comes to introducing a measure which will actually return money in a direct way to every person in this country who drives a vehicle, or every primary producer who needs fuel in the production of his goods, the Government will not do it. It has the courage when it is taking money from the private sector, but it does not have the courage when it means returning money to the private sector.

As I mentioned earlier, in the Budget of August 1983 the Government introduced an automatic six-monthly increase in fuel excise in line with movements in the consumer price index. For many people throughout Australia that is receding into the dim distant past. But the Government will never forget that measure because every six months its coffers swell. There is no longer any need to spell out in either a mini-Budget or the traditional Budget in August of every year the increases in excise on fuel. That is done by stealth and, for the most part without the public being aware. It now amounts to almost 10c a litre. Leaving aside the artificial world parity pricing formula we have in this country which, incidentally, is expressed in American dollars according to the price of Saudi Arabian light crude, the devaluation and the formula expressed in American dollars meant a bonus of hundreds of millions of dollars, almost a billion dollars, to this Government.

Earlier this year after the devaluation we argued that that formula, which artificially kept the price of world parity high, ought to be altered. We have now come a step further and said that world parity pricing is not appropriate to Australia. Even if one accepts, like every member of the Government appears to, that we ought to have world parity pricing-I and my colleagues do not-the Government should not have this artificial formula which gives a price of fuel much higher than the world market price. Of course it is a bonanza to a high spending government, but it means that our consumers and primary producers are severely disadvantaged.

In the 14 May 1985 mini-Budget we saw that the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme was largely destroyed. As I have said, for this House now to be discussing and passing legislation which reforms that scheme is, frankly, an exercise in stupidity as well as futility. Unless that scheme is restored to its previous operations or an even more efficient scheme is set up, we will find that country consumers are paying an even higher price for their fuel than at present. One of the real cuts in that mini-Budget of 14 May, among many others that hit the rural sector, was the destruction of the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme. That device was set up by the previous coalition Government to ease in a small way the cost burden of living in areas remote from the major metropolitan cities. The decision has meant already that fuel prices have increased in country areas by up to and over 4c a litre. I believe that that decision and the contribution of the Government to destroy the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme means that the Government is ignoring the very serious deterioration in farm terms of trade.

We have heard a number of Government speakers pay lip service to the cost burden on primary producers, but when there is a measure before this Parliament by which they can actively and constructively assist in reducing that cost burden, they run for shelter. There is not one amongst them who will break that Caucus pledge which binds them to abide by the decision of the Minister.

Government members have spoken of pricing and multinationals. The Government and this Parliament can attack and solve the problems in the petroleum industry, but it will require a government, with the exhortation of the Opposition, that is prepared to reduce the level of government taxation. There is no indication whatsoever that this Government will reduce the level of taxation. The Opposition, on the other hand, has put forward a policy which would abandon fuel parity pricing. The National Party's policy is to introduce deregulation of the petroleum industry and reduce the level of taxation on fuel. That would assist every consumer in this country, particularly the primary producers, who are suffering under a welter of government induced charges and costs, and who are so important to the export potential of this country.

It has been said many times and it deserves to be said again: This country has long relied on the primary producer for much of its export earnings and, by extension, its standard of living. If this Government ignores any longer the potential of the primary producers and the wealth they can bring this country, our standard of living will decline even more sharply. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Government have come into this House this afternoon and introduced a capital gains tax and prohibited negative gearing provisions in taxation. This can only further hurt the primary producers of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any one listening to this debate could be forgiven for not really being very clear on what it is all about. I do not say that in connection with those honourable members who have spoken so admirably from this side of the House. Let me say, in fairness, that from the Opposition speakers, there have been a few gems. The honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) made a few sensible observations. There have been occasions in this House in the past when the honourable member for Franklin has made some remarkably clever decisions. One which I remember distinctly was the occasion when he accepted the compelling nature of the arguments that had been presented by the Government-he joined the Government-in connection with a particular issue. That was a great credit to him. He is a man of conscience and commitment and I appreciate the honesty and integrity with which he made some very compelling and important observations tonight, particularly about the way in which the transnational oil companies operate in Australia in connection with distribution.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to be able to say the same thing about the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) and his contribution. I will make a few observations in connection with the honourable member for Gippsland as I proceed, but let me first put this debate into context. We need to understand, as does every one who listens to this debate, that this Bill will amend the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Acts 1965 to give effect to the Government's decisions announced on 7 September and 26 October last year to all the provisions of the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme. There are two adjustments to be made by the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a dead scheme.

—The honourable member for Gippsland has already made his contribution to the debate. I was not very impressed by it, neither was anyone else. What I am trying to do, for the benefit of Opposition members who may follow in this debate, is at least to set the scene.
—Taxes?
—If the honourable member for Gippsland stays quiet and listens, he will learn.
—From whom?

—Do not get so excited. Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would make the observation that while the honourable member for Gippsland was speaking, my colleague the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) said: `This man is hysterical'. It was not my comment. It was the natural response of one of my discerning colleagues about the nature of the contribution. Some comments by the honourable member for Gippsland were sensible, and if he had developed them further I would be giving him more credit that I am at present. But let me proceed. The two provisions in this legislation relate first to the introduction of various administrative reforms to control the potential for abuse by claimants for subsidy. In all honesty, who would complain at that?
—Nobody. The scheme does not exist.

—I am pleased that the honourable member would not argue about it because the shadow Minister who lead for the Opposition, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), made it perfectly clear that the Opposition recognised and accepted that there had been abuses of this scheme. We are concerned to ensure, as we are in all questions of public policy, that provisions designed to ensure a much better operation of the type of private operations that exist throughout Australia will not be abused by the manipulators.

SPEECH.PARA: We know well enough the extent to which people in this national community will take advantage of the opportunity to manipulate circumstances for their own benefit, whether their centre of control is in Australia or elsewhere. Far too frequently, and unfortunately, the centre of control is elsewhere. Those centres of control do not always find themselves in some sort of commonality in regard to their concerns, objectives and aspirations. I am not saying that happens on all occasions but there are occasions when they conflict with those of the average Australian community.

Secondly, this legislation extends the subsidy scheme to sales of petroleum products produced at inland mini-refineries. There is only one at present and that is at Roma. In connection with the output from that refinery, the honourable member for Dawson has indicated the terms of an amendment which the Opposition will move later in the Committee stage. I think the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) has indicated already that the Government sees some sense in that proposal and that it will be accepted.

The petroleum products freight subsidy scheme has been in operation since 1 July 1978 and the particularly important provision in the legislation is that it provides for the payment of a subsidy which is related to the cost of freighting eligible petroleum products to country locations. We know that this has been extended to the fuelling of fishing vessels off-shore in areas which are known as safe anchorages, as they have been classified and identified. The eligible products included under the provisions of the legislation are motor spirit, distillate, aviation gasoline and aviation turbine fuel. The subsidy levels are equal to the difference between the actual freight cost and a maximum consumer-paid contribution. The consumer-paid contribution was increased, as we know, from 1.2c per litre to 5.2c per litre from 21 May 1985. The initial announcement about that was made in the May economic statement, which was presented in this chamber by the Treasurer, the Hon. Paul Keating, member for Blaxland.

TALK.START.PARA: —The world's greatest Treasurer.

—I am reminded by the honourable member for Dunkley that the Treasurer to whom I have referred was identified by an international financial magazine as the world's greatest Treasurer. I interpolate that I would like to take this opportunity to make special mention of that very important statement made earlier today by the national Treasurer in connection with taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: The consumer-paid contribution is indexed each year in line with increases in the consumer price index with the purpose of maintaining in real terms the consumer contribution to freight costs. A total of $20.6m is being provided for the scheme in the current financial year as a result of the Budget the Treasurer brought down. This compares with expenditure of $130.2m in 1984-85. Those changes indicate the Government's concern to ensure not only that important programs and policies of this kind are continued, but also that where necessary appropriate amendments or variations are introduced. It was most important that those changes should be applied because the vast majority of petroleum product users live and work in areas where freight costs are less than 1.2c per litre. Thus they are not affected by the change, which increased the differential to 5.2c per litre. Of those affected, the great majority found that the price of petrol at the pump increased by less than 2c per litre as a result of the change because that was the actual level of subsidy which then applied in most places. It was only in very remote locations that the price increased by the maximum of 4c per litre.

I draw the attention of members of the Opposition to the Auditor-General's report. I imagine that the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) would be an authority on that report and I know that his thinking has been very much influenced by its content-the compelling arguments and conclusions reached. I am glad to see that the honourable member is nodding in agreement because that confirms my belief that he has understood the significance of that report. The Auditor-General's report found that the complexity of the scheme and the difficulties in developing suitable operating procedures for verifying claims had left the scheme open to deliberate abuse. The honourable member for Gippsland is aware of that. He nods in agreement; he understands. The Auditor-General also found that artificial schemes had been designed and operated specifically to attract the subsidy. I know that that sort of thing goes on, as do all honourable members, whatever political party they belong to. They all know that, unfortunately, there are in the community people who like to take advantage of public policies and programs which are designed to assist and encourage individual initiative and individual entrepreneurs in any area, whether it is on the land, in the mines, on fishing vessels, in factories and workshops or in transport companies. Public policies are not designed to impose penalty and burdens. Public policies, particularly when they are put in place by Labor governments, are designed to assist and to encourage. They are designed to overcome obstacles, to overcome the sorts of problems that so many operators in the private sector experience.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why kill the scheme?
—The scheme has not been killed.
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland has already spoken.

—He has indeed and, as I have said, without a great deal of conviction. The honourable member for Gippsland asks: Why kill the scheme? The scheme has not been killed and he knows-as I know-that very significant sections of the Australian rural community and the Australian fishing industry are benefiting from this scheme at present. It does the honourable member, his perception and his judgment no credit at all to say that the scheme has been killed because he knows differently. If the honourable member represents people who are currently benefiting from this scheme they will now be making judgment on the judgment which the honourable member has made. He must realise the implications of that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government was determined that this rise in the ceiling of the consumer-paid margin should not be exploited by unscrupulous dealers to raise the price of fuel by the maximum of 4c per litre in those places which do not justify it. The Government has kept a close watch on price increases at the pump, as it needs to.

As I have said, the honourable member for Dawson, who led for the Opposition, admitted that the Opposition knows of the false claims that were being made for payment of the subsidy. He also referred, quite correctly, to the role of jobbers in the market. Not only are jobbers connected with the operation of this scheme but there are jobbers in the urban, metropolitan areas as well. They are not tied to any particular distribution network but they are able to take advantage of gluts which occur and they are able to charge prices which are significantly different from the prices which are being charged by others who are permanently integrated into the market. Frequently, as a result of the operation of jobbers, those permanently in the market suffer significant disability, disadvantage and great damage. I know that as far as the consumer is concerned the jobbers may be fulfilling a useful purpose because they make it possible for the person who fills his tank to buy petrol at a lower price. However, it is necessary for some rationality to be contained within the market and the industry and to ensure that the jobbers are not causing the damage which they so frequently cause. That is a matter for the industry.

The ordinary retailer, the fellow who operates the bowser, puts in long hours. He often starts his outlet with great hopes and great ambitions about the opportunity he has of building up his own business. But far too frequenlty such people are being sent to the wall by not only unscrupulous operators but also, unfortunately, some significant operators in the industry. I refer to the transnationals. I do not want to make too much of that matter because even the large oil cartels, the large oil corporations, obviously fulfil an extremely important role not only in our national economy but also in the world economy, in terms of exploration, production and distribution. I do not need to spell out the fact that there is a great deal of disquiet. You are aware of the great deal of disquiet that exists within the community about the way transnationals operate. Even on your side-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will address the Chair.

—I certainly will, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am referring to the honourable member for Deakin, who is sitting at the table representing the Opposition at present. The honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) referred to one of his friends whom he asked to check the price of petrol at the pump at all the service stations he came to when he was touring around. He came back with an incredible array of prices.
—Do you think the oil companies are cartels?
—I do not know whether the honourable member for Deakin will now justify, excuse and defend that.
—What is wrong with an incredible array of prices? It is fantastic. It shows there is no cartel.
—That is typical.
—It shows there is no cartel.

—Rubbish! It is an indication of the operation of the cartel, you goat. The honourable member defends competition. That is okay if competition is constructive and if it achieves its purposes, that is, to instil some vitality into the industry and to make sure that the consumer benefits. Surely the honourable member for Deakin will not suggest to me or to the honourable member for Franklin that the prices represented at the pump are a result of competition in the industry. Surely the honourable member for Fisher is not going to endorse that? If the honourable members opposite endorse that sort of comment they will make themeselves look ridiculous. Apart from some members of the Opposition, no one in this community would endorse such rubbish. Honourable members opposite know it is a cartel. The honourable member for Franklin drew attention to that when he was speaking. If the honourable member for Deakin wants to defend private enterprise, I will go along with him if he will defend legitimate private enterprise. But he should expect me to support him or to endorse the nonsense he talks about true competition when we know that those artificial, contrived, manipulated prices result from-
—You said yourself that the prices were all different.

—They were different. I am not sure whether the honourable member for Deakin, who purports to be a pillar of the private sector, really understands the way in which the private sector operates. For him to be misled into believing that price variations of that kind represent hectic competition in the industry is an absolute absurdity. We are about 70 per cent self-sufficient in the production and distribution of petrol. Oil is fundamentally important. as I have said before, not only to the national economy but also to the international economy. So many changes in international relationships, trading relationships, prices, exchange rates, the balance of payments, world debt and world inflation have had as their source those two major oil hikes during the 1970s. It would not be appropriate for this Government, or for any other government, to lose sight of some of those essential facts.

SPEECH.PARA: This is extremely important legislation. I know it will be important to those in the rural community and those in the fishing industry who will be affected by it. The Government has been extremely conscientious in its approach to this question in an attempt to build rational decisions and rational policies into the programs that exist. We have continued the program that we inherited and we have introduced some variations to it.

In the remaining minutes that are available to me I refer to the matter of deregulation, which the honourable member for Gippsland mentioned. I want to make the comment that for the Opposition deregulation is simply a euphemism for some of those things I was talking about. It wants deregulation because it wants the Government and the public sector to step outside completely. In the words of Adam Smith, to keep the ring, to allow the private sector to operate as it wishes, to allow it to manipulate the markets, to manipulate prices and to contrive agreements, arrangements and understandings. There is only one authority which is able to provide adequate, sufficient and informed regulation, and that is government. When honourable members opposite want deregulation we know what they are after. They are after open slather by the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Science, the Hon. Barry Jones of Pick-a-Box fame, claimed in his second reading speech, the Bill proposes to amend the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Act 1965 to implement certain legislative changes to the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme. The Minister was eloquent, as he always has been. When I was at school I saw him on television overcome all opposition as Australia's leading quiz king. In those days I admired him, but I assure the House that that was before I suspected he may have harboured socialist tendencies. I do remember one spirited exchange between the Minister and Bob Dyer over the pronunciation of the word `controversy'. I do not know who won, but the Minister certainly raised one over this Bill and over the effect of the Government's fuel taxing actions on the people of Australia. My colleague the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) has indicated in a very effective way just how shallow, inadequate and hopeless the attitude of the Australian Labor Party is in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before the House exposes once and for all the Government's absolute hatred of country people and its determination to penalise those people who live outside capital cities. The Government's pretention of representing the nation as a whole is blown completely apart by this fraudulent Bill. Some people might suggest that it is almost a machinery Bill, and in some ways it is. It seeks to alter matters associated with the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme or such little part of the scheme as remains after it was torn to pieces and ripped asunder by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his May economic statement.

The Opposition shadow Minister, SenatorDurack, in the Senate confirmed the Treasurer had virtually abolished the scheme four months ago. All that remains is a shell, completely lacking in substance. The Treasurer's first attack resulted in the possibility of some expenditure cuts at the price of enormous fuel cost increases to rural people as well as restricting the scheme's area of application and consequent bureaucratic costs. While some respectable economic arguments could be advanced against the principle of subsidies, the Government's anti-rural motives were the driving force both behind the economic statement and this legislation.

The fuel industry is in an economic strait-jacket. It is over-regulated and overtaxed. The subsidy was originally given as a form of compensation to offset partly the heavy Federal and State Labor Government taxes already placed on fuel. About 50 per cent of the bowser fuel price is tax of one kind or another. The amendments seek to introduce registration conditions which will even further restrict the scheme and introduce a statutory declaration to inhibit false claims. The registration conditions may inhibit some abuses and penalty provisions may restrict some false claims. The people of Australia cannot have any confidence any more that the proposed alterations in law will make the scheme more effective because of its very complexity and inadequate claim investigation and verification.

The rural people of Australia do not want handouts. They do not want to be propped up or falsely supported by this or any other government. What they want, what they need and what they deserve is a fair go.

TALK.START.PARA: —A fair go.

—A fair go, as the honourable member for Franklin indicates quite correctly. We in the National Party will always ensure fair treatment for all people in this country, whether from the city or from rural areas. The Queensland National Party is the only party in that State which seeks to represent all people in the community. We believe that there can be no future for any political party which fails to seek to meet the needs of all Australians. Indeed, it is obvious that the people of Queensland, support us because we have 42 members in the State House after the tragic death of Water Resources Minister John Goleby, while Labor has a mere 31 members. The Labor Party has been rejected by the people of Queensland over and over again since 1957. The latest opinion polls show continuing strong support for the Nationals while Labor is backed by some 6 per cent fewer people than at the last election in October 1983. In view of this, it is amazing that the Labor Party is bringing in all of this anti-rural legislation for the wrong motives. What we need in this country and what we on this side of the House want and demand is a reduction in the size of government, a reduction in the size of the bureaucracy and more deregulation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Queensland National Party, which I am proud to represent in his place, forms the only State Government of any political colour which does not impose a State fuel tax. For this reason, fuel in my electorate of Fisher in recent times has varied from 46c a litre up to 54c a litre compared with a price of 65c a litre and 72c a litre in Labor governed New South Wales and Western Australia respectively. Federal Labor taxes could well take the price of petrol in other places even higher.

The original petroleum products freight subsidy scheme made provision that the subsidy would apply when the existing consumer-paid margin for freight costs exceeded 1.2c per litre. The May economic statement took $116m from country people by increasing the maximum consumer-paid differential by 4c per litre from 21 May 1985; that is, the existing consumer-paid margin for freight costs was increased from a maximum of 1.2c per litre to 5.2c per litre. The Government has not been able to identify financial implications, as the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) mentioned, as a result of the proposed amendments; and, in the words of Senator Durack, the shadow Minister, what a shambles!

This Bill also seeks to legalise payments made to the Roma oil refinery from 1984 and to provide for possible payments to this and other mini-refineries in the future. Prior to the May economic statement, payments were made without authority to the Roma refinery, and therefore there was a need to validate payments previously made. Since the May economic statement, Roma is no longer eligible because of the increase in the consumer-paid margin before the scheme becomes applicable.

No one is denying that there were problems in the Northern Territory fishing industry, and the Joint Committee of Public Accounts reviewed the scheme's administration in 1984. The main points of that review were: Firstly, there were continuing administration problems, backed up by information from both administrative and industry sources; secondly, large oil companies indicated that continuing abuse of the scheme by some operators had a disrupting effect on the market; and thirdly, widespread and substantial discounting of petrol and diesel in some areas indicated that there could have been some substance to the allegations. The Committee suggested that there should be a review of the scheme, but the Government, succumbing once again to its anti-rural bias, has declined the opportunity to confront the problems and has, instead, ignored them by attempting to abolish the practical application of the scheme by stealth.

Justification has been advanced by some for the petroleum products freight subsidy scheme because of the way that the Hawke Labor Government and its predecessor have ripped off the community, including the rural sector, through excessive fuel tax. The people of Australia condemn the Hawke Labor Government over and over again because of the way in which it has forced up the price of fuel, the way in which that Government is trying to tax the motorists the farmers and the graziers of Australia out of existence. But justice will occur. I am absolutely convinced that the people of Australia will put the Hawke Labor Government out of existence at the next election. If there were a free market in oil and no tax rip-off, there would be no need for any subsidy.

The Fisher Divisional Council of the National Party, which participated in my selection-honourable members on both sides of the House would agree that those people were very discerning-quite correctly identified the problem some time ago when it carried the following resolution:

That this Council utterly condemns the import parity pricing system of the Hawke Socialist Government and its predecessor because of the crazy manner in which Australian oil prices continue to spiral upwards whilst:
1. international oil prices drop;
2. the Australian dollar continues to plummet under Labor's mismanagement of the Australian economy; and
3. the Government fuel tax grab rises with the price of fuel.

What we need in this country is more free enterprise, and a free market in oil-and I am very pleased to see members of the National Party stand up and be counted for the people of Australia, those living in cities and those in rural areas-so that prices paid by Australians reflect the cost of production and usual profit. What we do not need is for the Labor Party to seek to reduce its deficit by slugging users of fuel. We know what a spendthrift government we have. We know that, on the Government's own figures, it will overspend by $4.9 billion this year. That means that it will spend $4,900m more than it takes from the taxpayers. As I mentioned when speaking to an earlier Bill, honourable members should imagine what their bank manager would say if, when he rang them up and stated: `You are overdrawn', they replied: `I have gone into deficit budgeting'. He would very quickly bring that situation to an abrupt and appropriate end.

The people of Australia are sick and tired of being slugged by this Government. The people of Australia are sick and tired of being used by this Government. They are sick and tired of a situation in which the Government spends, spends, spends and then wants to rip-off ever-increasing amounts of money from the users of fuel. It simply is not good enough. We in the National Party are not prepared, in any circumstances, to let this Labor Party go on doing this to the people of Australia. We all remember-the Minister for Science who is at the table will also remember this-that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised to reduce fuel prices by 3c per litre. The honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), who is an excellent member, constantly presents to this House petitions requesting that the price of fuel be reduced by 3c per litre in accordance with the Prime Minister's promise.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister is no expert.

—He is no expert, as the honourable member for Riverina-Darling has mentioned. The promise of the Prime Minister in the great charade at the Sydney Opera House in 1983 that the price of fuel would be reduced by 3c a litre was absolutely worthless. In reality, the Labor Government has increased fuel prices by more than 10c a litre-not 5c, 6c, 7c, 8c or 9c but 10c a litre.
—Shame!

—It is a shame, as the honourable member for Franklin has indicated. This Government has increased fuel prices by 10c per litre in just two years. Fortunately for the people of Australia, it will not be the Government for very much longer; so we will have to worry about this for only a short time. But it has increased the price by 10c per litre when it said that it would reduce it by 3c a litre. What would the situation in Australia be if the Government had said that they were going merely to stabilise the price? Perhaps it would have gone up by 15c or 20c per litre; who knows? Their solution to everything is tax, tax, tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Party is a party of low tax. We are a party that believes in a fair go for all Australians. The provision of the subsidy amounted to at least a partial refund of the exorbitant level of fuel tax being paid by consumers. With the May economic statement and this Bill, the Government now appears to be arbitrarily selecting sectors of the Australian community as sacrificial offerings in an attempt to pull down the Budget deficit a little and in an attempt-one which will fail-to make itself look a little better. Rural consumers in particular and our citizens generally are once again being placed on the thin edge of the fuel tax axe, and they have now been given the chop by Labor.

The fuel subsidy reduction makes a mockery of the claims of the Hawke Government during the election campaign that it would seriously consider the problem of rising farm costs. Its solution is to put country people and the small businesses of Australia into bankruptcy. The people of Fisher-those living in the urban areas and those living in the rural areas-are, in my opinion, totally disillusioned with Labor's empty promises.

This Bill before the House is another Labor nail in the rural sector's coffin. The people of Australia are in revolt over Labor's constant fuel price increases. I advise the House of the strong opposition of my electorate to Labor's increasing the price of fuel over and over again. I congratulate Mrs Barbara Treloar of D'Aguilar near Woodford and Miss Nancy Lee of Ravensbourne, the co-ordinators of the anti-fuel tax campaign in the Federal electorate of Fisher. They have collected almost 2,000 signatures opposing Labor's moves. It is interesting to note that Woodford in England was Sir Winston Churchill's constituency. I feel honoured that an area of the same name is included in my electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a resemblance between you.

—I thank the honourable member very much. Woodford was good for Sir Winston Churchill and so far it has certainly been good for me. I appreciated a letter published in the Near North Coast News, based in Caboolture, from Mrs Treloar and Miss Lee thanking me for my support and for my opposition to Labor's fuel price increases.
—Hear, hear!

—I very much appreciate the comments made by my colleague the honourable member for Hinkler, who is an excellent member. The more people I talk to in his electorate, the more I hear what a wonderful job he is doing.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill seeks to continue the Government's attempts to pretend that this subsidy scheme is still in existence after its emasculation by the Treasurer earlier this year. The scheme is in fact dead and buried; the scheme is finished. The Labor Party Government of Australia seeks to fool country voters but fails dismally. This is proven because election after election these voters come out to the polling booths and vote against the Hawke socialists in ever-increasing numbers. The odd few remnants left opposite who happen to be rural members will be swept from office after the next election.

I mentioned earlier that the fuel industry is in an economic strait-jacket and that it is over-regulated and over-taxed. The Bill does not deregulate; it does not abolish fuel tax; it does not help country people and it does not help city people. This Bill is an absolute disaster for Australia. I oppose the Government's approach and support the amendment to be moved by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable members who have already spoken for their contribution. Because the hour is late and we have got some pressing business to get through, I will not speak at any length. I just want to say that I may have inadvertently misled my colleague the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) by interjection. He was quoting petrol prices and I interjected that in April Australia had the cheapest petrol prices. I should have said in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development or the Western world, but I think I probably said `the world' which would not be correct, considering the lower prices in the Arab oil states.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had a particularly interesting debate, especially from some of the younger members of the National Party of Australia, which confirms that something very interesting is happening in the National Party. The young Turks are expounding free market heresies which are deeply upsetting to the older pork barrelling rural socialists. This may reflect the extreme pressure that the National Party old guard is coming under from the National Farmers Federation, and obviously the young Turks are seeing which way to jump. At this stage, because time is so pressing, I will say no more than that and wish the Bill a speedy passage and an even almost instantaneous passage through the Committee stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Administrator recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, sub-clause (2), paragraph (d), proposed new sub-section 5 (8), definition of `Mini-refinery', omit `238,500 litres of petroleum daily', substitute `a quantity of petroleum daily which is the prescribed quantity for the purposes of this section'.
I refer honourable members to the speech I made during the debate on the second reading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will accept the amendment which will have the effect that the figure now shown in the Bill will be prescribed by regulation. However, I should make it clear that the figure stated represents the maximum output of mini-refineries to which we will pay the subsidy. The question of the treatment of a refinery producing in excess of that figure will need to be considered in light of advice from the Prices Surveillance Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report-by leave-adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Barry Jones)-by leave-read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON ABORIGINAL AFFAIRSSELECT COMMITTEE ON ABORIGINAL EDUCATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received advice from the Opposition Whip that he has nominated the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) to be a member of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs and the Select Committee on Aboriginal Education in place of the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham).

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969 and by reason of the urgent nature of the work, it is expedient that the following works be carried out without having been referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works: Construction of Commonwealth office buildings at Parramatta, Fremantle, Wollongong, Dubbo, Rockhampton, Cairns and Mackay using instalment purchase procedures.

In 1983 this Government introduced its instalment purchase program which was intended then to achieve two main objectives: Firstly, to increase the level of ownership of Commonwealth office accommodation requirements and, secondly, to stimulate what was then a very depressed building and construction industry. Because of budgetary considerations the program was based on these buildings being financed by the private sector. To expedite the program the design and construction phases were to be largely the responsibility of the developer selected for individual projects. The cost of instalments were seen as being largely offset by reductions in the Commonwealth rent vote.

The instalment purchase method is a new process for delivery of Commonwealth works and assets. There was no established methodology and the status of projects in terms of the Public Works Committee Act was uncertain. These aspects have been the subject of close consultation since inception between the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services, which is responsible for the whole program, and the Australian Government Solicitor. At the time the projects were included in the program the legal advice was that they were not subject to the Public Works Committee Act.

One of the major problems for the Australian Government Solicitor in providing legal advice as the program has developed has been the fact that there is no standard form of contract, each project is unique, and the form of the contract is critical to a decision on whether an instalment purchase project is a work as defined in the Act. On the 9th of this month the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services formally received legal advice that the instalment purchase project at Parramatta was within the definition of a public work as included in the Public Works Committee Act 1969. At this time the Parramatta project and a number of other projects were at an advanced stage of negotiations with respective developers. As the process is based on a fixed price contract the negotiations with the developer include provision for price escalation for delays in finalising the contract. If the projects were now referred to the Public Works Committee a delay of some weeks would occur before parliamentary approval could be forthcoming and consequently the final cost of the projects would escalate significantly. For the Parramatta project alone the escalation is currently some $200,000 per week of delay in signing the contract.

Because of the cost implications it has been necessary for the Government to consider whether the penalty for delaying these contracts is sufficient to seek exemption of these projects under section 18 (8) (b) of the Public Works Committee Act. After consultation with the Public Works Committee earlier today it has now been decided to proceed in this manner. In considering this approach the Public Works Committee has requested that the ministerial statement I am making include a statement outlining the Committee's viewpoint in regard to this action. I am very pleased to do so. I intend to read the Committee's statement which it provided to me today in full. This formal viewpoint which the Committee wishes to place on record is as follows:

On Friday, 13 September, the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services wrote to the Committee stating that the Attorney-General's Department advised that the proposal for office accommodation for the Commonwealth at Parramatta was a project which does come within the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act. On Wednesday last the Committee was provided with a briefing paper by the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services setting out details of the Commonwealth's instalment purchase program for a series of new office buildings which was introduced in 1983. The Committee is aware that previous interpretations of the legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department were that instalment purchase projects were not `public works'.

At a meeting of the Committee this morning the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services and the Minister for Housing and Construction explained the position and suggested that in view of the current state of negotiations with individual developers and the potential cost implications to the Commonwealth if the projects were delayed the most appropriate course of action would be for the Government to seek exemption from the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act, on the grounds of urgency. The Committee has recognised the Government's predicament but at the same time is conscious of its statutory responsibilities to Parliament and of the established principles of reporting on public works.

The Committee acknowledges that it is intended to refer two office accommodation future projects (Newcastle and Sydney) as part of new procedures being developed and which are not affected by the current situation.
The Committee accepts that there is nothing insidious to engage in instalment purchase. In fact, it helps reduce the Government's rental payments which have risen dramatically in recent years.

In summary, whilst having reservations on the Parramatta project in respect of a number of matters such as car parking, which the Committee conveyed to Ministers this morning, the Committee is prepared to accept the extraordinary circumstances in which the Government is placed and its need to seek approval of the Parliament for exempting specified projects from referral to the Public Works Committee. In saying this, the Committee emphasises that this position should in no way be construed as giving tacit approval to the proposals, about which we have been told very little. It should also be recorded that this action by the Government absolves the Committee from any subsequent criticism which may result from the implementation of the proposal or the completed development. We certainly were not involved or consulted at any stage in the development of the proposal.

That completes the quotation from the Committee which the Government undertook to put before the House in seeking the urgency exemption. Amendments to the Public Works Committee Act to ensure that the matter and method of handling instalment purchase are clearly defined and are being considered to ensure the removal of any remaining ambiguity in the Act. The broad estimated costs of these projects, including construction, financing and other related costs are: Parramatta, $110m to $115m; Fremantle, $15.6m; Wollongong, $16.5m; Dubbo, $8.1m; Rockhampton, $8.1m; Cairns, $7.5m; and Mackay, $6.3m.

Should the House agree to support this motion, negotiations can continue expeditiously towards formalising contracts for these works. In commending the motion to the House, I would like to thank all members of the Public Works Committee for the expeditious consideration that they have given to this matter. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to offer a brief comment more or less in my capacity as Vice-Chairman of the Public Works Committee, which was heavily involved in this matter. I think it would be fair to say that the Committee was a little discomfited by being confronted with a problem of such a unique character requiring action at such short notice. However, on consideration of all the circumstances, recognising the situation in which the Government found itself, acting on advice from the Attorney-General's Department which would have encouraged anybody to so move, in view of the fact that benefit would accrue to the taxpayer in respect of a saving in escalating costs and bearing in mind that some of the projects listed have actually been started, it would seem to have been less than charitable not to respond to the special circumstances. Whilst the Committee elected, as the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) pointed out, to offer a disclaimer, in the ultimate it saw that the situation would be best served by permitting the House the opportunity to resolve the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Moncrieff Electorate-Australian Sugar Industry-Economy: Farm Sector-Death of Dr Charles Rowley-Unemployment-CATA-Taxation-Student Assistance-South Australia: Water Resources-Mr Ben Chifley

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr West) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, 17 September, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) made a speech on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1985-86 in which he referred particularly to me and a subject which had been canvassed in a debate I participated in last week. In that speech the honourable member referred to me as `the honourable member for Moncrieff who, of course represents the Gold Goast-the blue rinse set, the millionaires club'. He went on to talk about a matter relevant to the western suburbs of Sydney. The inference of his speech is that I represent an area which has particular advantage in terms of income and he represents an area which does not, and that therefore my comments were unworthy.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to put a number of things on the record so that this House, the Government and particularly the honourable member for Chifley might better understand the facts of the electorate I represent and the problems that it faces, because I would not want to think that the Government is under the same misapprehension as the honourable member. In particular, in a couple of minutes I will ask for some undertakings to be given by the Minister who is given the opportunity to reply to this debate.

Every member of this House has been issued with a booklet called `Comparisons of 1981 Census Characteristics', which contains a break-up by Commonwealth electoral divisions based on 1984 boundaries. The booklet was issued by the Legislative Research Service of the Department of the Parliamentary Library. I want to run quickly through some of the salient statistics which indicate such things as income and standard of living in my electorate and in the electorate of Chifley. For example, that booklet reveals that the number of constituents with an income of below $8,000 is 36.7 per cent in the case of Moncrieff and only 26.5 per cent in the case of Chifley. Moncrieff ranks in the bottom one-third of electorates in terms of income, whereas Chifley ranks in the top one-third. Only 8.4 per cent of the population of Moncrieff enjoy an income of over $26,000. Exactly the same percentage applies to the people represented by the honourable member for Chifley. Lest it should be thought that this indicates something in terms of population characteristics, the booklet goes on to indicate that the median family income is $10,953 in the case of Moncrieff and $13,318 in the case of Chifley.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?
—The amount is $13,318. Going from lowest to highest, Moncrieff ranks 39th and Chifley 102nd, so Chifley is certainly not a deprived area in terms of family income.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, lest it should be thought that what I am saying is a misrepresentation because of pensioners, I wish to point out another salient figure. Six per cent of the population of Moncrieff is made up of single parent families while the figure for Chifley is 9.8 per cent.

Going from the smallest to the highest, Moncrieff ranks 122nd out of 148 electorates and Chifley ranks 148th. One would think that that, given the problems of the standards of living of single income families, would have put Chifley in a special income position, but taken in conjunction with the other statistics I have already given we see that it does not average out that way at all. I point out just one other figure that shows a parity between the two. The percentage of population not in the labour force is 58.7 per cent in the case of Moncrieff and 58.5 per cent-almost the same-in the case of Chifley. So the income factor cannot be attributed to retirees.

When we compare the standards of living of people in these two electorates on the basis of households we find that the number of households living in separate houses is 82.5 per cent in the case of Moncrieff and 92 per cent in the case of Chifley. The significance of that, of course, is that Moncrieff is more likely to have two families bringing an income into one household, thus rebutting any easy-but fake-explanation as to how so many households in Chifley can achieve the same income as households in Moncrieff. In fact, on average, more people are contributing to a household income in Moncrieff to get the same outcome as people in Chifley. The number of people either living in their own homes or purchasing their own homes amounts to 68.9 per cent in the case of Moncrieff and 66.3 per cent in the case of Chifley. Going from lowest to highest, their relative rankings are 50th and 69th, both in the bottom one-third of the Australian average. However, when we come to actual household commitments we find that people paying a monthly mortgage in excess of $250 a month represent 46.2 per cent in the case of Moncrieff as against only 34.1 per cent in the case of Chifley. Going from the lowest to highest, Chifley ranks 73rd and Moncrieff 124th, almost at the very top.

I raise this matter not just for the sake of pointing out a list of statistics but to point out that there are problems in the electorate of Moncrieff, in particular in relation to youth, which I do not have time to elaborate on now. However, there are two applications before this Government for special assistance to unemployed and homeless youth in the electorate of Moncrieff which need urgent support. I would hate to think that the Government was approaching these excellent, worthy and most deserving cases in the same bigoted frame of mind as the honourable member for Chifley.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first record of sugar manufacture in Australia was in New South Wales in 1823. The industry was established in southern Queensland in the 1860s and in the tropics in the 1870s. From the turn of the century to this day the sugar industry has occupied a dominant position in Australia's tropics from the standpoint of agriculture and manufacturing. Sugar cane is Queensland's second most important rural industry, with a gross value of production of $499m in 1983-84. Australia is the world's fourth largest sugar exporter. Australia has always fulfilled its quota and quality obligations under various international marketing arrangements to which it has been a party. As a result, the Australian sugar industry has earned a reputation as a reliable producer and supplier of quality raw sugar.

SPEECH.PARA: Queensland produces 94 per cent of our raw sugar. The balance is produced in New South Wales. Over 95 per cent of sugar cane production occurs on owner-operated family farms, with about 5 per cent produced on plantations owned and operated by proprietary milling companies. Most of the cane is produced on farms of between 30 and 100 hectares. There are about 6,600 cane farms, of which 6,000 are in Queensland. In the 1984 season the industry produced 3.55 million tonnes of 94 n.t. sugar from its 33 sugar mills. This sugar was produced from 25.5 million tonnes of cane harvested from an area of 312,000 hectares. A hectare of land yields about 80 tonnes of cane which, in turn, yields about 11 tonnes of raw sugar. The total value of assets employed in the industry by cane growers and sugar millers in cane farms, transport facilities and mills, exceeds $6 billion. A sugar industry report recently commissioned by the Federal and Queensland governments has estimated that in 1984 over $4 billion worth of national output was associated directly and indirectly with the sugar industry.

World sugar prices collapsed in 1981 to record lows and are not expected to increase substantially due to several factors. Until recently Australian producers to some extent were shielded against the sharp international downturn due to negotiated long term price contracts. However, with the collapse of negotiations to establish a new international sugar agreement in July 1984, the current depressed international prices will have serious consequences for the Australian sugar industry. The reasons for the low world price for sugar include a high level of world stocks, currently at about 40 per cent of annual consumption, the agricultural protectionist policies of the European Economic Community and the wider availability of alternative sweetners.

As a result of a collapse in world prices for sugar, Australia's sugar industry is teetering on the brink of a major disaster. Not only are hundreds of cane farmers facing bankruptcy, but also the crisis is already having an effect on local business and employment. There has been a loss of business confidence. The crisis has created a potential loss of local government revenue and consequent implications for community and district infrastructure.

The worsening crisis is threatening the very livelihood of towns and shires which traditionally relied on sugar cane farming to maintain the local economy. Land which is no longer needed for sugar cane production has limited alternative economic opportunities. The sugar industry is regarded as the most highly socialised rural industry in Australia, with the production of raw sugar, the price of refined sugar and imports of sugar to Australia controlled by either, or both, the Federal and State governments.

The problems of the sugar industry crisis are not just confined to sugar cane growers. Tens of thousands of Australians earn their livelihood directly or indirectly from the sugar industry.
