The collapse of the sugar industry will affect not only those people directly involved in the industry but also the people who live in the sugar towns which are highly dependent upon the industry for survival. Unemployment will increase. Investment in the areas will be low so that unemployment levels will remain high. Tens of thousands of Australians are realising that their future and the future of their children is at stake. They are depending on the Federal Government and the Queensland Government to provide immediately a package of financial aid and other measures to rescue the great Australian sugar industry from calamity. Sugar industry representatives fear, with justification, that the Queensland Government is playing politics at their expense. How long must cane farmers, their families and the tens of thousands of Australians dependent upon the sugar industry for their livelihood, tolerate the Queensland Government playing politics at their expense?

Federal Cabinet will meet in Townsville next week. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) will meet with sugar industry representatives and other members of the community. North Queenslanders will have the opportunity of talking with their Prime Minister. The Minister for Primary Industry will be able to tell north Queenslanders the present state of his negotiations with the Queensland Government on the 100-day committee report. The people of north Queensland trust and admire the Hawke Government. In their hour of need they ask for assistance in equal measures from the Federal and State governments. In return for this support, I am confident that the sugar industry will diligently endeavour to put right its affairs and resolutely address itself to the world market situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to bring to the attention of the House a very interesting paper produced by the Centre for Economic Policy Research at the Australian National University. I think it is particularly appropriate to mention it tonight in light of the rotten deal that the rural sector has received in regard to the third instalment of the Budget announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). In this paper Dr Paul O'Mara discusses the contribution of the farm sector to annual variations in the gross domestic product. In fact, he points out that the importance of the farm sector is growing as far as GDP is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: While the paper relies on an empirical model, the conclusions make fascinating reading. Furthermore, the conclusions highlight what country people have been saying for years. No doubt those honourable members who have bothered to listen to people in the country have heard it often. Many is the time I have heard older people from both sides of the political fence say that when things go well in the country everyone benefits, and when they do not, the cities feel the pinch too. How many other members have heard it? Maybe now we have some real evidence to back that experienced judgment.

In this excellent paper Dr O'Mara, who is now working for the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, discusses the linkages between the farm sector and the main economy. His findings should be heeded. The summary of the main conclusions gives a clear message-that is, the ups and downs of farming, rather than having less effect on the overall economy, may in fact be increasing. In other words, cities are not too remote to feel a rural recession. We now have some empirical evidence to support the importance of the fortunes of primary industry for all Australia. In his summary, Dr O'Mara states in part:

There is considerable evidence that the relative contribution of the farm sector to annual changes in non-farm output has not declined over this period and may even have increased. This is despite the fact that the relative contribution of the farm sector to the absolute values of variables such as GDP, employment and exports has declined substantially over the period.
Further on Dr O'Mara states:
There is some evidence, however, that the overall importance of this channel of influence has tended to increase in the 1970s, reflecting the greater volatility of farm prices since the early 1970s.
In his conclusion Dr O'Mara states:

Finally, the results presented in the present paper could be interpreted as implying that a satisfactory and consistent treatment of the farm sector in Australian macroeconomic models has become more, rather than less, important over time.

I emphasise that last point `more, rather than less, important over time'. I trust that all honourable members will remember this. Those 100,000 farmers who marched already know it. It is time that the rest of Australia woke up to it. The treatment of the farm sector by this Government, especially tonight, has been one of the great disappointments of this Labor Government. Blind Freddie could tell us something is wrong on the farm. This year we have seen unprecedented numbers of farmers marching in an orderly manner in Perth, Adelaide, Melbourne and Canberra. Over 100,000 farmers have demonstrated their concern. Believe me, farmers would not be doing this unless there was something fundamentally wrong. Farmers do not take three days off and drive hundreds of kilometres just to have a picnic.

Let us look at some of the effects of tonight's announcement of the third instalment of a Budget on the farm sector. We have seen a capital gains tax. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has gone to great pains to say that it is not a death duty, but it is. It means that if a farm is handed on to a member of the family who then sells it, he is slugged with a capital gains tax. There is no doubt about it. It is a death duty by another name. If we look further at it we see the business of eliminating off-farm income being offset against losses. But how do most farmers start these days? They start as shearers and take jobs off the farm. Quite a few of them are fortunate enough to marry school teachers who help them to buy a farm. This is the way that people get into agriculture.

I suggest to honourable members that the paper that Dr O'Mara has produced should be heeded by all members of the House because it shows what we have been trying to tell the Government for ages-that the farm sector is important and that, when things are going down on the farm, the rest of Australia will feel it. It is not just a question of ignoring farming. It is increasing in its importance for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Charles Rowley, who died yesterday, was a pioneer in changing the attitudes of white Australians to Aborigines. He had a combination of qualities which inspired respect-fine scholarship, a strong sense of justice, determination and boundless common sense. He led the struggle for land rights for Aborigines through his rigorous analysis of the history of injustice to Aborigines and his quiet but tenacious advocacy of humane, equitable policies.

SPEECH.PARA: Charles Rowley grew up in central New South Wales towns where his father was a mounted policeman and gold warden. Scholarships enabled him to attend high school and Sydney University. After over a decade as a secondary school teacher he enlisted in 1942 and was discharged as a lieutenant colonel in 1946. He served with that unorthodox military unit of visionaries and pragmatists, of poets and agricultural scientists, the Directorate of Research. The Australian School of Pacific Administration, of which he became principal in 1951, was a practical decendant of the Directorate. His book The New Guinea Villages exemplifies his approach of teaching field officers to view with informed compassion the process of social change going on amongst the people with whom they worked.

In 1964 he was appointed director of the Aboriginal research project of what became the Australian Academy of the Social Sciences. His own three volumes, The Destruction of Aboriginal Society, Outcasts of White Australia and The Remote Aborigines are a monument to his capacity to cut across disciplinary boundaries, take the best intellectual tools and data, apply his own sharp common sense and industry and produce pioneering work of sustained high quality. The community is still catching up with the mass of material contained in those 1,200 pages. He transferred the calm, direct courteousness of his speech to his prose; but there is also a passion for justice that gives power to his writing. His accurate statement of the facts of history is more shocking than any rhetoric. As the foundation Professor of Politics at the University of Papua New Guinea he taught many of those now holding senior positions in parliament and the public service. His humanism and intellectual rigor were just right for Papua New Guinea on the eve of independence.

On returning to Australia in 1974 he became Executive Director of the Academy. In 1975 the Whitlam Government also appointed him as Chairman of the Commonwealth's Aboriginal Land Fund Commission, which was given the responsibility and opportunity of buying back land for dispossessed Aborigines. His 1978 book A Matter of Justice broke through the complexity and prevarication of official policy of the time to make a clear statement of the requirements for justice for Aborigines. One of his most penetrating insights was into the inconsistency in the treatment of the indigenous people and their land in Australia and Papua New Guinea. He said in an address after receiving an honorary doctorate from the Australian National University in 1983:

The British annexation of land as Crown land legally pauperised Aboriginal clans . . . no law recognised Aboriginal ownership of land. In contrast . . . the original promise to the Papuans-`your lands will be reserved unto you'-was, in general, kept.

Charles Rowley was a reasonable man; wise and honest, passionate and tenacious in the struggle for justice, but also unpretentious and self-effacing. He was universally respected by colleagues and generations of students. His spirit will live on in his writing and the affection of those who knew him. Our heartfelt sympathy goes to his wife, Irene, and his son, Brian. We who mourn him can celebrate him best by rededicating ourselves to achieve justice for Aborigines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I want to express my very great concern about the unemployed youth of Australia.
—What about the assets test?

—The assets test will keep. We will come back to that some other time. I want to state the fact that in the electorate of Cowper in the age group between 15 and 19 years unemployment has jumped by 20 per cent just in the last 12 months to June. I want to refer to a pledge made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) which, I believe, is one of the cruellest things that has ever been done to the youth of this country. As appeared in the Australian Financial Review of 15 July 1985, the Prime Minister claimed that he would wipe out unemployment for 16 and 17-year-olds and virtually eliminate unemployment for 18 and 19-year-olds. Obviously; if that could be achieved it would be marvellous. Frankly, if it can be achieved I will be the first to salute and applaud the Prime Minister for achieving it.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at act two of the Budget, which was the August part of the Budget in its three parts, and examine just what the situation is in relation to youth we see that for youth, including apprenticeship training and the new traineeship schemes, an additional $25.6m was allocated. At the same time job creation, including the community employment program, was down by $174.9m. That means that in reality the funds available for the youth of this country are down by $122.3m. That is far too much. The funds being provided to technical and further education are down. The number of teaching hours available for training youth are down very much as well.

With this highly commendable ambition, just how is the Hawke Government going to achieve that promise and wipe out unemployment for 16 and 17-year-olds and virtually eliminate unemployment for 18 and 19-year-olds? I believe that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has given us the secret of this. On page five of his Budget Speech he said:
In a nutshell, we have developed a comprehensive four-year plan designed to encourage young people to remain in education rather than opt out and pick up unemployment benefits.

At first glance that seems highly commendable too. But really it would appear that keeping the kids at school is the secret plan to wipe out artificially unemployment for the youngsters. I cannot agree with that. The cost in 1985-86 will be $35m; in 1986-87, $86m; in 1987-88, $170m; and in 1988-89, $251m. That is a great deal of money. I would be the first to acclaim the fact that it would be wonderful to have more educated Australians. People, and young people in particular, are the most important resource of this country, and training for employment is vital. But where are the jobs? If we keep the kids in school with the aim of getting rid of unemployment, we have to provide jobs. I suspect that the Labor Government plans to keep the children at school as a smokescreen to reduce unemployment artificially so that it can continue to praise itself.

My colleagues and the rest of Australia know the sort of praise that is given. We have heard phrases such as the world's best Treasurer, and words such as `great' and `stunning'. Even in the Budget Speech the Treasurer referred to the historic trilogy. It takes more than self-praise and blowing one's own trumpet to achieve a satisfactory result in ending unemployment.

I conclude by saying that if this is how Labor will wipe out unemployment for 16- and 17-year-olds, it should reconsider. We should be planning to provide jobs, not just to push aside the kids and baby-sit them in schools. It is a question of providing real jobs, not just keeping them out of circulation. Even though it is cheaper to keep the kids at school-it costs only $23.05 a week in secondary school fees, whereas the dole is $45 a week-I appeal to the Government to provide jobs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the House to the success and dedication of a group in my electorate which assists disabled people within the Wanneroo Shire and enables them to undertake craft therapy and social activities in a welcoming environment outside their own homes. I made brief mention of this group, the Creative and Therapy Activities Association, in the course of my maiden speech in this House, indicating at that time that it was seeking government financial assistance but did not easily fit into any of the existing funding categories. The group, commonly called CATA, has grown out of a scheme set up in 1979 by the welfare section of the Wanneroo Shire Council's health department. Its aim is to improve the quality of life for those who are housebound through age, disability, accident or illness, and for their caring partners. Its objective is to provide a stepping stone from being housebound to being involved in the community. CATA is the least restrictive alternative for disabled people. It is multidiagnostic, covering 34 different disabilities, including arthritis, multiple sclerosis, epilepsy, agoraphobia and speech impairment. It caters for both men and women from 20 to 90 years of age and provides its members with access to a wide range of therapy and activities such as arts, crafts, table games, swimming, riding and sulky driving.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage I outline the history of CATA's formation. Commencing in August 1979, when 13 people met once a fortnight in the home of an arts and craft therapist, CATA has progressed steadily to a membership in excess of 120 people who are able to be involved in activities at least four times a week at venues in either Warwick or Yanchep. My colleague the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) assisted the group to obtain a community employment program grant in late 1983, and subsequently a full time co-ordinator was appointed for a 12-month period. Earlier this year, on cessation of the CEP grant, the Wanneroo Shire generously contributed interim funding for a two- or three-month period in recognition of the value of the service provided by CATA to the disabled residents of the Shire. At that time also I joined the honourable member for Moore and our State Labor colleagues in the northern metropolitan corridor in an earnest personal appeal to the Western Australian Minister for Health for the provision of some funds to this unique group. Happily, after due consideration of the merits of our request, the Minister was able to allocate short term one-off assistance of $10,000 pending finalisation of the home and community care program guidelines this year.

I am pleased that the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) has undertaken to attend the official opening of CATA's open week at the Dorchester Hall in Warwick tomorrow night. The Minister is no stranger to the operation and achievements of this group, having visited it previously to view its activities and discuss a request for funds. On this occasion, the Minister will have the opportunity of inspecting an impressive display of arts and crafts, including examples of painting, basket weaving and chocolate making.

CATA provides an excellent example of community effort, dedication and co-operation. It continues to exist today by virtue of the combined endeavour and good will of local, State and Federal government representatives together with the hard work and commitment of a host of willing volunteers. The members of the group are especially deserving of praise for their continued enthusiasm in the face of great difficulty and adversity. The philosophy underlying this group's success and motivation is summed up in its newsletter Stepping Stone:
We are supports, not crutches: We are self-help, not dependency. We are a group, not an institution. We care, not smother, and We help, but are not used.
CATA has brought an essential service and facility to the disabled people in my electorate. It deserves the certainty which assured government funding provides.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tax package which has been introduced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in this House this evening is, as we all know, a savage attack on the wealth creators in our economy, the business sector and our primary producers; there is no doubt about that. But tonight I want to talk about one specific aspect of this new tax package, and that is the way the Treasurer and the Government have singled out the State of South Australia for particularly discriminatory and harsh action.
—Bannon will lose the next election.

—Exactly. Obviously the Government is totally unconcerned about the future of the Premier of South Australia, Mr Bannon, and his enfeebled Government, and this tax package is without any doubt the last nail in the Bannon Government's coffin. The Premier of Western Australia, at least to give him some credit, has a minuscule degree of influence over the Federal Government in being successful in getting the gold tax deferred for at least six months, but no such deal has been negotiated by the ineffectual and incompetent South Australian Government led by the Premier, Mr Bannon.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to go through one or two specific areas where this tax package particularly discriminates against the State of South Australia. In the first place the tax on fringe benefits will have an extraordinarily negative effect on my State. Honourable members will be aware that the State of South Australia is the heartland of Australia's automotive manufacturing industry. They will also be aware that the fringe benefits tax will have a particularly severe effect on the motor vehicle industry, and practically every motor vehicle manufacturer in Australia has been making that point ever since the White Paper was introduced, and indeed even the vehicle builders union has made that very same point. The motor vehicle industry is central to the South Australian economy; it is one of the industries that will suffer because of this package. Between 50 and 60 per cent of General Motors-Holden's cars are company cars, around 40 per cent of Mitsubishi's cars are company cars. The result of the tax on fringe benefits inevitably will be a reduction in demand for those cars and inevitably will lead to a loss of jobs in those industries. That ultimately means a loss of jobs in the State of South Australia.

One could turn to the measure that has been taken in relation to taxation on entertainment. This measure obviously will hit the restaurant industry in every single part of Australia, but I do not want to dwell on that. One aspect of entertainment that is relevant to South Australia that will be hit is the wine industry-that long suffering industry which was promised no specific wine tax by the Australian Labor Party during the 1983 election campaign, but was subsequently hit with a 10 per cent wine tax.

The people living and working in districts such as the Southern Vales of South Australia and Langhorne Creek, all of whom are in my electorate, are the ones who will suffer as a result of the taxation measures taken against business entertainment. They will suffer because they have had a 10 per cent wine tax and now once again the wine industry will suffer a reduction in demand as a result of these measures.

One could also add that the tax deductions taken away from business for other forms of entertainment will inevitably lead to less demand from business for seats for Mr Bannon's famous Grand Prix, which is to be held in Adelaide. No doubt there will also be a reduction in business demand for the casino. All these specific measures are seemingly designed to discriminate against South Australia. If one can put it another way, these measures prove that the Premier of South Australia and his Government are completely ineffectual in influencing a Labor government in Canberra. The only satisfactory result for South Australia in the months ahead will be to turf out the Bannon Government and replace it with a Liberal government led by the distinguished Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Olsen.

The Bannon Government has brought South Australia to its knees with a 47 1/2 per cent increase in State taxes since Bannon was elected. Interest rates in the State are higher than ever and unemployment has gone up by 6,000 people and inflation by 7 1/2 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fatin Ms W.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, we have heard a great deal in recent weeks about the new traineeship programs which are being introduced by the Federal Government as part of the new package for youth known as Priority One. What I want to discuss briefly this evening are some other aspects of the package which seem to me to be just as significant as the traineeships and equally vital to the ultimate goal of expanding the options available to young people in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is generally agreed that young people have a far better chance of finding and retaining employment if they have completed their secondary education and obtained some job-oriented qualifications. There are two basic issues for government to confront in this area. The first is that some families and young people may simply not be able to afford to stay at school past the minimum leaving age or go on to study at technical colleges or universities. The second is that some young people may find the option of leaving school more attractive financially, even if their chances of finding employment are slim.

The first of these problems has been very positively addressed by the Government in the Priority One youth package. The maximum benefit payable under the secondary allowance scheme-SAS-will be increased from $23.05 to $35 a week in 1986. This is an increase of more than 50 per cent. In addition, the income test applied under the scheme will be eased. In 1986 the level of adjusted family income at which the maximum allowance is paid will go up by 5 per cent from $14,281 to $14,995.

Another point of great significance is that levels of student assistance and income test levels will be indexed in future to ensure that the level of assistance will be maintained over a period. I know that this move will be warmly welcomed by parents and students who have been arguing the case for years.

There will also be changes affecting levels of assistance paid to tertiary students next year. Maximum benefit for the tertiary education assistance scheme will be raised from $44.51 to $47.50 a week for students living at home and from $68.67 to $73.28 for those living away from home. The income test will be eased in the same way as for the payment of SAS. The basic idea behind these changes is to simplify the whole structure of youth allowances, remove inequities and give young people some real encouragement to stay at school or college.

This brings me to the second problem, which has also been thoroughly tackled in the Priority One youth package. The increases in student allowance which I have just been outlining are only the first step in removing the gap between the amount paid to young people who leave school without a job and those who stay at school. Over the next few years, we will be gradually moving towards the stage where we have a single age-related scheme for young people, whether they are students or unemployed. This will obviously provide a very strong incentive for further study, both at secondary and tertiary levels.

Students and parents will obviously want to take all these changes into account before making decisions about the 1986 academic year and beyond. I want to finish by telling the House about how parents, teachers and young people can find out about all the details of eligibility and payment rates which I have not had time to explain this evening.

The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) has just informed me that application forms and publicity material will be distributed to all secondary schools in the very near future. To ensure that as many students as possible benefit from the increased allowances, information will also be sent to education authorities and interest groups. The Commonwealth Department of Education will be pleased to send representatives to school careers nights, meetings of school guidance officers or any other meetings with people who have regular contact with students and their parents. In addition, an information card will be sent to people receiving family allowance benefits for children turning 16, and a leaflet in various community languages will be distributed in the appropriate places.

I close by joining other members of this House in welcoming all the measures contained in the Priority One package, and by saying that I am looking forward to meeting with various groups of parents, students and youth workers in the electorate of Brand to discuss the new proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was forced into speaking in the adjournment debate tonight by the speech delivered by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). I support what the honourable member for Mayo said about the absolute failure of the Premier of South Australia to protect his State from what has been an erosion of its rights and privileges under the tax package which has been delivered today. The honourable member for Mayo touched on the dilemma that faces the motor vehicle industry and the dilemma that the wine industry may well face. I am even more acutely affected than the honourable member by that erosion as I represent both the Clare Valley and the Barossa Valley in this House and, as a result, am the envy of a number of honourable members. It is not only the wine industry to which I want to draw the House's attention tonight. That has been more than adequately covered by the honourable member for Mayo. I draw the House's attention to the attack on South Australia that is contained on page 15 of the Statement entitled `Reform of the Australian Taxation System'. Under the heading `Water Conservation' the Treasurer (Mr Keating) took the liberty of stating:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has decided to replace the immediate deduction currently allowed for expenditure by primary producers on conserving or conveying water with a write-off in equal instalments over 5 years.

The opportunity to write-off irrigation and water conveyancing has been a major influence in the electorate of Wakefield and in South Australia. Everyone knows that South Australians get the drainage water left over from the eastern States but few people appreciate the major factor that this write-off provision has been in cleaning up South Australia's water. Few people appreciate that the established irrigation areas in South Australia-government irrigation areas-have historically been irrigated by a flood irrigation technique. This opportunity to upgrade irrigation techniques has done more than anything else to improve water quality in South Australia. Instead of primary producers choosing to irrigate by the extravagant flood irrigation technique, they have chosen the alternatives of drip irrigation and low throw microjet irrigation to apportion water not to each acre but to each tree. So each tree gets the water it will use. Primary producers have been encouraged to do this by using the existing facility which has just been denied them by the Treasurer's package. This will be disastrous.

The Government's decision to install a major evaporation works at Noora, just out of Loxton, proved to be over-engineered when growers chose to change their irrigation technique so that they applied proportionately only the amount of water the crop needed. The drainage that once resulted from flood irrigation no longer occurred because little more than the water the plant needed was being applied. That change meant that the Noora Basin was over-engineered and it heralded a real change in water conservation in South Australia. That, of course, is now under threat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is your farm?
—I have a farm in the irrigation area so affected and that is why I speak-
—Are you declaring your interest?

—Of course, and that is why I speak with some compassion, because I know precisely what happens to irrigation water when it is other than carefully applied. This exercise will cost the Government money because we will cease to encourage-
—It will cost you money.

—No, not at all. I have done it. I have taken advantage of it, and I know how important it is. We will now deny growers the opportunity to use this particular irrigation application technique. The alternative will be an enormous evaporation scheme which would be quite unnecessary if we encouraged individual growers in South Australia to use carefully the water that is available to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —1985 marks the centenary of the birth of two great Australians-former Labor Prime Ministers John Curtin and Ben Chifley. I have a special interest in highlighting the significance of the birth of Ben Chifley, as this Sunday, 22 September, marks the centenary of his birth in the city of Bathurst, the oldest inland city in Australia, which is also celebrating the centenary of its declaration as a city. It is therefore important, as this event approaches, to reflect on the life of Ben Chifley.

SPEECH.PARA: Much of his early childhood was spent living with his grandparents where he was exposed to the world of bush politics, as well as witnessing the devastation of the Depression which swept Australia in the 1890s. He returned to Bathurst where he endeavoured to catch up on a missed education. On leaving school he first worked in a local store and then a tannery before, in 1903, embarking on his career with the railway, where he worked his way up to a first class driver. The bitter experience of the great strike in 1917, and his involvement and concern with his union, took him on a path which led him to Federal politics. He won the seat of Macquarie in 1928, and in 1929 joined the Scullin Cabinet as Minister for Defence, only to lose his seat when the Government fell. He stood twice unsuccessfully for Macquarie, having to wait until 1940 before winning a seat. In these intervening years Chifley spent his energies in setting up a new party machine in the wake of Lang Labor, as well as serving as a councillor on the Abercrombie Shire and as a member of the local hospital board. He took on the position of Treasurer in Curtin's Government and on 12 July 1945 assumed the position of Prime Minister only a month before World War II ended and a week after Curtin's death.

He played a leading and inspirational role in Australia's post-war reconstruction. However, difficulties appeared on the political horizon for him over the question of bank nationalisation, petrol rationing and, finally, coal strikes in 1949. Chifley's Government was ultimately defeated at the 1949 election. He continued to work hard in Opposition. In 1950 he suffered a coronary occlusion, but soon returned to politics were he threw himself, once again, into the fray by preparing for and fighting an election campaign in April 1951. His health, however, had been irreparably damaged and he died at work after suffering a heart attack on 13 June 1951. He was buried in Bathurst where thousands turned out to honour the city's most famous son.

To mark the occasion, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will deliver the inaugural `Light on the Hill' Chifley Seminar Memorial Trust address at the Mitchell College of Advanced Education at Bathurst this Saturday, 21 September. It is proposed that each year a prominent Australian will be invited to Bathurst to address a similar function and to outline his or her vision for the future; in other words, to explain their light on the hill. In the words of J. B. Chifley:

If I think a thing is worth fighting for, no matter what the penalty is, I will fight for the right, and truth and justice will always prevail. I try to think of the Labor movement . . . as a movement bringing something better to the people; better standards of living, greater happiness to the mass of the people. We have a great objective-the light on the hill-which we aim to reach by working for the betterment of mankind not only here but anywhere we may give a helping hand.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mrs Sullivan

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated at the end of my speech earlier that I had a particular point to make on youth unemployment in the electorate of Moncrieff. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table which illustrates my case.

INTERJECT.PARA: ELECTORATES OF MONCRIEFF AND McPHERSON-YOUTH UNEMPLOYMENT RATES
1. Moncrieff and McPherson-population as a percentage of Queensland's population...
2. Moncrieff and McPherson-15-24-year-old unemployed persons as a percentage of total Queensland 15-24-year-old unemployed persons...
3. Moncrieff and McPherson-population as a percentage of Australia's population...
4. Moncrieff and McPherson-15-24-year-old unemployed persons as a percentage of total Australian 15-24-year-old unemployed persons...

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted. The House stands adjourned until 2 p.m., Tuesday, 8 October 1985.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following notice was given:
Mr Braithwaite to move-
That this House-
(1) recognises the crisis which exists within the sugar industry, caused by the lowest world prices in real terms;
(2) recognises that Australia's return from sugar exports is expected to decline further over the next 3 years;
(3) recalls that in previous crises, particular in 1966-67, the Government supported the price to canegrowers whilst the Queensland Government concentrated its support to millers, and

(4) calls on the Government to accept its responsibilities to the sugar industry, and immediately implement an effective price support scheme to the industry, and share in the provision of the necessary reconstruction funding required through rural adjustment.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which section of this Department is responsible for (a) relations with Australian defence industry, (b) relations with overseas defence industry, (c) defence industry policy and policy implementation, (d) sales of defence equipment overseas, (e) defence purchasing, and (f) the Williamstown dockyard and follow-on destroyer project management.
(2) In each case, what is the chain of responsibility from the Minister to the person in charge of each section.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Relations with Australian defence industry are both formal and informal in nature, and are wide ranging.

The focus of the Department's consultation with industry is the Defence Industry Committee in which senior representatives of industry, the Services and Government departments develop advice to the Minister for Defence on defence industry issues. Other consultation machinery focuses specifically on the Department's responsibilities in the aerospace industry, in munitions production and quality control.

Commercial relations with industry are undertaken by officers in the Department who exercise purchasing and contracting delegations. These are located in the Capital Procurement Organisation, Defence Logistics Organisation, Office of Defence Production, Defence Science and Technology Organisation, Defence Purchasing Organisation and individual Service Offices.

(1) (b) Relations with overseas defence industry are focused through Defence representation overseas. Defence industry representatives known as Defence industry Attaches are located in the Australian Embassy in Washington and the High Commission in London. The Defence Industry and Materiel Policy Division is responsible for the development of policy guidance conveyed through those representatives.
Detailed negotiations with overseas owned companies that do business in Australia are undertaken by those who exercise the delegations outlined in 1 (a).

(1) (c) This function is centralised with the Capital Procurement Organisation. The Defence Industry and Materiel Policy Division is responsible for industry policy and the recently created Defence Industry Development Division for policy implementation.
The Defence Logistics Organisation and the Defence Science and Technology Organisation implement policies relating to logistics support and scientific and technical liaison with industry.
The Office of Defence Production is responsible for the management of the ordnance and explosives factories, the government dockyards and aircraft factory.

(1) (d) The export of defence materiel overseas is controlled under Schedule 13 of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations of the Customs Act 1901. Authority to approve export of all items in the Schedule lies with the Minister for Defence, and is subject to formal agreement on a case-by-case basis with the Minister for Foreign Affairs.
Within the Department of Defence, the intitial contact point on export proposals covered by Schedule 13 is the Defence Industry Development Division.
Defence areas consulted in policy consideration of particular proposals include:
the Strategic and International Policy Division,
the Defence Industry and Materiel Policy Division,
the Assistant Chief of Defence Force Policy, and
(1) (e) Defence purchasing is the responsibility of Deputy Secretary C.
(1) (f) The Office of Defence Production is responsible for the management of Williamstown Dockyard. Australian Frigate project management is the responsibility of the Chief of Naval Materiel.
(2) The chain of responsibility is through the Chief of the Defence Force and the Military Command or through the Secretary and the functional Divisions of the Department.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Victorian Joint Parliamentary Salinity Committee Report

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 21 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Has his attention been drawn to the final report of the Salinity Committee of the Victorian Parliament; if so, what is the response of the Government to the proposals on inter-governmental co-operation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: My attention has been drawn to the final report of the Victorian Joint Parliamentary Salinity Committee entitled `Salt of the Earth'. The Victorian Premier has written to the Prime Minister seeking the Commonwealth's views on recommendations relating to a salinity control strategy for Victoria. There are two recommendations in the report addressed specifically to the Commonwealth.

With regard to Recommendation 44 relating to the establishment of a Murray Basin Forum, the Government's view is that, while the matter might be kept under review, formal creation of the proposed forum does not appear to be justified at this stage. Opportunities already exist for the public at large, and interest groups in particular, to channel their views on river management and associated problems to the River Murray Commission, and likewise to be informed by the Commission at first hand of its response to these concerns, as well as its own plans for the future.

With regard to Recommendation 45 relating to strategies for controlling salinity in northern Victoria, the Commonwealth has provided almost $11 million since 1978-79 for most of the components identified by the consultants as key elements of future control strategies. This assistance will continue under the Federal Water Resources Assistance Program, subject to budgetary constraints.

The honourable member will no doubt have read a joint press statement of 19 August by the Prime Minister and the Premiers of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, foreshadowing a meeting of Commonwealth and State Ministers in November in Adelaide to discuss land and water management issues in the Murray Basin, and options for improved co-ordination in these matters. I have no doubt that the report of the Victorian Joint Parliamentary Salinity Committee will be a valuable contribution to these discussions.

Where the demands of production are likely to be beyond departmental resources, Film Australia is contracted to produce, or assist in production of, films and videos.
Internal production is carried out principally by the following functional areas:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 21 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that Australia Council funding, through its Community Arts Board, to the Arts Council has been severely reduced, both federally and to some State Divisions.
(2) Does this represent a deliberate change of policy towards the Arts Council; if so, what is the reason for the change.
(3) Has the decision meant that some country areas are now being denied access to arts programs which have been provided in the past through Arts Council touring programs.
(4) What action has been or will be taken to ensure that people living outside the major metropolitan centres of Australia have access to as wide a range of arts programs as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australia Council has informed me that:

(1) Grants for 1984/85 by the Community Arts Board to the Australian Capital Territory, Queensland and Victoria Divisions of the Arts Council were each reduced by 20%. Grants by the Board to the other State Divisions were increased by 6.5%. The Arts Council of the Northern Territory received the same amount of funding as the previous year. The Arts Council of Australia, Federal Division, was allocated $120,000 in 1983/84 and $5,000 in 1984/85, reflecting a significant variation in the structure and operations of the Division which now no longer operates as a permanent Secretariat at the National level.

(2) Yes. The decision allows the Community Arts Board to assess applications under its programs of assistance and gives it greater flexibility in the allocation of funds. As well, since 1983, intra-State touring has been regarded as predominantly a State/Territory responsibility rather than a Federal responsibility.

(3) and (4) While Community Arts Board criteria under the new funding arrangements for State Arts Councils do not include support for intra-State touring, the Council continues to offer support for intra-State tours which satisfy the criteria of the Touring and Access Fund established in 1983. The Fund supports projects which enable communities in more remote areas to have access to the performing arts and which at the same time encourage interaction between touring artists and the communities they visit. In 1984/85 the Australia Council allocated $810,000 for the Touring and Access Fund of which $304,974 (20 grants) was allocated to intra-State tours.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 28 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What South African companies invest in Australia.
(2) What is the leading economic activity of each of these companies.
(3) Does the South African Governement maintain a trade promotion office in Australia; if so, how many staff does it employ.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Information on Australian/South African investment is collected but, for legal and commercial confidentiality reasons, it is not possible to release information about the particular companies involved. In particular, in the course of administration of the Government's foreign investment policy the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) has access to information relating to proposed investments in Australia by South African companies. Because of the commercial sensitivity attaching to the information provided to the FIRB in connection with foreign investment proposals, however, it has been longstanding practice for the Government to treat all such information in strict confidence and not to disclose details of proposals or of the parties to the proposals, except in special cirucumstances and where the parties' consent is first obtained. In these special cases, the Treasurer issues a press release on the particular proposal. Companies directly owned by South African interests which proposed to invest in Australia in the past five years and on which press releases have been issued are:
mining, processing and marketing of industrial minerals
manufacture and distribution of diamond impregnated industrial tools and drilling bits

The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) also collects information on investment flows to and from South Africa. The secrecy provisions of the Census and Statistics Act prevent release by the ABS of information identifying particular companies. The maintenance of confidentiality in respect of commercial information is essential for the efficient operation of the ABS and FIRB.

(3) The South African Government maintains an office of the South African Trade Commissioner in Melbourne employing a staff of 2 officials with three administrative staff. There is also a Consulate of South Africa located in Sydney which employs four consular officers, including a Consul (Commercial) and Vice Consul (Commercial) and an administrative staff of eleven.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.

Drug Operations including attachment to Joint Task Force...

(6) There will never be enough resources to meet every criminal threat or action. The Government announced on 13 November 1984 its commitment to:
