ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 7 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What funds have been made available through the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation to combat the problem of millipedes which is currently affecting large areas of south eastern Australia.
(2) What research is currently being undertaken by CSIRO into the problem of millipedes.

(3) How many officers within CSIRO are currently engaged in research or work to eradicate the problem of millipedes on (a) a full time basis and (b) a part time basis and what is the location of these officers.
(4) Have funds been allocated through CSIRO for officers to undertake a research program overseas into millipedes and their eradication.

(5) Have officers of CSIRO identified a realistic period over which a biological agent can be captured in Portugal, specificity tested and synchronised so that its breeding cycle is re-oriented from Northern Hemisphere reproduction habits to those of the Southern Hemisphere.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A total of $104,700 has been expended by CSIRO between 1979-80 and 1983-84 in a study of the Portuguese millipede in Portugal (to which country it is native). An identical sum was contributed to the project by the South Australian Department of Agriculture. These funds were used by CSIRO to employ a millipede specialist, Dr G. H. Baker, who spent the period October 1980 to January 1983 in Portugal where a locally engaged technician was employed to assist him in his study of the biological control of the pest. A parasitic fly was identified as being worthy of close study as a possible control organism in Australia. From January 1983 to December 1983 Dr Baker was based at the Department's laboratories in Adelaide where he prepared a final report on his overseas studies, and carried out further observations on the millipede in South Australia. Departmental support terminated in December 1983, and Dr Baker has since been based at the CSIRO Division of Soils in Adelaide, and is currently studying another pest problem. However, Department support was temporarily renewed for the purpose of sending Dr Baker on a three-week return visit to Portugal in August 1984 to collect further specimens of a parasite he had discovered earlier. These were consigned to the Department which had appointed staff to carry out research on the millipede and its parasites.
(2) CSIRO is not currently involved in research on the Portuguese millipede.
(3) None, although Dr Baker has continued to provide advice on request from departmental officers.
(5) No, but discussions are currently in progress between CSIRO and the Department of Agriculture on the most effective way in which further research on the millipede might be undertaken.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 7 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many employees of Australia Post at Leightonfield Mail Exchange, New South Wales, have been off work on sick leave or workers compensation due to an `itchy rash' or similar skin trouble in each month since July 1984.
(2) Were any of these employees medically examined by a dermatologist at the request of the employer; if so, what was the determination of the specialist as to the cause of the rash.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on information provided by the Australian Postal Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The only cases of an `itchy rash' or similar skin trouble at the Leightonfield Mail Centre were reported in October and November 1984. Three and eleven employees respectively attended a doctor, or were off work on sick leave or had claimed, or were on employees compensation.
(2) Yes. The Commonwealth Medical Officer referred six employees (one employee attended twice) for examination by specialist dermatologists who found the cause of the rash to be-
in two cases, consistent with a mite bite
in one case, a form of dermatitis
in one case, consistent with a hive or nettle rash.
In the remaining three cases, there was nothing to find and/or no evidence of mite bites.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon P.A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 7 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister abrogated an agreement made in October 1984 between his predecessor and the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Mr Ian Tuxworth, on public service superannuation finance.

(2) Has the Minister stated that (a) the Northern Territory will be required to fund the employer superannuation contributions from its own resources, that is, no additional financial assistance will be provided by the Commonwealth to the Territory for that purpose and (b) should the Territory decide not to pay the employer superannuation contributions, action will be taken to terminate membership of Territory employees in the Commonwealth scheme; if so, does this remain the Government's intention.
(3) Will this action block access to the Grants Commission by the Territory.
(4) Will the Government continue to allow the Commission its long standing independence to assess a State or Territory's needs as it sees fit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In the light of the tight budgetary situation, the Government has decided that the Northern Territory will be required to meet the employer superannuation liability for its employees who are members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme from its own resources and without any additional financial assistance from the Commonwealth. The Northern Territory, however, will be required to meet only that part of the liability attributable to service with the Territory after 1 July 1984.

Moreover, the Northern Territory has been treated generously relative to the States. In its May 1985 report on special assistance for the Northern Territory the Commonwealth Grants Commission found that in respect of the 1982-83 financial year the Northern Territory had received more assistance from the Commonwealth than it required to provide the same level, range and quality of services as provided in Victoria and New South Wales.

The Grants Commission has also noted in its 1985 Report on Tax Sharing Relativities that it would not be practicable to incorporate the Northern Territory into the general financial assistance arrangements with the States until such time as measures were taken to bring the financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory into line with those applying between the Commonwealth and the States. The Government is moving in this direction and it expects that from 1988-89 onwards the Northern Territory will be treated more or less as a State in its financial dealings with the Commonwealth.

(2) Yes. The Commonwealth cannot reasonably be held responsible for the Territory's prospective superannuation liability. The cost to the Northern Territory will be small in the early years of operation of the revised arrangements and the Territory Government has ample time to arrange its affairs to enable it to meet the liability under the revised arrangements and thus avoid any disturbance of its employees' superannuation arrangements. The Territory receives large untied grants from the Commonwealth from which it can meet the liability.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 7 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to his answer to a question without notice (Hansard, 22 April 1985, page 1560) concerning the international terminal at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, what improvements will be made to the terminal and when will these be carried out.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The scope of improvement works to the international terminal at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport are currently being examined by my Department in association with the Department of Housing and Construction, the airlines and other terminal tenants.
The final scope of works has not yet been agreed, however, I can advise the honourable member that the following works are proposed:

Extensions to the departure hall. It is intended to improve the check in facilities, relocate and consolidate the outwards immigration/customs facilities and relocate and expand the concession facilities;
provision of suitable facilities for transit passengers including greater accessibility to concessions;
improvements to the baggage reclaim facilities;
improvements to the primary line queuing area including air conditioning.
Commencement of the proposed works will depend upon availability of funds and will be subject to a Standing Committee on Public Works examination and report to Parliament.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 9 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to reception difficulties of Orange-based Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio station 2CR broadcasting through 2LG to Lithgow and district.
(2) Is it in fact that 2CR is to broadcast on a new frequency in the Lithgow area through 2LG.

(3) Will funds be provided to purchase the necessary components and equipment to enable the transmitting power to be increased from 200 watts to 2000 watts in order to overcome the current reception difficulties.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The inadequate coverage of ABC Radio 3 in the Lithgow area is recognised.
(2) Yes. A frequency change was made on 18th May 1985 for 2LG to correct a minor interference problem to another service in the region.

(3) The suggested power increase for 2LG would be unlikely to solve all the present reception difficulties. A replacement service in the FM band may be the solution, but limitation on funds and resources preclude priority consideration at this stage for the project.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 10 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article in the May 1985 edition of Pacific Defence Reporter entitled `Australia's Vulnerable Sea Lines' particularly that part of the article which states that it appeared from material available either that Defence strategy does not recognise the importance of the defence of overseas trade, or that the defence of overseas trade had been placed in the `too hard basket', and that the Government in arriving at its decision on the submarine short list should not opt for cheap and unproven designs offered by companies with little or no blue-water experience.
(2) Is it a fact that neutral flags are no protection for merchant shipping in times of hostilities between other nations or groups of nations.
(3) Does Australia depend largely on there being free movement of maritime trade, both import and export, in order to sustain its agricultural, transport, mining and manufacturing industries.

(4) Can he assure those individuals or organisations in the Australian community looking to him as their principal ministerial decision maker that he will take an active role in Cabinet discussions on the choice of a new submarine design for the RAN, given the requirment that will be placed on these vessels to ensure that Australian sea lines of communication remain open.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Relate to matters which are portfolio responsibilities of my colleague the Minister for Defence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 13 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the details of the program he undertook during his overseas trip in January and February 1985.
(2) Who accompanied him on the trip.
(3) What was the cost of his trip including the cost of those accompanying him and what is the break down of this cost by function, in each country visited.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Social Science Research Centre, University of California
Dr R. Seymour of Haight Ashbury Clinic
Director, AIDS Clinic, San Francisco General Hospital
Dr S. Dietrich of Los Angeles Orthopaedic Hospital
National Parents Resource Center for Drug Education Inc.
Beth Israel Hospital-individual discussions with several doctors
Commissioner (AIDS and Drug Dependence) Department of Health
Gay and Lesbian Health Services, Department of Health
Meeting at Beth Israel Hospital with group of people working with AIDS
Dr V. Dole, researcher in drug abuse, Rockefeller University
Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotic matters, Department of State
National Institute on Drug Abuse, Rockville, Maryland
Science Advisor, Office Assisting Secretary of Health, Rockville, Maryland
Director, Sales and Marketing, and Director, Life Science Technology, Electro-Nucleonics Inc.
Vice-President, Health Services, American Red Cross Society
Director, Division of Population, Health and Nutrition, World Bank
Dr C. Turner, Special Assistant to the President for Drug Use Policy
Consulant Adviser (Addiction) to Minister for State for Health
Voluntary Sector Beds for Drug Treatment, Department of Health and Social Service
Chief Medical Officer and Deputy Secretary
Department of Health and Social Service Anti-Heroin Campaign
Tai Lam Compulsory Inpatient Drug Addiction Centre
Shek Kwa Chau Voluntary Inpatient Drug Addiction Treatment Centre
The cost of the trip was $58,428.26; however not all costs have yet been brought to account and some further costs are expected.
Miscellaneous (including departure tax, baggage insurance, gratuities etc.)...

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Has his Department received representations of any kind from the Human Rights Commission regarding discrimination in (a) funding of cadet units and (b) conditions of service for voluntary officers of cadets, if so, (c) what was the nature of those representations and (d) what action is being taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (c) The Honourable D. A. Lowe, Deputy Premier of Tasmania, wrote to Dr. D. Jarvis, Conciliator of the Human Rights Commission in Canberra on 15 August 1984 and 5 November 1984 concerning discrimination in the level of funding for school cadet units. The Conciliator considered the matter would be more appropriately addressed by the Secretary, Department of Defence, as it did not appear to relate to the functions of the Human Rights Commission. The issues raised by Mr Lowe were discrimination in funding for members of limited support cadet units as well as discrimination in the conditions of service for Officers of Cadets serving in those units.

(d) My colleague, the Honourable John Brown, acting in his capacity as Minister Assisting, wrote to Mr Lowe informing him of the consultative processes that had occurred during the restructuring of the Australian Army Cadet Corps.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 14 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many pensioners in each category of pension have had their pensions (a) suspended, (b) terminated and (c) reduced under the assets test and how many of the pensioners come from (i) each State and from (ii) metropolitan, (iii) provincial and (iv) rural areas.
(2) How many appeals against (a) valuations under the assets test and (b) other aspects of the assets test have been made.
(3) How many of these appeals have been successful.
(4) How many requests for reviews have been made against valuations used in assets test calculations and how many have been resolved.
(5) How many applications have been made for payment of pensions, and which types of pensions, under (a) the hardship provisions of the assets test and (b) the Pensioners Loans Scheme.
(6) How many applications have been (a) accepted and (b) rejected and on what grounds were they rejected.
(7) How many pensioners in the Electoral Division of Dawson have had their pensions (a) cancelled, (b) suspended or (c) reduced because of the assets test in each category of pension.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (b) (i) Pensions cancelled in assets test conversion of 8 March 1985 for pensions payday 21 March 1985:
# Includes wife and spouse carer pensioners.
(ii), (iii), (iv) The request classification is not available. See, however, answer to part (7).
(c) (i) Pensions reduced in assets test conversion of 8 March 1985 for pensions payday 21 March 1985.
# Includes wife and spouse carer pensioners.
(ii), (iii), (iv) The requested classification is not available. See, however, answer to part (7).
(2) As at 26 July 1985, there had been 1887 appeals lodged in respect of decisions under the assets test; 1445 related to valuations of property and 442 to other matters.

(3) Of 754 valuation appeals finalised by 26 July 1985, 314 had been conceded by the department and 7 upheld after a recommendation by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. Of the 82 other assets test appeals finalised, 28 were conceded by the department and 8 had been upheld after a recommendation by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.

(4) As at 31 May 1985, the last date for which those figures were recorded, there had been 1676 requests for review of valuations of property. About 75% of all requests for revaluation of property (including appeals) have been resolved.
(5) As at 26 July 1985, 2710 applications for payment of pension under the hardship provisions of the assets test had been received. Information by type of pension is not available.
17 applications for payment under the Pensions Loan Scheme have been received. Payment under the Loan Scheme is available only to age pensioners and their spouses.
(6) As at 26 July 1985, 280 claims under the hardship provisions had been granted and 2047 rejected. The grounds for rejection are not available.

As at 7 August 1985, 5 claims under the Pensions Loan Scheme have been granted and 2 rejected. The 2 claims were rejected on the grounds that the claimants' liquid assets exceeded 30% of the total value of their assets.

(7) Figures are not available for the number of pensions cancelled, suspended or reduced in a particular Electoral division. However, statistics by postcode districts are available for inspection at the House of Representatives Table Office.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Electoral Commission: Australian Citizens of Chifley Electorate

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 14 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Chifley Office of the Australian Electoral Commission automatically write and/or contact those people who have been recently made Australian citizens; if not, (a) are the lists of these citizens readily available from (i) Blacktown and Penrith Councils and (ii) the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and (b) when will the Chifley Office commence writing to or contacting these citizens.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Electoral Commissioner has advised that the Australian Electoral Commission's Divisional Returning Officers currently write to newly naturalised citizens as and when information requested of local councils is supplied.

In the case of the Division of Chifley, the Commission has an arrangement with the Blacktown and Penrith Councils regarding the supply of lists of people recently granted citizenship. The Divisional Returning Officer for Chifley checks those on the lists who fall within his Division against the roll and writes to those that are not enrolled enclosing claim cards and pamphlets on electoral rights and responsibilities.

The Commission is arranging with the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs for lists of all newly naturalised citizens to be supplied to the Commission in magnetic tape form each fortnight. This information, which will be more up-to-date and complete than that received from local councils at present, will be supplied to all Divisional Returning Officers who in turn will make contact with those who are newly entitled electors. This arrangement will relieve the Commission's Divisional staff of the need to deal with individual local government authorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 15 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to claims by the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations that the present state laws on labelling of processed foods, pesticides and other hazardous chemicals, and the packaging of all consumer goods are, in general, haphazard, superficial and ineffective.
(2) Is it a fact that the interstate distribution of goods requires 8 different sets of controls.
(3) What action can be or is being taken to bring about a national approach to packaging and labelling of products.

(4) What contribution is being made by his Department to achieve (a) appropriate consumer information standards for product packaging and labelling, (b) national recommended standards for including ingredients and nutritional values on food labelling, (c) clarification of regulations controlling deception in packaging and (d) the identification of food packers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. I am aware of these claims as detailed in the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations' 1983-84 Annual Report.

(2) It is true that packaging and labelling laws are enacted and administered essentially within State and Territory jurisdictions. However, good progress has been achieved in recent years towards uniformity of legislation and administration. Model legislation has been developed in several jurisdictions, including Health and Weights and Measures.

(3) Packaging and Labelling of products is essentially a State and Territory responsibility. In an effort to achieve a uniform, national approach in this area, a number of Ministerial and officials bodies have been established. These include the Health Ministers Conference, Australian Transport Advisory Council, Australian Agricultural Council, Weights and Measures Ministers meetings, National Health &Medical Research Council (NHMRC), Standing Committee of Consumer Affairs Ministers and the Standing Committee on Packaging. The Model Food Act, as developed by the NHMRC, has been or is being adopted by the States and Territories. I am advised that a scheme is currently being developed to provide for the rapid adoption of national food standards, including labelling aspects.

(4) (a) My Department is represented on the Standing Committee on Packaging and maintains close liaison with other relevant jurisdictions. The Standing Committee of Consumer Affairs Ministers has been given the responsibility of co-ordinating a uniform approach between jurisdictions.

(b) Ingredient and nutritional labelling is a State and Territory responsibility. My Department maintains close liaison with the Commonwealth Department of Health and monitors the introduction of the Model Food Act and Regulations by State and Territory Governments. The Model, when introduced by all jurisdictions will achieve a uniform, national approach in this field. The Model Food Standards Regulations have recently been amended to require uniform and specific labelling with respect to food additives.
(c) The Standing Committee on Packaging has developed a Model Act and Regulations on deception in packaging. Introduction is the responsibility of State/Territory Governments.

(d) My Department is represented on the Standing Committee on Packaging and the Food Standards Committee of the NHMRC. It also maintains close liaison with Health jurisdictions in respect of the introduction of the Model Food Act and Regulations. The Model Food Act requires the name of the party taking responsibility for a food package to be stated on the package.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 16 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do formal procedures exist for the handling of Ministerial representations in the Minister's Department and statutory authorities for which the Minister is responsible; if so, (a) what are the titles of the instructions and when were they issued and (b) are target times provided (i) formally or (ii) informally; if so, what are they.
(2) Is the performance with which representations are dealt with monitored; if so, what was the percentage of representations that met their targets in 1985, to 16 May.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Following my appointment as Minister for Trade I advised my Department of the particular procedures I wished to see followed in relation to Ministerial correspondence. The bulk of correspondence is forwarded directly to the Department by my office, with an indication of the action to be taken. The Department liaises with statutory authorities under my control as necessary.

On straight-forward matters I require advice from the Department within two weeks. For matters requiring extensive consultation with other Ministers and Departments, or matters affected by imminent policy decisions, I require the Department's response at the earliest date at which useful information can be provided.
(2) Ministerial correspondence is recorded on a computer-based system which produces regular reports on any items for which action is either overdue or in some way incomplete.

In the period 1 January to 16 May 1985 nearly 70% of correspondence was answered within two weeks. Many representations made to me during this period could not be answered until certain policy decisions had been taken by the Government.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Ministerial Representations: Department of Social Security

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do formal procedures exist for the handling of Ministerial representations in the Minister's Department and statutory authorities for which the Minister is responsible; if so, (a) what are the titles of the instructions and when were they issued and (b) are target times provided (i) formally or (ii) informally; if so, what are they.
(2) Is the performance with which representations are dealt with monitored; if so, what was the percentage of representations that met their targets in 1985, to 16 May.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes (a) Ministerial and Parliamentary Handbook, July 1983 (b) yes (b) (i) formally, 4 weeks from receipt in my Department.
(2) Yes. In the period 1 January 1985 to 16 May 1985 45% of Ministerial representations were answered within 4 weeks of receipt in my Department and 76% were answered within 8 weeks.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 16 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do formal procedures exist for the handling of Ministerial representations in the Minister's Department and statutory authorities for which the Minister is responsible; if so, (a) what are the titles of the instructions and when were they issued and (b) are target times provided (i) formally or (ii) informally; if so, what are they.
(2) Is the performance with which representations are dealt with monitored; if so, what was the percentage of representations that met their targets in 1985, to 16 May.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) In respect of my Department, formal procedures are included in the Central Office publication `Office Manual' in which a section is devoted to communications in general and to ministerial correspondence in particular. These procedures have existed for many years and have recently been reviewed; a revised version is being prepared for issue. Within that revision is a requirement that a substantive reply to non-urgent correspondence be provided to me within one month of my Department receiving it or, if this is not possible by reason, for example, of information having to be obtained from another organisation, an interim reply is to be provided advising the correspondent that there will be a delay.
At monthly intervals Departmental heads of divisions are formally advised of correspondence that they are holding and which is overdue for reply.

The statistics asked for by the honourable member are not routinely extracted and are not readily accessible. However my Department advises me that, of some 3000 letters chosen at random, about 70% were finalised within a month of receipt.
The Health Insurance Commission is encompassed by the departmental procedures outlined above.
In respect of the ACT Health Authority, the position is as follows:

(1) No formal procedures exist but it is normal practice to ensure that Ministerial letters are given a high priority at all times with the aim of providing the Minister, or the Chairman of the Authority, with a reply within one month of a letter being received by the Authority. Difficulties and delay are sometimes encountered in meeting this deadline because of the complex nature of the issues raised and the consequent need to consult with or obtain information from more than one section of the Authority.
(2) A report is completed at the end of each month showing all outstanding letters and the percentage of letters that met the one month target as at 30 June 1985 was 72%.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 20 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the recently published book entitled The Price of Affluence: Dilemmas of Contemporary Japan by Professor Hidaka and the Foreword and Afterword by La Trobe University academic, Dr Gavan McCormack, which quotes extensively from documents released under the Freedom of Information Act and drawn from the Australian Government files on Professor Hidaka's efforts to visit Australia.

(2) Do these documents indicate officials speaking of Japanese academics and distinguished groups of Japanese academic, cultural and political figures who supported Professor Hidaka, being described as being on the extreme left in Japan; if so, are these attitudes and opinions currently held by the Government or its officials concerned with relations between Australia and Japan.
(3) Was a Japanese police record of Professor Hidaka's opposition to the Vietnam War included in the file of information on him compiled by the Australian Government; if so, why.
(4) Are Japanese police reports on the political opinions or activities of applicants for visas to Australia routinely made available to the Australian Government.
(5) What role did this information play in the decision to exclude Professor Hidaka from Australia.

(6) In view of the statement made in a Department of Immigration memorandum from the then Minister that, in future, the Japanese authorities, on their own initiative, have indicated that no grants will be given by the Japan Foundation until both Japanese and Australian Governments are consulted, is Australia a party to any agreements to vet politically applications for academic or cultural exchange support from the Foundations of either Government.

(7) Does the record of the Hidaka affair indicate that innocent foreign individuals may be maligned, insulted and denied entry to Australia without any form of appeal or redress; if so, is this still the case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The documents indicate that one official was reported by another official as saying that a number of the people making representations on behalf of Professor Hidaka seemed to be on the extreme left in Japan. The Government's view is that support for Professor Hidaka appears to have been fairly broadly based.
(5) As far as I am aware Professor Hidaka's opposition to the Vietnam War was not a consideration in the decision to exclude him from Australia.

(6) I have been advised that Australia is not a party to any international agreements concluded under the auspices of the Foundations of either country in relation to processing applications for academic or cultural exchange support.
(7) No. Professor Hidaka and his supporters appealed to successive Ministers. This Government allowed Professor Hidaka's admission.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: New Zealand Dairy Farmers: Government Assistance

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 23 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say what (a) form and (b) level of assistance are provided to New Zealand dairy farmers (i) directly by the New Zealand Government and (ii) by indirect means.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Information on assistance available to the New Zealand industry is not readily available in the categorization requested. Various forms of government assistance known to be currently available to New Zealand dairy farmers are described below. However, details of the level of assistance provided to dairy farmers under schemes which are applied on a general basis to the New Zealand farm sector are not separately available. It should be noted that the New Zealand Government has recently terminated a number of assistance measures which were available, either directly or indirectly, to the dairy industry. These include the Supplementary Minimum Prices Scheme, the Dairy Export Suspensory Loans Scheme, the Export Program Suspensory Loan Scheme, the subsidy on milk for domestic consumption, the Dairy Beef Market Guarantee Scheme, the subsidy on the cost of transport and aerial spreading of fertilizers and an investment allowance scheme.

The New Zealand dairy industry is subject to a stabilization arrangement administered by the New Zealand Dairy Board in consultation with the Government. Under the scheme fluctuations in dairy industry income are brought within a defined range by levying producer returns in buoyant years and supplementing returns in depressed years.

Funds under the scheme are administered through a Dairy Industry Reserve Account which has been in surplus since 1980. In 1984 the surplus was $NZ352m, (of which some $NZ200m has been applied to capital expenditure). Credit balances in this account have until 1 June 1985 earned 1 per cent interest and borrowings from this account for income supplementation purposes were also charged at 1 per cent interest. However as from 1 June 1985 a market interest rate (of around 20 per cent) is to be applied.

Since its establishment in 1936, the New Zealand Dairy Board has had access to working capital, which includes funds required to supplement returns, from the New Zealand Reserve Bank at a concessional rate of 1 per cent. In 1983 the New Zealand Government placed a ceiling of $NZ750m on advances at the concessional rate. The balance of the Board's working capital requirements are now raised on normal terms through the financial system.

The $NZ750m advanced by the Reserve Bank has been converted from an overdraft payable on demand to a subordinated loan to be repaid over 40 years at 1 per cent interest with repayments to commence on 31 May 1986

The production of fresh milk for domestic consumption is oragnised on a quota system where producers are allocated daily production quotas for the supply of milk every day of the year. It is estimated that there were 1,247 town milk suppliers and 15,000 factory milk suppliers in 1984-85. The volume of town milk produced accounts for about 6 per cent of total production and manufacturing milk about 92 per cent.

Direct assistance to this sector is in the form of milk quotas which receive premium prices. Quota milk together with seasonal percentages above quota receive a premium price above the manufacturing price, which is intended to compensate producers for the higher costs of milk production particularly in winter. Town milk producer prices are linked to factory milk prices by an established formula in the ratio of 0.06 cents per litre of wholemilk for every 1 cent per kilogram milkfat change in the price of factory milk. Town milk prices are presently estimated to be 28-30 per cent above factory milk prices.
All dairy products except concentrated or sweetened milk in liquid/solid form may be imported without licence.
Imports of dairy products from Australia and certain Pacific countries are free of import duties.
However, for all other countries, an import tariff exists as follows:
milk, fresh, concentrated or sweetened-10 per cent

The Rural Banking and Finance Corporation (RBFC) was established in 1974 to provide loans at concessional rates of interest for farm purchase and development purposes. The Corporation has to date obtained its funds from the New Zealand Reserve Bank. However, in the November 1984 Budget it was announced that access to the Reserve Bank Loans Account for new loans would be phased out as follows:
From 1986-87 the Rural Banking and Finance Corporation will need to seek funds from the private sector at market rates of interest.

Interest rates on current loans through the RBFC are also being progressively brought into line with market interest rates. From 8 November 1984, the rate on current loans is being increased from 7.5 per cent in one or more steps up to the market indicator rate, which was set at 15 per cent in the 1984 Budget and is being kept under review. New loans are being offered at an initial rate of 12 1/2 per cent until 1 April 1986, from which date rates will be increased by 1 per cent until the market indicator rate is reached.
Total loan authorisations to the farming sector by the Corporation in 1984-85 were $NZ376.98m compared with $NZ390m in 1983-84 and $NZ443.6m in 1982-83.
The Export Performance Taxation Incentive Scheme provides a tax credit or refund on a specified percentage of the domestic value added of qualifying exports. Dairy products which qualify are:
dairy whip cream in aerosol cans

The relevant level of tax rebate on exports to all markets on these items was reduced by 50 per cent on 1 April 1985 in accordance with an established formula which will result in complete removal of the incentive by 1 April 1987. The current level of rebate on ice cream is 5.25 per cent, and, for the other products listed above, the rebate is 3.85 per cent.
The EMDTI, which provides tax credits for specified promotional expenditure incurred outside New Zealand, has been extended to 1990-91.

From 1987-88 the tax credit rate will be phased down over four years from 69 per cent to the corporate tax level of 48 per cent. This will remove the additional incentive for export. The New Zealand Government has indicated that further changes to the scheme may be made.
From the 1987-88 income year, the New Zealand Government intends to replace the EMDTI with support of a more selective and targeted nature.

A subsidy of $NZ12/tonne is paid to approved end users in respect of a nominated range of imported and locally manufactured fertilizers-but not to lime. The New Zealand Government has announced this subsidy will terminate on 30 June 1986.
Government expenditure on this item in 1984-85 was $NZ23.0m and $NZ24.9m has been allocated for the item in the 1985-86 budget.

Dairy inspection and grading services have been fully funded by Government until the end of the 1984-85 season. Funding is to be reduced in 1985-86 with a one-third cost recovery. Two-thirds cost recovery will apply in 1986-87.

The New Zealand farm sector has available to it a range of taxation deductions which are designed to encourage development and increase productive capacity. These deductions are subject to change from time to time. Current taxation allowances include income equalisation arrangements, depreciation, farm development expenditure and deferral of certain costs such as purchase and spreading of fertilizer and lime.

Other general assistance measures to New Zealand agriculture include pest (principally rabbits) and noxious weed control. Government cost of pest control was $NZ7m in 1984-85 and is to be phased down to nil in 1993-94. Weed control allocations are being phased down with $NZ3.7m being allocated in 1985-86 c.f. $NZ9.5m in 1984-85.
The New Zealand dairy industry also benefits from the provision of Government advisory, agricultural research, quarantine and animal health services.
Apart from the above-listed assistance measures, the New Zealand dairy industry has available to it negotiated access to several key markets.

(a) Under the Treaty of Accession of the United Kingdom into the European Ecconomic Community, New Zealand was granted access to the EEC market for certain quantities of butter under a number of conditions. The quantity and conditions have changed so that from an initial quantity of 166,000t in 1973, the 1985 level is 81,000t reducing to 79,000t in 1986. Levels for 1987 and 1988 are yet to be agreed.

(b) New Zealand negotiated access to several dairy markets in the last (Tokyo) round of the Multilateral Trade Negotiations (MTN). The Principal New Zealand MTN quotas are for cheese in the United States and EEC markets:
6,500 t.p.a. of cheddar cheese for direct consumption
3,000 t.p.a. of cheddar cheese for processing

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Consultants: Department of Employment and Industrial Relations

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 23 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister's Department, or any statutory authority or organisation for which the Minister is responsible, employed consultants since March 1983; if so, (a) who has been employed, (b) for what purpose, (c) what working plan was given to them, (d) what was the cost of their services, (e) when did their services commence and finish, and (f) was any fee in excess of the initial quote; if so, by what amount.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Columns (a) to (f) on the following tables relate to parts (a) to (f). Table 1 lists all consultants engaged other than those engaged for the purpose of training Community Youth Support Scheme (CYSS) Project Personnel. Table 2 lists the consultants engaged for the purpose of training CYSS Project Personnel.
The following consultants were engaged by the Bureau of Labour Market Research
Asian and Pacific Countries Labour Markets Research Report
Complementary technical paper of the research report on the wages and labour market adjustment project
Study of labour markets in rural Australia, Phase 1
Study of psychological impact on participants in the Wage Pause Program
Provide advice on development of National Longitudinal Study based on USA experience
Harvard University and National Bureau of Economic Research, USA
In-house review of BLMR research in `Progress in Planning', 2 seminars
Preparation of paper on `Working Life' tables for Australia
Comparative study of youth manpower program
Develop a proposal to survey the Aboriginal labour force to assess suitability for CEP projects
Developing research projects which would use National Longitudinal Survey data
Paper on potential research uses for National Longitudinal Survey data
Evaluation of employment and training programs in Australia
Preparation of papers and presentation of seminars on labour market programs

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Consultants: Department of Local Government and Administrative Services

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 23 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister's Department, or any statutory authority or organisation for which the Minister is responsible, employed consultants since March 1983; if so, (a) who has been employed, (b) for what purpose, (c) what working plan was given to them, (d) what was the cost of their services, (e) when did their services commence and finish, and (f) was any fee in excess of the initial quote; if so, by what amount.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Numerous consultants have been employed by my Department and agencies within my portfolio since March 1983. Details of these are provided.
In respect of the Australian Survey Office, the responses to part (b) and (c) of the question are as follows:

(b) Consultants and contract drafting services are used to provide a broad spectrum of survey services in the work program; filed surveys, aerial photography, photogrammetric plotting, drafting and digital terrain modelling. They are used in those areas where their services are cost-effective and/or on those occasions when in-house resources are not available.

(c) All engagements are made under the provisions of the General Conditions of Contract A and the Special Conditions of Contract. A technical specification forms part of the survey instructions with the letter of engagement.

The `working plan' supplied would vary considerably with the project and in most cases would comprise several plans e.g. a cover plan delineating the subject area and copies of existing plans covering the area and its abuttals.

To conduct a review of the Application of the Common- wealth's self-insurance policy in Government Contracting and provide an Advisory Service to Commonwealth Departments and Authorities on an as required basis in insurance-related matters.

The Consultancy services compare Phase One and Phase Two activities. Phase One activities include, inter alia, a review of the Contract Conditions for, and modes of application of the Commonwealth's insurance policy in the light of current Australian and overseas government and commercial practice, in the area of major projects, e.g. shipbuilding; and the provision of advice on insurance matters having wide applicability for other areas of government contracting for goods and services. Phase Two activities involve the provision of consulting services on insurance matters arising specifically in relation to the functions and operations of the Commonwealth departments within Australia and overseas.

The service is provided on the basis of a retainer fee of $15,000 per annum, adjusted retrospect- ively according to the actual number of hours of consulting time used at $95.00 per hour. Each advice request for Phase Two tasks is funded by departments on a per service basis at a rate of $95.00 per hour. Phase One tasks are to have priority. Commitments for Phase Two tasks are not entered into without the prior approval of the Department of Local Government and Administ- rative Services.

The service has been engaged for a period of three years from 14 June 1984 to 13 June 1987 inclusive. The Consultant was required by the terms of the Contract to complete Phase One consultancy services by 13 June 1985. It is now expected that the time for completion will be extended to 13 June 1986.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Re- creation, and Tourism, upon notice, on 23 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his Department finalised proposals for direct assistance to the tourism industry to compensate for the loss of assistance under the Export Market Development Grants (EMDG) Scheme.
(2) When will the proposals be considered by Cabinet.
(3) For what period will the tourism industry have to wait before knowing the Government's policy on this matter.

(4) Can he provide an assurance to industry that any new measures of direct assistance will at least compensate the tourism industry for the estimated loss of $9 million, because of its exclusion from the EMDG Scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) Proposals for direct assistance to the tourism industry have been prepared by my Department, they have already been considered by Cabinet and the outcome was made known in the Media Release on 19 June 1985 when details of the Tourism Overseas Promotion Scheme (TOPS) were announced.
I expect to be in a position to release the printed detailed guidelines of the Scheme in September.

(4) The question of compensation for the tourism industry for its removal from the EMDG Scheme is not relevant. The fact is that for the first time the tourism industry, through TOPS, will have an incentive scheme specifically designed to match its needs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 23 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister's Department or any statutory authority for which the Minister is responsible have in place a program under which organisations may apply for funding; if so, what are they.

(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an information paper entitled `Issues in 1984/85 Grant in Aid (GIA) Assessment' distributed by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, in particular the suggestion that large and established ethnic community organisations who in the past have received support from the Grant in Aid Program from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs are now expected to apply for funding from main stream sources.

(3) What special provision has been made to ensure that in consideration of applications, appropriate and sensitive consideration is given to the special needs of migrant organisations and their so-called established ethnic organisations are placed in a position to compete equitably for any funds made available under programs through the Minister's Department or related agency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (3) The Office of the Status of Women, in my Department, will administer a grants program (National Consultation and Assistance Program for Women) totalling $350,000 during 1985/86. The program is in two parts and provides for-

(a) grants totalling $150,000 to be distributed to National Women's Organisations. This financial assistance is aimed at improving the capacity of women's organisations to take part in community decision-making and at equipping organisations with the means to research, consult and debate on issues of particular significance to women;

(b) grants totalling $200,000 to be allocated to approved projects to raise the status of women. Such bodies as trade unions, churches, Aboriginal groups, ethnic groups and traditional women's organisations will be eligible to apply for grants, as well as individuals. There will normally be a limit to $15,000 on any one grant.

Applications from migrant and ethnic organisations will be considered on the same basis as applications from other groups. Applications will need to meet the selection and eligibility criteria for these grants. The final decision on the allocation of funds will be made by the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women.

The Office of Youth Affairs in my Department, administers the Program of Assistance to youth organisations (PAYO) which provides grants to national organisations which are comprised of or provide services to young people. Priority is given to proposals which promote equity amoung young people or which recognise the needs of disadvantaged young people and positively discriminate in their favour. Ethnic young people constitute one of the five categories of disadvantage which are recognised for PAYO purposes, the other being Aboriginal, young women, disabled and rural/isolated young people.
To ensure that all eligible organisations have equal opportunity to apply for and receive grants, the following procedures have been instituted:-
a detailed advice and instructions pamphlet is issued with application forms;
information seminars are held in the major capital cities prior to the close of applications;
individual interviews are conducted with applicant organisations to ensure that all the relevant information is supplied.

Assistance is also available through the Australian Bicentennial Authority for local and regional Bicentennial activities in a number of areas within the Commonwealth funded National Program. These areas are Heritage, Environment, Commissionings of Works of Art, Sport and Recreation, Multicultural and Community Arts. Applications under the Heritage and Environment Programs have already closed but applications will be called for the remainder of the programs over the next eighteen months.

Each of the programs under which Bicentennial funding is available will have guidelines based on the Authority's planning objectives which include provision of avenues of participation for all Australians irrespective of age, ethnic background or sex. The guidelines have been formulated after consultation with key groups in respective areas. The guidelines for the multicultural program will be discussed with a broad range of interested Government and non-Government organisations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 23 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister's Department or any statutory authority for which the Minister is responsible have in place a program under which organisations may apply for funding; if so, what are they.

(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an information paper entitled ``Issues in 1984-85 Grant in Aid (GIA) Assessment'' distributed by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, in particular the suggestion that large and established ethnic community organisations who in the past have received support from the Grant in Aid Program of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs are now expected to apply for funding from main stream sources.

(3) What special provision has been made to ensure that in consideration of applications, appropriate and sensitive consideration is given to the special needs of migrant organisations and their so called ethnic organisations are placed in a position to compete equitably for any funds made available under programs through the Minister's Department or related agencies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Australian Chicken Meat Research Trust Account
The Australian Honey Board finances some of the activities of beekeeper organisations in the promotion of honey.
The Pork Promotion committee finances some of the activities of organisations associated with the pig industry in the promotion of pork.

(3) In the types of programs administered, predominantly research funds to research institutions, questions of ethnic origin become irrelevant as in those cases and all other cases applications for funding are considered completely on the basis of individual merit.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 23 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister's Department or any statutory authority for which the Minister is responsible have in place a program under which organisations may apply for funding; if so, what are they.

(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an information paper entitled ``Issues in 1984-85 Grant in Aid (GIA) Assessment'' distributed by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, in particular the suggestion that large and established ethnic community organisations who in the past have received support from the Grant in Aid Program of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs are now expected to apply for funding from main stream sources.

(3) What special provision has been made to ensure that in consideration of applications, appropriate and sensitive consideration is given to the special needs of migrant organisations and their so-called established ethnic organisations are placed in a position to compete equitably for any funds made available under programs through the Minister's Department or related agency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Community organisations may apply for assistance provided to the States and the Northern Territory under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. Two specific assistance programs, the Crisis Accommodation Program and the Local Government and Community Housing Program, involve community organisations in the provision of low cost rental housing. These, and all other public housing programs funded under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, are administered in each State by the State Housing Authority.

(3) The Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, 1984 includes a specific provision which requires the States to provide assistance to all sectors of the community regardless of their race, religion, age, sex, marital status, disability or life situation with priority determined by the need for assistance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 23 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Minister's Department or any statutory authority for which the Minister is responsible have in place a program under which organisations may apply for funding; if so, what are they.

Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an information paper entitled `Issues in 1984-85 Grant in Aid (GIA) Assessment' distributed by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, in particular the suggestion that large and established ethnic community organisations who in the past have received support from the Grant In Aid Program of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs are now expected to apply for funding from main stream sources.

What special provision has been made to ensure that in consideration of applications and sensitive consideration is given to the special needs of migrant organisations and their so-called established ethnic organisations are placed in a position to compete equitably for any funds made available under programs through the Minister's Department or related agencies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Programs under which organisations may apply for funding are:
the Program of Assistance for Sport and Recreation for Disabled People;
the Innovative Employee Fitness and Recreation Program;
the Joint Recreation and Sport Program with States/Territories;
the Steel Regions Assistance Program; and

Applications for financial assistance which relate to the needs of migrants are eligible under these programs, to the extent that they satisfy the guidelines, and these applications receive equal consideration with other applications. The Sports Development Program, administered by the Australian Sports Commission, however, provides assistance to bona fide national sporting organisations rather than State, Local government or individual organisations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 31 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that four men were arrested in March 1985 for attempting to illegally procure and export arms to anti-independence forces in New Caledonia; if so, were they committed for trial; if not, why not.
Is any reform of the law under consideration following this action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Director of Public Prosecutions has advised me that on 5 March 1985, Alan Grelier, Paul Vu Ngoe Ly, Vu Viet Chuan and Jean Nicholas Bondaletoff were arrested and subsequently charged with accumulating arms and munitions for the purpose of committing an offence against section 6 of the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978, namely engaging in a hostile activity against the Government of New Caledonia. On 17 April 1985, the charges were withdrawn by the Director of Public Prosecutions on the basis that, on the evidence available to the prosecution, the defendants' alleged conduct did not constitute offences against the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act. Proceedings have been instituted against the defendants under the Customs Act for the recovery of pecuniary penalties.
The implications of this case are under study.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Convention on Access to Papers of Former Governments

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 31 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the terms of the convention governing the supply to Minister of information relating to the actions of previous administrations, documents brought into existence by Ministers of previous administrations and the files of previous administrations.

Was the provision to the Minister for Communications of advice referred to by the Minister in his answer to a question without notice (Hansard, 9 May 1985, pages 1954-1955) a breach of that convention; if not, under what part of the convention was the provision of that advice made.

Was the notification to the Minister for Communications of the fact that the then Minister for Post and Telecommunications had sought advice from the Attorney-General's Department a breach of that convention; if not, under what part of the convention was that notification made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) and (3) Successive governments-including the present Government-have accepted the convention that Ministers do not seek access to the deliberative documents of their predecessors, including Cabinet documents and other documents revealing ministerial deliberations. In particular, Cabinet documents are considered confidential to the government that created them and access to them by succeeding governments would not normally be given without the approval of the current leader of the appropriate political party.
The convention is a working rule that enables Ministers to express themselves freely, without risk that upon change of government they will be under challenge for every decision and comment.

Where an incoming government is formed from a different policital party, or parties, from its predecessor, continuity in administrative practice at times requires reference back to decisions of former governments, including Cabinet decisions. In such cases Ministers should be provided by their Departments with a resume of all relevant facts and operative decisions necessary for an understanding of the current issue-including, if essential to the understanding, summaries of Cabinet decisions taken by previous governments, though not the decisions themselves.

The convention does not affect access by incoming Ministers to the normal run of departmental papers generated by a previous government. In relation to the honourable member's particular question, the provisions of advice to the Minister for Communications by his Department was not a breach of the convention. Information of a factual nature concerning the exercise of ministerial powers under the Postal Services Act 1975 was sought and given. No deliberative decisions of a previous government were involved and the information provided was necessary for consideration of the proper handling of a Government responsibility by the Minister for Communications. No breach of convention was involved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 31 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many new cases have commenced in the Federal Court of Australia in each year since its establishment and how many cases were awaiting hearing on 1 January in each year.
(2) What (a) is and (b) has been, the anticipated delay in having matters in the defended lists of the Court heard.
(3) How many new judges have been appointed to the Court in each year since its establishment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The number of new cases (other than bankruptcy cases) commenced in the Federal Court of Australia in each year since its establishment is set out below:

Because of the nature of the jurisdiction and the diversity of proceedings which may be brought in respect of a single bankruptcy it is not practicable to provide equivalent figures for cases in the bankruptcy jurisdiction of the Court. The Registrar of the Federal Court has advised that the Court does not maintain records of the number of cases awaiting hearing as at 1 January in each year.

(2) The Registrar of the Court has provided the following information. The Court has no defended list as such. There are no appreciable delays in having matters heard. This has been the case particularly since 1979 when the Federal Court Rules were introduced which provided for Directions Hearings in all single Judge matters.
(3) The number of Judges appointed to the Court in each year since its establishment is set out below:

Of the above, two Judges resigned on being appointed to the High Court of Australia, one resigned on being appointed President of the New South Wales Court of Appeal, five have retired, three died in office and two resigned to return to practice at the Bar.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Computer Equipment: Department of Social Security

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What brands of computer or Automatic Data Processing hardware are in use in the Minister's Department and each authority for which the Minister is responsible.

(2) For each major system (a) what is its principal function, (b) when was it installed, (c) what was the hardware cost, (d) what is its anticipated life and (e) what action is being taken in relation to its replacement.
(3) Is any major system shared with any other user; if so, who and for what main purpose.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Social Security is undertaking a major computer re-equipment program, known as Stratplan, to provide mainframes in each State capital connecting to new minicomputers in over 200 sites at Regional, State and Central Offices to form a large network.

(1) The pre-Stratplan equipment which is being replaced consists of Natsemi and IBM mainframes and Honeywell and NCR networking hardware. The major items of Stratplan equipment is comprised of Amdahl mainframes, Datamatic tape libraries, Storage Technology peripheral devices and Wang minicomputers. Minor items of equipment are supplied by Datacraft, Memorex, Quest, Systems Technology, Techway, Tektronics and Telex.

(2) (a) The Department of Social Security is dependent on its ADP systems for the delivery of its income maintenance services such as the payment of pensions, family allowances and unemployment, sickness and special benefits. The principal function of the Stratplan systems is, firstly, to maintain the Department's capacity to provide income support and secondly to provide a basis for a more effective delivery of this support.

(b) The pre-Stratplan equipment was installed in the late 1960s and early 1970s. The installation of Stratplan equipment is progressive having commenced with the Central Office system in late 1983 and due to finish with the Perth system in 1986-87.
(c) The cost of the pre-Stratplan equipment is not readily available, however, the cost of Stratplan equipment, including vendor-supplied software is $108.3 million.

(d) The pre-Stratplan equipment is at the end of its useful life and this is the primary reason for undertaking such a large re-equipment program. The anticipated life of the Stratplan equipment is 10 years.
(e) Pre-Stratplan equipment is being progressively replaced. The Department has a strategic planning process which is an avenue for providing equipment upgrades, replacement or additions.

(3) The major systems are not shared with any other users, however, the Department makes available a limited amount of processing capacity to the Department of Community Services to run its ADP systems. This arrangement will continue until that Department becomes operationally independent.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Electoral Division of Tangney: Assets Test

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 22 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to his answer by the Minister for Social Security to question No. 458 (Hansard, 17 April 1985, page 1341) relating to the assets test (a) how do people in the Electoral Division of Tangney find out what the procedures are for appeals and (b) how many appeals have been lodged from pensioners in the Division to 20 August 1985 and how many of those were by farmers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Clients are informed by officers of the Department of Social Security of appeal procedures in several ways:
in the letter informing a client of the effect of the assets test on his or her rate of pension, there is specific reference to appeal rights and procedures.
brochures detailing appeal rights and procedures (in various languages) are available at all DSS offices and counter staff advise individual pensioners of appeal rights and procedures when asked.

when advised of an adverse decision following consideration of an appeal by a Social Security Appeals Tribunal, the client is also advised of the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
(b) Figures are not available for the number of appeals lodged in a particular Electoral Division, nor are any figures kept which would indicate the occupation of any appellant.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have been examining the study of the Australian Bank on the overseas trading company proposal, a copy of which has been released to the honourable member. No decision to proceed has been made.
