QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 23 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article in the `Dregs' column of the Electronics Today International, dated December 1984, on the subject of the electronic scarecrow device, which states that to project an infrasonic wave 12km would require the entire generating capacity of the N.S.W. Electricity Commission; if so, when.

(2) Is this the same device which was displayed at the Australian Pavilion at Expo 85 in Japan; If so, was he familiar with this exhibit at the time of making the statement that Australia has a great deal to be proud of in its technological achievements and these had been well displayed in our pavilion.
(3) Who recommended that this device be included in the display at the Australian Pavilion.
(4) Were demonstrations given of the device's effectiveness.
(5) How many people viewed the device.
(6) Were any orders or expressions of interest taken in relation to the device.
(7) Was any remuneration paid to the inventor, marketer or promoter of the device in connection with its display at Expo 85; if so, what amount and for what reason.
(8) Who (a) presented the device to the Government and (b) explained its operation at the Expo, and what was the text of any literature and/or exhibit material associated with the device's display.
(9) Did he or his Department enter into any contractual arrangement in relation to the device's display at Expo 85; if so, what was the nature of the arrangement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. It should be noted that a good report appeared in the Engineers Australia of 17 May 1985.

(2) The device was on display from 15 March 1985, when the Pavilion was opened until 7 April 1985. It was located in the Technology Gallery of the Australian Pavilion, one of nine major display areas in the Pavilion. The exhibits in this gallery comprise 56 display modules, 130 panels of text and associated graphics, 8 television monitors each showing a separate program as well as a number of wall and photo murals. The electronic scarecrow occupied one display module and was described in one piece of text.

(3) The displays in the Technology Gallery were selected after extensive consultation between officers of my department, the Departments of Science and Housing and Construction, the CSIRO and other government and industry groups. The electronic scarecrow was one of a long list of possible recent technological innovations suggested in discussion by the Minister for Science. The final list of displays and text was corrected and agreed by the Department of Science. The electronic scarecrow was withdrawn from exhibition on the recommendation of the Minister for Science. On further consideration by the Minister for Science, the electronic scarecrow was placed back among the exhibits on 28 August 1985.
(4) Because of the short lead time available none of the displays were specifically tested for inclusion in the pavilion at the Exposition.
(5) A total of 280,000 people visited the Australian Pavilion in the period up to 7 April 1985. It is not known how many of these may have paid specific attention to the electrosonic scarecrow.

(6) An International Exposition is not a Trade Fair and the maker's name and address did not appear on the display. Orders are not taken at an Exposition and any detailed enquiries are referred to the Trade Commissioner Service at the Australian Embassy, Tokyo.

(8) (a) The device was loaned by Hi Tech Control Systems Pty. Ltd., 43 Holland Street, Goonellabah, N.S.W. (b) Enquiries about the device would have been answered by Australian attendants who are stationed through the Pavilion.
No printed handouts describing the device were available. The text panel describing the device read:

A proven deterrent for repelling most air and land creatures, preventing them from affecting property. Intense acoustic air-waves are produced which affect the muscular and skeletal structure of the creature, causing it to avoid the protected area.

(9) A Loan Agreement was entered into by my Department and Hi Tech Control Systems Pty. Ltd. This specifies the period the item will be on loan to the Commonwealth, provides for the Commonwealth to assume responsibility for the item while it is under Commonwealth control and sets out provisions to be followed in the case of loss or damage to the property.
[ In substitution for the answer which appeared in Hansard of 10 September 1985.]

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 23 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 68 (1) and (3) (Hansard, 16 April 1985, pages 1229-1230), what other information programs, not in the sense of information campaigns, has the Information Co-ordination Branch been involved with since its inception.
(2) What advertising agencies were employed to conduct the information campaigns listed, what amounts were paid and what amounts were spent on actual advertising, as opposed to agency services.
(3) What firms conducted the research projects listed in the answer to parts (2) and (4).

(4) Were any other information campaigns conducted by the ICB, not included in his answer; if so, were these special information campaigns, what did each of the campaigns cost and what advertising agencies were involved in each of the campaigns.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Since its inception in 1982 the Information Co-ordination Branch has been involved with information programs of all departments. The Information Co-ordination Branch also regularly conducts surveys of departmental information programs and monitors for changes in proposed information activities. Many departments have sought advice and assistance from the Information Co-ordination Branch about aspects of their information programs.
(2) Following is a list of the advertising agencies employed to conduct the information campaigns, the amounts that the agencies were paid and the amounts spent on advertising.
* information campaign did not include any paid advertising
(3) Following is a list of the agencies which conducted the research projects.
Awareness and understanding of the 1983-84 Federal Budget
Attitudes of young Australians to various government policies and programs
Public understanding of policy on funding of schools
Initial and follow-up research into awareness of Tasmanian public of Commonwealth offers of assistance following the High Court decision on the Gordon-below-Franklin dam
Testing and evaluation of the Tax Form `S'
Community awareness and understanding of the 1984-85 Federal Budget
[ In substitution for the answer which appeared in Hansard of 10 September 1985.]

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 31 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many animals were used in the past 3 years to enable Australian surgeons to refine surgical techniques.
(2) Will he provide guidelines for the protection of animals used in transplant techniques.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The responsibility for the welfare of animals including those used for experimentation and refinement of surgical techniques lies with the State and Territory Governments and therefore the information requested is unobtainable from Commonwealth Government sources. Insofar as the Australian Capital Territory is concerned, I am informed that no animals have been or are being used by the ACT Health Authority for the refinement of surgical techniques.

(2) The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) in conjunction with CSIRO and the Australian Agricultural Council recently published a Code of Practice for the Care and Use of Animals for Experimental Purposes. While the Code does not specifically address the subject of the use of animals for transplant techniques, its general principles place the onus on the experimenter to ensure that he has the ultimate reponsibility for all matters related to the welfare of animals upon which he experiments and should be competent in the procedures to be carried out. This responsibility encompasses the proper design of experiments to ensure that most effective scientific use of the least number of animals, the appropriate care and housing of animals, before, during and after experimentation, and the competence and skills of co-investigators and technicians.

Although the Code has no legislative force, I understand that it has been adopted widely by research institutions and various funding bodies which, like the NHMRC, seek clearances by Animal Experimentation Ethics Committees before funding of research projects is provided.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 22 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he discuss possible changes to the Closer Economic Relations Agreement with the NZ Government during his visit in May 1985; if so, what impact are those changes expected to have on Australian primary industries.
(2) Were any aspects of bilateral trade in dairy produce raised during these talks; if so, what changes are proposed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The purpose of my visit to New Zealand in May 1985 was to address the Pacific Basin Economic Council Annual General Meeting in Auckland on the Australian perspective on Pacific trade issues.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Apple and Pear Juice: Imports by New Zealand

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice on 22 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that New Zealand is importing large quantities of apple and pear juice from Europe because of cheap European prices while exporting its own juice to Australia to achieve higher prices available to it because the Closer Economic Relations (CER) Agreement bestows sales tax exemption and because New Zealand products are duty free; if so, will he take steps to restrain New Zealand from taking advantage of the CER Agreement to the detriment of Australian growers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the CER Agreement New Zealand producers may export apple juice to Australia free of Government imposed restrictions notwithstanding any arrangements made for supplying the New Zealand market with juice from third countries. Similarly, juice originating in third countries may be exported from New Zealand and be considered of New Zealand origin provided the CER Rules of Origin provisions are met. Principally these require that the last manufacturing process is performed in New Zealand and comprises 50 per cent or more of the factory cost of the finished product.

There are safeguard provisions built into CER to protect industries in either country against specific instances of unfair competition or where imports have increased significantly and are causing, or threatening severe injury. There is also provision for consultations between the two Governments where difficulties arise. I would need to be convinced that imports of apple juice are causing the local industry difficulties before I would consider whether any specific action should be taken by the Government. I am advised that imports in 1984/85 came from a number of sources, with less than 40 per cent from New Zealand at prices comparable with other imports. Furthermore, I understand there was a significant local shortfall of apple juice last year necessitating Australian processors to import to meet local demand.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 16 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many officers in the Minister's Department, or in statutory authorities reporting to the Minister, are provided with credit cards.
(2) Which companies are used to provide these cards (for example, American Express, Diners Club).
(3) Who pays the membership and service fees.
(4) At what level is an officer entitled to credit cards.
(5) What limits are placed on the usage of the cards.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based in part on information provided by the statutory authorities in the Communications portfolio, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Communications-195; Australian Telecommunications Commission-18,800 (18,000 Shell Cards; 800 Cabcharge Cards); Australian Postal Commission-173; Overseas Telecommunications Commission-5; Australian Broadcasting Corporation-175; Australian Broadcasting Tribunal-25; Special Broadcasting Service-8; Aussat Pty Ltd-9.
(2) Credit cards available to officers are issued by:

(3) There are normally no membership or service fees applicable to TAA, Ansett, Telecom, Shell, Avis and Hertz credit cards; a service fee is payable to Cabcharge and Taxi Credit and these are paid by the approrpriate statutory authorities. In respect of AMEX and Diners Club credit cards, the Department and relevant statutory authorities reimburse the annual membership fee to an officer, in accordance with Finance Direction 34/25. AMEX and Diners Club have introduced special annual membership rates for officers who apply for and are issued with credit cards through `Corporate Card' schemes that were negotiated with the Department of Finance.

(4) The issue of TAA, Ansett, Telecom, Shell, Avis, Hertz, Taxi Credit and Cabcharge credit cards to nominated senior officers and staff of the relevant statutory authorities has been longstanding. There are no restrictions on the level of officers who may apply for AMEX or Diners Club credit cards. However, before a credit card is issued under the `Corporate Card' scheme, the Department/Authority must be satisfied that the officer has a `work-related' need for the card.

(5) TAA, Ansett, Telecom, Shell, Avis, Hertz, Taxi Credit and Cabcharge credit cards are intended for use by senior officers where there is an urgent need to use the services of those bodies for official purposes in circumstances that do not allow the usual procedures to be followed, such as outside normal business hours or in remote locations.

AMEX and Diners Club cards are subject to the limitations placed on the cards by AMEX or Diners Club. Officers are responsible for meeting all expenditure charged to their card account. Expenditure of an official nature incurred by the use of credit cards is subject to normal reimbursement procedures to which the disciplines of the Audit Act and other relevant legislation are applied. Other charges including interest, etc. that an officer chooses to incur in using these cards are the personal responsibility of that officer.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telephone Services: Nelligen, New South Wales

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 8 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the laying of a new 30 pair cable by Telecom to connect a telephone service to the small town of Nelligen, New South Wales.

(2) Is it a fact that after approximately 37 kilometres of cable had been laid, it was discovered that it was the wrong type and the correct cable was laid alongside; if so, (a) what was the cost of replacing this cable, (b) how did the error occur and (c) what quality controls can Telecom introduce to ensure that this does not happen in the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The project at Nelligen required the installation, by mole plough, of a total of 37 kilometres of cable to provide telephone service for waiting applicants in the area. The estimated cost of the project was $260,000.

(2) The correct type of cable was installed. However some minor changes in both final route selection and cable size were made following receipt of an unusually large number of additional unforeseen applications for service during progress of the work. The changes resulted in the need to plough an additional cable over a distance of approximately 500 metres alongside the original project cable at a cost of $400.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What action is being considered to overcome the delays in the Family Law Court and problems associated with the lack of counsellors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Principal Registry of the Family Court of Australia has advised that the overall maximum period of delay in the hearing of a defended case in the Court, from the time it is placed in the defended list until it is heard, is eighteen months. In New South Wales, both the Sydney and Parramatta registries have, in particular, had dislocations to their listing systems by virtue of security and accommodation problems.

I do not, however, necessarily accept that there is a lack of counsellors within the Family Court of Australia. Following representations from Family Court counsellors and their relevant staff association, a management review of the Family Court Counselling Service is presently under way. The review will, inter alia, canvass the question of counsellor numbers.
Specific measures have been taken over the last 12 months to overcome delays in the Family Court of Australia. These include-

the opening of five new registries of the Court, ranging from those with full filing facilities and a resident Judge (Dandenong), to those with counselling facilities only (Bendigo, Albury, Lismore and Wollongong);
the appointment of two additional Judges to the Court;
the allocation of additional staff to the Court, increasing the average operative staffing level of the Court by 61 staff units in 1984/85 and 14 staff units in 1985/86 to a total of 506.
In addition, it is expected that the following measures will reduce delays in the Family Court-

the exercise by Registrars and Deputy Registrars of powers under section 37A of the Family Law Act. These powers have been exercised by Registrars and Deputy Registrars in most registries of the Family Court since 1 July 1985. It is expected that judicial time will therefore be free to deal with defended matters rather than procedural applications.
the introduction of a case management system.

My Department has also sought the consultative advice of Professor Ian Scott, Barber Professor of Law at the Birmingham Institute of Judicial Administration. Professor Scott is a member of the Lord Chancellor's Committee of Inquiry into Civil Justice in England and Wales. He will be examining ways of reducing delays in the Court and of assessing, allocating and disposing of the work of the court.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 23 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many instances of multiple voting were ascertained in each electoral division in the last three federal elections.

(2) Have all instances of multiple voting been investigated in the 1984 election: if so, how many in each division were as a result of (a) clerical error, (b) action on the part of the voter, or (c) the actions of a person or persons unknown.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The following information on `multiple voting' in the last three general elections is supplied by the Electoral Commissioner:

Following a general election the Electoral Commission conducts a `mark-back' of certified lists of voters marked in polling booths against a master list in each electoral Division, to ascertain the electors who did not vote, and the electors marked as having voted more than once.

For the 1980 and 1983 general elections the majority of cases of `multiple voting' apparent after the mark-back procedure were attributed to clerical error, usually as a result of the wrong name being marked on the certified list as having voted. In a minority of cases electors admitted voting twice or strong evidence suggested that electors had voted twice. Table 1 shows the incidence of `multiple voting' in these two categories for the 1980 and 1983 elections. At these two elections there were no standard procedures for defining clerical error and such cases were decided according to the discretion of the relevant Divisional Returning Officer.

For the 1984 general election the initial processing of multiple voters was done in much the same way as for the two previous elections. However, in an attempt to obtain more meaningful information, the Divisional Returning Officers were asked to repeat the exercise where possible or to reconstruct it, so as to divide the cases of multiple voting apparent after the mark-back into four categories: Dual Voter/Non Voter Matched; Evidence Inconclusive; Elector Admitted Voting Twice; and Investigation/Prosecutions Being Pursued. The first category refers to entries on certified lists where it appears that an elector who was marked as having voted twice was matched after consideration of non-voters replies against an elector with a similar name who was marked as not having voted at all. The entries in this category are clear cases of clerical error. The other three categories are self-explanatory. On past experience it is probable that most entries in the Evidence Inconclusive column were also the result of clerical error. Table 2 show the incidence of `multiple voting' in the 1984 election.

It should be noted that those cases of `multiple voting' attributable to clerical error did not result in electors actually voting more than once; these figures relate to errors made in marking certified lists in polling booths or transcribing details during the mark-back.

There was only one known case of `multiple voting' attributable to the actions of a person or persons unknown in the last 3 general elections: in the Division of Cowan in Western Australia in 1984, where two declarations votes were received in the same name. The case has been investigated by the Australian Federal Police and remains unsolved.
Notes: Those Divisions marked with * were created in the 1984 Redistribution and those marked + were abolished.
**One case in the Division of Cowan in Western Australia has been investigated and found to be a case of personation (see text).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do formal procedures exist for the handling of Ministerial representations in the Minister's Department and statutory authorities for which the Minister is responsible; if so (a) what are the titles of the instructions and when were they issued and (b) are target times provided (i) formally or (ii) informally; if so what are they.
(2) Is the performance with which representations are dealt with monitored; if so, what was the percentage of representations that met their targets in 1985, to 16 May.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Departmental Manual entitled `Procedures for Handling Parliamentary, Ministerial and Cabinet Papers' was issued in 1978, supplemented by the following two Departmental Parliamentary Instructions:
1/84 Time Limits for Response to Ministerial Correspondence
1/85 Responsibilities of the Ministers Assisting the Minister for Defence
A second edition entitled `Manual of Ministerial and Parliamentary Procedures' was issued on 9 August 1985.

(i) for routine correspondence-15 working days from receipt of the representation in the Department to presentation to the Minister or Ministers Assisting for approval. Shorter target times are provided to departmental action areas for more urgent representations.

AUSTRALIAN AID TO PAPUA NEW GUINEA, 1972-73 TO 1985-86

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 19 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many former public service employees are in receipt of an invalid pension under the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme.
(2) What is the current annual cost of these pensions.

(3) How many recipients of the invalid pension applied in (a) 1983 and (b) 1984 to the Superannuation Board for re-employment in the Public Service and how many successfully obtained employment in the Public Service.
(4) Of those applicants who were unsuccessful in obtaining re-employment in the Public Service, how many were unsuccessful in obtaining employment for medical reasons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As at 30 June 1984, the total number of persons formerly employed in the Australian Public Service and by Commonwealth statutory authorities who were in receipt of invalidity pensions under the provisions of the Superannuation Acts 1922 and 1976 was 26,173.
(2) The annual cost of these invalidity pensions as at 30 June 1984 was $310,127,987.

(3) Invalidity pensioners who desire to be re-employed in the Australian Public Service and Commonwealth statutory authorities would normally approach the various Commonwealth employers direct rather than the Commissioner for Superannuation who does not therefore have records of such approaches. However, the Commissioner is empowered by section 74 of the Superannuation Act to require invalidity pensioners who have not attained the age of 65 years to provide information about employment and to undergo medical examinations. During the 1982-83 financial year 936 pensioners were medically examined and of these 126 were considered fit to resume duty. Thirty-five pensions were cancelled, 29 after the pensioners recommenced public service or statutory authority employment and six because offers of employment were not accepted by the pensioners. In 1983-84, 601 pensioners were medically examined and of these 90 were considered fit to resume duty. Forty-nine pensions were cancelled, 36 after the pensioners recommenced public service or statutory authority employment and 13 because offers of employment were not accepted by the pensioners.
(4) During 1982-83 810 pensioners who were medically examined were not considered fit to resume duty. In 1983-84 the relevant figure was 511.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 18 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What amount was loaned or granted by the Commonwealth to the Tasmanian Government or the Beaconsfield municipality for the development of the Legana industrial estate.
(2) On what conditions was the money loaned or granted.
(3) What is the annual service cost and what government body pays it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A loan of $195,374.50 was paid to the Tasmanian Treasury on 19 June 1981 for the development of the Legana industrial estate.
(2) The loan was paid under an agreement with the State of Tasmania, which provided for:

(a) dollar for dollar funding of the cost of certain works to develop the estate subject to financial assistance in respect of individual development activities being limited to 60 per cent of the original estimate of costs;
(b) an overall limit of $200,000 on assistance from the Commonwealth;
(c) repayment of the loan in twenty equal half-yearly instalments (which commenced 15 July 1981) at an annual interest rate of 13.1 per cent on outstanding balances.
(3) Annual interest costs to the State are disclosed in Budget Paper No. 7, `Payments to or for the States, the Northern Territory and Local Government Authorities 1984-85'.
Payments are made by the Tasmanian Treasury.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 20 August:

QUESTION.PARA: What was the cost of (a) transport and (b) travelling allowance for the assembly and dispersal of Members and their personal staff for the sitting of the House of Representatives on Friday, 31 May 1985.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) As the honourable member will be aware there are a number of alternative modes of transport that a parliamentarian or a staff member may utilise when travelling to or from Canberra within the entitlement. For example, travel may be undertaken by air, rail, coach or private vehicle as well as by utilising the entitlement to official car transport.

My Department has no control over the submission of invoices for such travel by companies and as such it would be necessary to examine accounts extending over several months in an attempt to identify costs associated with the May 31 sitting. There are also the difficulties of ascertaining the point where a member commenced travel to Canberra, particularly in instances where the member was not travelling from home base, and in determining whether such travel was primarily for the purpose of attending the May 31 sitting.
In the light of the foregoing I am not prepared to authorise the considerable expenditure of time and money which would be required to identify the costs requested by the honourable member.
(b) Payment of travelling allowance for Members of the House of Representatives is the responsibility of the Speaker.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Ministerial Media Group and National Media Liaison Service

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 28 February 1985:

(10) Does he anticipate any rationalisation of the functions of AGAS, ICB, AIS, AGPS, MMG and the NMLS now that they all come under his portfolio.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The MMG comprises those journalists designated as Press Secretaries and attached to the staff of individual Ministers and those journalists who provide general media assistance to Ministers.

(1) (b) The NMLS assists the Government in communication matters and the dissemination of policy to the media, community organisations and interest groups and provides liaison between Commonwealth government and the media in each State.
(2) The MMG was established in April 1983 and the NMLS in May 1983.
(3) The expenditure incurred is set out in the following table:
(4) Such programs as are required by the exercise of their functions.

(i) Since May 1985 the MMG and the NMLS have come under the control of a single Director, who is responsible for the overall supervision of both groups to ensure that their activities are properly integrated and co-ordinated.
(8) A combination of new positions and vacancies.
(c) The duties are to provide media assistance to their assigned Ministers. This includes writing news releases, answering media questions, liaison with the media, drafting speeches.
(c) The duties are to provide accurate and timely information on Government policies and programs to the media and to interest groups and community organisations throughout Australia.

(10) Since 1 March 1984 AGAS has been incorporated into ICB to effect a rationalisation of the functions of these two Branches of my Department. A review of AIS conducted by the management consultants, Price Waterhouse, is currently under consideration by my Department. The functions of NMLS and NMG are under review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 16 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do formal procedures exist for the handling of Ministerial representations in the Minister's Department and statutory authorities for which the Minister is responsible; if so (a) what are the titles of the instructions and when were they issued and (b) are target times provided (i) formally or (ii) informally; if so, what are they.
(2) Is the performance with which representations are dealt with monitored: if so, what was the percentage of representations that met their targets in 1985, to 16 May.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. (a) Instructions have been issued from time to time detailing and/or updating procedures for the handling of Ministerial representations. These instructions have generally been issued as staff circulars within the department. A substantial diversion of resources would be necessary to identify precisely the actual dates of issue of all these notices. Their issue, however, has been a constant reminder to staff to deal with Ministerial representations expeditiously. The last such notice was issued on 30 May 1985.

(b) A formal target time does exist within my Department. It is presently 21 days. However, some kinds of representations (for example, those requring consultation with or advice from other portfolios) often cannot be dealt with within this period.

2. Performance monitoring does take place within my Department and monthly reports are provided of long outstanding representations. Since the beginning of 1985, 2492 representations have been received and 1513 or 61 per cent were dealt with by the end of May. Of the remaining 979 some 644 were outstanding for less than one month.

No advertising campaigns have been commissioned or conducted by the Department since March 1983. TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Department of Defence has circulated, in the Australian Capital Territory, a notice requesting officers to exercise due economy in the use of ruled writing pads because of an over-stock situation of unruled paper.
Unruled pads are made from stationery such as obsolete letterheads, which has become obsolete, and which would otherwise be pulped. The paper is guillotined to remove the unwanted printed portion.

Over a period of time the Department has produced 45,000 unruled pads which, for the time being, are being issued in lieu of rule pads. As a ruled pad costs 76c this measure enables a saving of over $30,000 to be made.
The cost of the templates, which were produced in-house, was $150.
(2) The templates are reusable. They are placed under the sheet on which the officer writes. They avoid the need to draw lines.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were amendments to sub-sections 113 (1) to (3) of the Insurance Act 1973 proclaimed in 1980.
(2) Does sub-section 113 (4) deal with the collection of statistics disclosing the volumes of business approved for placement overseas outside the provisions of the Insurance Act.

(3) Did the Insurance Commissioner in his annual report 1981-82 state that industry statistics now covered the operation of sub-sections (1) to (3) of the Act; if so, can he now indicate what the precise effect these proclaimed sub-sections have had on the industry.
(4) Are these sub-sections effective despite the failure to proclaim sub-section (4); if not, why not.

(5) Is it a fact that sub-section (4) must be proclaimed if the industry is to be afforded the opportunity to evaluate and enable it to make meaningful and constructive decisions and submissions, and, in particular, to enable governments to respond to industry needs.
(6) Will he take immediate steps to proclaim sub-section (4) of the Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Section 113 of the Insurance Act 1973 was amended by section 32 of the Insurance Amendment Act 1977. Sub-sections (1) to (3) of section 113 as amended were proclaimed on 31 August 1980 and came into effect on 3 November 1980.

(2) Sub-section 113 (4) of the Insurance Act 1973, if proclaimed, would require intermediaries to furnish statistical information on business placed by them with overseas insurers not authorised under Australian legislation and to provide the insured with a prescribed notice informing him that his insurer was not so authorised.

(3) While the 1981-82 Annual Report of the Insurance Commissioner contains some information on the operation of section 113, it does not include any reference to industry statistics of relevance to that section.

(4) Sub-sections 113 (1) to (3) of the Insurance Act 1973 prohibit intermediaries from entering into insurance contracts in Australia as agents of overseas insurance companies not authorised under Australian legislation, unless exempted by the Treasurer. Exemptions have been granted to allow access to overseas insurance markets but these are subject to the condition that, inter alia, the insured acknowledges in writing that his insurance cover may be provided in whole or in part by an overseas insurer. Sub-sections 113 (1) to (3) operate independently and the effectiveness of these sub-sections is not affected by the non-proclamation of sub-section 113 (4).

(5) and (6) Sub-section 113 (4), as currently framed, would not provide an adequate basis for the collection of statistics on placements of insurance business overseas as it would not allow account to be taken of certain market practices, including the various capacities in which an insurance agent may operate. The provisions are being examined against the background of the costs and benefits of providing for statistical collections in this general area and of the regulatory system reflected in the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Act 1984.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the Courier-Mail of 25 February 1985 in which the Premier of Queensland advised that some Labor States and the Commonwealth were bent on financial discrimination against Queensland in tax-sharing arrangements.

(2) Is it a fact that Queensland (a) did not receive its proper allocation of tax-sharing funds recommended by the Commonwealth Grants Commission in 1982 and (b) has actually been deprived of $51m for 1984-85 and a total of $855m since 1977-78.
(3) Will he ensure that all moneys owing to Queensland are paid forthwith.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (a) and (b) Queensland's allocation of tax sharing grants since 1982-83 has been made on the basis agreed at the June 1982 Premiers' Conference, viz:-

* that the relativities recommended by the Grants Commission (slightly modified to take account of prior agreements between the Commonwealth and the States of South Australia and Tasmania under the hospital cost-sharing agreements) were to be phased in over the course of the three years 1982-83 to 1984-85; and
* that each State's tax sharing grant would be subject to a real terms guarantee to the annual level of tax sharing payments during the phasing-in of the relativities.

Those decisions, which were taken to cushion the potentially adverse impact on the financial position of the three smaller States of immediate introduction of the new relativities, represented a compromise which all States agreed to in the context of the overall Commonwealth/State financial bargain decided at that Conference between the then Commonwealth Government and the States. That bargain followed the provision by the Commonwealth of additional grants in 1981-82 in recognition of the likelihood that, following the further review of relativities decided at the June 1981 Premiers' Conference, relativities would be adjusted in favour of the three most populous States. Queensland's share of that additional grant was $20.5 million.

It should be noted that the arrangements resulted in Queensland's share of the grants being higher compared with the share it received in the years immediately prior to 1982-83. Moreover, since 1982-83 Queensland's tax sharing grants have, in fact, been increasing faster than those paid to all other States and in 1984-85 they increased by 11.9 per cent, compared with an average increase of 4.7 per cent for the other States.

In the period 1977-78 to 1981-82 Queensland's tax sharing grants were supplemented, in each year, by a special grant paid on the recommendation of the Commonwealth Grants Commission. The effect of this arrangement was that Queensland's share of total general revenue grants was determined on the basis of the recommendations of the Commission.
(3) All amounts due to Queensland under the tax sharing arrangements have been and will continue to be paid in accordance with agreed schedules.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Films and Videos: Department of the Treasury

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 21 March 1985:

(5) How many officers are employed in this area within the Minister's Department and what are their salaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Union Membership: Department of the Treasury

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a memorandum, dated 1 June 1984, to all permanent heads, heads of statutory authorities and staff organisations from the Secretary of the Public Service Board, concerning encouragement of union membership.
(2) Was the memorandum brought to the attention of all staff in the Minister's Department and all statutory authorities reporting to the Minister; if so, how and on what dates.

(3) What additional action has been taken within the Minister's Department and statutory authorities reporting to the Minister to avoid delays in constructive action being taken to encourage union membership and on what dates; if no additional action has been taken, what are the reasons for such a decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) The Treasury has taken steps to facilitate union membership in the Department including:
Provision for union delegates to address Departmental induction courses and provision of union membership material to officers joining the Department;
use of Departmental noticeboards to display union material and the display of such material at the Department's personnel counter;
access to Departmental typing, photocopying and telephone facilities for union delegates;
access to the Department's registry distribution system for the circulation of material to union members; and
access to the Department's staff list.
(2) No. However, the memorandum was brought to the attention of union delegates in each ABS office during June 1984.

(3) An arrangement has been made with union delegates enabling them to participate in ABS training courses for new officers, with the objective of encouraging union membership. Union literature is distributed to all new staff and their names are provided to the unions to facilitate initial contact. Notices are placed in the ABS Staff Gazette from time to time, giving details of union delegates in the ABS offices. The ABS also provides printing facilities for unions to publish regular newsletters which include membership information. Such information is also prominently displayed on office notice boards. All of these initiatives are ongoing and several commenced before receipt of the Public Service Board memorandum of 1 June 1984.
(2) A circular drawing attention to the Public Service Board's policy of encouraging staff to join an appropriate union was issued to Australian Taxation Office staff progressively from 21 June 1984.
(3) No additional action has been taken. Issue of the staff circular referred to is considered sufficient.

(2) The Federal Government's support for representative bodies of employees and its declared policy of encouraging members of the staff to join the appropriate union was conveyed to all Corporation staff by means of a Circular Letter dated 24 August 1984 over the signature of the Managing Director.

(3) In the abovementioned Circular Letter, the Managing Director also took the opportunity to make it clear that Corporation management's policy is one or encouraging membership of the Commonwealth Bank Officers' Association (CBOA) as exemplified by its willingness to deduct related fees from salaries/wages. This policy of encouraging union membership is a long-standing one and involves an arrangement for bringing the benefits of CBOA membership to the attention of all newly recruited staff.

(3) A copy of the Public Service Board Circular covering encouragement of union membership was provided to the Bank by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations on the basis that it would be used as a guide in determining appropriate action in respect of union membership. Since arrangements consistent with those suggested were already in place in the Bank no action was required.

(2) The Board's Memorandum was, upon receipt, circulated to representatives of staff associations for their information. Public Service Board Bulletin No. 52 of June 1984 was also circulated to all staff notice boards.

(3) No additional action has been taken as a consequence of the Board's Memorandum, other than detailed above. Information to new employees regarding membership of staff associations/unions has been an integral part of the Mint's induction process for a number of years. Each new recruit receives a conditions of service handbook which has also been issued to all staff since 1976 which encourages staff to join the appropriate union or association. Additionally, recruits are issued with a list which details staff association/union representatives and, where provided by associations/unions, handouts in the form of information sheets are given to prospective members.

(2) The Public Service Board's memorandum was brought to the attention of staff by means of its circulation throughout both Authority offices on or about 7 June 1984. The Authority did not issue a separate statement to staff on the issue.
(3) The Authority has taken reasonable steps to encourage union membership including the following:
new recruits are provided with union membership information;
an officer of the ACOA in Sydney was invited to visit the Authority's newly-established office to meet new recruits on 23 November 1984;
union material is distributed and placed on noticeboards for the information of all staff;
workplace union representatives are allowed access to office telephone, photocopying and registry facilities.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Credit Cards: Department of the Treasury

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 16 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many officers in the Treasurer's Department, or in statutory authorities reporting to the Treasurer, are provided with credit cards.
(2) Which companies are used to provide these cards (for example, American Express, Diners Club).
(3) Who pays the membership and service fees.
(4) At what level is an officer entitled to credit cards.
(5) What limits are placed on the usage of the cards.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question as at 16 April 1985 is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) American Express International-Corporate Card System (Amex), Diners Club International-Government Card Plan (Diners Club).
(3) The Department of the Treasury pays membership fees only.

(4) All Senior Executive Service officers are entitled to credit cards. Other officers may apply if justification can be provided in accordance with the guidelines to Section 34 of the Finance Directions.

(5) Amex and Diners Club cards are subject to the limitations placed on the cards by Amex or Diners Club. Officers are responsible to meet all expenditure charged to their card account. Expenditure of an official nature incurred by the use of the credit cards is subject to normal reimbursement procedures to which the disciplines of the audit Act and other relevant procedures are applied. Other charges, including interest, that the officer incurs in using these cards are the personal responsibility of that officer.
(3) All Senior Executive Service officers and any other officer who can establish a justifiable need in accordance with the guidelines to Section 34 of the Finance Directions.
(5) No limits are placed on the usage of a card since each officer is personally liable to meet all charges other than the annual membership fee.
(1) Five officers held credit cards which had been issued on the authority of the Australian Statistician, for the purpose of facilitating the performance of official duties.
(2) The five cards were provided by American Express International.
(3) The ABS pays the annual membership fee for each card. The card holder pays all other fees.

(4) Credit cards are provided regardless of the level of the officer, but subject to approval by the Australian Statistician and on the basis that official duties carried out by the officer are facilitated by the use of the credit card.

(5) A credit card provided to an ABS officer is a personal card issued in the officer's name. The ABS is not liable for any expenses charged against the card and places no limits on the card holder in his/her use of it. The credit cards issued so far have been to officers who were undertaking overseas travel for official purposes.
(1) Eleven, of which eight are issued for temporary use.
(4) Entitlement is not based on status.
(5) Cards are made available for convenience in meeting expenditures incurred when on official business. Any non-official expenditure is for the officer's account.
(1) 163 staff members are currently holding credit cards used for business related expenses.
(2) Bankcard, Mastercard and American Express cards are the only credit cards currently used for this purpose.

(3) Membership fees are not applicable to Bankcard and Mastercard credit cards issued in Australia. Nor are service fees/credit charges applied in the case of these Corporation staff business cards (see also Item 5). In respect of American Express cards, all membership and related service fees are paid for by the Corporation.

(4) Credit cards for business use by Corporation staff at various management levels have been utilised for some time. Authorisation of such cards is governed by the degree of expenditure necessarily incurred by the cardholders on behalf of the Corporation while the type of card issued ilargely dependent on the proposed usage and travel requirements (i.e. within Australia or overseas).

(5) Within the Corporation credit cards of the type under reference are instruments for convenience of payment and their usage is limited to authorised expenditure incurred on behalf of the Corporation.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Vehicles: Department of the Treasury

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 16 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many officers in the Minister's Department, or in statutory authorities reporting to the Minister, are permitted to garage Commonwealth vehicles at their places of residence (a) permanently and (b) occasionally.
(2) What are the levels of these officers.
(3) Are these vehicles used by officers to provide transport to and from work.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: 3. The three Deputy Secretaries are authorised to garage vehicles at their places of residence. These vehicles are used as courier vehicles during normal business hours.

(b) approximately 1650 officers may be permitted to garage a vehicle occasionally. On any day, approximately 80-90 vehicles could be garaged temporarily at officers' private residences, mainly for the purpose of facilitating field operations.

3. The great majority of vehicles are garaged by officers who drive direct from their homes to field work. In a small minority of cases, officers who garage vehicles at home drive them to and from the office.

3. With the exception of the Australian Statistician and, in special circumstances only, Senior Executive Service officers, ABS officers do not use Commonwealth vehicles for the purpose of transport to and from work.
Vehicles owned by the Commonwealth and Reserve Banks are not registered as Commonwealth vehicles.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 April 1985:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With respect to the garaging of Commonwealth vehicles at officers' places of residence, is any officer permitted to use the allotted vehicle on other than work days, that is, at times when the officer is not on duty.
(2) In the case of a vehicle garaged in the Australian Capital Territory, may the officer use the vehicle for recreation purposes outside the Territory.
(3) Has the Minister's Department or any statutory authority reporting to the Minister issued guidelines for the use of these vehicles; if so, what are the terms of the guidelines.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) Yes. The Secretary to the Treasury has issued internal instructions governing the use of official vehicles. The terms of the Secretary's instructions are derived from the relevant rules set out by the then Department of Administrative Services in its publication ``Rules for the Use of Official Motor Transport and Procedures of the Central Transport Authority''.

(3) Yes. The Commissioner of Taxation has issued internal instructions governing the use of official vehicles. The terms of the Commissioner's instructions are derived from the relevant rules set out by the then Department of Administrative Services in its publication ``Rules for the Use of Official Motor Transport and Procedures of the Central Transport Authority''.

(3) Yes. The Australian Statistician has issued a reprint of `Rules for the Use of Official Motor Transport and Procedures of the Central Transport Authority' (Published by the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services) to users of the Commonwealth vehicles in question.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Funding: Blacktown and Penrith City Councils

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 14 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What amounts have been paid each year by the Federal Government to (a) Blacktown City Council and (b) Penrith Council, since the introduction of revenue sharing of personal income tax (PITS).
(2) What has been the percentage increase in real money terms each year.
(3) In the year that the percentage of PITS was increased, what was the increase and what position in percentage terms did the increase represent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3). The following table shows the amounts of grants allocated to the Blacktown City Council and Penrith City Council from the total of grants paid to the State of New South Wales under the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976, and the total amount of grants provided to all States for local government under the Act. The table also shows the percentage increase in payments in each year deflated by the implicit price deflator for gross non-farm product. Under the Act, personal income tax sharing payments to local government were initially set at 1.52 per cent of personal income tax collections. This was increased to 1.75 per cent in 1979-80 and to 2.00 per cent from 1980-81.
(a) deflated by the implicit price deflator for gross non-farm product.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government remain committed to equality of opportunity for men and women; if so, why does the Australian Bureau of Statistics continue to gather statistics on married women in the paid workforce and not gather statistics on married men in the same circumstances.

(2) Does the Government also remain committed to ratifying International Labour Organisation Convention No. 156 regarding workers with family responsibilities; if so, why does the Bureau concentrate on a particular gender in the paid workforce rather than on the category of workers with family responsibilities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In its monthly labour force survey, the Australian Bureau of Statistics collects data on both married men and married women in the paid workforce. Statistical estimates of the labour force status of civilians aged 15 years and over, cross classified by sex and marital status, are published each month in `The Labour Force, Australia' (ABS Catalogue No. 6203.0).

The ABS collects data on both males and females employed in the paid workforce. The statistical bulletin referred to in part (1) above includes, among other data, information on the labour force status of married couple families, other families with a male head and other families with a female head.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Program Funding: Department of the Treasury

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister's Department or any statutory authority for which the Minister is responsible have in place a program under which organisations may apply for funding; if so, what are they.

(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an information paper entitled `Issues in 1984-85 Grant in Aid (GIA) Assessment' distributed by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, in particular the suggestion that large and established ethnic community organisations who in the past have received support from the Grant in Aid Program of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs are now expected to apply for funding from main stream sources.

(3) What special provision has been made to ensure that in consideration of applications, appropriate and sensitive consideration is given to the special needs of migrant organisations and their so-called established ethnic organisations are placed in a position to compete equitably for any funds made available under programs through the Minister's Department or related agencies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The portfolio is basically concerned with fiscal and monetary policy matters. Neither the Treasury nor statutory authorities within the portfolio conduct specific programs under which organisations may apply for Commonwealth funding.
The paper `Issues in 1984-85 Grant-in-Aid (GIA) Assessment' has been drawn to my attention.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 23 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When did (a) Mr T. Carroll of 66 Foamcrest Avenue, Newport, New South Wales apply to the Government for legal aid and (b) the Government decide to grant him legal aid.
(2) Under what scheme or guidelines was the legal aid granted and what are the details of the scheme or guidelines under which the legal aid was granted.
(3) What is the maximum amount of legal aid to Mr Carroll for which the Government is committed.
(4) Was Mr Carroll subjected to the provisions of any means test before the Government decided to grant him legal aid; if so, what means test.
(5) What conclusions did the Government come to after subjecting Mr Carroll to a means test.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) On or about 13 May 1985-a precise record is not available.
(b) On 21 May 1985 the Prime Minister informed Mr Carroll that the Government was prepared to provide legal assistance to him.

(2) The grant of assistance was made pursuant to the power of the Attorney-General to authorise financial assistance towards legal costs and related expenses pursuant to item 165-3-03 in the Attorney-General's Department appropriations in the Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1984-85.
(3) The grant of assistance was confined to the cost of an opinion by senior counsel advising on the legal and financial problems encountered by Mr Carroll in relation to his former sponsorship.
(4) No-in certain circumstances it is well established that financial assistance towards legal costs is granted without regard to the means of the applicant.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Small Arms Manufacture: St Marys and Lithgow Munitions Factories

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 31 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: 1. What types of and in what quantities are small arms being produced at St Marys and Lithgow munitions factories.
2. For what purpose are each of these small arms generally used.
3. Are any of the arms exported; if so, to which countries and what is the value of the exports.
4. Does he have any knowledge of the use to which these arms are put and can he give an assurance that the arms are not used in internal government military campaigns against civilian residents.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. No small arms are produced at the St Mary's Munitions Filling Factory. Production of small arms is undertaken at the Small Arms Factory, Lithgow, but its production is currently confined to the overhaul of 7.62mm L1A1 rifles and spares production, which equates to approximately 1500 equivalent complete weapons per annum for 1985/86.
2. The L1A1 7.62mm rifle is a self loading military rifle and is used by Defence and Police forces.
3. Australia has been exporting the 7.62mm L1A1 rifle and spares manufactured at the Small Arms Factory Lithgow since the sixties. During the last five years the value of exports have amounted to:
The rifles and spares have been exported to some 35 countries, and in the period 1980-1985 to 21 countries which are as follows:
Because of the security requirements of the countries concerned I am not able to make public the quantities of small arms exported, by country, without clearance from these countries.
Enquiries for the export of rifles and spares are diminishing as countries commence to change to smaller calibre weapons.
Approval from the Department of Foreign Affairs is required before any defence related material is exported from Australia.

4. Generally the refurbished L1A1 rifles and spares are supplied to both the Australian and Papua New Guinea Armies for military use. However, modified 7.62mm rifle bodies are being produced for a commercial customer in the United States of America, the bodies being modified to prevent possible conversion to automatic operation.
At present no rifles are being exported to any of the countries that I have previously mentioned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 20 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that (a) the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) contains no mechanism for price adjustment based on exchange rate movements and (b) manufacturers and suppliers of pharmaceuticals to the PBS are seriously affected by exchange rate fluctuations as imported materials represent an average of 40 per cent of total input costs.
(2) What is the likely impact of devaluation on (a) the availability of imported pharmaceuticals and (b) the cost of pharmaceuticals.
(3) How many applications for price increases for PBS pharmaceuticals involving the cost of devaluation are currently outstanding.
(4) What action has he taken to grant relief to pharmaceutical manufacturers seriously affected by the impact of the devaluation during 1985.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) No. The Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Bureau when considering applications for price increases takes into account movements in costs including some elements of costs resulting from changes in exchange rates.

(b) Obviously exchange rate fluctuations affect the cost of imported components of pharmaceuticals. However, companies are affected to varying degrees depending on whether products are fully imported or basic raw materials only are imported.
(2) (a) Devaluation in itself appears to have had little, if any significant effect on the availability of imported pharmaceuticals.
(b) Generally the cost of pharmaceuticals has increased as a result of devaluation.
(3) In recent months the prices of 1605 products have been reviewed with account taken of cost movements including those stemming from devaluation. There are still 69 products to be reviewed.
(4) The current series of price reviews have resulted in price increases which will increase Government expenditure on pharmaceutical benefits by approximately $14.8m per annum.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 August 1985.

QUESTION.PARA: Further to his answer to question No. 760 (Hansard, 23 May 1985, page 3156), will he provide:
(a) details of when and where his Department conducted the more than 200 seminars on the assets test, and
(b) as detailed as possible an account of the publicity costs associated with these seminars.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) As I indicated in my reply to question No. 760 (Hansard 23 May 1985 page 3156), the figure given in relation to the number of seminars was an estimate only and no statistical information, such as locations and dates of seminars, was kept.
(b) The cost of publicising the seminar was included in general publicity costs and is not able to be separated from the figure given in my earlier reply.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 22 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: With respect to farmers in the electoral division of Tangney who have had their pensions cancelled or reduced up to 20 August 1985 (a) who made the valuations of their assets; (b) on what were the valuations based; (c) were the farms inspected or was any other method used to confirm the valuation; (d) what net income could be expected from the farms in 1984/85 as a percentage of the valuations; and (e) what was the current market rental value of each of the properties deemed to be.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) In accordance with the emphasis on pensioner self-assessment, wherever possible the pensioner's estimates of the value of their assets were accepted. Some checking was required for certain items, e.g. the value of shares were checked against current share listings in the financial press. For cases where pensioners owned real estate (other than the home) and the total value of their assets would cause reduction in pension, or where the total value was within $20,000 of the allowable limit, or where the departmental officer was not satisfied with the pensioner's estimate, the real estate values were checked by officers of the Valuations Branch of the Australian Taxation Office.
Information provided by the pensioner on the Statement of Assets form; and, in the case of real estate, on recent sales information for the area;
local knowledge of the area; and

(c) Where possible external inspections of properties were carried out but due to the restrictions of time the majority of cases were checked against information available in the Valuations Branch offices, e.g. statutory valuations, recent sales information for the area, etc.

Where the pensioner was not satisfied with the valuation, provision existed to query it with department's review officer. If the matter could not be resolved to the pensioner's satisfaction, arrangements were made for an on-site valuation by a professional valuer from the Taxation Office. However, on-site valuations have not been undertaken without the pensioner's specific authority.
(d) This information is not available-estimated net income of the properties was not calculated as part of the assets test processing.
(e) This information is not available-current market rental value of properties was not calculated as part of the assets test processing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 19 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the task force which inquired into the categorisation of private hospitals did not make any inspection of Queensland private hospitals, or take evidence from sources within Queensland.
(2) What action is he taking to ensure that he is fully informed on Queensland's situation before any decision is made.
(3) In view of the fact that the task force's report is based only on selection data, will the Government now reject the recommendations of the task force.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Task Force had planned to visit a number of private hospitals in Queensland and arrangements for appropriate hospitals to be visited were being made through the Queensland Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes Association. However, the time of the proposed visit coincided with the annual conference of the Australian Private Hospitals Association being held in Sydney and the hospital representatives were attending that conference. In the circumstances, arrangements were made for representatives of a number of Queensland private hospitals, as referred to in the report of the Task Force, to meet the Task Force in Sydney. The hospital representatives produced written material and had substantial discussion with Task Force members. A representative of the Queensland Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes Association made these arrangements and was present at the discussions.

(2) I believe that the Task Force was adequately informed. Subsequently, my Department asked each private hospital in Australia for views on the report of the Task Force. Many Queensland hospitals responded, as well as groups representing the interests of Queensland hospitals.
(3) I refer the honourable member to my answer to parts (1) and (2) of question No. 151 (Hansard, 10 September 1985, page 369).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 19 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: When are decisions expected on the `Report of task force established to review private hospital categorisation arrangements'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the honourable member to my answer to parts (1) and (2) of question No. 151 (Hansard, 10 September 1985, page 369).

Building and Construction-Long Service Leave Board...

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 23 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister's Department or any statutory authority for which the Minister is responsible have in place a program under which organisations may apply for funding; if so, what are they.

(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an information paper entitled `Issues in 1984-85 Grant in Aid (GIA) Assessment' distributed by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, in particular the suggestion that large and established ethnic community organisations who in the past have received support from the Grant In Aid Program of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs are now expected to apply for funding from main stream sources.

(3) What special provision has been made to ensure that in consideration of applications, appropriate and sensitive consideration is given to the special needs of migrant organisations and that so-called established ethnic organisations are placed in a position to compete equitably for any funds made available under programs through the Minister's Department or related agency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Resources and Energy administers the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration (NERD&) Program under which applications may be submitted for grants in support of energy research, development and demonstration projects.

The Joint Coal Board has in place a welfare grants program. Under The Coal Industry Act 1946 of NSW and the Commonwealth, the Board has responsiblities to promote the welfare of workers engaged in the coal industry in NSW. One method by which the Board discharges this responsibility is through the making of grants which benefit the domestic welfare of mineworkers and the welfare of the communities in which they live.

The procedure is for an organisation to apply to the Board for a welfare grant towards the cost of a particular project. The Board does not make welfare grants for the funding of an organisation itself.

(2) Yes, but for general information only. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs had advised my Department that the information paper had some limited circulation amongst Grant-in-Aid agencies, some of whom have taken up its invitation to comment on the issues raised, and that the paper:
expresses the Government's policy to provide services and facilities to encourage and assist migrants to settle into the Australian community, building where possible on community networks through:
sensitising and developing Australia's mainstream services to ensure that they provide equitably for all members of the community, and
developing special arrangements, where necessary, to overcome disadvantages faced by particular groups in society.

suggest that the needs of the aged, to the extent that they apply equally to Australian-born and overseas-born should be met by adapting mainstream resources rather than through the establishment of separate services of a permanent nature.
does not assert that all established ethnic community organisations must in future seek funding from mainstream sources.

(3) The types of grants awarded under the NERD& Program have no perceived direct relevance to the needs of migrant organisations. Applications for grants are assessed against published criteria. No preferential treatment is given to any applicant.

The Joint Coal Board is not aware of any applications for welfare grants being made by migrant organisations, at least in recent years. Processing of a grant application always involves personal consultation with the applicant during which the proposed project is discussed in detail with a Board Officer with local knowledge. Applications for grants are usually made by small organisations with special needs and without expertise in making approaches to Governments for funds.
The Board is confident that the special needs of welfare grant applicants are properly and sensitively considered.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 16 May 1985:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to part (1) of question No. 305 (Hansard, 5 June 1984, page 2936), what action has been taken against any merchant bank for any role it may have played in handling cheques that were part of `round robin' tax avoidance schemes.
(2) If no action has been taken (a) what cases are still under investigation and (b) what was the outcome of the investigation referred to in his answer.

(3) Further to his answer to part (3) of the question, has the question of the need for legislative action to strengthen or further clarify the Commissioner of Taxation's powers pursuant to sections 263 and 264 of the Income Tax Assessment Act been resolved; if so, in what way was it resolved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The investigation I referred to in my answer to part (1) of Question No. 305 (Hansard, 5 June 1984, page 2936) has now been substantially completed. Charges have been laid against a number of persons and court proceedings are pending. The Commissioner of Taxation advises that as far as he is aware this is the only case of this kind under investigation.

(3) The question of whether there is a need for legislative action to strengthen or further clarify his powers pursuant to sections 263 and 264 of the Income Tax Assessment Act is still being examined.
