QUESTION.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 21 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many officers were employed in the Investigation Branch of the Taxation Office on 30 June 1984.
(2) What is the total annual cost of the operation of the Investigation Branch.
(3) What amount was recovered by the Investigation Branch in 1983-84.
(4) What amount was collected as a result of (a) court orders and (b) voluntary repayments.
(5) What were the sources of these recoveries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) During 1983-84 total staff usage on income tax audit/investigation activities in branch offices of the Australian Taxation Office was 1,167 man years.

(2) Total direct salary costs and overheads of the operation of these activities in the 1983-84 year was estimated at $43m. In addition, there were flow on costs in other areas of the Taxation Office resulting from these activities, estimated at $6.5m.

(3) The amount of tax and additional tax raised in assessments completed as a result of audit/investigation of income tax evasion during the 1983-84 year was $253,101,476. This figure does not include tax and penalty raised in assessments in tax avoidance cases, trust stripping cases or cases under the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act. It was necessary to divert 374 of the abovementioned 1,167 man years to these other activities during 1983-84.
(4) No data was kept in 1983-84 on the proportion of tax raised that was collected by court order or voluntary repayments.
(5) No data was kept by the Taxation Office to indicate the sources of the amounts collected.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 16 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can he explain why 200 taxation Form S Explanatory Notes written in Italian, arrived at the Lismore Post Office, N.S.W. on 5 October 1984.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In line with Taxation Office policy to assist non-English speaking persons to complete their salary and wages income tax returns, guidance notes in various ethnic languages are made available to all Taxation Offices and to select Post Offices. A supply of Notes has been provided to the Lismore Post Office as it is known that there is a sizeable Italian community in the region. However, due to the late passage of complex law which had to be accurately reflected in return forms and instructions, printing and delivery of those forms and instructions was much later this year than is normally the practice.

(2) Yes. Although income tax returns are required to be lodged by 31 August unless prepared by a tax agent, supplies of forms and instructions remain available in post offices until end of October to cater for those taxpayers who for one reason or another do not lodge their returns by 31 August.
(3) Yes. For NSW the information is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: How will the early retirement lump sum payment for Australian National Railways Commission employees recently announced by the Minister for Transport be taxed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian National Railways Commission's Separation Gratuity Incentive Scheme has been approved by the Commissioner of Taxation as an approved early retirement scheme for the purposes of section 27E of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

Subject to certain tests being satisfied, a payment under an approved early retirement scheme, to the extent that it exceeds the amount the retiree could reasonably be expected to have received if he or she had ceased employment at the same time otherwise than in accordance with the early retirement scheme, qualifies for a concessional basis of assessment in that only 5 per cent of the excess is included in the retiree's assessable income.

As the law now stands, one of the tests referred to-a premature retirement test-requires that termination of employment occur before the time when it could have occurred by reason of the employee having attained a particular age or completing a particular period of service. This means that, under the existing law, where an employee has an option to retire at a certain age (as is understood to be now the case with ANRC employees), termination must occur before that option becomes exercisable for any part of an approved early retirement scheme payment to qualify for concessional tax treatment.

However, an examination of the effect of the premature retirement test in relation to a wide range of applications for approval of early retirement schemes has made it clear that the existing premature retirement test is too restrictive. For that reason the Government has introduced into the Parliament amending legislation (the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1985, introduced on 23 May 1985) that will ease that requirement of the income tax law.

The proposed amendment will provide for access to the concession if termination of employment occurs before age 65 and before the date on which termination would necessarily have to occur by reason of the employee having attained a particular age or completing a particular period of service. In other words, the availability of an option to retire at a particular time before age 65 will not preclude the application of the concession.

The amending legislation will not come into effect until it has been passed by the Parliament and receives the Royal Assent. However, the particular amendment is to apply with effect from 1 July 1983.

The Commissioner has advised that, subject to the amendment being enacted, the conditions applicable to the National Railways Scheme are such that the whole of the early retirement gratuity payable, being additional to the benefits to which a retiree would otherwise have been entitled on termination of employment, would be eligible for the special 5 per cent basis of assessment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 13 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the corporate structure of the organisation known as `Pat Dukes Nurses' Agency', of 280 Pitt Street, Sydney.
(2) What is the purposes of the organisation and when was it established.
(3) Who is the chief executive and who are the beneficial owners.

(4) Is he able to say whether this organisation has satisfied the requirements of the Commonwealth and NSW Governments for the necessary registration procedures and the provision of routine corporate, finance, tax and employee information; if they remain unsatisfied, why is this so.

(5) Since 1980, with which hospitals that have been in receipt of Commonwealth and State funding, and with which other hospitals and health institutions has Pat Dukes Nurses' Agency had contractual and organisational arrangements and what are those contracts and arrangements.
(6) How many nurses have been involved in these contracts and arrangements since 1980, and what corresponding amounts have been involved.

(7) Has it been the practice of the organisation to charge nurses a fee of 10% of each nurse's total earnings, to charge hospitals a fee of 10% of the nurses earnings for placement of nurses, and then to indicate to nurses that only one fee of 10% is being received by the organisation in respect of their work.

(8) Is it the practice of the organisation to receive payment from hospitals for work previously and satisfactorily performed by nurses and then to withhold those funds for months before actual payment to the individual nurses; if so, how many nurses have been subjected to these witholding arrangements since 1980, what amounts are involved and what has happened to that money between receipt from the hospitals and the payment to nurses.

(9) Has this organisation refused to issue appropriate and complete financial and other documentation to both nurses and hospital for work undertaken and have receipts and accounts taken the form of unsigned and undated plain scraps of paper, not on any form of letter-headed paper.
(10) Will he ascertain from the Treasurer, whether the Agency has satisfied the requirements of the Income Tax Assessment Act since the organisation was established.

(11) Is he able to say whether (a) the Commonwealth and (b) the NSW Governments believe it is appropriate for this organisation to continue to be involved in the provision of services for publicly funded and other hospitals; if not, what course of action is proposed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (9) and (11) My Department has no dealings with Pat Dukes Nurses' Agency and I am consequently unable to provide answers to these parts of the question. I suggest the honourable member raise them with the Minister for Health in the NSW Government which has responsibility for the provision of services in hospitals there.

(10) Advice received from the Office of the Commissioner of Taxation states that the secrecy provisions of the income tax law prohibit the Commissioner from divulging information about the taxation affairs of particular taxpayers. The Commissioner is therefore unable to answer this part of the question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General and the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 14 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will the Government have enacted throughout Australia the model uniform Food Bill and the companion model regulations, approved by the June 1980 Health Ministers' Conference.
(2) Is he able to explain why only Queensland has legislated on this matter to date.
(3) Is he prepared to pursue the issue of a model uniform Food Act at the next meeting with his State ministerial counterparts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member has asked identical questions of both the Attorney-General and me, as indicated by the above question numbers. With the concurrence of the Attorney-General, I provide the following answer to the honourable member's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Enactment throughout Australia of Model Food Legislation is the responsibility of the individual State and Territory Governments. I am unable therefore to advise when all States and Territories will adopt Model Legislation.

(2) While I am unable to explain why only Queensland has legislated on this matter to date, I am aware that South Australia, Tasmania, Victoria and Western Australia have passed the legislation, South Australia and Tasmania are awaiting proclamation. New South Wales has the legislation drafted to go to the next session of Parliament, and the Territories have the matter currently with their legal draftsmen.

(3) Yes, I am prepared to pursue the matter with my State Ministerial counterparts and in fact, I raised the issue at the recent Australian Health Ministers' Conference in Brisbane on 16-17 May 1985. The Conference agreed on a plan of action to facilitate the automatic adoption of uniform legislation by all States and Territories. In June 1985 the Government agreed to my joint proposals with Senator Button for the achievement of uniform food standards. These proposals involve the State and Territory Governments agreeing to adopt automatically by reference, the food standards issued by the National Health and Medical Research Council unless otherwise decided by a Commonwealth/States Ministerial Council, the National Food Standards Council. The establishment of this Council was further discussed at the Australian Health Services Council meeting in June 1985. An agreement between the Prime Minister, Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory is currently being developed by my Department and the Attorney-General's Department. It is proposed that the national Food Standards Council will commence operation from 1 January 1986.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 15 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government granted, or does it intend to grant an entry visa to Mr Faris Glubb; if so, can he say whether this is the same Faris Glubb who is reportedly an active member of the Palestine Liberation Organisation through its affiliate the Palestinian Writers Union and who has recently reaffirmed his support for the PLO and its aims.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has not granted a visa to Mr Faris Glubb, a member of the Palestinian Writers and Journalists Union.
Mr Glubb re-applied for a visa to visit Australia in March of this year. The Government has not yet taken a decision on Mr Glubb's application.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 16 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do formal procedures exist for the handling of Ministerial representations in the Minister's Department and statutory authorities for which the Minister is responsible; if so, (a) what are the titles of the instructions and when were they issued and (b) are target times provided (i) formally or (ii) informally; if so what are they.
(2) Is the performance with which representations are dealt with monitored; if so, what was the percentage of representations that met their targets in 1985, to May 16.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Within my portfolio formal procedures exist for the handling of Ministerial representations in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Public Service Board and the Australian Bicentennial Authority. Other authorities which are involved in handling Ministerial representations follow procedures consistent with those applying within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet or provide the Department with input to replies which are prepared in the Department.
The answer to the remaining parts of the honourable member's question in respect of each of the three bodies which have formal procedures are-
Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet:
1 (a) The instructions are titled `Ministerial Corres- pondence Procedures' and were last issued in March 1984.

(b) (i) and (ii) Target times are not provided in the procedures either formally or informally. Correspondence is to be handled without delay, but the drafting of replies often depends upon information being supplied by other agencies.
(2) Not applicable, in view of answer to 1 (a) and (b) above.

1 (a) The instructions are titled `Procedures for Handling Representations and Similar Ministerial Correspondence'. The instructions are updated regularly, most recently on 3 April 1985 when improved monitoring procedures were instituted.

(b) Target times for answering representations are set formally. Correspondence from Ministers and Members of Parliament is to be answered within three weeks of receipt. Target times for urgent matters are as required.

(2) Performance is monitored; overall 20 per cent of representations met their targets in 1985, to May 16. With the introduction of improved procedures on 3 April 1985, this has increased to 37 percent.
1 (a) The Authority follows as closely as possible the procedures set down in the Ministerial Correspondence Procedures of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.
(b) In addition target times are set formally. The Authority aims to respond to all Ministerial representations within four weeks of receipt.

(2) Performance is monitored; 54 per cent of representations met their target to 16 May 1985. Of the remainder 32 per cent required advice from areas outside the Authority's National Office where the reply is prepared.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Visas and Work Permits: South East Asian Women

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 20 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many works permits and other visas entitling visitors to work in the tourist and entertainment industry have been issued to women from South-East Asia in the last 12 months.
(2) In which States are these women employed.
(3) What are the visitors countries of origin.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand the honourable member is interested in figures relating to persons from Indonesia, the Philippines and Thailand.

Most recent figures show that in the financial year 1984/85 the following numbers of temporary residence visas were issued in Indonesia, the Philippines and Thailand for the holders to work in Australia as entertainers:
Visitors to Australia are not permitted to engage in employment and visas are endorsed accordingly.
People who enter Australia for short or long-term periods to engage in employment, enter as temporary residents.
Although statistics are kept at overseas posts for visas issued to temporary residents, they are not separated by sex or country of origin.
Statistics are not maintained for temporary residents in specific industries but are recorded by occupation. Figures, therefore, are not available for persons employed in the tourist industry.
Policy provides for the entry of entertainers to work in Australia provided they are sponsored by an enterprise or person of good standing and reputation.
(2) Statistics are not maintained for temporary residents' state of intended residence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the current cost per taxpayer for the administration, including collection, of personal income tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Information on the cost per taxpayer for the administration, including collection, of personal income tax is not maintained by the Australian Taxation Office.

However, related information maintained by the Australian Taxation Office indicates that for the financial year ended 30 June 1984, there were 9,334,000 income tax returns lodged. This figure represents current and prior year income tax returns lodged by individuals, partnerships, companies, trusts and superannuation funds.

The net cost of collecting income tax for the financial year ended 30 June 1984 was $314,589,004. By dividing the net cost of collection figure by the number of tax returns lodged, the Australian Taxation Office can say that the average cost (per income tax return lodged) was $33.70.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Display of Portraits at Australian Embassies

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 23 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) At which Australian Embassies are framed photographs of the Prime Minister and himself displayed in public areas.
(2) Was the decision to hang these photographs publicly a ministerial decision; if so, who gave the directive.
(3) Are framed photographs of Her Majesty the Queen displayed in public areas of these Embassies; if not, will he ensure this is done.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) No. There is no formal requirement to display portraits of the Prime Minister and Foreign Minister in Australian posts abroad. Portraits are distributed as requested by each overseas post.

(3) Framed photographs of Her Majesty the Queen are displayed in public areas of a number of Australian overseas posts, although there is no formal requirement to do so. Portraits of Her Majesty are displayed in non-public areas at a number of other overseas posts. It is not practical in all instances to display portraits in public areas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When were (a) personal income tax, (b) sales tax, (c) death duties, (d) gift duties, (e) pay-roll tax and (f) entertainment tax, first introduced and by which Government.
(2) What were the reasons for the introduction of each tax as stated by the then Government.
(3) At the time of the introduction of each tax did the then Government state that it was intended as a temporary or permanent impost.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Federal personal income tax was introduced in 1915 by the Fisher Government.
(b) Sales tax was introduced in 1930 by the Scullin Government.
(c) Estate duties, also known as death duties, were introduced in 1914 by the Fisher Government.
(d) Gift duty was introduced in 1941 by the Curtin Government.
(e) Pay-roll tax was introduced in 1941 by the Menzies Government.
(f) Entertainment tax was introduced in 1916 by the Hughes Government.
(a) Personal income tax was introduced to provide ``. . . additional revenue necessary to meet the great and growing liabilities created by the First World War . . .''.
(b) Sales tax was introduced ``. . . because of the state of the Commonwealth finances.''.
(c) Estate duty was ``. . . imposed for the purpose of raising revenue.''.
(d) Gift duty was introduced for a twofold purpose ``. . . namely, revenue protection and revenue production.''.
(e) Pay-roll tax was ``. . . intended to provide additional revenue for the payment of cash allowances for the benefit of children.''.
(f) Entertainment tax ``. . . was part of a scheme . . . for raising money for the purposes of paying the war expenses.''.
(a) Not specified. Described by the then Attorney-General as ``a war measure, designed to meet the present circumstances''.
(b) The then Treasurer said: ``How long it will operate I cannot say. I do not assert that it is temporary or emergency legislation.''.

(c) The then Attorney-General said: ``I do not pretend that, in its present form, it ought to be permanent, though that is not a declaration that probate, estate, or succession duties will not form a permanent part of the Commonwealth scheme of taxation''.

(d) Not specified at the time of introduction, but subsequently in 1951 the then Treasurer stated that Gift Duty was not intended as a temporary measure, but its primary purpose was to protect the revenue from other sources, particularly income tax and estate duty.

(e) The then Minister Assisting the Treasurer said: ``No'' in response to the question ``(Is) this tax intended to be a temporary tax?''. He later added ``. . . I do not hold out hope to employers that this tax will be imposed for only a short time.''.
(f) Not specified. Government members' speeches referred to the tax as necessary ``to meet the extra demands of the war'' and ``to meet a special emergency''.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Advertising Campaigns and Research Studies: Department of Community Services

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 20 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What advertising campaigns and research studies have been conducted or commissioned by the Minister's Department since March 1983.
(2) Did any other Government agencies advise or co-ordinate any of these campaigns or research studies.
(3) If an advertising agency or market research firm was used:
(a) what was its name; and
(b) what amount was it paid.
(4) What was:
(a) the cost; and
(b) in the case of advertising campaigns, the split between agency fees and actual campaign costs for each campaign or study.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) Since the creation of the Department of Community Services on 12 December 1984, one activity of the type outlined in the honourable member's question has been undertaken.

On 7 May 1985 a public relations company and a design studio-Neilson McCarthy &Partners Pty Ltd and Corporate Graphics-were jointly awarded a consultancy to develop a communication strategy and visual identity for the Department. Specifically, the consultancy involved the design of a logo, design and production of brochures and a newsletter, design and production of stationery and development of an information strategy.

The consultants were selected from the tenders of agencies recommended by the Australian Government Advertising Service, with advice from the Information Co-ordination Branch of the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism.
The total cost of the exercise was $69,930.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 20 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What brands of computer or automatic data processing hardware are in use in the Minister's Department and each authority for which the Minister is responsible.
(2) For each major system
(a) what is its principal function,
(b) when was it installed,
(c) what was the hardware cost,
(d) what is its anticipated life, and
(e) what action is being taken in relation to its replacement.
(3) Is any major system shared with any other user; if so, who and for what main purpose.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Brands of computer or ADP hardware.
IN RELATION TO THE DEPARTMENT OF HOUSING AND CONSTRUCTION
In addition there are numerous small ancillary items of various brands.
IN RELATION TO THE SNOWY MOUNTAINS ENGINEERING CORPORATION
IN RELATION TO THE HOUSING LOANS INSURANCE CORPORATION
IN RELATION TO THE DEPARTMENT OF HOUSING AND CONSTRUCTION

The table below provides answers to questions 2 (a) to 2 (d). In this table `anticipated life' is quoted as the number of years now remaining before replacement is assessed as being warranted on economic grounds.

In addition to the major processor systems identified below minor systems and peripheral equipment including disk drives, tape drives, controllers and terminals essential for the functioning of the major systems have been progressively installed from December 1981 at a hardware cost totalling $13.728 million and with an `anticipated life' ranging from one to eight years.
Interactive system to service professional technical and management functions throughout the Department
System to be recommissioned for the above functions
To handle time critical applications (including accounting and wages) in each State
A pilot system for distributed processing located in Melbourne using the MVS operating system for technical and management tasks and to provide back up of critical systems
Pilot system in the WA Region to provide evaluation of Computer Aided Drafting in a production environment
Single user Technical/Graphics workstations now used in Central Office and the Vic/Tas, SA/NT and ACT Regions
Data entry equipment for the 4331 Regional computers in WA, Vic, SA, NSW and ACT.

(e) In 1983 a major study by consultants recommended that the Department should adopt a policy of distributed data processing. Further studies in 1984 considered the capacity of the existing network and defined a number of strategic options for the introduction of distributed processing.

Specific technology plans and business cases are now being developed to demonstrate the essential need for an expansion of the Department's computing facilities which will provide replacement of some systems and increase the life of other systems by increasing their capacity.
IN RELATION TO THE SNOWY MOUNTAINS ENGINEERING CORPORATION
The only major system is the HP3000 Processor:
(a) Principal function: Main processor for commercial (payroll, costing, ledger, drawing index etc.) and technical (engineering analysis, design etc.) systems.
(d) Anticipated life: Central processor-nil. Peripherals 0-10 years.
(e) Proposal for replacement is under consideration.
IN RELATION TO THE HOUSING LOANS INSURANCE CORPORATION
The only major system is Datapoint:
(a) Principal function: Interactive system providing data entry, general business, statistical and accounting functions.
IN RELATION TO THE DEPARTMENT OF HOUSING AND CONSTRUCTION

The Department of Veterans Affairs shares the use of the IBM 3033 computer for the development of a patient care system. The Department of Transport shares the use of data base systems on the IBM 3081 for motor vehicles and sea transport systems.
IN RELATION TO THE SNOWY MOUNTAINS ENGINEERING CORPORATION
The hardware and payroll software are shared with SMHEA.
IN RELATION TO THE HOUSING LOANS INSURANCE CORPORATION

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Computer and ADP Hardware: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 20 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What brands of computer or automatic data processing hardware are in use in the Minister's Department and each authority for which the Minister is responsible.

(2) For each major system (a) what is its principal function, (b) when was it installed, (c) what was the hardware cost, (d) what is its anticipated life and (e) what action is being taken in relation to its replacement.
(3) Is any major system shared with any other user; if so, who and for what main purpose.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Brands of computer and ADP hardware which are in use in my Department and the authority responsible to me are as follows:

In Australia: Mainframe Computer; Processor-Amdahl; Disk storage-National Advanced System, IBM, Memorex; Communications Processors-Amdahl; Magnetic tape units-Storage Technology; Printers-Storage Technology, IBM; Network Equipment-Raytheon, IBM, Memorex, Hewlett-Packard, Facom; Micro-computers-Sigma Data.
To control and track the movement of departmental nominal and subject files
To administer English language training of migrants through State Education Authorities
To administer processing of applications for Australian citizenship
To track and report on the movement of passengers and crew in and out of Australia
Major upgrade envisaged in 1986-87 to facilitate better Data Entry Services
To record and report on administration of personnel within the Department

(3) The eleven Honeywell systems (Overseas) are used by the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Department of Trade for general office automation such as Word processing, Library systems, Trade information, Travel diary and Accounting purposes. The Department's main use is on the Visa Registry System.
The Adult Migrant Education System is shared by the State Education Departments.
(1) Wang office computer, President personal computers.
(2) (a) Word processing and data analysis; (b) 1981; (c) $146,500; (d) Until 1987; (e) Re-placement is planned in 1987-88.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 22 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Decca position fixing system for Port Hedland be switched off; if so, (a) when and (b) why.
(2) Will methods be available to sea-going vessels to keep on course in the strong tidal currents when the channel at Port Hedland is upgraded, and the Decca system is no longer operating.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes-anticipated mid-1986; (b) The extended channel will be marked by fixed structures with a dual band beacon on the outer-most mark and consequently the Port Hedland Decca chain will no longer be required. These arrangements have been endorsed by the commercial shipping industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 23 August 1985:

(2) What was the (a) amount and (b) nature of the expenditure in each case for (i) compensation and (ii) legal expenses.
(3) What was the name of each recipient of payment for legal expenses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) (i) Compensation-Expenditure in 1984-85 totalled $69,544 and, for the most part, covered regular on-going compensation payments (amounting to $51,438) made to seven former employees in accordance with determinations of the Commissioner for Employees Compensation. The balance of expenditure covered payments to medical practitioners, chemists, hospitals, etc. relating to employee compensation determinations in respect of 53 officers and comprising 165 individual transactions.
Memorandum of fees-Mr T. Simos, Q.C. representing the Commonwealth re: Whitlam v. Australian Consolidated Press
Memorandum of fees-Mr L. Katz appearing with Mr Simos, Q.C. in above case

Memorandum of fees-Mr S. Walmsley-Commonwealth v. Carroll
Expenses, fee-Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and Toohey
Counsel fees and expenses-The Secretary, Attorney-General's Department and ors v. Hallows. (Counsel acted for five Departments-expenditure represents one-fifth of charges)

Counsel fees and expenses-Mr L. Katz Public Service Board and Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and Dr F. E. Peters-Administrative Appeals Tribunal proceedings (cost shared with Public Service Board-expenditure represents one-half of charges)

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Compensation and Legal Expenses: Department of Veterans' Affairs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 10 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why has $87,000 been appropriated for compensation and legal expenses for the Defence Service Homes Corporation in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1985-86 when, in 1984-85, no moneys were expended for these services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: `Compensation and Legal Expenses' is a new item introduced in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1985-86. In 1984-85 funds for compensation and legal expenses were included in the appropriation for `Administrative Expenses'. Expenditure of $63,097 by the Corporation in 1984-85 is included in Sub-division 693.2 Administrative Expenses.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 12 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to his answer to question No. 531 (Hansard, 13 May 1985, page 2245) can he now say (a) what the cost for the July Tax Summit was and (b) what part of the cost was for the use of Parliament House, for a forum of unelected Government appointed participants.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 23 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister's Department or any statutory authority for which the Minister is responsible have in place a program under which organisations may apply for funding; if so, what are they.

(2) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an information paper entitled `Issues in 1984-85 Grant in Aid (GIA) Assessment' distributed by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, in particular the suggestion that large and established ethnic community organisations who in the past have received support from the Grant in Aid Program of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs are now expected to apply for funding from main stream sources.

(3) What special provision has been made to ensure that in consideration of applications, appropriate and sensitive consideration is given to the special needs of migrant organisations and their so-called established ethnic organisations are placed in a position to compete equitably for any funds made available under programs through the Minister's Department or related agencies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Funding for organisations and/or individuals is available under the following programs:

Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment-Commemoration of Historic Events and Persons, Control of Historic Shipwrecks, Australian Biological Resources Study, National Tree Program, National Estate Grants Program, Grants to Voluntary Conservation Organisations.

Aboriginal Arts Board-Music, Dance and Drama, Community Festival and Ceremonies, Visual Arts, Literature and Aboriginal Writing, Multi-Arts Programs, Aboriginal Community Arts Officers, Film, Video and Radio, Major Aboriginal Arts Organisations.

Crafts Board-Grants to Organisations: Craft Councils-basic annual grants, Assistance for Projects, Challenge Grants for Equipment, Local/ Regional Development Grants. Grants for Access and Education: Craft Residencies, Conservation and Curatorial, Publishing, Traineeships in Craft Related Areas, Craft in Public Places. Grants for Exhibitions: Exhibition Development, Local/Regional Access Exhibitions, National/State Exhibitions, Contemporary Craft Acquisitions, Special Projects.
Community Arts Board-Residencies, Organisers, Events, Public Art, Workshops, Multi-Form and Innovative Activities, Activities throughout the year, Resource, Information and Network Development.
Design Arts Board-Design Communication, Design Applications, Pilot Projects.

Literature Board-Residencies: Writers in Residence in Tertiary Institutions, Playwrights in Residence, Dramaturgs in Residence, Screenwriting Attachments. Community Based Activities: Writers in the Community, Community Access Program. Book Publishing Subsidies, Literary Magazines, Literary Organisations, Promotional Grants. International Program: General Activities, Translation and Overseas Publications Program.

Music Board-Composer Commissions, Composer in Residence, Publishing, Radio Projects, Community and Regional Music Co-ordination, Community Music or Arts Centres, Youth Music, Visiting Teachers, Composer or Musician in Residence in the Community, Pioneer Electronics Australian Award, Ensemble Development, Performance, Performance Bounty, Musician in Residence, Opera/Music Theatre Special Projects, State Opera Companies, International Touring, National Music Service Organisations, Australian Folk Trust, Innovative Projects, Improvement of Management.

Theatre Board-General Support Grants for Companies, Project Grants for Companies, Project Development Grants, Playwrights in Residence. Training and Development Grants: Traineeships, Professional Service Assistance to Multicultural Dance Groups, Visiting Teachers. Communication Projects Grants, Interstate Movement of Artists.

Visual Arts Board-Artists in Residence, Public Art, Assistance with Murals, Australian Contemporary Art Acquisitions, Australian Contemporary Art Special Purchase Program, Support for Contemporary Art Spaces and Organisations, Grants for Exhibitions, International Visitors Program, Publications.
In addition to these programs offered by the Boards, applications from organisations may be be made to the Touring and Access Program, Amateur Groups Overseas Program and the Inter Board Committee.

Australian Film Commission-Creative Development: Exhibition and Distribution of Films, Publications on Film Appreciation and Culture, Enhancement of Film Culture. Special Purpose Funding Program: Publications, Special Events, Travel and Study, Research and Development.
The form of funding, whether by way of grant, loan or investment, is at the discretion of the Australian Film Commission.
Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service-Scientific Research Survey and Collection of Statistics Consultancy Program.
Australian Heritage Commission-Australian Heritage Grants Program.
Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority-Research and Monitoring Program.
National Library of Australia-Research and Development Program.
Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region-Scientific Research Consultancy Program.

(3) No special provisions other than the normal ones of equal opportunity and objective consideration of all proposals are considered either applicable or necessary for most of the bodies listed above.

An exception is the Australia Council, which has taken steps to ensure that appropriate and sensitive consideration is given to the special needs of migrant organisations through the provisions of the Multicultural Incentive Fund which encourages grants towards multicultural arts projects undertaken by organisations and individuals.
The Council advertises its programs of assistance in the ethnic press and produces a promotional pamphlet detailing available grant programs in ten community languages.

The Council employs two full time multicultural liaison officers who provide multicultural organisations and individuals with a special resource to service their needs in relation to the Council's programs of assistance

A new initiative of Council is the establishment in February 1985 of the Multicultural Arts Committee consisting of representatives of each of the Boards of Council and practising artists in the area of multicultural arts from all States. This Committee provides a base to promote multicultural arts, within the programs of both Council and its Boards.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 31 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the wholesale sales tax equivalent of the current protection for (a) clothing and (b) footwear.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There are no current estimates of the wholesale sales tax equivalent of the protective regimes applying to the clothing and footwear industries. According to an Industries Assistance Commission background paper, prepared in December 1984, assistance arrangements for clothing and footwear products were estimated to have an impact on domestic prices equivalent to a sales tax of some 80 per cent. Since that paper was prepared, there has been a substantial depreciation of the $A. This would have acted to reduce the sales tax equivalent figure.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 31 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the June 1984 Annual Conference of Family Court Judges resolved that all Judges of the Family Court of Australia are gravely concerned at the present lack of court counsellors and registrars and other resources to deal adequately with the present volume of work, over the inadequate, crowded and insecure accommodation in the Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane registries, the delays, risks, anxiety and costs which these deficiencies cause to the judges, staff and people using the Court, the potential damage to children when matters cannot be dealt with expeditiously and the way in which the situation is frustrating the policy and intention of the Family Law Act.
(2) Was this resolution communicated to his predecessor by a letter, dated 2 July 1984, from the Chief Judge of the Family Court.
(3) What steps have been taken or will be taken by the Government in response to the resolution.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) Since June 1984 a number of actions have been taken in regard to the issues discussed in the Judges' resolution. These actions are a result of Government and Family Court initiatives and are not in consequence of the resolution. Details follow:

(a) Additional staff have been allocated to the Family Court to alleviate the pressure of the workload on existing staff. During 1984-85, the Average Operative Staffing Level of the Family Court was increased by 58 staff units and in 1985-86 it has been increased by 17 to a total of 506. Approximately 55 of these units have gone or will go towards additional conciliation and counter/reception staff.

(b) Arrangements have also been completed between the Public Service Board, the Attorney-General's Department and the Court to pay an allowance to Registrars who will exercise powers contained in Section 37A of the Family Law Act. The exercise of these powers by Registrars will free Judges from routine and procedural matters, allowing them to devote a greater proportion of their time to defended hearings. In this way, delays in defended hearings are expected to be reduced.

(c) In addition, the Court is embarking on a program to introduce improved case management procedures at all of its Registries. These procedures are designed to enable the Court to control and monitor the passage of all cases through its system. Such a program is unique in Australian Courts and it is expected to cause a marked reduction in many of the delays and costs that have become associated with litigation in the Family Court.

(d) The Department has obtained the consultative advice of Professor Ian Scott, Barber Professor of Law at Birmingham University and Director of the Birmingham Institute of Judicial Administration. Professor Scott is a member of the Lord Chancellor's Committee of Inquiry into Civil Justice in England and Wales. He will be examining ways of reducing delays in the Court and of assessing, allocating and disposing of the work of the Court.
(e) (i) Moves have also been made towards extensive improvements to accommodation occupied by the Family Court especially in the Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane registries.

(ii) The Brisbane Registry is expected to occupy a new building early next year. The Registry will occupy part of the ground floor and all the remaining five office floors of the building, giving it an increase in size of about 94 per cent over its existing accommodation. The floor plan will be designed specifically to cater for the specialised requirements of the Family Court. Officers of the Court will be consulted over design plans and at all stages of the project and the same is true of other accommodation projects.
(iii) Considerable expansion and renovation of the Sydney Registry accommodation is expected to be completed in October 1985. A major part of this project involves the floors containing court rooms.

(iv) An additional two floors are to be leased in Marland House for the Melbourne Registry as well as extensive renovation and refurbishment of the existing area. The major part of the project is to provide more suitable court rooms and public waiting areas, as well as more suitable accommodation for Court Counsellors and their clients.

(v) A number of security measures have been introduced or improved at each of the Registries. It is certain that security and other conditions for Judges, Court Staff and people using the Court will be considerably improved once the accommodation projects are complete.
All these improvements are being undertaken with a view to reducing the delays, risks, anxieties and costs presently experienced by Judges, staff and people using the Court, as quickly as possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 20 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Government oppose, support or is it neutral about moves to make self-employed Australians (a) employees or (b) members of a union.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government recognises that there are many self-employed Australians who are, on any definition, employers. The Government believes that such employers should not be eligible to join associations of employees registered under the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 (``The Act'').

The rights of unions to enrol particular categories of labour, the regulation of their conditions of engagement and protection from coercion were examined by the Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems (the Hancock Committee). The Committee recommended that the jurisdiction of the federal industrial tribunal be extended to cover disputes involving persons described by the Committee as `quasi-employees', that is, persons who contract for service of their labour only or for the provision of labour and equipment but are in all other respects employees. In so recommending the Committee said that it did not include in this category genuine independent contractors or small business owners, and that associations of employees registered under the Act should not be able to enrol as members persons who are not `employees' within the definition it proposed.
The Committee also recomended that the provisions of the Act dealing with coercion be examined to ensure that they provide a remedy for `genuine independent contractors.'

The Government is presently engaged in wide ranging consultations with interested parties on the recommendations of the Hancock Committee. We will be giving careful consideration to the results of these consultations before any final decisions are made as to the implementation of the Committee's recommendations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 20 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to press reports claiming that the establishment of a waste disposal incinerator near Broken Hill, NSW, posed a potential problem to water quality in the Murray-Darling Basin.
(2) Has the River Murray Commission considered the implications of this proposal; if so, what conclusion did they reach; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The River Murray Commission has written to the New South Wales Government's Western Lands Commission, which has responsibility for land use and management in the region, noting that Rinex Environmental Services Pty Ltd intends to comply with the requirements of the New South Wales Dangerous Goods Act for the transport of materials to the proposed incinerator, and that exceptionally dangerous materials will be placed in double drums as an additional safety precaution during transport. The Commission has asked that its desire be recorded that all possible precautions are taken, both during transport and processing of waste materials, to ensure that contamination of tributaries of the River Murray does not occur.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 20 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to reports in the Federal Republic of Germany that the ingestion of Canthaxanthin can cause the accumulation of crystal-like deposites behind the eye and that this chemical is contained in many suntan pills and in some cosmetic preparations.
(2) Will he arrange for his Department to obtain the evidence presented to the German Bundesgesundheitsamt on the effects of the chemical.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) My Department has received information from the Bundesgesundheitsamt. This was reviewed by the Adverse Drugs Reactions Committee at its last meeting in August. Recommendations from that Committee will be reviewed by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee on 20 September.
